description: When disco nights roll around this summer at the Glastonbury Festival in England, neighbors may well wonder if they have lost their hearing. If all goes as planned, they will have little cause for their usual complaints of noise. Plans call for a "silent" disco, where the dancers will be equipped with headphones through which the music will be piped. "There are about a thousand residents within two miles of the festival location, and it's important to keep noise down, but first and foremost, it's a fun thing to do -- the first time its been tried in the U.K.," explained Emily Eavis, co-organizer of the festival. Attracting as many as 2,000 visitors, the event says on its Web site, glastonburyfestivals.co.uk, that it is the "largest greenfield music and performing arts festival in the world," and is held to coincide with the summer solstice in this village near Stonehenge. A spokesman for the festival said that the Mendip District Council, the local authority for Glastonbury, agreed in January that the festival could proceed as long as organizers met new restrictions, including monitors who will patrol to ensure that noise is kept to an acceptable level. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WAGNER, RODNEY B.
description: WAGNER--Rodney B. The Board of Trustees of the American University of Beirut and the AUB community deeply mourn the death of Rodney Wagner, distin guished Trustee of the University for the past 16 years and member of the AUB Board's Executive Committee. Retired Vice Chairman of the Board of J.P. Morgan, Rod also served as Chairman of the Board of the Population Council and formerly Chairman of the Board of Robert College of Istanbul. We are deeply grateful to Rod for his great service to the University, for applying not only his financial acumen but also his wide-ranging expertise to meet the unique challenges and opportunities of this American university in the Middle East. His shoes cannot be filled. We shall sorely miss our kind and wise friend, and we offer our heartfelt sympathy to Sukey Wagner and their children. Richard A. Debs, Chairman WAGNER--Rodney B. Chairman of the Board of Robert College of Istanbul from 1979-2002 and a Trustee from 1968. His knowledge of and devotion to Turkey were legendary and his counsel sought by many. He led Robert College through decades of change gracefully, generously and with great enjoyment. His contributions will be remembered and celebrated for years to come. The school community and, indeed, many in broader Turkish society deeply mourn his loss and offer sympathies to his family. WAGNER -- Rodney. The Saint Ann's School community mourns the loss of our former Board member. He served the School in its early years, from 1970 to 1981, and is remembered for the intelligence, generosity of spirit and kindness with which he guided us. We send sympathy and love to his wife Sukey, and to his children Lisa and Ben and their families.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOREMATSU, FRED
description: KOREMATSU--Fred. The American Civil Liberties Union, its officers, Board of Directors and staff deeply mourn the passing of a courageous fighter for civil liberties. Following Japan's December 7, 1941 attack on Pearl Harbor, America rounded up in its very own internment camps fellow citizens just because of their Japanese ancestry. Korematsu, born to Japanese immigrants, was a 23-year-old welder in Oakland, CA when military officials ordered all Japanese-Americans on the West Coast into internment camps. Korematsu's family and friends complied and urged him to do so, too. He refused, was arrested, convicted and sent to an internment camp in Utah. The ACLU fought to reverse President Roosevelt's executive order instituting the internment. The ACLU--with the leadership of its West Coast offices--represented Korematsu before the United States Supreme Court, which sided with the government. Scholars now acknowledge this ruling as one of the worst in the court's history. A U.S. District Court in 1983 overturned Korematsu's conviction. "I thought what the military was doing was unconstitutional," Korematsu later said. "I was really upset because I was branded as an enemy alien when I'm an American." Korematsu helped win a national apology and reparations for internment camp survivors and their families in 1988. President Bill Clinton awarded him the nation's highest civilian honor, the Presidential Medal of Freedom, ten years later. In 2001, the ACLU bestowed its prestigious Roger N. Baldwin Medal of Liberty award--named for ACLU's founder--on Korematsu, who continued campaigning for civil liberties. He opposed the USA Patriot Act and the U.S. government denial of due process to suspected terror detainees held at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. The ACLU extends its deepest sympathy to the Korematsu family for the loss of one of America's greatest patriots.

title: New Faces of Swedish Cinema
description: Rarely has a cinematic assessment of middle-class teenage life divested itself of its sensual glamour as relentlessly as Lukas Moodysson's 1998 film, "Show Me Love," a sweet comedy with a bitter aftertaste that stars Alexandra Dahlstrom and Rebecca Liljeberg (above). The clueless young people in the Swedish backwater town in which its youthful dramas erupt are so desperate for the trappings of sophistication that they raid their parents' medicine cabinets in search of drugs and guzzle cheap wine until they vomit. When they have sex, they don't know what they're doing or why they're doing it. Peer pressure is so omnipotent that assurances by their parents that the high school pecking order is no indication of their future status don't help. "Show Me Love," which has two screenings on Monday, is the earliest of the four films directed by Mr. Moodysson to be shown in "New Faces of Swedish Cinema," a seven-day series of 9 feature films and 10 shorts that begins today at the Walter Reade Theater. Mr. Moodysson is the leading light among the younger filmmakers in a national cinema that is still quaking under the shadow of Ingmar Bergman. Unlike Bergman films, whose characters are in the grip of metaphysical and psychological crisis, Mr. Moodysson's are the prisoners of social forces beyond their control. His comedy "Together" explores the tensions inside a 1970's commune in Stockholm with an easygoing intimacy. His masterpiece, "Lilya 4-Ever," observes the struggle for survival of a 13-year-old girl, abandoned by her mother in a rotting city, who is tricked into a life of enforced prostitution in Sweden. "A Hole in My Heart," which has its United States premiere tomorrow, is the most experimental of the four and observes the making of an amateur pornographic film by two men and a woman in a grimy suburban apartment. In surreal flashes, it suggests the chaos and violence that can result when social restraints are discarded.("New Faces of Swedish Cinema" opens today at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center, (212)875-5600; www.filmlinc.com. description: IN 1846, a New Yorker named Eugene Skinner settled along the Willamette River. He built a small log cabin on a low hill, made peace with the Kalapuya Indians, raised a family and started a ferry service. Today, the hill is called Skinner Butte and the town that grew up to surround it bears the settler's first name. While Mr. Skinner would look with wonder at the sprawling University of Oregon campus, the quaint but modern downtown and the many bicycles, much remains in his namesake town that he would recognize. The trout-filled Willamette and McKenzie Rivers wend their way down from the Cascades; 19th-century houses peer out from behind massive fir trees; rich farmland rolls out to the north; and on a clear day the view extends to the snow-covered Three Sisters, 10,000-foot dormant volcanoes rising about 60 miles to the east. title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Journalist Was Beaten, Doctor Says
description: An Iranian doctor who examined an Iranian-Canadian photojournalist, Zahra Kazemi, days before she died in police custody in Iran in 2003 said there were signs she had been beaten, tortured and raped. Dr. Shahram Azam, who was recently granted asylum in Canada after leaving Iran last year, worked for the Defense Ministry when he examined Ms. Kazemi in Tehran. At a news conference in Ottawa, he described finding severe bruising over her body, broken fingers, a broken nose, missing fingernails and toenails, flogging marks and a ruptured eardrum. His account contradicts Iran's position that Ms. Kazemi, 54, died after falling and hitting her head. Canada's foreign affairs minister, Pierre Pettigrew, said the new account "reinforces our position that this was not an accident." Ms. Kazemi was in detention for having taken photographs outside a prison in Tehran. Colin Campbell (NYT)

Inmates told officials that Mr. Higgins repeatedly touched himself and the inmates in exchange for cigarettes, said the Union County prosecutor, Theodore J. Romankow. Mr. Higgins, free on $750,000 bail, faces 20 years in prison if convicted. Mr. Higgins's lawyer, Robert Morton, said that his client denied the charges and that there was no evidence of assault. title: The Listings; PITTSBURGH BALLET THEATER
description: It was a sad day for New York balletomanes when Terry Orr and Marianna Tcherkassky left American Ballet Theater in the late 90's for what, to parochial Manhattanites, was simply the hinterlands. No one quite believed Ms. Tcherkassky, a leading ballerina with the company and Mr. Orr's wife, when she commented with her characteristic gentleness that now she could have a garden. But this week we have them back in spirit with performances by the Pittsburgh Ballet Theater, which Mr. Orr has directed since 1997. Ms. Tcherkassky is growing dancers as the company's ballet mistress. The 36-year-old company was known for performances of ballets by George Balanchine, the backbone of its repertory. But Mr. Orr decided to branch out with newer choreographers. And so the Pittsburgh dancers will perform ballets by Kevin O'Day, Derek Deane and New York's own Dwight Rhoden. Mr. O'Day's new "Sting/ING Situations" (above, with Jennifer Langenstein and Richard Brown) is set to hit songs by the rock singer, including "Walking on the Moon," "Every Little Thing She Does Is Magic" and "Roxanne." The choreographer, who has performed with the Joffrey Ballet, Frankfurt Ballet and Twyla Tharp, has set the timing, patterns and spacing, but the rest is left for the dancers to decide. Mr. Deane, a former Royal Ballet principal, has set his "Hungry Heart ... 'we all have one'!!" to music by Bruce Springsteen. In the ballet, he tells the stories of the everyday people who frequent a diner in the 1950's and 60's. And Mr. Rhoden takes on Beethoven and Bach in his new "7th Heaven." (Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; tomorrow and Sunday at 2 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212)242-0800. Tickets: $40.) JENNIFER DUNNING

title: The Listings; ALL ABOARD
description: "End Station," the nearly full-scale replica of a subway station that the artist team of Michael Elmgreen and Ingar Dragset have built in the capacious basement of the Bohen Foundation in Greenwich Village, provides a delicious instant of displacement. You walk downstairs and almost fall into your personal waiting-for-the-train mode, except there's no tunnel to peer into. The replication is meticulous. Facing platforms hover above tracks. There are white tile walls, trash in and out of baskets, sickly light and real graffiti by the 1980's graffiti artists Coco 144 and Ghost. Torn posters by Act Up and the Guerrilla Girls also suggest we have journeyed back to the 80's, and the Time Before Chelsea. Add a turnstyle, third rail and a raunchy smell, and you've got a ghost limb of the L line. It helps that the Bohen Foundation space, designed by LoTek, already had a wide band of sidewalk-style grating on its ground floor and a basement reached by a heavy metal staircase (the banister temporarily severed to enhance the illusion), with I-beam columns all but identical to those in the New York underground. The fact that the whole thing looks real while also feeling fake -- too hollow, unused and clean means that the often poetic solitude of an empty subway station becomes simultaneously funny and unfunny, like the Venetian canals of Las Vegas. "End Station" funnels 1970's site-specific installation art through the current obsession with meticulous replication. A result is Photo Realism in the round, the environmental equivalent of one of Duane Hanson's trompe l'oeil sculptures of construction workers or tourists. Other antecedents include Andy Warhol's Brillo boxes, Robert Gober's sinks and drains and, more recently, Gregor Schneider's bleak, dead-end alleyway cut into the Gladstone Gallery two years ago. Finally, "End Station" is also the latest, super-sized instance of the thousands of spawn of that Surrealist one-liner -- Meret Oppenheim's fur-lined tea-cup. With such an easily traced pedigree, the installation's bang does not quite equal the bucks, logistical planning and stagecraft that went into it. But as a panorama for an imaginary museum of New York's natural history, with us playing the native cave dwellers, "End Station" is not to be missed. It's the New York subway for visitors from Las Vegas. (Noon to 6 p.m., Tuesdays through Fridays, Bohen Foundation, 415 West 13th Street, Greenwich Village, (212)414-4575. Through July 1; free.) ROBERTA SMITH

title: The Listings; DAVID HARBOUR
description: The last time David Harbour appeared on Broadway, in Tom Stoppard's "Invention of Love," he portrayed the stolid object of desire of an inhibited university professor. In the exciting new revival of "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?," Mr. Harbour (above, with Kathleen Turner) is again a stolid object of desire, though this time it's a very uninhibited professor's wife who has focused her lustful attentions upon him. Now, you might think there's nothing to being stolid and desirable when you're the owner of a sharp square jaw and shoulders to match. But in Anthony Page's beautifully balanced production of "Woolf," which stars Ms. Turner and Bill Irwin, Mr. Harbour demonstrates that there can be all sorts of lively and arresting angles within manly squareness. Mr. Harbour plays Nick, the ambitious young academic and late-night party guest who is perfectly willing to bed his much older hostess (Ms. Turner) in the name of career advancement. And while Nick may be "a flop in some departments," as Ms. Turner's disappointed character snarls, Mr. Harbour seems more than likely to advance his own career with this unflinching, surprisingly varied portrait of a hungry all-American cad. (Longacre Theater, 220 West 48th Street, (212)239-6200. This weekend's schedule: Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $46.25 to $91.25.) BEN BRANTLEY

description: Who will play the next Doctor Who? But Christopher Eccleston, who plays the space- and time-traveling doctor, will not be returning, citing fears of being typecast. Mr. Eccleston is the ninth Doctor Who. Eight different actors played him in the previous series, which ran for 26 years, beginning in 1963. The BBC has confirmed that it is in discussions with David Tennant, who played Ginger in "Bright Young Things," the Stephen Fry adaptation of Evelyn Waugh's "Vile Bodies," for the role. description: Don Imus, below, and Walter Cronkite were among the 32 members elected to the inaugural class of the New York State Broadcasters Association Hall of Fame on Thursday night. The Gambling family, whose roots in New York radio date to 1925, was honored with three inductions: John B., John A. and John R. Gambling, each representing a different generation of hosts of the famous "Rambling With Gambling" program on WOR (710 AM). Frankie Crocker, the former program director of WBLS (107.5 FM) and WLIB (1190 AM), who died in 2000, was also inducted. So was Mr. Cronkite's old boss, the CBS and Museum of Television and Radio founder, William S. Paley, who died in 1990. The Broadcasters Association is a nonprofit organization based in Albany. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON ISSUES ALZHEIMER'S DRUG WARNING
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it was warning doctors about the deaths of 13 people who took its Alzheimer's drug Reminyl. The deaths occurred during clinical studies to test the drug's effectiveness in treating mild cognitive impairment, a form of memory loss. The drug has been used to treat two million people for Alzheimer's since it was approved in 2001. The company said it had mailed letters to thousands of doctors after negotiations with the Food and Drug Administration. Johnson & Johnson has also amended its packaging insert to disclose the deaths. During the two-year studies, 13 participants taking Reminyl died while one patient who received a placebo died. The clinical trials involved about 2,000 patients in 16 countries. Stephanie Saul (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; 'South Park' Echoes the Schiavo Case
description: On Wednesday's episode of "South Park," Kenny, the member of the animated quartet of Colorado kids who dies in every show, was kept alive by a feeding tube. "Kenny is the same he ever was," his doctor tells his parents. "It's just that now he's more like a tomato." The question of whether to take out the tube divides the other three friends, as two want him to live and one wants him to die so he can get the portable Sony PlayStation Kenny left him in his will. According to Matt Stone, who created the series with Trey Parker, "South Park" was able to parody the politics of the Terri Schiavo legal battle so quickly because they began the episode from scratch the Thursday before it was telecast. "There's kind of nothing funny about the Terri Schiavo thing," Mr. Stone said on the telephone from Los Angeles, "so that's why we did it." He added: "We, like everyone else, found that whole thing fascinating. That show, and humor in general, is how we work it out." For each episode, Mr. Stone, Mr. Parker and their staff write, animate and give voice to the show scene by scene, delivering the final version to Comedy Central on Wednesday for its broadcast that night. KATE AURTHUR

description: Think of it as the intelligent woman's guide to how not to have sex. You go on a blind date. The guy has a shaved head and beady eyes, and within seconds tells you that you are not as thin as he imagined. Most women -- check that, most sensible, sane women -- would tell baldy to take a very short hike off a very long pier. You know better. Even Bridget Jones, with her trembling jowls and insecurities, knows better and would cuddle up with a pound of toffee rather than subject herself to such outrage. The woman in the film "Primo Amore" is not made of such sternly self-reliant stuff.

title: Arts, Briefly; Sony-BMG Is Sued Over Gospel Artists
description: A lawyer who represents some of the biggest names in the gospel music industry said that Sony-BMG, several of its record labels and its president had used "trickery and deceit" to intimidate his clients into firing him, according to papers filed in United States District Court in New Haven yesterday. The lawyer, James L. Walker Jr. of Stamford, said that the defendants, including Max Siegel, an executive in Sony's gospel division, warned the artists that as long as they were represented by Mr. Walker their songs would not be recorded. Mr. Walker's client list includes performers like Elbertina Clark, Bobby Jones and David Frazier, a songwriter. Jojo Pada, a spokeswoman for Zomba Gospel, the parent company of the Verity Records and Gospocentric labels, said, "We haven't seen a copy of the lawsuit, and we don't comment on pending litigation." A Sony-BMG spokesman also declined to comment. STACEY STOWE

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Exports Increase
description: South Korean exports rose to a record in March, led by European sales of cars. Exports gained 14.2 percent from a year earlier, to $24.2 billion, accelerating from February's revised 6.7 percent growth, which was the slowest pace in almost two years, the Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Energy said. Overseas sales of automobiles surged 30 percent, to $28.2 billion, after increasing 1.2 percent in February, overtaking semiconductors as the nation's leading export product. Chip sales were up 13.5 percent, to $24.8 billion, last month, slowing from 16.7 percent growth the previous month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STOLMAN, DR. CYNTHIA JEAN
description: STOLMAN--Dr. Cynthia Jean, 63, Assistant Professor of Pediatrics at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Newark, NJ died at her home in Short Hills, NJ on April 1, 2005. She received a BA from Brooklyn College in 1964, a M. Ed. in 1975 and a Ph.D in 1981 from SUNY Buffalo. She was Director of Medical Ethics at United/The Children's Hospital of New Jersey from 1994-1997, Chairperson of the Pediatric Bioethics Committee of the Department of Pediatrics and Curriculum and Evaluation, Director of the Pediatric Residency Training Program at UMDNJ from 1997-2005. She was the author of many medical journal articles and publications related to ethical challenges and dilemmas. She was a charismatic and admired teacher of medical students and physicians. She will be missed by her many friends, colleagues, students, and most of all by her family. She is survived by her husband Dr. Lewis P. Stolman, their children Lara Stolman Watzky and her husband Michael of NY, Dr. Karen Stolman Shmookler and her husband Eric of Sandy, UT, their grandson Caden Shmookler, and her brothers Dr. Michael Fein of Westin, CT and Dr. Eric Fein of Bernardsville, NJ. Funeral services will be held at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Ave, Short Hills, NJ on Sunday at 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the National Colorectal Cancer Research Alliance, C/O Entertainment Industry Foundation, 11132 Ventura Blvd, Suite 401, Studio City, CA 91604. For additional information please call BernheimApter - Kreitzman 1 - 800 938-6372.

title: Arts, Briefly; Survival Instinct
description: CBS's "Survivor," still going strong after five years on the air, relies more on combustible casting than innovations in the structure of the game to provide drama for the show. But in this installment, filmed in Palau, something genuinely new has happened, purely by fluke: for the first time, one of the two tribes of nine people has lost every single immunity challenge, and is now down to just two contestants. But rather than seeming repetitive, the group's consistent losses have given this "Survivor" underdogs to root for, as well as a story arc that recent seasons have lacked. It is fifth in this season's rankings, with an average viewership of 22.2 million. Thursday's episode, which featured another loss for the woeful tribe, brought in 21.06 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. The CBS lineup, which also included new episodes of "CSI" and "Without a Trace," was No. 1 in total viewers and among 18-to-49-year-olds. KATE AURTHUR

title: British Writer Mines Bleak Youth for TV Drama
description: LONDON - When Paul Abbott won his first award for writing, at age 14, his nine brothers and sisters did a double take. "They only found out I was writing when they saw a picture of me in the paper," said Mr. Abbott, whose siblings were otherwise preoccupied with holding down at least two jobs and keeping child-protective services away. "Suddenly, they were thinking about my last 12 months and going, 'What have you been up to?"' That's because when Mr. Abbott was 9, his mother went out for a loaf of bread and never returned. Two years later, Mr. Abbott's workphobic, alcoholic father followed suit. At this point, the Abbott children felt ready to take charge of their crowded, bathroomless household in a rough part of a depressed industrial city in England. "There was a real sense of liberation; I thought we could do anything," Mr. Abbott said. "It was grim by fact and by certain events, but it wasn't grim."

Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSS, MARTIN MAYER
description: GROSS--Martin Mayer, age 87 passed away at his home in Verona, NJ on Thursday, March 31, after a long illness. He was a professional engineer, a builder and an appraiser. A WWII veteran, Marty served in the US Army Special Engineers unit as a port and dock specialist. Later, he was attached to MacArthur's headquarters in Luzon. Marty was awarded 2 Bronze Stars; one for the New Guinea Campaign and one for the Philippine Campaign. He also received the American Theater Ribbon, Asiatic Ribbon with arrowhead and 2 battle stars, Victory Medal, Meritorious Service Unit Plaque and the Philippine Liberation Ribbon with 2 battle stars. Marty was active in improving the lives of the developmentally disabled. He was a founder of the Essex County Association for Retarded Citizens, a member and President of the Board of Trustees of Woods Services for over 50 years. He was also a member of The Society of Military Engineers, The NJ Engineers Society and Master, Appraisal Institute. Some of his more notable appraisals included Ellis Island, Yankee Stadium, and Gateway National Park. He was a member of Green Brook Country Club and an avid golfer. Marty was predeceased by his first wife, Phyllis Simon, and by his son, Jonathan. He is survived by his loving wife of 35 years, Arlene Ross Scott, and by his adoring step-daughter, Emily Scott Pottruck, his son-in-law, David Pottruck, and step-son, William Scott. He is also survived by his sisters, Augusta Citron of Tucson, and Dina Simon of Philadelphia. And by a niece, Belinda Dumont and nephews, Mark Raven, Samuel and Alexander Simon. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, April 3rd at Noon at the Bernheim - Apter Kreitzman Funeral Home located at 68 Old Short Hills Rd, Livingston, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Marty's memory to Woods Services, Langhorne, PA 19047

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Opening A Door To Comparing Hospitals
description: The Department of Health and Human Services has established a Web site to help people assess the quality of care at their local hospitals. The site, hospitalcompare.hhs.gov, lets people compare performance for three conditions, heart attack, heart failure and pneumonia. Performance is based on factors like the percentage of patients given aspirin on arrival, which is important in the case of a heart attack because aspirin can help with dissolve blood clots. Hospitals provided the information under the Medicare reform act passed last year that gave monetary incentives to hospitals to collect and report the data. More data was collected for more conditions, but the three selected were among the most common ailments experienced by Medicare recipients and older people, an agency spokesman said. Courtney C. Radsch (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Suge Knight Loses Suit
description: Suge Knight, founder of Death Row Records, has been ordered to pay $107 million to Lydia Harris, a Los Angeles producer who contends she helped found Death Row (now called Tha Row) and was pushed out of the business once it became lucrative. Judge Ronald M. Sohigian of California Superior Court ordered Mr. Knight to pay Mrs. Harris $60 million in punitive damages, $45 million in economic damages and $2 million in noneconomic damages. Mrs. Harris is the wife of Michael Harris, who is in prison for distributing cocaine. He says that in 1991 he gave Mr. Knight $1.5 million in seed money to start the label, which at its height was home to the rappers Snoop Dogg and Tupac Shakur and the veteran producer Dr. Dre. Mr. Knight has repeatedly denied the assertion. "The expectation that she'll collect $107 million is unlikely," David Casselman, Mrs. Harris's lawyer, said in a telephone interview. "He's sufficiently sheltered whatever assets he has. We do, however, fully expect that she will collect millions if not tens of millions of dollars." LOLA OGUNNAIKE

ORMET, AN ALUMINUM PRODUCER, EXITS BANKRUPTCY
description: The Ormet Corporation, a closely held aluminum producer, said yesterday that it had exited bankruptcy protection under a court-approved reorganization plan. Ormet said former creditors, led by the investment group MatlinPatterson Asset Management of New York, would become shareholders under the plan. Ormet filed for Chapter 11 protection in January 2004, citing lower metal prices and rising costs for energy and health benefits. The company, based in Wheeling, W.Va., received permission from the United States Bankruptcy Court in Ohio to change its benefits plan for retirees, a move that had been fought by members of the United Steelworkers' union. Ormet shut its Hannibal, Ohio, smelter in January amid the dispute with union members, who have been on strike since November. Ormet has continued to operate the rolling mill at the site with salaried workers.

BEST BUY PROFIT FOR FISCAL YEAR TO MISS ESTIMATES
description: The Best Buy Company said yesterday that its profit this fiscal year would be below some analysts' estimates, driving its shares lower by 6 percent. The company, which is based in Richfield, Minn., also said its fourth-quarter profit rose 22 percent, helped by a tax benefit of 15 cents a share from the sale of the Musicland chain. Fourth-quarter revenue increased 9.2 percent, the smallest quarterly gain in seven years, because of sluggish holiday demand. Best Buy forecast fiscal 2006 earnings of $2.95 a share to $3.10 a share from continuing operations, including 17 cents a share for stock-based pay. Analysts had forecast $3.31 a share without the stock expense. Best Buy shares fell $3.41, to $50.60.

description: Brazil's trade surplus widened for the second consecutive month in March, confounding predictions that a strengthening local currency would gnaw away at export growth. The government said that Brazil, South America's largest economy, posted a trade surplus of $3.35 billion last month, up from $2.58 billion in March of last year and $2.79 billion in February. Exports jumped to $9.25 billion last month, while imports continued to creep higher, totaling $5.9 billion. Brazil's trade surplus stands at $8.32 billion so far this year, up from $6.13 billion in the 2004 period. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Aaron Davis Hall Expands
description: The Croton Gatehouse, above (circa 1890), at the southwest corner of Convent Avenue and 135th Street in Manhattan, will be turned into additional space for Aaron Davis Hall, which calls itself Harlem's Center for the Performing Arts. The gatehouse, designed by Frederick S. Cook in a Romanesque Revival style, was completed in 1890 as part of the New Croton Aqueduct system. The building was designated a New York City Landmark in 1981 and added to National Register of Historic Places two years later. The city took it out of service in 1989, and it is now under the jurisdiction of the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, which is to cover the $13 million cost of restoring it. Aaron Davis Hall, across Convent Avenue on the campus of the City College of New York, is seeking more space for performance programs and administrative offices. The hall develops new work by emerging artists of color and provides a youth educational performance series. Currently under construction, the Gatehouse is scheduled to be completed in the fall of 2006. The renovation was designed by Ohlhausen DuBois Architects, in collaboration with Wank Adams Slavin Associates. ROBIN POGREBIN

title: Before the Fall
description: The recent rally of the United States dollar notwithstanding, the greenback has nowhere to go but down. But the Bush administration is betting that foreign investors will continue to invest huge sums in this depreciating currency. How huge? Last month, the government reported that the United States' deficit in international transactions, mainly trade, reached an unprecedented $666 billion in 2004, a 24 percent increase from the 2003 level and, at 5.7 percent of the economy, about two to three times what most economists consider sustainable.

title: SEARS HOLDINGS TO LAY OFF AT LEAST 250 AT HEADQUARTERS
description: The Sears Holdings Corporation, created last week by the Kmart Holding Corporation's purchase of Sears, Roebuck & Company, will lay off at least 250 workers at its headquarters in Hoffman Estates, Ill., as the company streamlines operations. Sears Holdings gave notice of the job cuts March 29, according to a statement on Web site of the Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity. Layoffs of at least 250 employees must be posted 60 days in advance, according to Illinois law. Sears Holdings employs about 4,000 people in Hoffman Estates and about 1,000 at the office in Troy, Mich., that was Kmart's base. The company will keep the vast majority of its 336,000 workers in the United States, the chief executive, Alan J. Lacy, said last week.

title: Paperback Row
description: HOW TO BREATHE UNDERWATER: Stories, by Julie Orringer. (Vintage Contemporaries, $12.95.) In these taut, powerful short stories, children operate in a secret world of their own, parents seem well meaning but ineffectual, and violence erupts without warning. In one story, "The Isabel Fish," a car accident kills a spirited teenager; in another, "Stations of the Cross," a child binds and beats her cousin in an enactment of the Crucifixion. Orringer (at right) handles adolescent grief and alienation with subtlety. "The harsh landscape in which Orringer's characters dwell corresponds to the fierce beauty of her writing," Lisa Dierbeck wrote in the Book Review. In the 11 thematically linked stories in Hannah Tinti's ANIMAL CRACKERS (Delta, $12), animals are the unwitting repositories of human desires and fears (in the title story a zoo employee commits suicide with the help of an elephant).

Here are puckery crimson blossoms called hot lips; here, too, black orchids, clay-colored robins and madre de cacao flowers that cure pink eye. Mr. Smith, who works for Francis Ford Coppola at Blancaneaux Lodge, the most spectacular of Mr. Coppola's Central American properties, crushes a small green leaf and reaches back over his horse's rump to hand it to me. title: Table of Content
description: The Italian architect and designer Marco Zanuso (1916-2001) was responsible for some of the 20th century's most recognizable objects. His curvaceous Lady chair, designed in 1951 for Arflex, celebrated that newfangled material foam rubber. His boxy plastic scale for Terraillon was a kitchen staple in the 1970's. With another design giant, Richard Sapper, Zanuso came up with innovations like the molded plastic child's chair for Kartell, the folding Grillo telephone for Siemens and the clamshell-cube radio for Brionvega. But my favorite Zanuso product is the Marcuso dining table, designed for Zanotta in 1969. Its square glass top has rounded corners -- very mod -- and its legs attach to the top by screwing into stainless-steel discs that are electrostatically welded to the underside of the glass. It was this last detail that stopped me in my tracks when I first saw the table, at the late, lamented Design Research. At that moment, I understood the relationship between technology and aesthetics in modern design, and I was hooked. A few years ago, I might have said that the Marcuso table seemed a little dated, but today it looks fresh again. Its lines are as taut as -- though more sensual than -- its International-style and Minimalist counterparts. It's about modernism with verve, which is one of Italy's great contributions to design.

title: The Remix; Tony Montana
description: About halfway between downtown Bozeman, Mont., and the regional airport, the new Avis Rent a Car building sits as an arresting paean to the New West. Designed by the Czech-born architect Thomas Bitnar, the Avis outlet is perched in the lonely Gallatin Valley like a luminous toolshed. It is bold architecture, given the local preference for tradition. "It's not easy to sell the 21st century in Montana," Bitnar says. "Here, people prefer cowboy architecture, which means taking beautiful materials like stone and wood and leading them in the wrong direction." While Avis is pleased with the structure, some neighbors are not, though some of the farm kids in the area seem to approve. That's no coincidence, since the design was inspired by the farm outbuildings that dot the Montana landscape. "When I moved here," Bitnar continues, "I noticed these amazing farm structures, like silos and horse stalls." For the Avis building, he extracted the basic contour of these simple sheds -- the gridded box and the sloped roof -- and clad it in glossy metal and glass to create a glowing billboard for passing traffic. "Around here we have so many sunny days. And when the sun is out, the building really shines. That might help the locals get used to it. But it's hard. People here dream about cowboys." MIKE GUY

Beloved wife of the late Milton; loving mother Randese Owen Leoni and Barbara Owen Smithen; mother-in-law of Serge Leoni and Charles Smithen; dear grandmother of Oliver and Hugh Leoni; step-grandmother of Kevin, Corinne and Lindsay Smithen and great grandmother of Chloe Smithen. She will always be remembered as a vibrant spirit who will never be forgotten by all who knew her from close friends to New York taxi drivers. She was the epitome of grace, elegance and style who dedicated her life to family and friends. Private interment. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Sharing Village Cancer Survivor Group, 161 Main Street, Peapack, N.J. 07933.

Paid Notice: Deaths   MAZZOLA, PATRICIA
description: MAZZOLA--Patricia, 63, died at her home in Kent, CT. on Wednesday, March 23, 2005. Pat received a BSN from Cornell University in 1964 & a MBA from Columbia University in 1984. She had a 31 year career in nursing at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She served as Chairman of the Department of Nursing for 15 years, from 1981-1997. Instituted under her leadership were many innovative changes that influenced the practice of nursing. These included but not limited to, Primary Nursing; Collaborative Practice; Flexible Scheduling; Development of a Master's Degree Program with Columbia University, and the implementation of the Nurse Practitioner and Clinical Nurse Specialist Advanced Practice Roles. In addition to serving as the longest chairman of the department, she was the first recipient of the Enid A. Haupt Chair of Nursing. In addition to family and friends, Pat leaves behind her legacy of true generosity of spirit and person. She deeply affected the lives of all those she came in contact with. Her generosity, wisdom, integrity, strength of character and knowledge of herself and others, will remain with all of us who knew and loved her. She will truly be missed. A Special remembrance service, followed by a gathering of friends & family to celebrate Pat's life, will be arranged in the near future. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be sent to New Milford Hospital Regional Cancer Center, 21 Elm Street, New Milford, CT. 06776.

description: WAGNER -- Rodney. World Wildlife Fund mourns the loss of our long time board member and dear friend, Rodney Wagner. title: Steep Thoughts
description: Teatime in London, how frolicsome, how fine. The Samurai Shopper is in her element, gadding about at dusk to partake of a fast-fading ritual. Tea, by definition, is the bracing, leafy beverage you drink after hours of getting and spending. Coffee makes for crazy shopping, wine wreaks havoc on the ability to discriminate and a half-pint of Guinness makes you smell like a half-pint of Guinness. This week, teatime coincides with Samurai shopping, since teapots are the coveted prize. If a pot pops up befitting budget and sensibility comparable to, say, Mrs. Tiggy-Winkle's, pouncing will ensue. The trick is to find a pot that functions efficiently, balancing impeccable taste and flaming eccentricity. Samurai shopping is electromagnetic: a current of desire passes through a live wire -- like me -- creating fields in which all fabulous objects gravitate in one's direction. In short, I'm expecting the teapot to find me.

title: A Symbol of Rebirth in Bushwick

title: An Infusion of Energy in Yale's Backyard
description: DOWNTOWN New Haven has been transformed over the last five years from Yale's mundane backyard into a vibrant neighborhood of shops, theaters and restaurants. In 1999, Mayor John DeStefano Jr. decided to take a chance on energizing the city's stagnant economy by capitalizing on its theaters, symphony orchestras, art galleries, ballet company, museums and the presence and participation of the university. But it needed new, attractive housing and an infusion of businesses and shops.

title: The Remix; Stick-to-It-iveness
description: The home-design guru Marian McEvoy is trigger-happy -- and she has the glue-gun-appliqud dining chairs to prove it. The soon-to-be published ode to her favorite tool, "Glue Gun Dcor: How to Dress Up Your Home -- From Pillows and Curtains to Sofas and Lampshades," might seem like a downscale departure from her previous role as a shelter-magazine editor in chief. While McEvoy admits that most people consider home crafts "cornball and tacky" (two words: "hooked rug"), she promises that a glue gun can create elegance -- as the seashell-covered fireplace in her former Manhattan apartment illustrated. It's what led McEvoy to her prized possession. "I had superglued about 1,000 shells onto the fireplace, and they all fell off," she says. "Then someone told me about the glue gun, and I found the process very cathartic." McEvoy quickly moved to gluing things onto cotton muslin, and then graduated to cushions, curtains, lampshades and upholstery. "Glue-gunning decoration can introduce something old into a room or dcor that's new in a way that looks crisp, tailored and modern," she says. "This isn't shabby chic." McEvoy has a few tips for would-be crafters:

It speculated that Hitler's bent for cruelty and mass murder stemmed from self-loathing, and it predicted that one likely end to his life would be suicide in a bunker.

title: They Come to Praise Brutus
description: DURING his working vacation away from Hollywood, Denzel Washington may be willing to go without the luxury trailer, but the bodyguard stays: a very large bearded man leads the way to the small room in the Belasco Theater where Mr. Washington, in a long-sleeved T-shirt and jeans, is relaxing before afternoon rehearsal for "Julius Caesar." The show is still in previews, but in the corner, there's already a bin full of letters from fans who have seen the show; the theater had to hire extra security to handle the mob that waits for him each night after the curtain falls.

Our prayers and condolences go out to his family. Mr. Cochran was elected chairman in October 2001 and guided the organization through a transition in the makeup of its senior staff. title: Flouting the Law of Nail and Claw
description: HERE in S.U.V. land, it's the little things that define us. My friend Meg keeps ducks in her yard and allows shoes in her house. A mother I car-pool with reads "The National Enquirer" and kick-boxes. The couple who just moved in across the street, to judge by the rumble that rocks the block at 10 p.m. every other Monday, put away a case of wine every night and are responsible about recycling.

title: Car and Driveway
description: Although his first words weren't "classic car," Steven Harris was dreaming about his fantasy automobile collection when he was still toddling. "I knew the name of every car on the road when I was 3 years old," says Harris, who heads the New York-based design firm Steven Harris Architects. For his clients, he believes that the car parked in the driveway is just as important as the house and the personalities of the people inside. "About 15 years ago, I decided to focus on interior as well as exterior design," he says. "I help with furniture and art and everything else," which includes finding the perfect set of wheels. "The first thing I ask myself is how these people live: are they flashy, subdued, sensual? Are they reserved, sturdy, or will they have a driver?"

title: PAINFUL MEDICINE
description: Perhaps Jamie Reidy was nave, but he said it barely occurred to him that Eli Lilly & Company would object to his new book, "Hard Sell: The Evolution of a Viagra Salesman," a humorous take on his life as a Pfizer Inc. sales representative from 1995 to 2000. "Hard Sell" has nothing to do with his more recent job as a sales trainer for Lilly.

title: Tar Heels Give Coach Another Title Shot
Moralists at the Pharmacy
description: Scattered reports suggest that a growing number of pharmacists around the country are refusing to fill prescriptions for contraceptives or morning-after birth control pills because of moral or religious objections. Although the refusals are cast as important matters of conscience for self-described "pro-life" pharmacists, they have the pernicious effect of delaying, and sometimes even denying, a woman's access to medications that may be urgently needed. This is an intolerable abuse of power by pharmacists who have no business forcing their own moral or ethical views onto customers who may not share them. Any pharmacist who cannot dispense medicines lawfully prescribed by a doctor should find another line of work.

title: Japanese Cuisine With a French Twist
description: SOME locations seem to be trouble for restaurants. A place will open and hang on for a couple of years, then it is gone and a new one takes its place. And 192 East Main Street in Clinton has seemed like such a location.

Set near the Napa River, it cost me a smidgen more than $100,000 to buy and $40,000 for construction. title: Seeking Heroes, Finding Humans
description: We live in a country where professional athletes are not merely idolized, but worshipped as heroes. They can't just excel; they have an obligation to be role models. We're aware of this obligation because politicians and sportswriters periodically remind us of it. And since March 17, when Mark McGwire offered his infamous nondenial of steroid use to the House Committee on Government, they have reminded us more shrilly and more sanctimoniously than ever.

title: Fields of Dreams
description: In 1868, Laura Ingalls set out in a covered wagon with her parents and two younger sisters from the woods of Pepin, Wis., and journeyed toward the rugged Kansas Territory, eventually settling in a small log cabin on Osage land near Independence. "Little House on the Prairie," the memoir published by Laura Ingalls Wilder in 1935, immortalized that odyssey. And nearly 40 years later, the long-running NBC drama series starring Michael Landon put a Hollywood gloss on it.

title: A Broker's Fee on Lease Renewal
description: Q. When I moved to Manhattan a few years ago, I resigned myself to paying a broker's fee to find an apartment. What I didn't foresee was that I would be asked to pay this same broker an additional $300 each time I renewed the lease, for faxing forms between me and the landlord. The apartment is not rent-regulated. Is there any legal basis for the broker to collect $300 every time a tenant renews her lease? . . . Cathy Ellis Stadecker, Manhattan.

title: The Politics of Ibrahim Parlak
description: I worked for Ibrahim Parlak in 1999 and found his main flaw as a restaurateur was that he was a perpetual soft touch for hard-luck cases. I've barely thought about him since, except to worry about him, briefly, in the chaos and fear of post-Sept. 11. No one is more quintessentially American in his ideals of inclusion than Ibrahim is, and I find myself sickened by his treatment at the hands of our government.

title: Bad Connections
description: I have been reading a lot about how rude cellphones have made us (The Way We Live Now, Christine Rosen, March 20). A more important question is, where has our collective sense of humor gone? There's nothing funnier than listening to a pretentious guy on his cellphone. Relax. Eavesdrop. It's fun.

title: Channeling Mamet
description: Some writers win Nobel Prizes. Some inspire parody contests. Some -- well, Ernest Hemingway -- do both. So there's still hope for David Mamet, subject of a "Write Like Mamet" contest at the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco. Nearly 100 aspiring tough guys (and gals) entered the derby, held to publicize the premiere of Mr. Mamet's adaptation of Harley Granville-Barker's "Voysey Inheritance." The 10 winners had their expletive-laced entries read at the Geary Theater after performances of "Voysey" on Friday and Saturday. As these excerpts show, the winners found "Glengarry Glen Ross" to be Mr. Mamet's most imitable, or at least most familiar, work. Unlike the real estate salesmen of "Glengarry," the writers didn't stand to win a Cadillac or even a set of steak knives. But as far as we know, they weren't viciously insulted by Alec Baldwin. title: Not-So-New Wave
description: Few things are more frustrating than delaying the purchase of a coveted object, only to find that by the time you eventually pull out your credit card, the product has been "improved," "restyled" or, worse, "redesigned." While virtually every consumer category is guilty of "new and improved" marketing campaigns, the automotive industry must be the worst offender. Rather than leaving well enough alone and allowing a brand to build equity through a distinct set of design characteristics, the automotive industry trades on insecurity. As a consequence, car design has become less about creating vehicles of exceptional quality and engineering and more about adding so many superfluous bells and whistles that the previous model immediately looks dated in the eyes of the customer. This flagrant abuse of design talent and hard-won brand equity looks increasingly unsustainable.

title: The Remix; My Pod
description: Today's urban nomads want homes that are both flexible and stylish. The Loftcube, a modular dwelling by the Berlin-based designer Werner Aisslinger, is just large enough, at 390 square feet, for one nomad and mate. Its exterior shell is made of steel coated in white Corian, with a menu of choices -- solid or glass, wooden louvers or doors -- for the side walls. The inside is as practical as it is cool. A hinged faucet is carved into a Corian panel dividing kitchen from bath so that it can swing in both directions. But the kitchen can just as easily be a home office: it's all customizable. Heating, plumbing and electricity are all built-in or integrated with connected buildings. And there is no messy foundation work required, because the whole thing sits on steel-and-fiberglass legs. "I wanted it to look more like a product than a house -- small, lightweight and mobile," Aisslinger says. The Loftcube is perfect for city rooftops, "for the urban nomads who stay in their jobs for about two years, then move on." It should be in production by late spring. Go to www.loftcube.net. JULIE V. IOVINE

title: The Murakami Method

A sequence of galleries exhibiting luggage and handbags proceeded to a large advertising photograph of the actress Uma Thurman and smaller shots of runway models, all wearing Vuitton fashions. What drew me to the show, however, were two bags in the variation of the Vuitton pattern that the Japanese contemporary artist Takashi Murakami developed with the company in 2003. The brightly colored Murakami line has been phenomenally successful, with sales reported to be in the vicinity of $300 million. Murakami's handbags were presented along with two small paneled screens painted in the same patterns that appear on the bags.

title: Inside the List
description: SEST BELLER: "Runny Babbit," Shel Silverstein's silly tale of a rabbit with a penchant for inverting his consonants, makes its debut at No. 1 on the children's picture book best-seller list. Silverstein, the much loved poet and author of idiosyncratic and often bittersweet books like "The Giving Tree," "Where the Sidewalk Ends" and other children's classics of the past four decades, worked on "Runny Babbit" on and off for 20 years, before his death in 1999. Silverstein was a constant reviser. "He had mountains of poems and stories, in bits and pieces, and in different versions, written on stray pieces of paper," his friend and former editor, Joan Robins, told Publishers Weekly. Robins and Toni Markiet, the executive editor of HarperCollins Children's Books, both helped shepherd "Runny Babbit" into print. Written in jolly inverse verse, the book recounts the adventures of a kindhearted, rather hapless rabbit, from restaurant to bath to library ("A bience scook? A boetry pook? / Oh, no -- a bomic cook!"). HarperCollins has done a first printing of 500,000 copies, betting that deprived Silverstein fans will be eager to snap it up. A good bet: The Times Magazine reported after his death that Silverstein -- who in the course of his career was a playwright, a regular cartoonist for Playboy and a country-western songwriter -- left an estate worth $20 million, so he clearly knew a thing or two about what people want.

Everyone gets both friendly and frantic at a country-house dinner party given by Desiree's current lover, and there is some changing of partners. title: The Remix; Fiber Optics
description: Architects don't often become weavers. But Jorge Lizarazo did just that when he founded de Rhodes Hechizoo, a Colombian textile company, with the weaver Mnica de Rhodes. "Jorge sees his textiles as his buildings, only in different materials," says Cristina Grajales, a decorative-arts consultant who is their New York representative. The two have been using a combination of natural materials to create carpets, fabrics and panels since 2002. Cumare, agave, yare reed and fique, a hand-hewn, biodegradable fiber from the Andes, are woven by Bogot artisans with tin, glass, aluminum and nonharmful copper. The result is decidedly modern. Metal panels that can be fashioned as wallcoverings, table mats or room dividers are their most experimental offering. Grajales uses agave panels as curtains; they create unusual light. "You have transparency and opacity," she says. "There's a very warm feeling." ALEXANDRA ZISSU

title: The Remix; Back to the Future
description: In 1929, a 27-year-old Danish architect named Arne Jacobsen was struck with a vision of utopia. In his revelation, the citizens of tomorrow would inhabit dwellings reflecting an accelerated pace of life: homes with helipads, boating docks in the basement and doormats that doubled as vacuum cleaners. A life-size model of this "House of the Future" (executed by Jacobsen and his partner, Flemming Lassen) was temporarily erected that year at the Housing and Building Exhibition in Copenhagen. Audiences marveled at wall panels that beamed in paintings from remote art collections, a kitchen stocked with ready-made meals and a conveyor tube that dropped mail directly into the home. The exhibition, which established Jacobsen as a master of Danish Modernism, was eventually dismantled, and the "House of the Future" faded into the past. Now a group of Danish architects is reconstructing the house in Bellevue, located just north of Copenhagen and home to several other Jacobsen buildings. The new structure, to open next year, is a wrinkle in time: once futuristic, it's now historical. But despite certain retrograde elements -- windows that are rolled down like car windows -- it's still cutting edge. You can also tour the rest of Jacobsen's local legacy, including his beachfront house, the Bellevue Theatre and Jacobsen, a restaurant featuring his modern-primitive silverware (made famous as the astronauts' cutlery in "2001: A Space Odyssey"). Jacobsen's seaside shrine remains ahead of the curve. ADAM GOLLNER

title: Daughter of the Enlightenment
description: Last spring, Ayaan Hirsi Ali took her "Dutch mother" -- the woman who taught her the language and cared for her after she arrived in the Netherlands as a refugee in 1992 -- to lunch at the Dudok brasserie, near the Parliament in The Hague. As always, Hirsi Ali's armed security detail was there. They have been her companions since she started receiving death threats in September 2002. Hirsi Ali, who was born in Somalia and has been a member of the Dutch Parliament since January 2003, had endorsed the view that Islam is a backward religion, condemned the way women live under it and said that by today's standards, the prophet Muhammad would be considered a perverse tyrant. She had also announced that she was no longer a believing Muslim. The punishment for such apostasy is, according to strict interpretations of Islam, death. That day at the Dudok, several dozen vocational students were taking up the main restaurant, so she and her guards parked at two tables near the bar. Hirsi Ali had her back to the restaurant when one of the students, apparently a Dutch convert to Islam, tapped her on the shoulder. "I turned around," she recalls in her elegant English, "and saw this sweet, young Dutch guy, about 24 years old. With freckles! And he was like, 'Madam, I hope the mujahedeen get you and kill you.' " Hirsi Ali handed him her knife and told him, "Why don't you do it yourself?"

But in skilled hands, like those of Deborah Buck, eclectic is a triumphant melding of disparate parts. Buck was trained as a painter, which helps when she's decorating one of her own residences (she has two) or buying for Buck House, her Upper East Side antiques shop. "It's all the same thing," she says. "It's the same finding the right magenta for a chair as it is finding the right color in a painting." For the living room of her country house, a three-story Dutch Colonial in Garrison, N.Y., she approached it as if she were putting together a guest list for a party. "You want to make sure that each piece has at least one other piece to relate to, and introduce objects that have something in common with one another," she says. "Once you get the right balance, you can just stand back and watch the fun ensue." CAROLE NICKSIN

title: The Remix; Let There Be L.E.D.
description: Silicon Valley has moved from laptops to lamps. The Palo Alto-New York start-up Lucesco has introduced Halley, a supersleek task lamp that snubs bulbs in favor of L.E.D.'s (light-emitting diodes), which are smaller and more ecofriendly, with a life span of up to 20 years. To create an iconic design, the company turned to Richard Sapper, who put halogen lights on the map in the 80's with the Tizio lamp. Sapper didn't exactly jump at the prospect. "The L.E.D. lighting fixtures I'd seen gave off a light that was much too cold -- inhuman, really," he says. Only after being convinced that Lucesco had diodes capable of emitting a warm light did he sign on. The biggest challenge was the intense heat that the L.E.D.'s generate. Sapper dealt with it the same way he had when designing the IBM ThinkPad -- with a tiny fan. Springs and wires were something else he wanted to avoid, but L.E.D.'s require cables. So he took another page from computer technology, employing the tiny wire hinges used in laptops to conduct electricity to channel energy through Halley's base. To balance the arms, which allow the lamp to move in three dimensions, Sapper connected them with a metal ball. The light revolves around this ball like a comet; hence its name. Having seen the light source, Sapper is an L.E.D. convert: he's already at work on two more lamps for Lucesco. Go to www.lucesco.com. MARISA BARTOLUCCI

title: UP FRONT
description: Walter Kirn, who lives in Montana, is a novelist whose books include "Thumbsucker" and "Up in the Air." He is also a regular contributor to these pages; he weighs in this week on Jonathan Safran Foer's much-anticipated second novel, "Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close." For Kirn, criticism and fiction writing have always been closely linked. "When you're writing fiction, there are two voices in your head -- the one doing the storytelling and the one who is reviewing that story and second-guessing it," he said in a telephone interview. "On some level you can't be a novelist without being a critic, even if you never turn that critical ability into essays and publish them." Kirn, who was New York magazine's book critic in the mid-1990's and who was also the literary editor of GQ for several years, said that reviewing books is vastly different from reviewing, say, movies. "Roger Ebert knows people will go see the films he writes about. But when you write about books, you can't depend on people agreeing or disagreeing with your opinion -- no matter how much you rave, you can count on maybe 5 percent of your readers actually buying the book. It becomes more important to write something that's worth reading in and of itself." Kirn's fourth novel, "Mission to America," will be published this fall; a film version of "Thumbsucker," directed by Mike Mills, is scheduled to be released at about the same time. Meanwhile, look for more of his reviews here. The Editors

description: Japanese restaurants may have reached the mainstream and beyond -- Masa, in Manhattan, was recently awarded four stars by The New York Times -- but Japanese cooking has so far failed to gain a foothold in American kitchens. One of the most important books on the cuisine continues to be "Japanese Cooking: A Simple Art," by Shizuo Tsuji, and it was published 25 years ago. Instead, home cooks have taken more to the ingredients of a Japanese kitchen, things like panko (bread crumbs), wasabi powder, miso and sake. A few dishes have become part of the American repertory, like miso-marinated cod, popularized by the chef Nobu Matsuhisa, and tempura, battered and fried vegetables and seafood served with everything from mayonnaise to ponzu. And of course, there is the saketini. Despite its dubious name, a dry floral sake shaken with an herbal gin makes a fine drink. Adding an olive drives home the martini idea, but it's better going the British route and floating in a paper-thin cucumber slice.

The Art of Grading
description: My ninth-grade art teacher doesn't give any grade above 94 percent because, she says, "There's always room for improvement." In previous years, I earned a 99 percent and a 100 percent. The 94 I received this term does not reflect the hard work that I put into this course. Because of her "improvement" theory, I got a lower grade than I deserve. Is her grading philosophy ethical? Audrey Wachs, Larchmont, N.Y. Your teacher's grading system may be unwise, but it is not unethical. A teacher deserves wide latitude in selecting the method of grading that best promotes learning in her classroom; that is, after all, the prime function of grades. It is she who has the training and experience to make this decision. Assuming that your teacher is neither biased nor corrupt -- she would be wrong to let students staple a crisp $10 bill to each art project -- and that her system conforms to school rules, you can't fault her ethics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRECKER, RICHARD L.
description: BRECKER--Richard L. Of Vero Beach, FL and Nantucket, MA, died unexpectedly of respiratory failure on March 29, 2005. He was 83 years old. Prior to his retirement in l991, he was Chairman of Brecker & Merryman, Inc., an international consulting firm headquartered in New York which he co-founded with Andrew Merryman in 1973. The firm was subsequently acquired by Manpower, Inc. Born in New York, he attended the Pawling School and graduated with honors with exceptional distinction from Yale in December, 1942. While at Yale he was an editor of the Yale Daily News and wrote music and lyrics for two Yale Dramat shows which toured the country. During World War II he served for two years in the U.S. Marine Corps attached to the OSS (Office of Strategic Services). He then spent eight years here and abroad as a U.S. Foreign Service Officer, including tours as Vice Consul and U.S. Information Officer in India, Chief of the USIS Exhibits Branch, Officer in Charge of the official U.S. exhibition at the International "Atoms for Peace" conference in Geneva in 1954, and Briefing Officer for the Secretary of State. While in Geneva, on loan to the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission, he escorted President Eisenhower through the live atomic reactor which was part of the U.S. exhibition. Before establishing his own firm, he spent a number of years with several leading advertising agencies in New York and as a co-owner of a flag manufacturing company in Clifton, NJ. Active in various civic and community affairs, he was a member of the New York City Youth Board, a member of the New York Republican County Committee, and a Director of the New York Young Republican Club. He was also Vice Chairman of the YMCA of Greater New York, a member of the YMCA's National Board, a Board member of the Professional Children's School, and Vice President and for fifteen years a member of the Council of the University Club in New York. From 1979 to 1994 he served on the Board of Visitors of the Fuqua School of Business at Duke University. Music played a big part in his life from his earliest years, and while at college he briefly considered making a career out of it. He was an accomplished pianist, playing popular music largely by ear. Two of the numerous songs he wrote were published and one was recorded by Carmen Cavallero. When the Yale Dramat staged a retrospective musical in 1980 called "Deja Review", the pre-opening announcement said the show would "pay tribute to Yale composers from Cole Porter to Maltby and Shire and Richard Brecker". At his death he was a Trustee of the Naval War College Foundation in Newport, RI, President emeritus of the Yale Club of the Treasure Coast, and a Director of the Indian River Land Trust Association. Having traveled widely, including a mule-back trip to Tibet the year before the Chinese took over that country, he was also an Honorary Fellow of the Explorers Club. Mr. Brecker was a member of the John's Island Club, the Nantucket Yacht Club, the Sankaty Head Golf Club, the Siasconset Casino Association and the Metropolitan Club in Washington, D.C. A master mason, he was a member of Holland Lodge in New York. He is survived by his beloved wife of 47 years, the former Joan Rowcliffe, by their three children, Mrs. Douglas T. Hendrickson of New York, Mr. Jarvis R. Brecker of Portland, OR, Mrs. Jon R. Yenor of Riverside, CT, by five grandchildren, and by his sister, Mrs. Richard H. Leeds of Upper Brookville, NY. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Church in Vero Beach on Thursday, April 7th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the Naval War College Foundation Inc., 686 Cushing Road, Newport, RI 02841.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSS, MARTIN MAYER
description: GROSS--Martin Mayer, age 87 passed away at his home in Verona, NJ on Thursday, March 31, after a long illness. He was a professional engineer, a builder and an appraiser. A WWII veteran, Marty served in the US Army Special Engineers unit as a port and dock specialist. Later, he was attached to MacArthur's headquarters in Luzon. Marty was awarded 2 Bronze Stars; one for the New Guinea Campaign and one for the Philippine Campaign. He also received the American Theater Ribbon, Asiatic Ribbon with arrowhead and 2 battle stars, Victory Medal, Meritorious Service Unit Plaque and the Philippine Liberation Ribbon with 2 battle stars. Marty was active in improving the lives of the developmentally disabled. He was a founder of the Essex County Association for Retarded Citizens, a member and President of the Board of Trustees of Woods Services for over 50 years. He was also a member of The Society of Military Engineers, The NJ Engineers Society and Master, Appraisal Institute. Some of his more notable appraisals included Ellis Island, Yankee Stadium, and Gateway National Park. He was a member of Green Brook Country Club and an avid golfer. Marty was predeceased by his first wife, Phyllis Simon, and by his son, Jonathan. He is survived by his loving wife of 35 years, Arlene Ross Scott, and by his adoring step-daughter, Emily Scott Pottruck, his son-in-law, David Pottruck, and step-son, William Scott. He is also survived by his sisters, Augusta Citron of Tucson, and Dina Simon of Philadelphia. And by a niece, Belinda Dumont and nephews, Mark Raven, Samuel and Alexander Simon. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, April 3rd at Noon at the Bernheim - Apter Kreitzman Funeral Home located at 68 Old Short Hills Rd, Livingston, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Marty's memory to Woods Services, Langhorne, PA 19047

title: Contributors
description: Carol Troy "I experience space as a New Yorker," says the California transplant Carol Troy (right, center, in the 1970's) of her trailer getaway, which she describes on Page 70. "I arrive at my destination,I go inside and shut the door." After her divorce, Troy sought an affordable second home. "There's no way a designer-writer, a divorced woman, can afford a weekend place," she says, describingher novel solution as "my little experimental lab." Troy has long honed her budgeting prowess: her1975 book, "Cheap Chic" (near right and far right), written with Caterine Milinaire, inventedthe phrase. "'Cheap Chic' was really sort of seismic," she says. Troy was also a founding editor of Rags, the 70's fashion magazine. "It was looking at fashion with a sense of humor," says Troy,who has had many lives since then, even penning a book about online investing. She yearns to return to New York but can't imagine finding an affordable equal to her former 2,000-square-foot loft.But then, being in the white loft, Troy says, "was like living in a squash court."

title: A 21st-Century Occupant Asks About an 1888 Builder
description: Q. My partner, Richard Montoya, and I recently renovated a floor-through apartment at 444 West 50th Street. Mahogany pocket doors and elaborate ceiling moldings, all of very high quality, indicate a building originally intended for a family whom I wouldn't immediately associate with an industrial area like ours, near the bustling riverfront. Why was it built? . . . Robert Rowe, Manhattan.

title: The Get: Style Map; Walk On, Buy
description: Los Angeles has long been a Mecca for good design. Now, a new group of houseware stores has joined some favorite standbys near Beverly Boulevard and Third Street to create the neighborhood for picking up everything from midcentury modern pieces to avant-garde works. Even Dodd Mitchell, the interior designer of Hollywood hot spots like Dolce Enoteca, Sushi Roku and the revamped Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel, has a studio nearby. This new hub has Angelenos parking their cars and walking -- walking! -- from store to store. PETER DAVIS

title: Iraqi Politicians Complain of Flaws in Interim Law
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 2 - After weeks of factional haggling that have prompted warnings of increasing civil distress, several leading Iraqi politicians have begun saying that flawed measures in the interim constitution are partly to blame for the failure to form a new government.

title: Putin/Poutine
description: The last name of the president of Russia is Putin, right? Not so fast. Paris, we have a pronunciation problem. To solve it, we must plunge headlong in the argumentative world of transliteration -- the representation of sounds of words from one alphabet in another alphabet. However you do it, with whatever authority you cite, some native speaker will surely tell you that you're all wrong.

title: The Lost Apple
description: In 2002 and 2003, Fiona Apple recorded what would have been her third album, "Extraordinary Machine." Its producer, Jon Brion, has said that Ms. Apple's label, Sony Music's Epic Records, shelved the album because it didn't hear potential hit singles. An Epic spokeswoman said, "Fiona has not yet delivered her next album." Lately, what purports to be the full album, 11 songs, has been leaked onto the Internet, where -- despite the efforts of Sony's legal department -- a simple search will find multiple sources of downloads. The album is an oddball gem.

title: Summitt's Intensity Stokes Tennessee's Fire
description: Normally, coaching milestones come packaged with an inevitable discussion about retirement -- particularly when the milestone becomes as weighty as 880 victories -- and people begin wondering aloud how much longer the coach in question can muster the energy for the job.

title: Soap Opera
description: Dove Cool Moisture Body Wash These days, when you see a character in a television show or a movie using a brand-name product, you can't help wondering: did that happen because the creators thought it was the right choice or because the brand paid to be there? On "The Apprentice," however, you don't have to wonder. "The Apprentice" is the reality show in which people compete to work for Donald Trump, and marketing doesn't get tacked onto the story line; it is intrinsic. Perhaps the most extreme example was this season's fourth episode, in which nearly the entire hour was given over to the question of how to advertise Dove Cool Moisture Body Wash. The contestants' handling of this assignment was a fiasco, but the real-life marketers of Dove (who spent about $2 million for the placement) insist they were thrilled with all the "buzz." After all, it drove hundreds of thousands of people to a Web site to sign up for samples.

title: Torre Pencils In His Scorecard a Day Before the Opener
description: At one point during the off-season, the Yankees were not sure that Jason Giambi would don pinstripes again, much less have a meaningful role with the team. But yesterday, Manager Joe Torre announced that Giambi would start at first base tonight in the team's opener against the Red Sox at Yankee Stadium.

title: An Early Advocate of Stock Options Debunks Himself
description: FIFTEEN years ago, Michael C. Jensen, a professor at the Harvard Business School, wrote a paper with Kevin J. Murphy, then a professor at the University of Rochester, that trumpeted some pretty radical ideas for the time. Compensation systems, they posited, prompted chief executives to add revenue, not to increase profit, pay dividends or otherwise reward long-suffering shareholders. Their suggestion was to make stock options a big component of top management's pay, ensuring that they do well only if shareholders do well. "It seemed a way to tie managers tighter to the mast," Professor Jensen recalled recently.

title: Illini Guard Finds Way to Make Amends
description: ST. LOUIS, April 2 - Last season, Illinois guard Luther Head was accused of participating in a burglary. Although charges were not pressed, he was soon in more trouble over multiple traffic violations and was benched for two games.

title: Old Man and the River: A Hemingway at Home
description: Craig, Mont. - It is the new generation of guides that gets Pat Hemingway's goat -- the articulate, hip, Starbucks cowboys and aspiring screenwriters whose voices sometimes carry across the Missouri River and the railroad tracks that go right by Hemingway's house in this enclave of matchbox-sized homes and trailers. This is a place that nobody would ever mistake for that more glitzy Hemingway family haunt, Ketchum, Idaho.

title: Tokyo Girls
description: Hellen van Meene is one of a handful of Dutch photographers who are currently enjoying something of an international vogue for their portrait work. From the glamorous and theatrical celebrity photographs of Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin (seen in the "Great Performers" portfolio in our Feb. 27 issue) to the stark, intently observed subjects of Rineke Dijkstra's pictures (one of which, as it happens, appears on Page 27 of this issue), there is no single Dutch style; there is only a shared taste for original portraiture. Van Meene, for her part, has developed a characteristically small, square and intimately composed portrait shot -- most often of pubescent girls, soft and languorous and at times, she observes, innocently erotic.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about embryonic stem cell research misstated the surname of a supporter of state financing for it. He is Bob Mandelkern, not Mandel.

Holt of Washington, was married there on Monday to William Temple Emmet Darman, a son of Kathleen Emmet Darman and Richard G. Darman of McLean, Va. The Rev. Stuart Kenworthy, the rector of Christ Church, Georgetown, performed the Episcopal ceremony there. The Rev. Loren B. Mead, also an Episcopal priest, took part in the service.

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: LOW-COST CRUISING -- On May 6 easyCruise.com begins its inexpensive weekly European sailings aboard the 170-passenger easyCruiseOne. Passengers can get on or off at any port (two nights' minimum stay), and the ship remains in each port overnight. The first cruise leaves from Nice, France; sailings end on Oct. 15. Twin rooms cost $113; quads are $228 and suites are $304. For reservations see www.easyCruise.com.

title: Ellen Barkin and Todd Solondz: Brains and Beauty
description: LOS ANGELES - IT may be a new iteration of that old combination of brains and beauty (like Arthur Miller and Marilyn Monroe). When Todd Solondz, the 46-year-old director, and Ellen Barkin, the 50-year-old actress and fourth wife of the Revlon tycoon Ronald Perelman, walk into a restaurant here, heads turn.

Extraordinarily wonderful grandmother of David and his wife Charlene of Upper Saddle River, NJ, and Deborah Posner and her husband Gordon of Boca Raton, FL. title: Comings and Goings
description: The Washington Monument, closed last September, was scheduled to reopen April 1 after the installation of a vehicle barrier security system. But the entire project will not be finished until late June; the grounds surrounding the monument are still off limits. Free daily tickets to the monument, which can be reached by a narrow fenced-in walkway, are distributed from a kiosk on 15th Street. Open daily; (202) 426-6841; www.nps.gov/wamo. Citing the continued potential for violence and terrorism against Americans in Indonesia and the Philippines, the U.S. State Department has updated security information on its Web site and continues to urge American citizens to defer nonessential travel to those countries. Information: (888) 407-4747 or www.travel.state.gov. Most major U.S. airlines have reinstated a fare increase of $10 for most round-trip domestic flights because of rising jet fuel costs; the increase has been matched by some discount airlines such as Jet Blue. The Transportation Security Administration has added all lighters to its list of prohibited items. Some types had already been banned, but now all lighters are forbidden. Enforcement will start April 14. MARJORIE CONNELLY

title: A Good Year, Lower Yields at Paumanok
description: PAUMANOK'S 2004 whites illustrate how nature can influence boutique wineries, which predominate on the East End. The year brought a good vintage, reduced production, stylistic changes and economic adjustments.
