title: The Quality Cure?
description: David Cutler argues in Roger Lowenstein's March 13 article that controlling health-care costs should be through improved quality of care rather than by rationing services. This is the basis for the movement toward "pay for performance," which rewards physicians based on outcomes.

title: Police Search in Bronx for a Missing Deliveryman
description: An extensive search in and around a Bronx apartment complex was under way yesterday for a restaurant deliveryman who failed to return to work on Friday night after taking food to the complex, the authorities said.

title: Soldier's Death Ruled Accident
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 - A Bulgarian soldier in Iraq was killed accidentally by American forces last month when combat patrols from each country shot at each other in the dark in response to what each side thought was a hostile attack, an American military investigation has concluded.

title: The Nation; A Guide to the Republican Herd
description: HERE is an attempt to portray various philosophical and political factions under the Republicans' big tent, taking account of the many overlapping concerns that unite them. This is based on the views of various Republican sources, notably Frank Luntz, the Republican pollster, who himself is controversial within his party. Different analysts prefer their own classifications, so there will be a lot here to provoke discussion. BILL MARSH

title: As Winter Ends, Afghan Rebels Step Up Attacks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 2 - The United States military said Saturday that insurgents in Afghanistan were becoming more active now that the winter months were over. The assessment came a day after attacks killed five people and wounded five others around the country.

title: Boy Problems
description: 'It's her future. Do the math," instructs a poster that is part of the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A.'s two-year-old "Girls Go Tech" campaign. Accompanying the message -- which belongs to a series of public service announcements also sponsored by the Ad Council -- is a photograph of an adorable little girl reading a book called "Charlotte's Web Site." The cover of the E. B. White takeoff shows Fern and Wilbur looking intently at Charlotte on a computer screen. The text below warns that "by sixth grade, an alarming number of girls lose interest in math, science and technology. Which means they won't qualify for most future jobs."

title: The Politics of Ibrahim Parlak
description: Your article did an effective job of dispelling the Department of Homeland Security's case against Ibrahim Parlak. What it touches on but fails to explore fully is the hypocrisy of the government's position on terrorism. In this case, it would have us believe that the Kurdish rebels in Turkey are terrorists, while those in Iraq are freedom fighters. This distinction is based on nothing more than our cozy relationship with the Turkish government, which has proved to be as resistant to Kurdish autonomy as was Saddam Hussein.

title: With Enthusiasm to Spare, Illinois Strikes Yet Again
description: St. LOUIS, April 2 - It is a fitting pastime for a team that has knocked down one opponent after another to hold the No. 1 ranking in the nation for the past four months: bowling. The players have done it as a team all season, and Illinois Coach Bruce Weber decided that the tradition should, well, roll on.

title: The Underminer
description: "I still find it hard to explain to my mother what it is that I do," says 30-year-old Tobias Wong. How about this? Wong is a furniture and object designer with the soul of a conceptual artist; a sometime curator; a sophisticated prankster. A Vancouver native, Wong has courted controversy since the 2001 furniture show "intransit," held at the now-shuttered Terminal-NYC showroom. Why controversial? For starters, whose work did he really show? His piece "This Is a Lamp" began as Philippe Starck's Bubble Club chair, which Wong wired for light. He was then able to procure the chair from its license holder, Kartell, early enough to unveil it before Starck even showed his original work in America. Now, that's timing.

title: Eat, Memory: Our Lady of Lawson
description: To live in Japan without eating Japanese food seems an advanced kind of heresy. My sushi-loving friends in California regard me as a lost cause; my housemates in Japan simply shrug and see this as ultimate confirmation -- me dragging at some lasagna in a plastic box while they gobble down dried fish -- that I belong to an alien species. I grew up in England, I tell them, on boarding-school food, no less; I like Japan at some level deeper than the visible (or edible). They look away and try not to scream.

title: Here's Why the Centrist Democrat Is Feeling Unloved
description: ONCE upon a time, not so very long ago, the centrist Democrat was among Washington's hardiest and richly plumaged species. He was a privileged guest on Sunday-morning chat shows, the go-to guy for blue-ribbon commissions, the arbiter of Beltway conventional wisdom. He -- this being Washington it was usually a he -- was the pragmatist, the middle-splitter, the politician who came to Get Things Done.

Do Taxes Thwart Growth? Prove It
description: TAX reform, like a second marriage, is the triumph of hope over experience. The United States has just gone through the most sweeping tax cuts since the 1980's, but hardly anybody is satisfied. President Bush contends that we need still-lower taxes in order to prosper. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, is suggesting a radical shift to a consumption tax. And the Republican Party has taken aim at the entire tax system.

title: The Politics of Ibrahim Parlak
description: Alex Kotlowitz (March 20) did an excellent job of shedding light on a very complicated situation. There are hundreds more of Ibrahim Parlak's friends, neighbors and supporters here in southwest Michigan, northern Indiana and northern Illinois who are asking the same question: why? A line from "Casablanca" has been running through my head since he was arrested last July: "Round up the usual suspects." I fear that our government has been doing just that on a massive scale, with many like Ibrahim, who are living hard-working, honest and open lives, being arrested and deported.

title: Pitching Camp

title: DISABILITIES AND CRUISING
description: To the Editor: As a partly disabled senior citizen, I embarked on a South American cruise in February. I do not negotiate steps well anymore. When I, walking with my cane, first entered the dining room, the headwaiter saw me and helped me up the one step -- doing so when I entered and left for the entire cruise. The ship, the Marco Polo, also had accessible restrooms in several public areas. The Marco Polo (Orient Lines) has a connection with Norwegian Cruise Lines, which was covered in the article.

Born in New York City on December 1st, 1930, she attended Hunter Elementary and High School, Tyler School of Fine Arts at Temple University, and Columbia University. She is survived by her husband Carl, son Pieter, grandson Elio, and sister Susan Zuch.

title: A Brisk Trade in Noodles, Wonton and Job Seekers
description: The Chinese restaurants on Eldridge Street just below Canal do a brisk lunchtime business with their fish-ball soup, duck noodles and dumplings laced with leeks. But the commodity exchanged most in this part of Chinatown is labor. Employment agencies line the narrow block, and even the one shoe store doubles as a jobs center.

title: Stadium Clock Speeds Up in a New York Minute
description: THE New York minute is fabled for its brash double-time urgency. Wait till you see a quarter of a year whiz past in New York.

title: Design Resolutionary
description: A few years ago DuPont, trolling for designers to appear in a show that would demonstrate the joys of its synthetic material Corian, approached the designer Ron Arad, and Arad turned them down flat: "I said, 'When you want to do a major project, come back."' Playing hard to get worked. Arad, as it happened, had been experimenting with putting images inside an object -- planting fiber optics in solid materials -- and Corian turned out to be the perfect vehicle. "It becomes translucent, but you can cut it or carve it," he says. In this case, he carved Corian into three parts -- a 32-foot-wide wall, a 16-foot column and an M&M-shaped table -- for his Lo-Rez-Dolores-Tabula-Rasa. The three pieces look like blank surfaces when not in use, but when turned on, the images hug their curves without distortion but with a little pixelated mystery.

title: More Homes, Fewer Malls
description: Garden City - EVERYONE knows that Long Island has a serious affordable housing problem. Nearly every local politician has pointed this out, but few have offered any real solutions. Well, I have a suggestion. Let's build homes on the thousands of acres of land that are owned by the government. Why? Because in order to recruit workers to sustain our communities, we need to think outside the box when it comes to housing.

title: Excuse Me While I Kiss the Buddha in the Sky
description: PREVIOUS generations of Hong Kong action heroes have flown through the air with the aid of hidden wires and trampolines. But now, Hong Kong filmmakers are following Hollywood into the digital age, using computer technology to manipulate images and make the feats of their protagonists seem even more otherworldly and astonishing. One of the comic (and even poetic) highlights of Stephen Chow's new film "Kung Fu Hustle" finds Mr. Chow leaping so far off the ground that he encounters Buddha in the form of a cloud formation, before he plunges back to earth to deliver a devastating coup de grce to an opponent.

'Oklahoma!' I did 'Music Man' as my first tour. I was blessed with that. A lot of my peers say my technique is great, I'm ready to compete. I've paid my dues, been around the block a little bit."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHRATWIESER, MARGE

Marge is now reunited with her beloved husband, Joseph J. Schratwieser, and cherished daughter, Meg Hectus. We will see you in every ocean wave and every tree and mountain and flower, Mom. We love you dearly and will miss your love and generosity and vitality through all the coming years.

title: Memorials in Chalk
description: SONIA WISOTSKY, Nicolina Nicolosci, Yetta Rosenbaum. These women were among the 146 workers who died in the Triangle Shirtwaist fire, New York's most infamous disaster before the attacks of Sept. 11. title: Accommodating Disabilities
description: Q. My wife and I are shareholders in a co-op in Queens. We have a parking space in the garage. The co-op has a 30-minute limit on parking in front of the building. I have a New York City parking permit for people with disabilities. I have asked that, from time to time, I be allowed to park my car in front for longer than 30 minutes so that I don't have to negotiate the steps that lead from the garage to the rear entrance of the building. The board has stated that the 30-minute limit is a courtesy, and that it does not have to comply with rules governing access for people with disabilities. Is it correct? . . . There were some, like John Martin, dance critic of The New York Times, who felt initially that American dance was modern dance and that ballet represented a regression to what might now be called "old Europe."

But when a California couple commissioned him to reconfigure their Manhattan pied--terre -- an exposed 1,400-square-foot box in the north tower of the glass-and-steel complex designed by Richard Meier off the West Side Highway -- he found himself adding, not subtracting, and actually minimizing a view for which most New Yorkers would kill.

A sequence of galleries exhibiting luggage and handbags proceeded to a large advertising photograph of the actress Uma Thurman and smaller shots of runway models, all wearing Vuitton fashions. What drew me to the show, however, were two bags in the variation of the Vuitton pattern that the Japanese contemporary artist Takashi Murakami developed with the company in 2003. The brightly colored Murakami line has been phenomenally successful, with sales reported to be in the vicinity of $300 million. Murakami's handbags were presented along with two small paneled screens painted in the same patterns that appear on the bags.

Based on the book by Rachel Simmons, "Odd Girl Out: The Hidden Culture of Aggression in Girls," tonight's movie intelligently dramatizes a convincing adolescent breakdown - one that proceeds without benefit of booze or anorexia, hastened by nothing but old-fashioned cruelty.

title: The Arts, Briefly; Friel on the Road

Mr. Friel's latest effort, "The Home Place," closed at the Gate on April 2 after its premiere run and will reopen at the Comedy Theater in the West End in London on May 25. The play, about an aging landlord in 1870's Ireland as tenant farmers begin to rebel, features Irish actors like Derbhle Crotty, Tom Courtenay and Nick Dunning, and is directed by Adrian Noble. And a Friel classic, "Faith Healer," will move to Broadway in April 2006 after a run at the Gate, Variety reported. It will star Ralph Fiennes as a washed-up medicine man and Ian McDiarmid as his manager; Jonathan Kent directs. BRIAN LAVERY

description: On some late-night subway trains last week, New York City Transit closed off access to half the cars in a crime-fighting experiment, police officials said yesterday. The last five cars on each 10-car train were kept shut at certain times between midnight and 6:30 a.m. To give passengers enough time to reach the doors in use, conductors kept them open longer than usual. Paul J. Browne, a police spokesman, said the experiment was intended to prevent robberies of sleeping or intoxicated passengers who have been preyed upon in recent months when alone in cars late at night. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEBER, DAMON DANIEL
description: WEBER--Damon Daniel. 16, died on March 30, 2005, from a post-transplant infection he fought like the lion he was. He had greater strength, courage and dignity than any man. Damon was born in Brooklyn on August 8, 1988 and lived a full, active and creative life despite severe congenital heart disease. He was fearless and determined and full of love and never felt sorry for himself. He had many passions, but acting was his first love. He made his television debut on the hit HBO series Deadwood 10 days before he died. Previously he appeared on stage in The Great Kapock Tree, Mary Poppins, The Sound of Music, The King and I, Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, Guys and Dolls, Frog Prince and Cindafella. He also performed at the Provincetown Playhouse in Cymbeline, Pericles and Romeo and Juliet. At Brooklyn Technical High School, Damon appeared in The Importance of Being Ernest, Picasso at the Lapin Agile and Tommy. As vice president of the drama club he made a brilliant directorial debut with The Man Who Came to Dinner. A gifted student and avid reader, Damon attended the Rockefeller Children's School, P.S. 29 where he graduated with highest honors and the Salk School of Science where he won the Literature prize, the Science Prize and the prize for Outstanding Student. He wrote beautifully (though his spelling needed work). He planned to graduate Brooklyn Tech next year and go on to a career in acting and international relations. A born diplomat, Damon attended special events at the Council of Foreign Relations and hoped to intern there. Damon was a natural leader and explorer and enjoyed summers in the Adirondacks, Truro, Martha's Vineyard and family homes in the Catskills and the Isle of Skye. He led his younger siblings, Sam and Miranda, on many exiting adventures. He also read out loud to them for hours, made up his own spellbinding strories and created magical home theatricals and puppet shows. He liked sailing, kayaking and horseback riding. Perhaps Damon's greatest gift was for friendship. He had many close, dear friends and tended each one with love and care. He kept his friends, who ranged in age from the very young to the old. He had deep wells of empathy and kindness and sensitivity, even for strangers. He also possessed insight and wisdom beyond his years. He was gregarious and hosted many large parties and sleepovers at his house, where everyone was always welcome. And he could be wickedly funny, with impeccable mimicry and timing. Damon had striking red hair, blue eyes and pale skin. He was beautiful, iside and out. He had a powerful moral force, purity of character and integrity rare in this world. He will be mourned every moment of every day by his heartbroken father, Doron Weber, who tried desperately to save his adored, firstborn son and flesh of his flexh, and by his grieving mother, Shealagh Weber, who poured all her brave love and generous spirit into this amazing child. His brother Sam and his sister Miranda will never forget their extraordinary sibling. His grandparents Robert and Helga Weber cared for Damon with all their hearts. He was loved by many aunts, uncles, cousins, grandmother, and friends. Funeral services on Monday, April 4, at Temple Beth Emeth in Brooklyn and burial at The Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx. In lieu of flowers donations can be sent to The Damon Weber Prize for Acting and Directing at Brooklyn Tech, c/o Temple Beth Emeth, 83 Marlborough Road, Brooklyn, NY 11226.

description: WOJTYLA--Karol Jozef. The Members, Board of Trustees, and the Rabbis of Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York join with all of God's children in mourning the passing of His Holiness Pope John Paul II. May the Holy One remember him for his unique relationship to the Jewish people and for his sensitivity to the traditions of Judaism, rooted in his expriences as a child of Poland, as he grew up in the midst of one of the greatest of all historic Jewish communities. The bonds that he forged with our people during the Second World War brought to him an understanding of the religious, historic, and cultural authenticity of the Jewish world and its people. His life was dedicated to the teaching of the prophet Malachi: "Have we not all one Father? Hath not one God created us all?" May his soul be bound up in the bond of eternal life. Rabbi David M. description: The crime noir thriller "Sin City," featuring an unusual black-and-white format with digital enhancement, lured action-hungry audiences to the theaters over the weekend, opening at No.1 with an estimated $28.1 million in receipts. From the Dimension unit of Miramax, the film stars Bruce Willis, Clive Owen, Benicio Del Toro, Jessica Alba, Rosario Dawson and Brittany Murphy and is the second R-rated film this year to open at No.1. ("Hide and Seek" was the first.) Another star-studded film, "Beauty Shop," edged out last week's top earner, "Guess Who," for the No.2 spot. "Beauty Shop" (MGM), which opened on Wednesday with Queen Latifah, Kevin Bacon, Andie MacDowell and Alicia Silverstone, took in $13.5 million over the weekend; "Guess Who" (Sony) had $13 million in ticket sales. Rounding out the top five were two holdovers: "Robots" (Fox) made $10 million in its fourth week of release, and the comedy "Miss Congeniality 2: Armed and Fabulous" (Warner Brothers) with Sandra Bullock landed in the No.5 spot with $8.4 million in ticket sales in its second week of release. title: The Arts, Briefly; Simpson Sisters Sign Off
description: Fans of the singing Simpson sisters, Jessica and Ashlee, below with Jessica on the left, have reason to be in mourning, as both "Newlyweds: Nick and Jessica" and "The Ashlee Simpson Show" concluded last Wednesday. Throughout their runs on MTV, the two reality shows regularly won their time slots on advertiser-supported cable in the 12-to-34 demographic the channel aims at, and the series finales drew higher numbers than usual: an estimated 3.43 million viewers watched "Newlyweds" and 2.54 million watched "Ashlee." Elsewhere on MTV is the newest installment of the indomitable "Real World/Road Rules Challenge" series. This season, "The Inferno 2," in which former cast members from the two shows battle for prizes and camera time, is averaging 2.74 million viewers each week. And in the fourth week of March, it was the No.1 cable show among 12-to-34-year-olds. Two other shows were added to the MTV schedule last week. "I Want a Famous Face," in which young people undergo plastic surgery to look like their favorite celebrities, began its second season, and "Trippin," Cameron Diaz's globe-trotting nature show, had its series premiere. "Famous Face" drew an audience of 1.25 million, and "Trippin" brought in 1.46 million. KATE AURTHUR

description: The death of Pope John Paul II has prompted an adjustment in Showtime's promotional efforts for a forthcoming made-for-cable movie called "Our Fathers." The movie, a dramatization of the sexual abuse scandal in the Boston archdiocese featuring Ted Danson (as a lawyer for several victims) and Christopher Plummer, right (as Cardinal Bernard F. Law), is scheduled to have its premiere on the premium cable channel on May 21. While that date apparently still stands, Showtime decided over the weekend to postpone a screening it had planned in Boston, at Faneuil Hall, on April 12. The screening was to have been followed by a panel discussion that would have included several men who have come forward to say they were abused as boys by their priests. In a telephone interview yesterday, Robert Greenblatt, president of Showtime, said: "We just thought that in this transition time between now and the election of a new pope, it wasn't appropriate to do a screening of this movie, especially in Boston, which has a very big and thriving Catholic community." title: Watching the Schiavo Story
description: Cable news networks are tailormade to cover around-the-clock events and, thanks in part to the blanket coverage, that's what the Terri Schiavo case became. According to data from Nielsen Media Research, ratings spikes on some cable networks followed several major announcements in the case: the denial on March 10 of a request to keep in her feeding tube; the denial by a federal judge 12 days later of a request to reinsert it; and, finally, her death early Thursday morning, on the 13th day after the tube was taken out.

Paid Notice: Deaths   GUREASKO, ESTHER FREDEN
description: GUREASKO--Esther Freden. 97, on March 5, 2005 in Boynton Beach, Fla. She lived a rich and varied life: as wife for over 50 years of her childhood sweetheart, Edward Martin, a NYC high school teacher and Lieutenant Colonial, Army Air Force WWII, who succumbed to Alzheimer's disease, and as devoted companion of Herman Jacobs, for the last fifteen years. Originally trained as an elementary school teacher, she was involved in innumerable civic and religious activities, among them, President of the Brooklyn Women's Division and National Vice President of the American Jewish Congress, AJC delegate to UN Commission on Human Rights, Executive Board of the Council of Jewish Organizations for Israel Bonds, National Chairman UJA Women's Division, Executive Board of the Brooklyn Jewish Community Council, Monroe (N.J.) Board of Education, Founding Editor, Rossmoor News (N.J.), political campaign manager, and local chairman of the United Way Campaign. In 1982, she received the Distinguished Service Award from the Rossmoor Kiwanis Club for her many contributions to that community. title: National Briefing | West: California: Domestic-Partner Law Is Upheld
description: A state appeals court in Sacramento upheld the state's new domestic partner law, which the Legislature intended to give registered same-sex couples many of the protections of marriage. A three-judge panel of the Third District Court of Appeal unanimously rejected a challenge by the Campaign for California Families, an advocacy group. The group argued that the new law violated Proposition 22, a state law approved by voters in 2000 that defined marriage as a union between a man and a woman. The court action upholds the Domestic Partners Rights and Responsibilities Act, which took effect Jan. 1. It found that Proposition 22 addressed the definition of marriage but not the rights and responsibilities of registered domestic partners and that the two laws were therefore not in conflict. Officials at the Campaign for California Families said they planned to appeal. Carolyn Marshall (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Long Drought Could Lead To Dust Bowl
description: The longstanding drought in the Northwest will probably intensify over the next six months and could produce disastrously dry conditions and severe fire dangers by August, according to a new analysis by climate scientists at the United States Forest Service and Oregon State University. The worsening drought will mainly affect Idaho, Montana, Northern California, Washington and Wyoming, the scientists said. Five computer models generally found the same trend, said Ronald Neilson, a bioclimatologist for the forest agency, adding that conditions "will only get worse in coming months, and reach levels that were generally seen during the Dust Bowl of the 1930's." Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

description: Infinity Broadcasting's WXRK-FM (K-Rock, 92.3) ditched much of its alternative-rock programming on Monday to favor more mainstream and older rock acts, the latest in a string of such format shifts that have swept across alternative radio outlets across the country. The modified playlist will now feature acts from the 1980's and 90's like Guns N' Roses, Nirvana, AC/DC, Green Day (lead singer, Billie Joe Armstrong, below) and Audioslave, with bands from the 70's like Led Zeppelin and Pink Floyd also in the mix. The station, which broadcasts Howard Stern's morning show, said it would start a separate online stream devoted to playing new music from alternative acts like the Killers, Mars Volta, Arcade Fire and Taking Back Sunday. The move comes as Infinity faces the loss of Mr. Stern at the end of the year, when he is to begin a program on Sirius satellite radio. It also comes as other alternative rock stations have been suffering. In January Infinity flipped its Washington alternative station WHFS-FM (99.1) to Spanish, citing poor ratings. After an outcry from local listeners, Infinity began broadcasting alternative rock on weeknights on another Washington-area station and created an online version of the defunct station. JEFF LEEDS

title: Major Carriers Gain
description: MAJOR CARRIERS GAIN -- Network carriers are reclaiming a bigger share of business travelers from low-cost carriers, according to a survey by Accenture, the consulting company. Last month, 82 percent of business travelers said they were now "primarily" using major airlines, up from 72 percent a year ago, according to the survey, which reported a "significant shift" back to major network carriers over the past year for both business and personal travel. For business travelers, a shift back to network carriers reflects a loosening of corporate travel policies in an improved economy, Paul Chiu, the head of travel and tourist research for Accenture, said in an interview. Business travelers now have "more flexibility to pick airlines and flights more conducive to their schedules and destinations, rather than selecting them strictly on price," he said. A third of business travelers surveyed said they expected to travel more in the next six months than they did in the comparable period last year, while a little over half said their travel frequency would be about the same.

title: UNITED SELECTS TWO CARRIERS FOR COMMUTER ROUTES
description: United Airlines chose SkyWest and Trans States Holdings to fly 30 jets on United Express routes as part of an effort to cut commuter carrier costs. United, part of the UAL Corporation, is trimming expenses to help with its exit from bankruptcy. It said that new 70-seat Bombardier jets will begin flights in August and be fully in place by the first quarter of 2006. United, based in Chicago, had requested bids in November from 10 commuter carriers to operate as many as 70 jets on routes flown by its second-biggest regional partner, the Air Wisconsin Airlines Corporation. Some of those routes will now be flown by SkyWest of St. George, Utah, which will operate 20 of the jets, and by the closely held Trans States' GoJet of St. Louis, which will fly 10, United said.

title: Justices Decline to Rule on Limits for Drug-Sniffing Dogs
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 - The Supreme Court in recent years has drawn constitutional rules for the use of newly popular law enforcement techniques. The police need a warrant before aiming a heat-detecting device at a private home in an effort to find out whether marijuana is growing inside under high-intensity lights. The police do not need a warrant before permitting a trained dog to sniff a car, or a piece of luggage at an airport, in order to detect drugs.

title: Teasing Out Hair and Sisterly Ties
description: In "Steel Magnolias," Robert Harling's freeze-dried comedy from 1987 about friendship among Southern women, people speak in the kinds of sentences that wind up embroidered on decorative pillows. None of the six actresses in the flat new production that opened last night at the Lyceum Theater actually say, "Old age is not for sissies." But much of what is spoken is in the same sententiously homey vein: lines like "There is no such thing as natural beauty" or "I'd rather have 30 minutes of wonderful than a lifetime of nothing special."

title: Pow! Why Designers Are Mad About the Comics
description: In the opening scene of "Sin City," Robert Rodriguez's film adaptation of the gruesome graphic novels of Frank Miller, the actress Marley Shelton stands on a balcony in a sequined halter gown that has been digitally rendered in red, a vivid slash of color against a tableau that is otherwise black and white. The intention of such orchestrated pops of color, repeated in lone strokes of paint across irises, lips and satin bed sheets, was to replicate the frame-by-frame illustrations of Mr. Miller, a director of the film, whose heroines form an army of prostitutes dressed, for work or war, in leather chaps, thongs and fishnets. The effect is a film that uses visually stunning technique to highlight its style.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Contractor Seeks Dismissal Of Charges
description: Lawyers for a contractor, who reaped millions in state contracts while doing favors for then-Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut, asked a federal judge yesterday to dismiss 12 out of the 14 counts against their client, saying prosecutors had overreached. While Mr. Rowland began serving a year and a day in a Pennsylvania prison on Friday, his former associates still face prosecution, including the contractor, William A. Tomasso, as well as Peter N. Ellef, Mr. Rowland's former co-chief of staff, and his son, Peter Jr. All have maintained their innocence. In September, they and others were charged with having turned the governor's office into a "racketeering enterprise," and the multiple fraud, racketeering and money-laundering charges pose far graver consequences than Mr. Rowland's single conspiracy count. Alison Leigh Cowan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRIFFIN, JOHN JOSEPH
description: GRIFFIN--John Joseph. After a life well lived, John Griffin, North Peninsula Drive, New Smyrna Beach, FL, passed away on March 30, 2005 at the age of 92 at Hospice Care Center, Port Orange, FL. Born in Jamaica, Long Island, NY on March 2, 1913, he is survived by his beloved wife of 54 years, Isabel, his devoted sister Ellen Greenfieldt (John Greenfieldt) of Bronxville, NY; three nephews Kevin Griffin, Bethpage, NY, Brian Griffin, Deland and John Griffin, Johnsburg, IL and one niece, Maureen Howard, Lake Mary, FL. Mr. Griffin was a 1934 graduate of Holy Cross College in Worcester, MA. A Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy, he served aboard the Destroyer U.S.S. Emmons in World War II, taking part in the invasions of both Normandy and Okinawa, and was a recipient of the Silver Star and Purple Heart Medals. After a career as Vice President of Johnson and Higgins Insurance Company on Wall Street and lengthy affiliations with the New York Athletic Club and University Club of NYC, Mr. Griffin retired to New Smyrna Beach in 1976. Thereafter, Mr. Griffin enjoyed a more than thirty year membership in the Smyrna Yacht Club. He was best friend to a host of people who valued his integrity, wisdom and loyalty. Farewell to a noble and wonderful man. Memorial donations may be made in Mr. Griffin's memory to Southeast Volusia Humane Society, 1200 S. Glencoe Road, New Smyrna Beach, FL 32168 or Our Lady Star of the Sea Catholic Church, 4000 S. Atlantic Avenue, New Smyrna Beach, FL 32169. Mass of the Resurrection will be 9:30am Wednesday at Our Lady Star of the Sea Catholic Church, New Smyrna Beach, with the Reverend John S. Murray officiating. A reception will follow at Smyrna Yacht Club. Friends may call 6pm-8pm Tuesday at the Settle-Wilder New Smyrna Beach Chapel. Settle-Wilder Funeral Home, New Smyrna Beach, FL is in charge of services.

title: TV's Latest Obsession Seems to Be Television

So, locked in the writing room, sitting through endless pitch meetings, Hollywood found gold, or at least dramatic fodder, in its own bellybutton.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Holiday No More

The government said it was making the change to reduce the number of holidays and because most people now regard Arbor Day simply as a day off. Su Hyun Lee (NYT)

title: KRISPY KREME SECURES $225 MILLION IN LOANS
description: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts said yesterday that it had received $225 million in loans from a group led by Credit Suisse First Boston and the hedge fund Silver Point Capital, pulling the company from the brink of bankruptcy. The financing replaces a $150 million credit line frozen by lenders after Krispy Kreme, which is under investigation for accounting fraud, failed to report earnings results on time. The loans will be used to repay about $90 million in debt, pay fees to lenders and finance operations. Krispy Kreme, which is based in Winston-Salem, N.C., has been in danger of running out of cash after having its first quarterly loss and sales decline last year.

Technology Briefs | Hardware: Microsemi Closes Eight Plants
description: The Microsemi Corporation, whose chips regulate power and amplify signals in electronics, said yesterday that it had closed eight plants and cut more than 1,200 jobs as it seeks to become as profitable as its competitors. The company now plans to consolidate production at its plant in Broomfield, Colo., and at other factories and to close its manufacturing operations in Ennis, Ireland. Microsemi said that it was aiming to increase its operating margin to 27 percent by the end of 2006, up from a previous target of 25 percent. Operating margin is a company's income, minus general expenses, as a percentage of its sales. The company had a 12 percent operating margin in the first quarter of its 2005 fiscal year, according to Bloomberg data. Intel, the world's biggest chip maker, had a 30 percent operating margin in its most recent quarter, according to Bloomberg data. Shares of Microsemi, based in Irvine, Calif., rose 33 cents, or 2 percent, to $16.46.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Top Serbian Suspect To Face Tribunal
description: Sreten Lukic, a former Serbian paramilitary commander who served as deputy interior minister from 2001 to 2003, was flown from Belgrade to the United Nations tribunal, accused of committing crimes against humanity during the 1999 war in Kosovo. A Serbian government statement said he had surrendered, but his lawyer told the Beta news agency that Mr. Lukic had been "approached by two men and taken." Mr. Lukic is one of the most senior Serbian suspects to be sent to face charges this year. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: Technology Briefs | Services: Google To Enhance Map Service
description: Google said yesterday that it was enhancing its Google Maps service using the satellite mapping imagery it acquired last year when it bought the Keyhole Corporation, a small Silicon Valley start-up. By combining satellite and aerial images with mapping data, the service allows users to view both maps and travel directions superimposed on high-resolution digital photos by selecting a satellite mode. As with the original Keyhole product, it is possible to zoom in and out and scroll across the satellite image in any direction. The feature will also be part of the Google Local service, which helps users find local businesses. Keyhole, now a unit of Google, will continue to offer stand-alone software products that feature a 3-D global database of images and map data. Google is based in Mountain View, Calif. John Markoff (NYT)

title: PITNEY BOWES TO SPIN OFF CAPITAL SERVICES FINANCING
description: Pitney Bowes, the maker of postal equipment and other business equipment, said yesterday that it would spin off its capital services financing unit and sell a portion to Cerberus Capital Management for $115.7 million to focus on its main business. Pitney Bowes may have costs of $150 million to $250 million for discontinued operations; the transaction itself may cost as much as $35 million, the company said in a regulatory filing. Cerberus, which is based in New York, will pay $28.5 million for 19.9 percent of the spinoff's common stock with voting rights and $87.2 million for preferred shares, Pitney Bowes said. Shareholders of Pitney Bowes, which is based in Stamford, Conn., will get 80.1 percent of the new public company's common stock.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Moldova: Communist Re-Elected And Looks West
description: The incumbent president, Vladimir Voronin, easily won re-election by a vote in Parliament and pledged to pursue closer ties to the European Union for his small country, sandwiched between Ukraine and Romania. Mr. Voronin, the Communist Party leader, was once a Kremlin ally but has had bitter relations with the Russian government over its refusal to move troops out of the separatist region of Trans-Dniester. He has been in office since 2001, when the Communists swept in on a pro-Russian ticket after the collapse of the Soviet Union. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Ferry Inquiry Dispute Resolved
description: Ending a bitter legal dispute, lawyers for New York City agreed yesterday not to interview city employees about the crash of a Staten Island ferry before the trial of the city's former director of ferry operations. After the October 2003 crash, which killed 11 people, the ex-director, Patrick Ryan, was charged with making false statements and what is known as seaman's manslaughter. Federal prosecutors had accused the city of planning coercive interviews to gather information that would help Mr. Ryan. A conviction in the trial, scheduled to begin May 2, could make it harder for the city to defend more than $1 billion in civil suits stemming from the crash. Under yesterday's agreement, the prosecutors are to give city lawyers reports prepared by their investigators about potential witnesses who are city employees. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: The Price of Infallibility
description: WITH the news media awash in encomiums to the indisputable greatness of Pope John Paul II, isn't it time to ask to which tradition he belonged? Partisans unfamiliar with Christian history may judge this a strange question. Why, they may answer, he belonged to the Catholic tradition, of course. But there is no single Catholic tradition; there are rather Catholic traditions, which range from the voluntary poverty of St. Francis of Assisi to the boundless greed of the Avignon popes, from the genial tolerance for diversity of Pope Gregory the Great in the sixth century to the egomaniacal self-importance of Pope Pius IX in the 19th century, from the secrecy and plotting of Opus Dei to the openness and humane service of the Community of Sant'Egidio. Over its 2,000-year history, Roman Catholicism has provided a fertile field for an immense variety of papal traditions.

Also selling strongly was "Witness to Hope: The Biography of Pope John Paul II," by George Weigel (HarperCollins, 1999). Over the weekend, HarperCollins also announced that Mr. Weigel would write a new book, to be published this year, about the pope's death, his legacy and the selection of a new leader for the Roman Catholic Church. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHANNESEN, GRANT
description: JOHANNESEN--Grant. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sadness the passing of the distinguished American pianist Grant Johannesen on March 27, near Munich, Germany at the age of 83. A deeply valued member of our Steinway Artist family for 54 years, Mr. Johannesen won acclaim throughout the world for his performances of Poulenc, Faure, Milhaud, and SaintSaens. He was an elegant exponent of Bach, Beethoven and Chopin as well as American composers including Barber, Bowles, Copland, MacDowell, and Sessions. A native of Salt Lake City, Mr. Johannesen studied with Robert Casadesus, Egon Petri and Nadia Boulanger. He was a frequent soloist on television's "Bell Telephone Hour", and he appeared in every music capital of the world and with the most illustrious conductors of his time. Mr. Johannesen's discography is highlighted by the fact that he was the first pianist to record the complete works of Faure. He led the Cleveland Institute of Music with great distinction from 1974 to 1985, and he was named to the rank of Chevalier des Arts et Lettres by the French government for his vast contribution to French music. He was a cherished friend to us, and his dedication to our piano was a perpetual source of inspiration. We will miss him deeply and wish to convey our heartfelt condolences to his son David and his family. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Opposition Weighs Next Move
description: Hundreds of opposition supporters marched in Harare, the capital, to protest what they called the fraudulent victory of President Robert G. Mugabe's party in parliamentary elections on Thursday. There were conflicting reports over whether the police had broken up the protest or whether the marchers fled before they could be arrested. It was the largest of a handful of sporadic protests since Mr. Mugabe's party swept the elections. Morgan Tsvangirai, the opposition leader, said through a spokesman that he had ruled out a court challenge, which in the past proved fruitless. The question of whether to call for national demonstrations is a difficult one for the opposition. The last time Mr. Tsvangirai called for major protests, in 2002, they fizzled, and he was charged with treason. This time, Mr. Mugabe has promised to crush any demonstrations, and it is not clear that Zimbabweans, who depend on the government for food, would risk their stipends. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Officer Charged With Rape
description: A Manhattan police officer was arrested Sunday and charged with raping his 15-year-old daughter over three years, prosecutors said yesterday. The police said they were withholding the officer's identity to protect the accuser's privacy. The officer is 42 years old, lives in Queens and has been a member of the Police Department since 1995, currently assigned to the Manhattan Traffic Task Force, the police said. A second daughter, who is now an adult, has also accused him of attacking her, the police said. The officer was suspended from the force yesterday and arraigned before Judge William M. Harrington of Criminal Court on charges of rape, sexual abuse and endangering the welfare of a minor, and released in his own custody, said Patrick B. Clark, a spokesman for the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Attacking a Free Judiciary
description: The low point in the politicking over Terri Schiavo came last week when the House majority leader, Tom DeLay, threatened the judges who ruled in her case. Saying they had "thumbed their nose at Congress and the president," Mr. DeLay announced that "the time will come for the men responsible for this to answer for their behavior, but not today." Coming so close to the fatal shooting of one judge in his courtroom and the killing of two family members of another, those words were at best an appalling example of irresponsibility in pursuit of political gain. But they were not an angry, off-the-cuff reaction. Mr. DeLay's ominous statements were a calculated part of a growing assault on the judiciary.

Dramatic hillsides, which often go hand in hand with great wine, are nowhere to be seen, nor are the usual gravelly soils, riverbanks or valleys. Instead, this skeletal finger of land, which points northeast through the Atlantic Ocean in the general direction of Rhode Island, offers plain former potato fields. Ask Jeeves Espaa, currently being tested and expected to start this year, is aimed at users in Spain and is the first of several projects in Europe this year, said Jim Lanzone, Ask Jeeves's senior vice president for search properties, in an interview. The company, which is based in Oakland, Calif., has already expanded its business into Japan and Britain.

title: ZODIAC BUYING MAKER OF AIRCRAFT INTERIOR ITEMS
description: Zodiac, a French maker of airline seats and rigid inflatable boats, agreed to buy C&D Aerospace for $600 million to become the world's largest decorator of aircraft interiors. The closely held C&D Aerospace's products, like overhead luggage compartments and side panels, complement Zodiac's passenger seats and water systems, Zodiac said. Zodiac and C&D supply aircraft manufacturers like Airbus and Boeing. The C&D Aerospace purchase is Zodiac's third takeover in the United States in a year. Sales in North America accounted for about a third of Zodiac's 2004 revenue. C&D Aerospace, based in Huntington Beach, Calif. employs about 4,000 people and had $400 million in sales last year, Zodiac said. Zodiac has about $550 million a year in sales of aircraft cabin components.

title: World Briefing

description: Sheltered from the bustle of Midtown on the mezzanine of the City Club Hotel, 55 West 44th Street, is a quiet escape: a complete tea service. Tracy Stern, who runs what she calls Salon Tea as a concession, offers six themed tea blends. Among them, the Artist is a Ceylon tea, and the Society Hostess is a decaffeinated vanilla-scented China black. The Romantic, a green tea with jasmine, suited me fine. Ms. Stern serves them with a copious assortment of scones, tea sandwiches and pastries prepared by Daniel Boulud's DB Bistro Moderne in the hotel. Tea is offered from 3 to 5 p.m. on Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays. The price is $32, and the serving can be shared; an extra pot of tea is $8. Reservations: (212)398-1323. Ms. Stern's teas are also sold at the hotel and at www.salonteas.com.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: A Different Bird Flu
description: Chickens in North Korea are suffering from a rare outbreak of H7 avian influenza, and not the more lethal H5N1 strain that has infected poultry across Southeast Asia, a United Nations official said. The H7 virus showed a greater capacity for human-to-human transmission during an outbreak in 2003 in the Netherlands but tended to produce less serious illness, often limited to conjunctivitis. The presence of the disease in northeast Asia is surprising, the official said, adding that no human cases had been found in North Korea. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Fairview: Two Fires In Same Apartment
description: A two-alarm blaze broke out at alow-income apartment building for the elderly last night less than an hour after firefighters had already fought a fire in the same apartment there, the authorities said. Mike Mesisca, the deputy chief of the Fairview Fire Department, said that the first fire started about 8 p.m., when a resident, whose name was not released, fell asleep with a lighted cigarette in her seventh-floor apartment. She suffered severe burns to her face and chest and was taken to Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck. Chief Mesisca said that firefighters doused the blaze and used a heat-seeking device, called a thermal imaging camera, to search behind the walls for more fire before they left. About 45 minutes later, a fire began in another part of bedroom, he said, spreading to two alarms and causing the evacuation of two floors. Last month, four children died in Teaneck in a fire that was not detected by the fire crew, which did not use its thermal imaging camera. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

Results from prior periods will be restated to include the impact of the options, I.B.M. said. title: Some Thoughts on Seeing the Polymerized Remains of Human Cadavers
description: Most museums aren't open at 3 a.m. But at 3 a.m. on the final Saturday of a recent exhibition, crowds were still moving through the California Science Center in Los Angeles, where the show, "Body Worlds 2," had been on display since July 2. It had already been held over, and it was kept open for 62 hours, nonstop, before closing in the early hours of March 28. Security videotapes show that about 3 a.m. on that Saturday, when no one was nearby, two young women reached into a plexiglass case and stole a preserved 13-week-old fetus -- one of a sequence of fetuses in the reproduction section of the exhibition. No one knows whether it was a prank or a protest.

Net income was $1.30 a share to $1.40 a share, up from 92 cents a year earlier, Reliance said. Final results will be released April 21. Earnings topped the Feb. 17 forecast of $1.05 to $1.15 and the average estimate of $1.11 in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Harvard To Divest Stock
description: Harvard University is selling its stake in a Chinese oil and gas company with ties with the Sudanese government, which the United States has accused of participating in genocide in the Darfur region. The decision to sever ties with PetroChina, whose parent company, the China National Petroleum Corporation, drills in Sudan, came after students and faculty spent months pressing the university to divest. The university held about $4.4 million worth of PetroChina stock, according to The Harvard Crimson, a fraction of its $23 billion endowment. In a statement, Harvard's president, Lawrence H. Summers, said the university believed there was a "compelling case" for divestment in light of the "extraordinary combination of circumstances" in Darfur and the role the company plays in the country's oil industry. description: Russian officials warned that Shamil Basayev, the Chechen rebel who has claimed responsibility for the country's worst terrorist acts, was preparing large attacks to coincide with the 60th anniversary of the Soviet Union's victory over Nazi Germany, on May 9. Mr. Basayev's supporters have attacked before on Victory Day, killing 43 at a military parade in Dagestan in 2002 and assassinating Chechnya's president, Akhmad Kadyrov, last year. This year's ceremonies in Moscow will include dozens of heads of state, including President Bush. A spokesman for the Federal Security Service said the warnings were being taken seriously. The Atlantic Monthly Cuts Back on Fiction
description: The Atlantic Monthly magazine, which in its nearly 150-year history was among the first to publish short works of fiction by Ernest Hemingway, Mark Twain, Henry James and Sue Miller, is eliminating the regular publication of fiction from its pages, according to a letter from the magazine's editors in the May issue. The change, the editors say, is to allow for more space to be devoted to "long-form narrative reporting." The magazine, which now publishes 10 issues a year, down from 12 a few years ago, will add an annual fiction issue each August for sale on newsstands. Subscribers to the magazine will have access to its contents online but apparently will not receive a printed copy. "Everyone knows that the surface features of the news are being reported faster all the time, in smaller and smaller bits," the editors write in their usual monthly letter to readers, titled "77 North Washington Street," signifying the Boston address of the magazine's editorial offices. "But explaining the deeper features of the world requires a different and more expansive kind of reporting -- one that has increasingly become the Atlantic's signature. That reporting consumes a lot of space." The change is part of a multiyear trend of general-interest magazines publishing fewer works of fiction. C. Michael Curtis, fiction editor of The Atlantic Monthly, said in an interview that the staff was informed of the change in an e-mail message within the last two weeks. Mr. Curtis said that with the fiction issue the magazine hopes to publish about as much fiction as it had done throughout the year.

The winner, Rouge et Noir Brie from Marin French Cheese in Petaluma, beat out the French cheeses even though it is very small -- a mere eight ounces -- compared with classic wheels of Brie, which are a foot across and weigh about five pounds. Rouge et Noir also has more butterfat than the French cheese. But its mushroomy aroma is on the money, and when ripe, the cheese is nicely satiny and nutty tasting. It can be ordered from www.marinfrenchcheese.com at $37 for three wheels, including shipping. And for serving, this clever beechwood cheese board will gladly show off whatever cheese you have, though it begs for Emmenthal. It is $45 at the MoMA Design Store, www.momastore.com or (800)447-6662.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Judge Censured For Lapses
description: A Westchester Family Court judge has been censured for trying to get fellow judges to give favorable court treatment to her friends. Both incidents occurred in 2003, and in neither was the censured judge's effort successful. The State Commission on Judicial Conduct, which made public yesterday its censure of the judge, Nilda Morales Horowitz, concluded that she was evasive about her actions and did not appear to understand the gravity of her misconduct. The commission rejected a recommendation that she be removed from the bench. Deborah A. Scalise, the judge's lawyer, said her client was grateful that the commission recognized that her motive was "sympathy for her friends and a strong belief in them as parents." In one case, Judge Morales Horowitz tried to get a family court judge whom a friend did not like to recuse himself from her case. In another, she repeatedly told judges and court workers that she was friendly with a couple seeking custody of a child; the case was then transferred to another county. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Schumer Seeks New Inquiry Into Flight 587
description: Sen. Charles E. Schumer called on federal safety officials yesterday to reopen their investigation into the fatal crash of a passenger jet in Belle Harbor, Queens, because equipment failure, not pilot error, might have been the cause. In November 2001, the jet's tail fell off shortly after takeoff from Kennedy International Airport. Last month, a similar plane flying over the Atlantic Ocean lost its rudder, prompting federal regulators to require rudder inspections. But even though the planes had the same manufacturer, safety experts do not believe the circumstances in the two cases were sufficiently similar to make comparisons. The National Transportation Safety Board said that in the Belle Harbor crash, which killed 265 people, the pilot swung the rudder from side to side, straining the tail, which eventually broke off. On March 6 of this year, an Airbus A310, similar to the A300 in the Belle Harbor crash, lost a rudder but landed safely. Both the rudder in the March crash and the tail in the harbor crash were made of composite materials. But the rudder apparently went through routine operations and stress, while the Belle Harbor tail, the safety board said, went through abnormal stress in an unusual operation. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHANNESEN, GRANT
description: JOHANNESEN--Grant. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sadness the passing of the distinguished American pianist Grant Johannesen on March 27, near Munich, Germany at the age of 83. A deeply valued member of our Steinway Artist family for 54 years, Mr. Johannesen won acclaim throughout the world for his performances of Poulenc, Faure, Milhaud, and SaintSaens. He was an elegant exponent of Bach, Beethoven and Chopin as well as American composers including Barber, Bowles, Copland, MacDowell, and Sessions. A native of Salt Lake City, Mr. Johannesen studied with Robert Casadesus, Egon Petri and Nadia Boulanger. He was a frequent soloist on television's "Bell Telephone Hour", and he appeared in every music capital of the world and with the most illustrious conductors of his time. Mr. Johannesen's discography is highlighted by the fact that he was the first pianist to record the complete works of Faure. He led the Cleveland Institute of Music with great distinction from 1974 to 1985, and he was named to the rank of Chevalier des Arts et Lettres by the French government for his vast contribution to French music. He was a cherished friend to us, and his dedication to our piano was a perpetual source of inspiration. We will miss him deeply and wish to convey our heartfelt condolences to his son David and his family. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AINSLIE, PETER G.
description: AINSLIE--Peter G. 58, died on April 2, 2005. Peter's friends and colleagues throughout Time Warner join in mourning his passing. Peter was a first-rate journalist at Women's Wear Daily and Time, where he covered national and international news. He served as director of media relations for the Warner Music Group from 1992 to 2000, a position that allowed him to exercise his considerable writing skills in promoting an industry for which he had a profound passion. In 2001, Peter was tapped by Time Warner corporate to create an internal companywide magazine. He handled this assignment, at a challenging time in the company's history, with extraordinary skill and flair. Under his editorship, Keywords quickly became an award-winning example of corporate communications at its best. Everything Peter did was characterized by his acute integrity, unceasing decency and gentle sense of humor. He was an editor who knew how to correct and direct without ever being condescending or hurtful. His razor-sharp mind was joined with a compassionate soul. Peter was a lover of the arts and a patron of dance. Above all, he cherished his family, his beloved Lori, his children, Erin and Patrick, his parents, brothers, and sister, and his wide circle of friends. We will miss him deeply, and while we grieve his loss, we are grateful for his life and his lasting impact on all of us. May you rest in peace, Peter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, NATHAN
description: KATZ--Nathan. Real estate entrepreneur, dead at eightyfive. By Joshua Resnek. Founder of the real estate company bearing his family name and headquartered in Elmhurst, Queens, died Saturday morning, April 2, 2005, at his home in Roslyn following a short illness. Mr. Katz, who was a Holocaust survivor, came to New York City in 1951, broke and not knowing a word of English. A decade later, he had begun a long steady climb in the residential real estate business. With enterprise, hard work and skillful management, Mr. Katz, over the decades, built one of the leading residential real estate and management companies that remain independently owned in the area. He worked every day alongside his daughter, Rita Levy, and sons-in-law, Marvin Katz and David Levy. Mr. Levy, the company's Chief Executive Officer, said that Mr. Katz was a true entrepreneur. "He was our mentor and our leader and one of the most unique individuals I have ever met," Levy said. "This was a man with a vision who started with nothing and who, through hard work and enterprise, built a family owned company that today is something to behold." Mr. Katz was born in Lithuania in 1919. He was educated there with a traditional Jewish education and later trained as a butcher. When Lithuania was invaded by the Nazis, Mr. Katz and his family fled their home town but could not get out of the country in time. They were captured and sent to Latvia, to a slave labor camp. They escaped their bondage in Latvia and returned to Shavel, Lithuania, only to find that the entire population was about to be sent to Auschwitz. Mr. Katz and his new bride, Sima, who wed in The Shavel Ghetto, fled into the neighboring forest where they lived hidden by Righteous Gentiles until the Russians liberated Lithuania. They then fled the Russians and with falsified papers, passed through Poland, into Germany and finally to the United States in March 1951. He published a book about his life experiences entitled: "Teach Us To Count Our Days." Mr Katz leaves his wife of sixtyone years, Sima Katz, and two daughters, Miriam Katz, Bethpage, and Rita Levy, of Roslyn. He also leaves grandchildren Lisa, Michelle, Rebecca, and Matthew, and great grandddaughter, Fay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEPARD, EDWARD MORSE, M.D.
description: SHEPARD--Edward Morse, M.D. of Oyster Bay, NY, beloved husband for 25 years of Joan Pulling Shepard, died Sunday, April 3rd at the age of 90. He is survived by his loving children, Reese Alsop Shepard, Paul Cooper Shepard, Wendy Shepard Chisholm, Edward Morse Shepard III and Elizabeth Shepard Corley, as well as stepsons William A. Flanigan, Edward P. Flanigan, Russell L. Flanigan, nine grandchildren, four stepgrandchildren and one greatgrandson. He was predeceased by his sister Lee Shepard Judge and daughter Jean Adams Shepard. Born in Brooklyn in 1915, Dr. Shepard was raised in Lake George, NY. After living in Paris for three years as a child, he graduated from Deerfield Academy in 1932, Williams College Phi Beta Kappa in 1936, and Cornell Medical School in 1940. During World War II, he was a Naval Flight Surgeon serving on a destroyer in the North Atlantic. After serving on the faculty of Cornell Medical School and practicing internal medicine in New York City for over 20 years, Dr. Shepard moved to Woodstock, VT in 1969. Until his retirement in 1985, he practiced internal medicine in Woodstock and served on the faculty of Dartmouth Medical School. He was also a Fellow of the American College of Physicians and the New York Academy of Medicine. Dr. Shepard was an athlete and a great lover of the outdoors. He was a member of Piping Rock. An avid skier who began skiing before one could ride up the mountain on a lift, he skied every winter for 85 years with only one exception--the year he was on a ship in the North Atlantic. Tennis, hiking and golf were other favorite sports. His deep curiosity in the world showed in his passion for travelling and reading. He had a broad range of interests and continously contributed significant time and resources to civic and non-profit organizations dedicated to supporting social causes and the environment. He was on the Board of Directors for Planned Parenthood of Northern New England for many years. He was an inspiration to all who knew him. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor, NY on Saturday April 9th, at 11.30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Hudson-Peconic Planned Parenthood, 70 Maple Avenue, Smithtown, New York 11787.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOSEPHS, RAY
description: JOSEPHS--Ray, 93, died April 5, 2005. Founder of one of America's earliest and most successful public relations firms, International Public Relations Co. (N.Y.), a pioneer in international public relations. His clients included Mitsui Bank, Bank of Hong Kong, The Anglo-French Supersonic Aircraft Concorde, Toshiba, GM, and others. Mr. Josephs began as a journalist for the Philadelphia Inquirer and International Herald Tribune. He also wrote exposes about Juan Peron while a reporter in Buenos Aires,and published the best selling "Argentine Diary" for which he gained international notoriety. He was a protege of Benjamin Sonnenberg until founding his own firm. Josephs also found time to write 12 books, including "How To Gain An Extra Hour Every Day" that sold over 2 million copies, 700 articles published in The New York Times, Reader's Digest, Saturday Evening Post and others. Josephs devoted substantial time and energy helping numerous institutions, including the UJA, SelfHelp Community Services, Yeshiva University, American Jewish Commitee, Stern College, American Public Relations Society, University of Wyoming, and others. Mr. Josephs is survived by his loving wife of 64 years, Juanita, and by his nephew and wife, Robert Josephs and Gerri Carr Josephs. JOSEPHS--Ray. Selfhelp Community Services, Inc. notes with sadness the passing of Ray Josephs. Mr. Josephs was a dedicated advocate of independence living services for senior citizens and an inspiration to Selfhelp's home care and senior service staff. description: Callaway Golf, a maker of golf clubs, reported preliminary first-quarter earnings that were below analysts' expectations because of an 18 percent drop in sales. The company said it earned 26 cents to 28 cents a share, based on sales of $300 million, in the period. The figures compare with profit of 59 cents and sales of $364 million a year earlier. Callaway attributed the drop in sales to a plan to stagger new product releases and changes in inventory management. Excluding a 3-cent charge from consolidating its Top-Flite and Callaway Golf operations, the company said it would earn 29 cents to 31 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected the company to earn 49 cents a share.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Forrester In Debate Snarl
description: The New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission may bar a gubernatorial candidate from televised debates in May because he has not raised enough money from the public. The candidate, Douglas R. Forrester, who owns a large pharmaceutical business, has provided most of the $1.8 million in his campaign treasury as of Dec. 31. Commission regulations require that candidates must have raised at least $300,000 in increments of $3,000 or less to be included in the debate. Mr. Forrester is one of seven candidates vying for the Republican nomination, which will be decided in a primary on June 7. He has been considered a leading contender because he was the party's nominee for United States Senate in 2002. Mr. Forrester's lawyers have asked the four commissioners, who recently deadlocked on whether to allow him into the debate, to reconsider. The lawyers have threatened to sue if Mr. Forrester is barred. David Kocieniewski (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PACHNER, CHARLES
description: PACHNER--Charles. Frenkel & Co., Inc. notes with great sadness the passing of Charles W. Pachner, its former chairman and president. Charles joined Frenkel in 1951 after having practiced law at the firm of Demov and Morris. He pioneered many risk management concepts which are still being used, and was one of the first professionals to attain both the Chartered Property Casualty Underwriter and Chartered Life Underwriter designations. Charles taught an insurance course to all newly appointed insurance commissioners and their deputies through the College of Insurance, where he established an innovative student internship program. Charles retired in 1995 but continued as chairman emeritus at Frenkel through 2004. His high professional standards established the foundation that has carried Frenkel & Co., Inc. to its current growth and success. Frenkel now has offices in New York City with branches in California and New Jersey. We will miss him, and wish to convey our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Janice, and their children. John F. Kelly, Pres. and CEO Robert E. Shunk, Chairman Frenkel & Co., Inc.

Paula was a woman of great strength, who never made the material things in life important, and felt the strongest of callings for the living. With a deep religious conviction and background, she utilized her inner strength to raise her family with the greatest of moral values, to preserve human dignity through her philanthropic endeavors, to honor her friends and acquaintances, and to inspire learning. She will be sorely missed by her son, Andrew and his wife Angela, daughter Barbara, sister Elaine Muller, brother Morty Levine and his wife Bernice, and the Kalmanash and Levine families. She is reunited with her husband Samuel and sons Marc and Robert. Funeral Service today Thursday 1:00 pm Westchester Jewish Center, Mamaroneck, NY. Followed by Interment at Sharon Gardens Cemetery. description: The Bank of Japan decided to continue its ultraeasy monetary policy, a decision that was widely expected after an important survey showed that optimism about the economy was fading among corporate executives. Survived by her brother Arnold, sister-in-law Atsuko, nieces Rebecca and Lucille, cousins Lorraine, Pam, Alison and Benita and many loving friends and family around the planet. No-one was ever more appropriately named for Joy, truly possessed a joie de vivre. She will be remembered for her irrepressible humor, footloose spirit and talent for making fast friends, whether on a bus tour to Quebec or a dance floor in Vegas. Funeral service will be held April 8, 11AM, at Mount Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LYMPANY, MOURA
description: LYMPANY -- Moura. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with deep sadness the passing of its beloved friend, the celebrated English pianist Dame Moura Lympany, on March 28 in Menton, France at the age of 88. Dame Moura was a valued member of our Steinway Artist family for 56 years. A native of Cornwall, Dame Moura was first taught by her mother and continued her piano studies with Mathilde Verne and Tobias Matthay. During the war she participated in London's famous National Gallery midday concerts, and a brilliant international career followed. Dame Moura was a featured artist in Steinway's Centennial concert at Carnegie Hall in 1953. Through her elegant performances and her sought-after recordings, she influenced more young pianists and piano aficionados than even she may have realized. She was, as well, a treasure to us, and her loss is deeply felt. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: Manila's battle with the church: population control
Arts, Briefly; Honors for Ailing Ligeti
description: The composer Gyorgy Ligeti, below, received the Frankfurt Music Prize at a ceremony in Frankfurt's city hall on Tuesday, a day before the opening of the city's international Musikmesse, an annual trade fair for the musical-instrument industry. Mr. Ligeti, who was born in Romania in 1923 and now lives in Vienna, could not attend the ceremony because of illness. The Musikmesse and the Federation of German Musical Instrument Producers, who alternate between classical and pop in presenting the annual prize (worth about $19,350), honored Mr. Ligeti as "one of the most eminent composers of our time who had a major formative influence on contemporary music over more than four decades." KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

title: Hong Kong tower face-lift
Hong Kong Ready to Involve Beijing in Coming Vote for Executive
description: HONG KONG, April 6 - Hong Kong asked the Chinese government on Wednesday to issue a legally binding decision on how long the next chief executive will serve here. Such a decision would be the third intervention by Beijing in the legal system here.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: Warring Factions Sign Peace Accord
description: Rebel forces who hold the northern half of this cocoa-rich country signed a peace deal with the government, which holds the south, to end hostilities in a civil war that has flared intermittently since 2002. The agreement, brokered in Pretoria by President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, is similar to past deals, including a French-sponsored accord that led to a cease-fire in January 2003. That cease-fire was shattered in November when government forces attacked the rebels in their northern stronghold, setting off a crisis that led thousands of French citizens and African emigrants to flee. The new accord seeks to bring to an end an often brutal conflict that took on xenophobic overtones and pitted the wealthy Christian south against the north, which is made up mostly of Muslim immigrants from other African countries. Under the agreement, militias on both sides are to disarm and elections are to be held in October, said Bheki Khumalo, a spokesman for Mr. Mbeki. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: An Executive Is Leaving at Scholastic
description: The Scholastic Corporation announced yesterday that Barbara A. Marcus, who built its children's book business into an industry powerhouse, was leaving and would be succeeded by Lisa Holton, the publisher of the children's books division at the Walt Disney Company.

title: Arts, Briefly; 50 Cent on Charts Again
description: It's starting to look like Groundhog Day atop the Billboard album chart: 50 Cent's "Massacre" (Interscope) is No.1 yet again. The album has held the position for five weeks, though its sales have steadily declined; it sold 211,000 copies last week, bringing its total to 2.81 million, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The No.2 album was Beck's "Guero" (Geffen), which sold 162,000 copies in its first week of release, Beck's best sales week ever. Among other new releases, Beanie Sigel's "B. Coming" (Def Jam) opened at No.3, 112's "Pleasure & Pain" (Def Soul Classics) reached No.4 and Will Smith's "Lost and Found" (Interscope) was No.6. The 18th volume in the pop compilation series "Now That's What I Call Music!" was No.5. The chart this week also has an unusual debut: Larry the Cable Guy's "Right to Bare Arms" (Warner Brothers) opened at No.7, with 92,000 sales, the first comedy album to open in the Billboard Top10, the magazine said. BEN SISARIO

World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Bid For Food Company Raised
description: The Philippine beer and food conglomerate San Miguel raised its bid for Australia's largest dairy company, National Foods, to 1.9 billion Australian dollars ($1.46 billion), beating an offer by the Fonterra Cooperative Group of New Zealand. San Miguel's latest offer values National Foods at 6.40 Australian dollars a share ($4.92), compared with a bid of 6.20 Australian dollars from Fonterra, a farmer-owned cooperative that is the world's largest dairy exporter. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

Francona Spends Game 3 Listening in a Hospital
description: Boston Red Sox Manager Terry Francona felt uncomfortable during the bus ride yesterday morning from a Midtown Manhattan hotel to Yankee Stadium, so Brad Mills, the team's bench coach, teasingly told Francona to take a nap. Mills was waiting for Francona to laugh. But a fatigued Francona conceded that he felt as poorly as he looked.

title: Two Girls Held as U.S. Fears Suicide Bomb
description: Two 16-year-old girls from New York City were arrested last month and charged with immigration violations after the F.B.I. asserted that they intended to become suicide bombers, according to a government document. A spokesman for one of their families, however, said the accusation was false and said the government had probably misinterpreted a school essay written by one of the girls.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 3 Charged In Counterfeit Case
description: A man and his two sons were arrested yesterday and charged with operating a counterfeit money ring that passed an estimated $9.5 million in phony bills over the last six years, the police and federal authorities said. The man, Yakub Yusupov, 44, and his sons, who were identified as Eduard, 23, and Pinchas, 18, live in Fresh Meadows. They were accused of selling $100 bills, which were said to be almost flawless, from a Parsons Boulevard video store. Some $2.5 million remains in circulation. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREEMAN, SUSAN LEE
description: FREEMAN--Susan Lee of Florida and formerly of Rye Brook, NY. Died April 5, 2005 at age 59. Born August 22, 1945 in the Bronx to Benjamin and Frances (Preizer) Phau. Survived by her daughter Alex Freeman Osz (husband Charly), her mother Frances Phau and brother Donald Phau. Predeceased by her husband Arnold Freeman.
