title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Ex-Mayor's Jail Sentence Overturned
description: A federal appeals court has vacated the prison sentence of former Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr. of Providence, who was convicted of racketeering in 2002 and sentenced to 64 months in prison. A three-justice panel from the United States Court of Appeal for the First Circuit, in Boston, based its decision on a January Supreme Court ruling that made federal sentencing guidelines advisory, not mandatory, for judges. Mr. Cianci's case will return for resentencing to federal court in Providence, where he was convicted of running a bribery ring. Mr. Cianci, who has served 28 months of his sentence, will remain in prison in Fort Dix, N.J. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: The Emperor's Life: These Boots Are Made for Talkin'
description: To paraphrase Mel Brooks: it's good to be the emperor. You get to be worshiped, wield power over life and death, have your whims instantly satisfied and, at the Classical Theater of Harlem, pontificate and prance about in a studded leather jock strap and see-through leopard-print robe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELLOW, SAUL
description: BELLOW--Saul. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of Nobel Laureate Saul Bellow. He was the first writer to receive ADL's America's Democratic Legacy Award, in November 1976. We extend our condolences to the entire family. Barbara B. Balser National Chair Abraham H. Foxman National Director BELLOW--Saul. The Faculty, Trustees, and alumni of Bard College mourn the passing of Saul Bellow, former faculty member and great man of letters. He will be deeply missed. Charles P. Stevenson, Jr. Chair Leon Botstein, President BELLOW--Saul. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague, whose passing will be mourned by the world of literature. BELLOW--Saul. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Saul Bellow, and send condolences to his family.

title: Senate Passes Civil Unions for Gays in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, April 6 - The State Senate on Wednesday passed a measure to allow civil unions between same-sex couples, setting the stage for Connecticut's Democratic-controlled Legislature to become the first in the country to approve civil unions without pressure from the courts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WELLIVER, NEIL
description: WELLIVER--Neil. It is with deep sadness that we mark the death on Tuesday of our dear friend Neil Welliver. The magnificent light filled paintings of his beloved Lincolnville woods will live on along with his great and generous spirit. Our condolences to his wife Mimi and surviving children Titus, Ethan and John. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in Neil's memory to Waldo County General Hospital, PO Box 287, Belfast, ME 04915. A memorial service is planned for 11 AM on July 22 at St. Margaret's Episcopal Church in Belfast. Phil Alexandre Alexandre Gallery, New York alexandregallery.com

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Auto Sales Rise
description: Automobile sales in Brazil rose 30 percent in March from the previous month, to about 150,000 vehicles, bouncing back from a slow start to the year, the national automakers' association said. Auto production also rose last month, jumping 17.5 percent from February, to 220,000 vehicles. Production is up 12.5 percent so far this year, driven in part by surging exports. The auto sector data, which is a leading indicator of industrial activity in Brazil, was released just hours after the government said industrial output fell in February for the second consecutive month, dropping 1.2 percent from January. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Election Results Challenged
description: A date was set to start a trial that could potentially unseat Gov. Christine Gregoire, a Democrat. On May 23, Judge John Bridges of Chelan County Superior Court is to hear arguments in a lawsuit brought by Dino Rossi, the Republican who lost an election so close that it required three recounts and was not settled until late December. Mr. Rossi says illegal votes by felons and mistakes by elections officials should invalidate the results of the election, which Governor Gregoire ultimately won by 129 votes. If the results are thrown out, Republicans hope for a special election in November. Eli Sanders (NYT)

title: In Russian Church, Still an Undercurrent of Animosity to the Vatican and the Pope
description: MOSCOW, April 6 - Last August, a delegation from the Vatican came here bearing an old Russian Orthodox icon that Pope John Paul II had kept in his private chambers for more than a decade. Already in the twilight of his papacy, the pope hoped the return of the icon, known as the Mother of God of Kazan, would at last clear the way for one of his lasting but unfulfilled desires: a papal visit to Russia.

title: Let Mexico's Voters Decide
description: The campaign for president of Mexico has taken on the air of the bad old days, when the dictatorial PRI, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, loaded elections for its candidates. The top contender, Mayor Andrs Manuel Lpez Obrador of Mexico City, is expected to be barred from the 2006 race by a transparently political indictment on charges of ordering the construction of a service road to a hospital after a judge said no. We don't endorse his actions, but Mexico's voters should be allowed to make their choice, not have it made for them.

title: A Young Voice Has Its Say
description: Gwyneth Herbert is 23, an English jazz singer with slightly gawky enthusiasm, special control over her low notes and, beyond that, youth. It's much too soon to see where she's going. In the wake of Jamie Cullum's success, she was signed by Universal last year to what was widely reported as a five-album, million-pound deal. Rapidly, she put out an album -- actually her second -- called "Bittersweet and Blue." It featured originals and the expectedly tasteful range of covers, from standards equally claimed by jazz and pop ("The Very Thought of You," "Ev'ry Time We Say Goodbye") to songs by Portishead, Neil Young, Tom Waits and Crowded House. (The album will be released in America this year.)

title: Shameless Photo-Op
description: Imagine this: On his next trip to Japan, President Bush visits the vault at the Bank of Japan, where that country's $712 billion in United States government bonds is stored. There, as the cameras roll, he announces that the bonds, backed by the full faith and credit of the United States, are, in fact, worthless i.o.u.'s. He does the same thing when he visits China and so on around the world, until he has personally repudiated the entire $2 trillion of United States debt held by foreigners.

National Briefing | Science And Health: Let The Rovers Rove
description: As long as the Mars rovers, Spirit and Opportunity, keep rolling, NASA will keep using them. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said it was extending their mission as much as 18 months. That follows two previous six-month extensions to the original mission, which was intended to last just three months. Except for problems with a couple of instruments, both rovers remain in good operating condition, NASA said. The Opportunity, left, has almost reached a mottled terrain, where scientists hope to find rock layers exposed by wind erosion, while the Spirit continues a climb through ancient hills on the other side of Mars. Kenneth Chang (NYT)

description: The Finisar Corporation, a maker of fiber optic communications equipment, said yesterday that it filed a lawsuit against the DirecTV Group, the satellite-television provider, accusing it of infringing on patented technology to transmit TV program guides. Finisar, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said its patent was granted in 1995. The company said its efforts last year and early this year to work out a licensing agreement with DirecTV were not successful, and that it had filed the suit on Monday in United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas. A DirecTV spokesman, Bob Marsocci, said the company had not fully reviewed the complaint, but did not think Finisar had a valid claim. DirecTV is based in El Segundo, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHANNESEN, GRANT
description: JOHANNESEN--Grant. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sadness the passing of the distinguished American pianist Grant Johannesen on March 27, near Munich, Germany at the age of 83. A deeply valued member of our Steinway Artist family for 54 years, Mr. Johannesen won acclaim throughout the world for his performances of Poulenc, Faure, Milhaud, and SaintSaens. He was an elegant exponent of Bach, Beethoven and Chopin as well as American composers including Barber, Bowles, Copland, MacDowell, and Sessions. A native of Salt Lake City, Mr. Johannesen studied with Robert Casadesus, Egon Petri and Nadia Boulanger. He was a frequent soloist on television's "Bell Telephone Hour", and he appeared in every music capital of the world and with the most illustrious conductors of his time. Mr. Johannesen's discography is highlighted by the fact that he was the first pianist to record the complete works of Faure. He led the Cleveland Institute of Music with great distinction from 1974 to 1985, and he was named to the rank of Chevalier des Arts et Lettres by the French government for his vast contribution to French music. He was a cherished friend to us, and his dedication to our piano was a perpetual source of inspiration. We will miss him deeply and wish to convey our heartfelt condolences to his son David and his family. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HSH PRINCE RAINIER III OF MONACO
description: HSH PRINCE RAINIER III of Monaco. The Trustees and staff of the Princess Grace Foundation--USA are profoundly saddened by the death of HSH Prince Rainier III of Monaco. Through His thoughtful and effective leadership, the Foundation was established in 1982 to carry out the ideals and goals of His beloved wife, Princess Grace of Monaco: to support young, emerging theater, dance, and film artists in America. HSH Prince Rainier's commitment and continued dedication to seeing The Foundation thrive has enabled the support of over 400 artists nationwide. We deeply mourn the loss of our founder for His vision and humanitarian efforts. Heartfelt condolences are extended to the Princely Family and the people of Monaco. RAINIER--Prince of Monaco. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HORVITZ, PHILIP
description: HORVITZ--Philip, 44, of Manhattan, of heart failure, March 30. Adored son, brother, uncle and friend. He was the writer, director and choreographer of several theatre works nationwide and the author of other scripts and essays. He trained as an actor and dancer at Circle in the Square and the Alvin Ailey School of American Dance in New York, was a graduate of UC Berkeley and the Laban Institute of Movement Studies. From 1986-1996 Phil worked as a performer, writer, director, producer and curator in San Francisco. He co-created, wrote and performed with the performance trio Absolut Manpussy and artistic directed The Karidian Players for whom he wrote directed and choreographed "Being Alive: A New Musical." Plays he wrote and performed included his critically acclaimed 1993 one-man show, "Yes I Can," and "Faith." Phil moved back to New York in 1996. "Starting Over", a collaboration with visual artist Nayland Blake exhibited at Matthew Marks Gallery in 2000. From 2001-2003 Philip was Program Coordinator and later consultant for the MAP Fund, a performing arts granting program funded by the Rockefeller Foundation. He was a member of Actors Equity and Screen Actors Guild, and a devoted student of yoga and other spiritual practices. He leaves behind his father Wayne L. Horvitz of Washington, D.C., his brothers Bill Horvitz, Lee Horvitz and Wayne B. Horvitz, his nephews Asa and Lowell and his niece Nica. He is also deeply missed by his loving family of friends. Donations may be made to the Laban Institute, 520 8th Avenue, Suite 304, 3rd Floor, New York, NY 10018.

Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Still Powers Fox
description: Nielsen's ratings estimates for Tuesday night showed that Fox's "American Idol" brought in 23.65 million viewers. While that number is nothing to sneeze at, it was low for this talent-show juggernaut, which began its season in January regularly toppling CBS's "CSI" in the weekly standings but in recent weeks has placed second to it. Even a slightly weaker "Idol," though, was strong enough to lead Fox to an overall victory for the night, particularly when the show that followed it, a repeat of "House," managed to beat the competition during the 9 p.m. hour, including a new episode of CBS's "Amazing Race." NBC's "Office," at 9:30 p.m., continued to do poorly, attracting only 5.81 million. And on WB, the finale of "The Starlet," the acting reality show led by Faye Dunaway, drew 2.92 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

description: The 2005-6 season is shaping up early for ABC. The network announced yesterday that it would renew the first-year hits "Desperate Housewives" and "Lost," which have proved enormously popular and helped to lift its ratings, as well as "Alias" and "Boston Legal." "Desperate Housewives," a dark suburban comedy that earned Teri Hatcher, right, a Golden Globe for her starring role, is ABC's top-rated series of the season with an estimated Sunday-night audience of 22.8 million viewers. It is followed on Sunday nights by "Boston Legal," which is ranked No.1 in the 10 p.m. hour. The series "Lost," featuring an ensemble cast as plane-crash survivors on a tropical island, leads its Wednesday-night slot with 15.9 million total viewers. title: Rococo Prose in Defense of Dcor Is No Vice
description: AS a word, "amateur" popularly conjures images of half-baked ideas inexpertly but enthusiastically executed. But back in the 18th century the word described someone whose enthusiasms were as respected as those of a professional. One enlightened amateur of recent vintage was John Cornforth, whose lack of academic credentials did not impede him from becoming the 20th century's leading expert on 18th-century English architecture and decoration.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Green Creek: Small Plane Crashes, Killing 2
description: Two people died in the crash of a single-engine plane whose wreckage was discovered in a Cape May county campground yesterday morning, federal and local officials said. The victims, Barbara W. Freedman, 57, of Elkins Park, Pa., and Stephen D. Baughn, 58, of Marlton, N.J., were both licensed private pilots, according to Federal Aviation Administration records. It was unclear yesterday which one of them was flying the plane, a Piper Arrow, when it crashed. The plane was practicing landings Tuesday night at Cape May County Airport about two miles from the campground when nearby residents reported hearing "popping sounds" from an airplane, the police said. Jason George (NYT)

The lottery's profits would go to school construction, college scholarships and other education financing, said the bill's sponsor, Representative Bill Owens. title: World Briefing | Middle East: Jordan: High Expectations For New Prime Minister
description: The newly appointed prime minister, Adnan Badran, continued efforts to form a government that would accelerate economic and social reforms. King Abdullah II dissolved the embattled government of Prime Minister Faisal al-Fayez this week and appointed Dr. Badran, a respected American-educated academic who has served as president of Philadelphia University in Amman. He is seen as an experienced technocrat who can push through efforts to decentralize the government and put into place a plan for sweeping political, social and economic reforms. Analysts said the government shakeup was one of the most significant in a decade. Hassan M. Fattah (NYT)

title: Mr. Bellow's Planet
description: Saul Bellow was the first writer to appear to me in flesh and blood. I got my initial look at him in the fall of 1975, when I was a nervous graduate student at the University of Chicago. I was awed by the lofty environment, away from my hometown for the first time and longing to become a writer. He was the literary eminence of Hyde Park. He taught in the university's loftiest department -- the Committee On Social Thought -- and prowled the streets with a fedora pulled low over searching eyes. That day he had drawn a huge crowd to the bookstore where he was signing his novel "Humboldt's Gift," which would earn the Nobel Prize.

title: Princeton, N.J.
description: I think of Princeton as being lazy and good-looking and aristocratic - you know, like a spring day," F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote in "This Side of Paradise." Eighty-five years later, the appraisal still fits. From the restored, century-old wrought-iron FitzRandolph gates of Princeton University to the sleek rowing shells on sparkling Lake Carnegie, the town retains an air of easygoing noblesse. It is studded with landmarks from a Revolutionary War battlefield to Albert Einstein's workplace, but nevertheless lives firmly in the present - traditional but not stuffy, charming but not quaint. A backpack-toting student walking a sheepdog with dreadlocks (that's right, the dreadlocks were on the dog) shares the sidewalk with chattering 10-year-olds and tweedy luminaries in town for one conference or another. In the tree-shaded downtown, Colonial-era buildings and high-end spots coexist with a used-record store, jeans-and-corduroy vegetarian hangouts and ice cream shops. And the campus is its own luxurious green city, in the words of Raymond Rhinehart, author of a guide to campus architecture, "a marketplace of ideas, set in a garden."

description: STIEBER BERNSTEIN--Evelyn. The American Friends of The Hebrew University (AFHU) and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem express profound sadness over the passing of our treasured friend, Evelyn Stieber Bernstein. A Benefactor of The Hebrew University and recipient of an honorary fellowship, Evelyn displayed a lifelong commitment to Israel, the Jewish people and to the cause of higher education. Over three decades, her devotion to Hebrew University faculty and students took many forms. Evelyn served on the Board of Governors and as an honorary vice president of AFHU, and established the Otto Stieber Chair in Cancer Research in memory of her beloved first husband. Evelyn and Sol Bernstein perpetuated these efforts and worked tirelessly in support of AFHU's mission as co-chairs of Florida's Hollywood/Hallandale Chapter. Prized for her personal warmth as well as for her humanitarianism, Evelyn created a lasting legacy. We extend our deepest condolences to Evelyn's daughters Janice, Elaine and Fran, her grandchildren, and greatgrandchildren. AFHU Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Abbott, based in Abbott Park, Ill., is seeking entry into the $5 billion-a-year market for stents, tiny mesh tubes designed to prop open cleared arteries. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Drug Chain To Sell Unit
description: The Boots Group, the British drugstore chain, put its nonprescription medicines unit up for sale to focus on reviving its British drugstore chain and said profit may drop for a second year. More than half the money raised by the sale will be returned to investors, the chief executive, Richard Baker, said in a conference call. With competition from discount retailers growing, sales at Boots stores open a year or more fell in the last quarter, Mr. Baker said. Boots Healthcare International makes products including Nurofen pain killers, Strepsils throat lozenges and Clearasil skin lotion. The sale of the business will enable Boots to concentrate on its 1,400 British stores, Mr. Baker said.

title: Arts, Briefly; Strike Disrupts an Opera
description: The Thtre du Chtelet in Paris has been forced to postpone the opening-night performance of the opera "The Bassarids," composed by Hans Werner Henze, below, to April 15 from April 13 after a four-day strike of technical and administrative employees of the state-owned Radio France. The continuing strike severely disrupted rehearsals of the Orchestre Philharmonique de Radio France. The orchestra itself is not on strike, but the staff that transports its instruments is. The situation prompted the Thtre du Chtelet to replace the Philharmonique with the Orchestre Lamoureux, Paris's oldest orchestra. "In France, the right to strike is established," said Franois Boudeau, a Thtre du Chtelet press officer. "Radio France employees have their claims, and that's normal. At the same time, this situation shows how dynamic our theater is. We found a solution within 24 hours." Performances on April 17, 21 and 23 remain on the schedule. "The Bassarids," composed in 1966, is based on a script by W.H. Auden and Chester Kallman. Produced by Yannis Kokkos and conducted by Kazushi Ono, it stars the soprano June Anderson and the tenor Kim Begley. The strike forced the cancellation of some of the network's programming, including news reports and concerts. Unions and employers met yesterday to discuss a possible settlement. HLNE FOUQUET

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Welfare-To-Work Success Mixed, Audit Says
description: Wisconsin's welfare-to-work program, a model used by other states, has had mixed success in helping people become economically self-sufficient over the past seven years, according to a report by the state's legislative audit bureau. About 20 percent of former program participants earned more than the poverty level in their first year out of the program, the audit found. The report also said that program agencies had made more than $3 million in excess payments to some participants. The bureau made several recommendations, and the Department of Workforce Development, which administers the program, has already acted on some, like improving financial monitoring, making program sanctions more consistent and changing the way job placements are tracked, a department official said. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Fists Fly and Feet Spin in a Place Called Pig Sty
description: The recent popularity of Chinese-language action movies has been a curiously highbrow phenomenon, as filmmakers of lofty reputation, like Ang Lee and Zhang Yimou, have discovered the pleasures (and the profits) of swordplay and wire work. Their forays into action romance -- "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon," "Hero" and "House of Flying Daggers" -- are full of swooping choreography and thrilling combat, but they are also marked by a stately, almost reverent tone. Luckily, Stephen Chow, the writer, director and star of "Kung Fu Hustle" (and the earlier "Shaolin Soccer"), is around to knock the genre off its high horse, and to remind American audiences, as Jackie Chan did before him, that clowning is as much a part of this cinematic tradition as nobility and sacrifice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LYMPANY, MOURA
description: LYMPANY -- Moura. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with deep sadness the passing of its beloved friend, the celebrated English pianist Dame Moura Lympany, on March 28 in Menton, France at the age of 88. Dame Moura was a valued member of our Steinway Artist family for 56 years. A native of Cornwall, Dame Moura was first taught by her mother and continued her piano studies with Mathilde Verne and Tobias Matthay. During the war she participated in London's famous National Gallery midday concerts, and a brilliant international career followed. Dame Moura was a featured artist in Steinway's Centennial concert at Carnegie Hall in 1953. Through her elegant performances and her sought-after recordings, she influenced more young pianists and piano aficionados than even she may have realized. She was, as well, a treasure to us, and her loss is deeply felt. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Immigrant-Smuggling Case
description: Two men accused of being leaders of an international immigrant-smuggling ring were brought to New York on Wednesday to face trial after they were deported from Venezuela by military intelligence police there, federal authorities said yesterday. The men -- Niranjan Maan Singh and Ramesh Patel -- had used false Venezuelan passports to smuggle immigrants from many countries through Curaao to the Dominican Republic and from there to the United States, according to federal prosecutors in Manhattan. The prosecutors said they had identified at least 10 immigrants brought to the United States by the ring since February 2004. Despite tense relations between the Bush administration and Hugo Chvez, the president of Venezuela, Mr. Chvez's military police helped capture the ringleaders, prosecutors said. Julia Preston (NYT)

Having ended his first concert with Mussorgsky's "Pictures at an Exhibition," he began the second with the same composer's "Khovanshchina" Prelude. Prokofiev, represented on Monday by the Piano Concerto No. 1, also remained on the agenda: his rarely played Symphony No. 2 was one of the draws of the program, which also included Borodin's Symphony No. 2 and the first non-Russian work of the series, Sibelius's Violin Concerto. A neighbor, Tim McInerny, told WABC-TV, Channel 7, that he rushed over to help the men, who lay on the ground. The men were taken to Winthrop University Hospital, where they were pronounced dead. Arts, Briefly; Networks Divide the Spoils
description: Wednesday's night of television resulted in a victory divided among ABC, NBC and Fox, as each network featured a notable episode of one of its programs. According to Nielsen's estimates, ABC had the most total viewers, but it tied with NBC in households. And among 18-to-49-year-olds, Fox was No. 1, buoyed by an "American Idol" show during which another of the contestants liked by the judges garnered the fewest votes. "Idol" was the most-watched show of the night, as an audience of 23.2 million saw Nikko Smith, above, the son of the former St. Louis Cardinals shortstop Ozzie Smith, eliminated, leaving the other contestant in the bottom two, Scott Savol, safe for another week. (Mr. Savol had a reason to be nervous: late last week, the Smoking Gun Web site reported that he had been charged with felony domestic violence in 2001 for hitting his girlfriend and later pleaded guilty to misdemeanor disorderly conduct.) On ABC, "Lost" (16.49 million viewers) killed off a major character for the first time, as Boone (Ian Somerhalder) met his maker. NBC made it into the Wednesday winners' circle because the "West Wing" season finale turned in stronger numbers than usual: 11.5 million viewers saw Jimmy Smits's character win the Democratic presidential nomination after a convention floor fight among four candidates. KATE AURTHUR

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES WILL CUT 600 JOBS IN KANSAS CITY

The reduction of up to 43 percent of the center's workers will occur in June, American told employees in a letter. The airline expects to eliminate 500 to 600 jobs, a spokeswoman, Sonja Whitemon, said. American, which is the operating unit of the AMR Corporation, had losses of $7.26 billion in the last four years. The carrier said fare competition and record fuel prices forced it to reduce work at the Kansas City base. AMR is based in Fort Worth.

A fusion of old and new, it both is and isn't a delirious escape into adventure-serial heaven. Amid its madcap derring-do, the movie inserts clear, simple alarms about environmental protection, African despotism, global interdependence and bureaucratic cowardice.

title: Arts, Briefly; Paging Tiny Tim
description: What the dickens would Charles Dickens, right, have made of plans to build a $116.6 million theme park, Dickens World, around his life and works? The South East Development Agency, a body responsible for planning in the Chatham area, 35 miles from London in southeast England, has announced that construction will start in two months as part of a regeneration project in the town's former dockyard section. Dickens (1812-70) lived in Chatham from ages 5 to 12. Scheduled for completion in April 2007, the roofed attraction devoted to the author of "David Copperfield," "Oliver Twist" and other classics will include an Ebeneezer Scrooge ride, cobbled streets with a replica of the Old Curiosity Shop and themed restaurants, a marketing spokesman said. A re-creation of a Victorian theater will present evening dinner shows with "naughty delights" in the "free and easy" style of Victorian music hall, according to the development agency. Thelma Grove, joint secretary of the International Dickens Fellowship, who is advising on the project, said: "I think it's a marvelous thing. It's an entertainment but also instructional and educational and will put Dickens across to a new audience." Kevin Christie, chief executive of the project, said, "We have great expectations." PAM KENT

title: Peckinpah's Messy Vision, a Little Less Truncated
description: "Yes, they cut a lot of it," the famously unruly director Sam Peckinpah said about his famously butchered 1965 western, "Major Dundee." "They left out what it's about." The "they" was Columbia, the studio that hired Peckinpah to direct "Major Dundee," then grabbed the movie and cut it so grievously that the director tried to have his name removed from the credits. title: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan: New Presidential Vote Put Off
description: Parliament heard a recorded statement from the country's ousted president, Askar Akayev, but failed for a third day to accept his resignation. It also canceled plans to hold a new presidential election on June 26 and is expected to set a new date. The new speaker, Omurbek Tekebayev, said lawmakers should first amend the law that provides Mr. Akayev, who fled the country after protesters stormed the presidential compound last month, with immunity and other guarantees, Interfax reported. In his address, which was recorded in Moscow this week after he signed a resignation agreement and was also shown on state television, Mr. Akayev appealed for a peaceful, democratic transfer of power. "Kindling squabbles and internal strife, which are capable of turning the forthcoming elections into a scandalous farce, need to be stopped," he said in a translation by the BBC. title: The Listings; NATIONAL BALLET OF CANADA
description: James Kudelka has been credited with shaking up the sometimes stodgy National Ballet of Canada, a group that he performed with early in his career and returned to in 1996 as artistic director. The Toronto-based company, now celebrating its 50th anniversary, was known for an impeccable classicism and for faithfully following tradition in repertorial matters. Mr. Kudelka -- a choreographer who has sometimes seemed a blend of the fluid Jiri Kylian and the darkly psychological Antony Tudor -- gave the National Ballet a "Swan Lake" with a gang rape and a "Firebird" with lizards and a killer egg. So it would be foolhardy to have expected a "Pied Piper" from Mr. Kudelka that featured Robert Browning's lad with a pipe leading a line of a town's ratlike children into oblivion after not being paid for his exterminating services. Instead, the choreographer who once named a ballet "Sin and Tonic" has brought the National Ballet to the Brooklyn Academy of Music with a version of that old story, here called "The Contract (The Pied Piper)," in which the piper is modeled on the glamorous Ontario-born evangelist Aimee Semple McPherson. The enchanted youngsters are children of rigidly moralistic parents who have come down with a mysterious movement disorder. Eva (Martine Lamy, above, with Guillaume Cote), as the McPherson character is called, has an affair with an engaged man and the townspeople cancel her contract. There go the children. Critics have had reservations. But "The Contract," set to live music by Michael Torke and performed by a cast of 36 adults and 18 child performers, addresses such weighty (and timely) themes as the struggles between right and wrong and tradition and the modern. (The National Ballet of Canada will perform "The Contract" tonight at 7:30 and tomorrow at 2 and 7:30 p.m. at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718)636-4100 or BAM.org. description: His most recent recording, a cycle of the Rachmaninoff piano concertos with Stephen Hough, has been called "definitive," "breathtaking" and "a terrific achievement" by reliable sources. He's made more than 65 recordings, conducted around the world and is music director of a significant American orchestra. And yet all this hasn't helped Andrew Litton, above, to build up real career momentum. At the end of the 2005-6 season, he steps down after 12 years as music director of the Dallas Symphony and heads off, not to a bigger post, but to the joys of freelancing. The group's concerts this weekend at Carnegie, its swan song here under Mr. Litton, are geared to the strengths of both conductor and players: "Also Sprach Zarathustra" and "Carmina Burana" play to Mr. Litton's penchant for big impressive works while showing off both the orchestra and the fine Dallas Symphony Chorus. A children's concert tomorrow afternoon flags another of Mr. Litton's strong suits -- he's done great work in the area of children's programming -- while offering almost more music than tonight's concert, for a fraction price. For some listeners, though, the real drama lies in the Dallas Symphony's search for a new music director who will truly take the orchestra to the next level. Stay tuned. title: The Listings; LADYSMITH BLACK MAMBAZO/VUSI MAHLASELA
description: Apartheid in South Africa ended with elections in 1994, and music was one of the things that rallied the forces of democracy, even as it stayed gentle. This double bill features two of South Africa's household names. In South African music, native traditions merged with imported colonial elements to yield songs that can sound familiar to Western ears yet thoroughly South African. Ladysmith Black Mambazo, the unaccompanied male choir led by Joseph Shabalala, merges traditional Zulu harmonies with the contours of gospel hymns, and goes on to add some synchronized dance steps. In the group's dynamic "stalking style," Mr. Shabalala's companionable tenor voice hovers above resonant, bass-heavy harmonies, which build from a cavernous hush to fervent, driving peaks. Vusi Mahlasela, above, was one of the most important songwriters of the anti-apartheid movement, not just for his political courage but for his sterling voice and for three-chord tunes that make earnest sentiments bounce. On his American debut album, "The Voice" (ATO), he sings in six languages from South Africa, including English. His music encompasses protest without turning strident. "Should I now stop singing of love, now that my memory is surrounded by blood?," his "Red Song" song asks before rejecting the idea. In the way Mr. Mahlasela's voice leaps between registers as he plucks guitar syncopations, there's as much playfulness as righteousness. (Sunday night at 7, Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, Manhattan, (212)840-2824 or (212)545-7536.; tickets are $25 to $45; $15 for students.) JON PARELES

The Listings; TRACY LETTS
description: Theatergoers familiar with the name Tracy Letts may be relieved to discover that he doesn't stalk onstage at the Barrow Street Theater toting a chainsaw dripping blood. Mr. Letts is best known hereabouts, after all, as the author of the psycho-thriller "Bug" and the white-trash gorefest "Killer Joe," popular shows that kept the city's stock of stage blood depleted for months on end. But Mr. Letts is an actor as well as a playwright, and in "Orson's Shadow," Austin Pendleton's tart valentine to a handful of theater greats of the last century, he's playing the British theater critic Kenneth Tynan, whose weapons were mere words. Tynan is the primary narrator in the play, the uneasy ringmaster in Mr. Pendleton's fanciful look at a 1960 production of "Rhinoceros" starring Laurence Olivier and directed by Orson Welles. Mr. Letts (above right, with Ian Westerfer) turns in a quiet gem of a performance as the anxious critic-turned-dramaturge, who is kept busy taming egos and soothing tempers even as he struggles with his own flagrant neuroses. Mr. Letts's gift for writing pungent characters may in part explain the wit and authority with which he channels the voice of one of the 20th-century theater's most famous wordsmiths. (Barrow Street Theater, 27 Barrow Street, Greenwich Village, (212)239-6200. This weekend's schedule: Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 and 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $55.) CHARLES ISHERWOOD

title: Princeton, N.J.
description: "I think of Princeton as being lazy and good-looking and aristocratic -- you know, like a spring day," F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote in "This Side of Paradise." Eighty-five years later, the appraisal still fits. From the restored, century-old wrought-iron FitzRandolph gates of Princeton University to the sleek rowing shells on sparkling Lake Carnegie, the town retains an air of easygoing noblesse. It is studded with landmarks from a Revolutionary War battlefield to Albert Einstein's workplace, but nevertheless lives firmly in the present -- traditional but not stuffy, charming but not quaint. A backpack-toting student walking a sheepdog with dreadlocks (that's right, the dreadlocks were on the dog) shares the sidewalk with chattering 10-year-olds and tweedy luminaries in town for one conference or another. In the tree-shaded downtown, Colonial-era buildings and high-end spots coexist with a used-record store, jeans-and-corduroy vegetarian hangouts and ice cream shops. And the campus is its own luxurious green city, in the words of Raymond Rhinehart, author of a guide to campus architecture, "a marketplace of ideas, set in a garden." LOUISE TUTELIAN

description: LYMPANY -- Moura. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with deep sadness the passing of its beloved friend, the celebrated English pianist Dame Moura Lympany, on March 28 in Menton, France at the age of 88. Dame Moura was a valued member of our Steinway Artist family for 56 years. A native of Cornwall, Dame Moura was first taught by her mother and continued her piano studies with Mathilde Verne and Tobias Matthay. During the war she participated in London's famous National Gallery midday concerts, and a brilliant international career followed. Dame Moura was a featured artist in Steinway's Centennial concert at Carnegie Hall in 1953. Through her elegant performances and her sought-after recordings, she influenced more young pianists and piano aficionados than even she may have realized. She was, as well, a treasure to us, and her loss is deeply felt. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

description: GOTTESMAN--Rabbi Aaron, 63, born in Brooklyn on September 27, 1941, died April 5 in San Diego, his home for the last several decades. Son of Rabbi Harold Zvi and Hadassah. He attended Eitz Chaim, Brooklyn Talmud Academy, and graduated from St. John's in Puerto Rico. He attended YU, JTS, and a got a BA from NYU. He was an NYC caseworker, volunteer firefighter and photographer in Yorktown Heights and worked for NYPD and FDNY in the 1960's. He was often seen at fires taking photos for NY newspapers, with his German shepherd, Sparky, by his side. In San Diego, he was a chaplain for the SDPD, SDFD, and hospitals, Burn Institute, FBI, state and federal prisons, SD Heart Association, and SD Eye Bank, SD Mayor proclaimed August 4, 2003, to be Rabbi Aaron Gottesman Day. He was the 2004 Man of the Year in SoCal's St. Patrick's Day Parade. He was chaplain for SD Chapters of Retired NYPD and FDNY. He was buried with full honors from the SDFD and SDPD. He is survived by his wife of 36 years, Elaine; daughters, Judith, Ziva and his beloved dog Tovah, brothers Uriel and Meyer. Donations may be sent to the Rabbi Aaron Gottesman Fund at SD Firefighters Federal Credit Union, 10509 San Diego Mission Road, Suite A, San Diego, CA 92108. Funds will go to the Israel Guide Dog Center for the Blind and the San Diego Zoo's Australasian Exhibit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BACOT, J. CARTER
description: BACOT--J. Carter. Died April 7 at his home in Montclair, NJ at age 72. Mr. Bacot served as chairman and chief executive officer of The Bank of New York Company, Inc. from 1982 to 1998 and remained on its Board of Directors until 2003. Under Mr. Bacot's leadership, The Bank of New York completed a series of groundbreaking mergers and acquisitions that enabled the bank to dramatically expand its operations both in the US and abroad. Born in 1933, Mr. Bacot was a native of Utica, NY. Mr. Bacot married the former Shirley Schou in 1960. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his daughters, Susan Bacot and Betsy Bacot-Aigner, Betsy's husband Stefan Aigner, and two grandsons, Christoph and Erick Aigner. Mr. Bacot graduated from Hamilton College in 1955 and Cornell Law School in 1958. Mr. Bacot joined The Bank of New York in 1960 and at various times served as the Head of the Bank's Investment Research and Personal Trust Departments. He was named Vice Chairman of the holding company in 1975 and President in 1979. Mr. Bacot served as Non-Executive Chairman and Director of Footlocker, Inc., a Director of the Phoenix Companies, NVR, Inc., Trustee of Atlantic Mutual Insurance Companies and a Director of Time Warner, Inc. He was a Director of The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, Inc. and the Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation. He was a Life Trustee and Chairman Emeritus of Hamilton College, a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and Economic Club of New York. Mr. Bacot's funeral will be held at 4:00PM on Saturday, April 9, at St. James Church in Upper Montclair, New Jersey. A reception will follow at Montclair Golf Club in West Orange, NJ. Memorial donations can be made to the Trustees of Hamilton College for the Bacot Family Scholarship Fund, 198 College Hill Road, Clinton, NY 13323.

title: World Briefing | Europe: U.N. Has Idea In Macedonia Name Debate
description: The United Nations special envoy for Macedonia, Matthew Nimetz, recommended that the country be known internationally as Republika Makedonia-Skopje to meet objections from Greece, which has a northern province called Macedonia. Petros Molyviatis, the Greek foreign minister, said the proposal did not "totally satisfy" his country but could be a basis for negotiation. Vlado Buckovski, Macedonia's prime minister, said its official position was unaltered -- "Republic of Macedonia" for international use and a "mutually acceptable solution for bilateral communications with Greece." The country entered the United Nations in 1993 under the name Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and is officially referred to by the acronym Fyrom (pronounced FIE-rum). He retired as President & Chairman of Wire-O-Binding, Inc. after 54 yrs. Besides his wife of 58 yrs, he leaves six daughters and their husbands, one brother, Richard, one sister, Rita and 10 grandchildren. A Penchant for Surprise in a Postpunk Frenzy
description: After the first crude blast of punk rock in the late 1970's, musicians started to get analytical about making rock disruptive. Caustic guitar tones, stop-start rhythms, discordant vocals and fractured lyrics were set in asymmetrical structures, honed and then hurled at listeners who danced to the jolts. A generation later, postpunk is back, in reunions of bands like Gang of Four and Mission of Burma and with some further twists in bands like Bloc Party, which played a taut, thrilling set at the sold-out Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night.

description: ORLANDO, Fla., April 8 - Six farm animals at a Florida petting zoo have been identified as the source of the potentially deadly strain of E. coli bacteria that caused more than 26 people, most of them children, to be hospitalized, state health officials said Friday. As a result, the officials said, all 37 animals at the zoo have been quarantined.

And so, at the funeral of Pope John Paul II, there was news about a president of the United States who did not shake the hands of two Middle Eastern adversaries, and a president of Israel who did.

description: VATICAN CITY, April 8 - Many of the hundreds of thousands of Poles who converged on Rome this week had one more item left on their agenda when the funeral ended: They wanted to see Pope John Paul II beatified -- immediately. Two hours after the ceremony, a ragtag crowd of thousands of Poles replaced the rows of silent priests at the front end of St. Peter's, where they lobbied loudly and exuberantly for their man.

title: Our Near-Death Experience
description: MOVEEN, Ireland - IMAGES of the papal wake dominated the news this week: the dead man's body vested, mitered, laid out among his people in St. Peter's Square, blessed with water and incense, borne from one station to the next in a final journey. Such images -- along with the idea that millions of people would wait for hours merely for a chance to pass by the body itself -- may have given pause to many Americans for whom the presence of the dead at their own funerals has become strangely unfashionable.

description: BASS HARBOR, Me. - IT began in the 1970's. Or at least that's when I became conscious of it. People began cleaning up after themselves in fast-food restaurants. I had been living abroad and didn't know about such things, but my children, faster to pick up on American cultural expectations, made sure I took back my tray and put my trash in the appropriate bin.

description: A 42-year-old mother of six was stabbed to death yesterday in an Upper East Side housing project, and the police said last night that they had not determined a motive.

title: The Song of the Hyperliterary
description: Good news first: Will Sheff, leader of the Austin indie-rock band Okkervil River, writes like a novelist. His songs are full of elegant phrases and unexpected images that tell -- or don't quite tell -- stories of characters trying to figure out if they need each other. With each release, he prints the lyrics in elegant and (this makes a difference) well-punctuated booklets, eschewing line breaks to encourage listeners to read the words as stories.

A Time for Mourning, but Also for Study and Very Quiet Politics
description: ROME, April 8 - Pope John Paul II's funeral Mass on Friday began nine days of spiritual mourning, but it also opened a political chapter -- the subtle campaigning before the gathering of cardinals in a conclave starting April 18 to elect a successor.

title: Teachers and Classmates Express Outrage at Arrest of Girl, 16, as a Terrorist Threat
description: At Heritage High School in East Harlem, where the student idiom is hip-hop and salsa, the 16-year-old Guinean girl stood out, but not just because she wore Islamic dress. She was so well liked that when she ran for student body president, she came in second to one of her best friends -- the Christian daughter of the president of the parent-teacher association, Deleen P. Carr.

title: World must live with high oil prices, IMF warns
World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Inflation Rises
description: Inflation in Brazil rose in March for the second consecutive month, keeping economists guessing about whether the central bank will raise its benchmark lending rate next week for the eighth consecutive month. The government's statistics agency said that its consumer price index, the central bank's main gauge for determining interest rates, rose 0.61 percent last month after climbing 0.59 percent in February. Prices have risen 1.79 percent so far this year and 7.54 percent in the last 12 months, raising doubts about the government's ability to meet its inflation target of 5.1 percent. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Made in China. Bought Everywhere.
description: HONG KONG, April 8 - After years of running large trade surpluses mainly with the United States, China is now exporting around the world at such a rapid rate that other countries find themselves racking up large bills to China as well. The resulting boom for China is certain to step up trade frictions elsewhere and increase pressure on Beijing to let its currency appreciate.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sanyo Electric Selects Executives
description: The consumer electronics giant Sanyo Electric chose a former television anchor, Tomoyo Nonaka, as its chairwoman and chief executive and named as its president the grandson of the company founder. A journalist by training, Ms. Nonaka, 50, recently served on Sanyo's board as well as on the boards of Asahi Breweries and the Nippon Broadcasting System. The choice of Ms. Nonaka was a surprise because female executives are rare in Japan and because it is unusual for Japanese companies to recruit leaders from outside. Toshimasa Iue, 42, the son of Sanyo's current chairman, Satoshi Iue, and grandson of the founder, Toshio Iue, was appointed president, succeeding Yukinori Kuwano, 64. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: U.N. Agency To Cut Darfur Rations
description: The World Food Program will cut food rations for a million people who have fled the conflict in the shattered Darfur region because it is dangerously low on money, the United Nations agency said in a statement. It said that the cuts were needed to make sure its current supply of food will last through July and August, the leanest months of the harvest cycle, and that it had received just $275 million of the $468 million it requires to feed as many as 2.3 million people in Darfur each month this year. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Exploring the Right to Share, Mix and Burn
description: The tickets for the event Thursday sold out in five minutes on the Internet, and on the evening itself the lines stretched down the block. The reverent young fans might as well have been holding cellphones aloft as totems of their fealty.

title: About These Listings
description: Starting on Monday, this page will carry listings for 29 additional channels and more program details for the existing ones. To accommodate the expansion, to 105 channels, the highlights section will be redesigned and lengthened, the Late Movies section discontinued and the daytime entries replaced by expanded listings of guests and topics for daytime news and talk shows. These changes are a response to the increased offerings of cable providers in the New York area and the widespread availability of all-day programming guides on television and the Internet. Morning, afternoon and late-night listings for the entire week will continue to appear, with an expanded prime-time guide, in the Television section on Sundays.

ICAHN NOMINATES SLATE OF BLOCKBUSTER DIRECTORS
description: The financier Carl C. Icahn nominated himself and two other people yesterday to the board of Blockbuster, the video rental chain, where he is the largest shareholder. Mr. Icahn, 69, nominated a music executive, Strauss Zelnick, and a former executive of Warner Brothers, Edward Bleier, to the board, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Blockbuster shareholders will vote on the nominations at the company's annual meeting on May 11. Mr. Icahn said on Thursday that he would nominate directors because he opposed an "unconscionable" $51.6 million pay package for Blockbuster's chief executive, John F. Antioco, last year and what he said was management's failure to curb spending. Randy Hargrove, a Blockbuster spokesman, declined to comment.

title: Congress Fetches for the Gun Lobby
description: Americans stunned at recent sprees of gun mayhem in churches, schools and courthouses should know that Congress is gearing up for action on this issue. No, lawmakers are not rushing through legislation to cut down on the 29,000 gun deaths a year. Rather, the Senate is preparing to revive a craven proposal to shield irresponsible gun manufacturers and dealers from accountability.

title: Pachyderms in the park?
National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Illegal Immigrants Arrested
description: Thirty-nine illegal Mexican immigrants were arrested after they were found crammed into four motel rooms in Las Cruces, the authorities said. It was the second major roundup of illegal immigrants in the city after the arrest of a Mexican teenager, Rolando Cervantes-Hernndez, last week. Mr. Cervantes-Hernndez, 19, was stopped by Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents while driving a vehicle containing 11 illegal immigrants. A subsequent investigation led to the discovery of 53 other immigrants in a trailer. Mr. Cervantes-Hernndez was charged with smuggling and will be prosecuted by the United States attorney's office in Albuquerque. The immigrants were returned to Mexico. Joseph Kolb (NYT)

title: New Jersey Symphony Chief to Head Glasgow Orchestra
description: After a year on the job, Simon Woods, the president of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, has announced that he will leave in July to become the chief executive of the Royal Scottish National Orchestra in Glasgow.

title: Killing Off Housing for the Poor
description: The Bush administration pays lip service to the goal of "ending chronic homelessness" -- while undermining the very programs that keep poor people from ending up in the streets. The Housing and Urban Development Department is proposing unreasonable cuts in federal subsidies, which would make it harder for underfinanced housing authorities to keep their developments livable and safe. And a proposal in Congress would make it harder for the poor to get rental subsidies from Section 8, the public-private partnership that underwrites rents for nearly two million of the country's low-income families and encourages builders to develop affordable housing.

title: Union Seeks Wal-Mart Files About Payments
description: The United Food and Commercial Workers Union called on Wal-Mart Stores yesterday to release all documents connected with accusations that its former vice chairman, Tom Coughlin, had obtained improper expense account reimbursements to finance secret anti-union activities.

description: As the coffin of Pope John Paul II was carried from St. Peter's Square for burial, Tila Wea Samu, 33, a bookseller from Indonesia's predominantly Catholic island of Flores, tapped her fingers together in rhythm with mourners in Rome while she watched in Jakarta.

title: CONAGRA DELAYS QUARTERLY FILING TO REVIEW TAX ERRORS
description: ConAgra Foods, the food company, delayed the filing of its quarterly earnings report to allow for more time to review accounting errors it disclosed last month. The company is still determining the effect of the errors on the three-month and nine-month periods ended Feb. 22, 2004, ConAgra said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday. ConAgra said on March 24 that it found errors in accounting for tax expenses that would reduce net income by a total of $150 million to $200 million in fiscal 2003 and 2004. A new president for tax matters and more accounting staff are to be hired to fix "a material weakness in internal controls," the company said.

Bronx Man Charged in Killing of Midtown Diamond Dealer
description: A Bronx man who the authorities said was convicted of killing a man nearly 20 years ago by stabbing him in the eye was charged yesterday with the fatal shooting of a diamond merchant on a crowded Midtown sidewalk last spring. Investigators say they believe the murder was a contract killing.

title: A Challenge for Miss America in Reality TV Era
description: ATLANTIC CITY - Miss America has lost her TV show, and now has to decide how much of her famous modesty she's willing to shed to get it back on the air.

title: After DeLay Remarks, Bush Says He Supports 'Independent Judiciary'
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 - President Bush appeared to distance himself on Friday from recent comments by the House Republican leader, Representative Tom DeLay, that Congress should crack down on unaccountable judges.

title: UNITED FLIGHT ATTENDANTS THREATEN TO SCRAP CONCESSIONS
description: Flight attendants at United Airlines, who agreed in January to $131 million of concessions, threatened to terminate that contract in 20 days unless the company provided details on givebacks by salaried employees. The Association of Flight Attendants union said yesterday that some concessions by salaried and management employees might be "illusory." The union represents 21,000 attendants at United, a unit of the UAL Corporation. The airline, based in Chicago, called the union's statement "absurd." The attendants agreed in January to accept a 9.5 percent pay cut after United said concessions were needed to help lift the airline out of bankruptcy. United is seeking $725 million in annual pay and benefit givebacks from employees, as well as savings of $639 million by scrapping pension plans.

title: MORNINGSTAR SAYS NO SETTLEMENT WITH S.E.C.
description: Morningstar, a provider of mutual fund analysis and data, said yesterday that talks with the Securities and Exchange Commission about suspected misrepresentations of fund returns had concluded with no settlement. The company said in an S.E.C. filing that it could not predict whether the talks would resume. Morningstar previously disclosed that in May 2004, it received a Wells notice from the S.E.C. that indicated the agency's staff intended to recommend enforcement action against the firm. The investigation related to incorrect data published by Morningstar for the Rock Canyon Top Flight Fund in 2004. Morningstar disclosed the end of the talks in a filing related to its proposed initial public offering. In its filing, Morningstar, which is based in Chicago, said it expected to offer 7.6 million shares, with pricing to be set the week of May 1.

title: Where Chariots Raced, a Modern Spectacle Brings Together, if Briefly, a Diverse Church
description: ROME, April 8 - In the Circus Maximus, the dusty stadium nearly two miles from the Vatican where chariot races were held in pagan times, more than 10,000 people on Friday watched the funeral Mass of Pope John Paul II on two giant screens, live from St. Peter's Basilica.

description: WASHINGTON, April 8 - A federal appeals court heard arguments on Friday in a five-year battle over whether the Environmental Protection Agency has the authority to regulate carbon dioxide emissions from motor vehicles.

title: Major Water Main Ruptures in New Jersey
description: More than 350,000 residents in three counties of north-central New Jersey were left without water or with low water pressure last night after a major water main near the banks of the Raritan River in Bound Brook ruptured in the afternoon, sending torrents gushing into the flood-swollen river. But officials said they expected to fully restore service by early this morning.

title: Kenya: Taking Inspiration
description: Thousands of people packed into the compound outside the Holy Family Basilica in Nairobi, enduring the midday heat and keeping their teary eyes glued to giant television screens showing the pope's funeral. Kenya is about 30 percent Roman Catholic, and despite the fondness the country has for the pope, Kenyans often struggled with some of the church's teachings, especially his condemnation of condoms in a time of AIDS.

The spokesman, Joaqun Navarro-Valls, said they would attend a Mass at 10 a.m. and meet afterward, not vice versa.

title: Avoiding potholes when renting a car
Arts, Briefly; And Then There Was One
description: Daylight saving has taken its toll on television ratings this week: overall viewership has been down each night since Sunday. CBS won the Thursday ratings clash with only one of its shows, "Survivor: Palau," offering an original episode. An audience of 19.27 million watched "Survivor," on which the two-person Ulong tribe lost yet another immunity challenge, resulting in a one-person tribe for the first time in the show's run. A repeat of "CSI" followed "Survivor" and was the night's most-watched show. Other than a new episode of "The Apprentice," NBC, second to CBS for the night among both viewers and adults 18 to 49, also programmed repeats. Surrounded by poorly performing reruns, the rating for "The Apprentice" was down 9 percent from its season average and attracted 13.3 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Rise
description: Orders for Japanese machinery rose 4.9 percent in February from January, a stronger-than-expected gain after two months of declines. The increase in orders was larger than the 2.4 percent predicted by economists and an encouraging sign amid recent disappointing economic data. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Army Cadet Pleads Guilty in Sex Case at West Point
description: A West Point cadet was sentenced on Thursday to four years in a military prison and dismissed from the Army after pleading guilty to a series of sex-related charges stemming from his breaking into the rooms of four female cadets in the middle of the night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEN, DOV, RIVKA. ''SAVTAH''
description: BEN-DOV--Rivka. "Savtah" the matriarch of the Ben-Dov and Spanier clans, born in Safed, Israel on February 20, 1915, daughter of Baruch Barzel, the "Boyaner Rebbe" and Chava, passed away on April 7, 2005. Her children Zohar, Ktziah and Chana, her son-inlaw Sidney and her grandchildren Noam, Talia, Tamar, Ariella, Eitan and Elianna will remember a true "Eshet Chayl" (woman of valor). Services will be held at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, Sun, April 10, 10AM.

title: In Rare Legal Protest, Chinese Seek Boycott of Japan Goods
description: BEIJING, Saturday, April 9 - Several thousand young Chinese marched through Beijing's high-tech district on Saturday morning calling for a boycott of Japanese-made goods, a rare legal protest that underscored the sharp deterioration in relations between Asia's two most powerful countries.

description: Ambiguity was wiped away last night, replaced by an abundant clarity that left the Knicks no room for further delusions. Their season will end April 20, and there is no form of mathematics that will change their ill fate. The out-of-town scoreboard is officially irrelevant.

But as this rain-interrupted Masters awaited today's resumption of the second round, all of those flags were as much a symbol of this prestigious golf tournament as a green jacket.

title: Nukes Are Green
description: If there was one thing that used to be crystal clear to any environmentalist, it was that nuclear energy was the deadliest threat this planet faced. That's why Dick Gregory pledged at a huge anti-nuke demonstration in 1979 that he would eat no solid food until all nuclear plants in the U.S. were shut down.

description: VATICAN CITY, April 8 - John Paul II, a little-known Polish cardinal when he was chosen pope in 1978, was buried Friday after a funeral Mass that attracted admirers from the around the world, the important and the ordinary alike, in the hundreds of thousands.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Aid To Ease Rover Impact
description: The British government offered to provide financial support worth $75 million to help component suppliers hurt by the looming collapse of MG Rover, the country's last volume car producer. Worried about possible political repercussions with an election set for May 5, Prime Minister Tony Blair and Chancellor Gordon Brown traveled to Birmingham, where MG Rover is based, to meet with labor union leaders after the breakdown of takeover talks between the British company and a Chinese suitor, Shanghai Automotive Industry. Mr. Blair told reporters that he and Mr. Brown had been in touch with Chinese leaders and that a more limited deal might still be possible. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Two States Get High Marks for Five-Day Antiterrorism Exercise
description: Despite sporadic breakdowns involving roadblocks in New Jersey and fire department radios in Connecticut, a five-day antiterrorism drill did not reveal any glaring deficiencies in the way the two states responded to the simulated terror attacks, homeland security officials said on Friday.

title: Cardinals in conclave will be watched for tilt
Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, LENA
description: SCHWARTZ--Lena. Passed away quietly at her home on April 8, 2005. Age 94. Survived by her daughter, Joan Shore and her loving family.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a thumbnail sketch on Tuesday about the winner of the Pulitzer Prize for public service, a series by The Los Angeles Times about problems at the Martin Luther King Jr./Drew Medical Center, referred incorrectly to the status of the hospital. It has not been shut down.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Uganda Study On Aids Drug Is Ruled Valid
description: Reviewing a controversial study that endorsed the AIDS drug nevirapine to prevent mothers from infecting their babies, an independent medical panel has concluded that the study's findings were valid. The study, conducted in Uganda in the 1990's, was scientifically sound despite some flaws in record-keeping and procedures, the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences said on Thursday. Nevirapine is widely used in Africa. Later studies also found the drug to be inexpensive, safe and effective, though evidence recently emerged that it could make some mothers more resistant to subsequent antiretroviral treatment. Last year, an expert in clinical trials who was fighting threats of dismissal by the National Institutes of Health claimed publicly that the Uganda study was seriously flawed. His arguments gave fuel to governments that have hesitated to pay for antiretroviral treatment. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: Head of Unit That Trained School Principals Resigns
description: Robert E. Knowling Jr. announced his resignation yesterday as chief executive of the New York City Leadership Academy, a costly and controversial program to recruit and train public school principals.

title: Familiar Name Helping North Dakota
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 8 - When North Dakota faces Denver for the N.C.A.A. college hockey championship Saturday night, the last name of the goalie for the North Dakota Fighting Sioux, Jordan Parise, may sound familiar to many hockey fans, especially in the New York area.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Teaneck: Deal Enables A Yeshiva To Compete
description: After intervention by legal groups and threats of Congressional action by a New Jersey official, a deal was struck yesterday that will allow Torah Academy to become the first Jewish school to participate in a national high school mock trial championship. A team from the Teaneck-based yeshiva beat out some 250 competitors to become New Jersey's representative at the annual event, which is to be held next month in North Carolina. But officials from the Orthodox academy had complained that their students would be unable to compete in the final round of simulated legal battles that was scheduled for a Saturday -- the Jewish day of rest. After intense lobbying by the New Jersey State Bar Association, the North Carolina Academy of Trial Lawyers and United States Representative Steve Rothman, among others, the coalition of state bar associations sponsoring the championship agreed to a compromise solution that will allow Torah Academy's aspiring attorneys to make their closing arguments, if necessary, after sundown. Josh Benson (NYT)

title: Lawmakers vote to strip ex-leader of protections
Scrushy Fights Use of His Testimony to S.E.C.
description: Richard M. Scrushy, the founder of the HealthSouth Corporation, has asked the judge in his fraud trial to exclude testimony he gave federal regulators that prosecutors contend proves he committed perjury. The trial is in recess until Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, OZZIE
description: SCHWARTZ--Ozzie. You will be sorely missed. Your smile and kindness will never be forgotten. You will always be in our hearts. The Lubliners

title: Budget Cutbacks in Subway Stir Upkeep Debate
description: Amid a drumbeat of subway disruptions in recent weeks, the city's transit union has attacked the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, saying it has lowered the maintenance standards that brought the transit network back from its abyss in the 1980's.

description: To the Editor:

Psychics Can Wreak Havoc, But You Should Do the Math
description: Half a century ago a young genius burst onto the British bridge scene and represented his country on many occasions. His creativity repeatedly exasperated team captains, one of whom discovered that a psychic overcall had led to seven spades doubled down 10, a "save" against a small slam.

title: Trade Quotas? Ah, the Good Old Days
description: SAIPAN, Northern Mariana Islands - This quiet little American territory, a tropical island that struggled for years to improve working conditions in its sweatshops, may now lose many of its apparel factories to free market forces.

title: China Opens New Inquiry of Times Researcher Held Incommunicado
description: A Chinese researcher for The New York Times who has been held incommunicado for seven months on suspicion of leaking state secrets is now being investigated for financial fraud, Chinese security officials told the man's lawyer in Beijing this week.

title: JURY DECIDES WYETH NOT LIABLE IN DIET DRUG CASE
description: A Philadelphia jury decided that Wyeth was not liable for $5.5 million in potential damages for health problems suffered by two former users of its Pondimin drug, part of the fen-phen diet combination, the company said. The jury in the Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas returned the ruling yesterday after a weeklong trial. In the first phase of the trial, jurors decided last month that the two Utah women suffered heart valve damage after using the drug. "We believe the evidence validated what we've been saying all along, that Wyeth acted properly and responsibly" once it discovered a link between the diet drugs and heart valve leakage, said Robert Limbacher, a lawyer for Wyeth. Wyeth is based in Madison, N.J.

title: Yanks Spared Watching Red Sox Celebrate Again
description: The Yankees will not have to watch the Red Sox celebrate their historic World Series victory again when Boston presents the World Series rings and raises the championship banner during the home opener at Fenway Park on Monday. The Red Sox have arranged an itinerary that allows the Yankees to disappear briefly.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan: Ousted Leader Loses Privileges
description: Parliament stripped Askar Akayev, the ousted president, of his privileges and perquisites, including his official residences, medical care and the right to address state bodies, according to news reports from the capital, Bishkek. Parliament left in place his immunity from prosecution, though not that of his relatives, whom opposition leaders accuse of corruption. Mr. Akayev announced his resignation in Moscow on Monday, but lawmakers here have failed to vote to accept it, disrupting plans for new presidential elections. An envoy from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe warned that the political situation remained unstable. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: North Korea signals a willingness to talk
World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: American Dead In Cairo Bombing
description: The death toll from a presumed suicide bombing in Cairo's main bazaar on Thursday rose to three after an American tourist died of his injuries, said the tourism minister, Ahmed el-Maghrabi. Ten other tourists remain hospitalized, including three Americans. The blast also killed a French woman and a still unidentified person suspected of being the bomber. A previously unknown group of Islamic militants claimed responsibility in an Internet posting that could not be independently verified, saying it wanted to protest both the "tyranny" of President Hosni Mubarak and United States policy in the region. Opposition groups condemned the bombing and called on the government not to use it as an excuse to extend emergency laws that have been in effect for 24 years. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: Shipments of children, a darkly growing trade
Next, the trial of Saddam

title: World Briefing | Europe: Europeans In Chechnya To Study Needs
description: The European Commission is dispatching officials to Chechnya for one week, starting today, to explore ways of providing economic and reconstruction aid. It is the first time the Europeans have tried to give such help. The group of about 10 officials will visit Chechnya and the neighboring Russian republics of Ingushetia and North Ossetia. Relations between Moscow and Brussels have been strained because of what the Europeans see as rights abuses by Russia as it tries to regain control of Chechnya. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Barnes Foundation Appeal
description: The Supreme Court of Pennsylvania decided on Thursday to consider a Barnes Foundation student's appeal of a lower-court decision permitting the foundation to move its gallery, below, from suburban Merion, Pa., to downtown Philadelphia. The latest ruling, initially sought by the Barnes but applauded by both sides, expedites the long-running case by bypassing Superior Court review. Speeding up the appeals process "was important given the financial strains of the Barnes Foundation," said Ralph G. Wellington, a lawyer for the Barnes. Mr. Wellington said it was still unclear whether the court would dismiss the appeal by the student, Jay Raymond, or review it. Mr. Raymond has argued both that the Montgomery County Orphans' Court judge, Stanley R. Ott, unfairly denied him standing to intervene in the case, and that Judge Ott's decision in December, which overturned Albert C. Barnes's written wishes that his art collection remain in Merion, was incorrect. The Supreme Court ruling is "excellent news, because if we are to succeed in overturning the Orphans' Court approval of the move, we would have to prevail ultimately in the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania," said Howard J. Bashman, Mr. Raymond's lawyer. "And now we have a chance to do that at the outset." JULIA M. KLEIN

title: Amid the Glow, Searching for Honest Answers
description: John Paul II has been laid to rest but not the debate about his legacy. The arguments were irrelevant to the hundreds of thousands of passionate admirers who flooded Rome to pay their respects. But the clashing assessments of this papacy will not be irrelevant to the cardinals now beginning intense consultations about the needs of the church and which man might best serve them.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Clues Sought In Fatal Hit-Run
description: The police said yesterday they were baffled by a hit and run that claimed the life of a woman Thursday night on the Upper East Side. They said they had no description of the car and have been unable to find witnesses to the hit and run in which Maria Panagakos Nolan, 46, was hit by a vehicle. A passer-by found her unconscious at Madison Avenue and East 65th Street at 10:37 p.m. Ms. Nolan was taken to New York University Hospital, where she was pronounced dead. The police quoted her husband, John Nolan, as saying that she left her apartment on East 57th Street at 10 p.m. Ms. Nolan worked at RBC Dain Rauscher Inc., according to a Web site listing brokers registered with National Association of Securities Dealers. Anthony Ramirez (NYT)

title: Mets Add Cameron to D.L. and Give Heilman a Start
description: ATLANTA, April 8 - The Mets are not a week into their season and already they are in roster distress. They put another player on the disabled list on Friday and on Saturday will need help from a pitcher who started the season in the minor leagues.

title: Let the beatification begin, and promptly, Poles urge
Waves of applause for a beloved pope
For Charles, Camilla and Britain, the Wait Is Over
description: LONDON, April 8 - Maybe we already know enough about Saturday's royal wedding. But the details have been so complicated, the last-minute adjustments so harrowing, the sense of doom over the whole thing so ominous, that it is worth reviewing a few outstanding items.

title: Dashing From Grassy Hill to City Sidewalk in Dancers Choreography Showcase
U.S. Says Banned Nuclear Technology Went to Pakistan and India
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 - Federal prosecutors investigating the smuggling of nuclear technology disclosed Friday that a South African businessman had pleaded guilty to arranging illegal exports of American-made equipment both to Pakistan and its regional rival, India.

title: When Mourning Becomes Television: Even Anchors Stay Behind the Cameras at Vatican
description: If anything brought home the stature of John Paul II, it was the sight of all the major networks covering his funeral live at 3:30 a.m. yesterday -- and keeping their anchors off camera for almost the entire ceremony.

title: Briefcase: U.S. Social Security draws youth focus
Italian Bank Approves Bid by Suitor From Spain
description: MILAN, April 8 - Banca Nazionale del Lavoro approved a takeover bid of 6.5 billion euros from Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria of Spain on Friday, shifting the spotlight to Italy's central bank, which has expressed doubts about the offer and could block it.

title: Kenneth Morley Wilson, 83, Renowned Glass Expert, Dies
description: Kenneth Morley Wilson, a noted historian of glass manufacture in America, who was long associated with the Corning Museum of Glass and the Henry Ford Museum, died on March 29 at his home in Punta Gorda, Fla. He was 83.

title: GILLETTE TO CLOSE NORTH CAROLINA BATTERY PLANT
description: The Gillette Company, which is being bought by the Procter & Gamble Company, said yesterday that it would close a Duracell battery plant in Lexington, N.C., because of declining demand for lithium batteries. Gillette said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it would record an expense of 4 cents a share in 2005 for the closing. Costs to shut the plant by next year include $29 million for severance and other employee-related expenses and noncash asset impairment costs of about $46 million. The company, based in Boston, did not specify how many workers are employed at the plant.

title: Meanwhile: A tale of two princes
Diallo Remarks Haunt Ferrer at Convention
description: Fernando Ferrer faced a torrent of criticism yesterday for telling a police union last month that the 1999 shooting death of Amadou Diallo was not a crime. Participants at a convention organized by the Rev. Al Sharpton accused Mr. Ferrer of flip-flopping and turning his back on an issue crucial to many blacks.

title: Verizon Buys Stake in MCI to Bolster Takeover Bid
Paid Notice: Deaths   CHESNER, RACHEL
description: CHESNER--Rachel. Born December 20, 1910, died April 7, 2005. Her children Avi, Carmela and Bilha and her grandchildren Arbel, Eldan, Lirone, David, Jonathan, Daniella, Jordana and Ariel and great grandchildren are mourning her loss. She devoted her life to her family and she will be missed forever. Funeral Services to be held Sunday, April 10, at 11:30 A.M. at Gutterman's Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY followed by burial at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont Road, Elmont, NY.
