title: The Old College Try May Work After All
description: OAKLAND - NEARLY a year ago, Mike Montgomery seemed to have made a Faustian pact. After 18 seasons as basketball coach at nearby Stanford, Montgomery leaped to the Golden State Warriors, a franchise that had not made the playoffs since the 1993-94 season. By the All-Star Game break, critics were using Montgomery as the latest example of a college coach struggling to make the transition to the pros.

title: Venezuela: Official Pomp
description: President Hugo Chvez's government has frequently clashed with the Catholic Church, which has been seen as allied with the opposition, but on Friday the authorities spoke only warmly of the pope.

Will miss his kindness, humor and love of family, his warmth and charm will stay in our hearts forever. Services Sunday, April 10, 9;30 A.M. at "The Riverside", 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Arts, Briefly; Police Find Stolen Picasso
description: The French police returned a stolen painting by Picasso yesterday to the Pompidou Center in Paris. The 1924 Cubist oil on canvas, "Nature morte  la Charlotte," valued at $3.2 million, disappeared from one of the museum's warehouses, and a complaint was filed in March 2004. Investigators discovered that a 32-year-old guard had given his marijuana dealer access to the building, and that the dealer had carried out the theft. He passed the painting to a third man, who confessed to hiding it behind a cabinet in his house on the outskirts of Paris, where the police found it in good condition on Tuesday. "I don't think they realized what the value of this painting was," said Catherine Driguet, a Paris police spokeswoman. "They deal drugs, not stolen artworks." The investigation is continuing. HLNE FOUQUET

title: Yongle art: Outside impacts
Smarter than its masters
North Korea Said to Reject China's Bid on Nuclear Talks
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 - After two senior-level meetings between North Korean and Chinese leaders over the last two weeks to discuss the North's nuclear-weapons program, the Chinese have failed so far to persuade North Korea to rejoin nuclear disarmament talks, senior administration officials and diplomats said Friday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Water Board Proposes Increase
description: The New York City Water Board yesterday proposed raising water rates by 3 percent beginning July 1, the smallest increase since 2001. The rate increase for each of the past two years has been 5.5 percent. Charles Sturcken, a spokesman for the city's Department of Environmental Protection, said the 3 percent increase would be used to help pay for investments in a long-term rebuilding program for the city's water system. If the proposal is approved by the seven-member Water Board, an independent body appointed by the mayor, annual water and sewage charges for apartments would reach an average of $486, or an increase of $15. Annual charges for single-family homes would rise to an average of $571, or an increase of $17. The board will hold public hearings on the proposal across the city from May 2 to May 4. The final rate will be set on May 13. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Back Annan's call for a new human rights body
A Farewell to a Pope for the Ages (8 Letters)
World Briefing | Asia: Turkmenistan: Autocrat Plans Elections
description: Saparmurat Niyazov, Turkmenistan's autocratic leader, said the country would hold a presidential election, though not until 2009, according to news reports. Mr. Niyazov, 65, who calls himself the Father of all Turkmen and whom Parliament has already declared president for life, told his ministers on Thursday evening that the country should also hold elections for regional parliaments, followed by a vote for the national Parliament, by 2008. Last month's popular uprising in Kyrgyzstan has raised hopes that democracy would spread through Central Asia, but the powers of Mr. Niyazov, who has led Turkmenistan since 1985, remain dictatorial. Still, he said, "The country's destiny must not depend on one person." Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Domestic Disturbances: Portraits of Abused Women
description: Of the many ways Americans have been coached to view domestic abuse -- as torture, as a public health issue, as an epiphenomenon of various social problems -- the model of terrorism might have the most contemporary traction.

title: Other Views: Gulf News, Montreal Gazette, The Times
National Briefing | Washington: Hazardous Materials Signs To Stay On Trains
description: The Department of Homeland Security has decided to leave warning signs on rail cars carrying hazardous materials despite concerns that terrorists could use them to identify the trains as targets. Michael Chertoff, the secretary of homeland security, said Thursday that federal officials would drop a proposal to remove the placards because of opposition from firefighters and other emergency workers. The workers feared that removing the placards, which identify the chemicals being carried, might have endangered their lives. Mr. Chertoff said the department listened to those concerns and decided it was "a matter of common sense" to keep the signs. Christopher Drew (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Cablevision Is Shutting Most of Its Voom Business Cablevision Systems has decided to discontinue its Voom satellite business, but maintain ownership and sell rights to 21 high-definition television channels.

title: New York and New Jersey
China to mark emergence as leader of Third World
Atonal, Edgy and in Control
description: During an informative preconcert discussion with the composer Augusta Read Thomas, whose music was featured Thursday night in one of the Miller Theater's "Composer Portraits" programs, the vivacious Ms. Thomas expressed one earnest hope to the large and noticeably young audience.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the nomination of John R. Ryan as acting chancellor of the State University of New York misstated the given name of the university's chairman. He is Thomas F. Egan, not John.

title: E.P.A. Halts Florida Test on Pesticides
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 - Stephen L. Johnson, the acting administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said on Friday that he was canceling a study of the effects of pesticides on infants and babies, a day after two Democratic senators said they would block his confirmation if the research continued.

title: Vantage Point: Missing: 'So much a part of this place'
Rebuilding Indonesia
Metro Briefing | New York: Floral Park: OSHA Investigating Two Deaths
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration is investigating the deaths of two Long Island workers who were electrocuted on Thursday while working on a Floral Park home. The workers, identified as David Coy Sanchez, 25, and Elquin Astaiza Ceballos, 19, both of Elmont, were installing siding when the scaffolding they were dismantling struck a high-voltage line, the Nassau County Police said. Three other workers were injured. The incident occurred at a home at Calla Avenue and Zinnia Street in Floral Park about 5:30 p.m. The men's employer was Home Exteriors of Elmont, a subcontractor for United Windows Doors and Siding of Hempstead, said Ted Fitzgerald, a spokesman for OSHA. The men were pronounced dead at Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola. With some exceptions, regulations require that scaffolding be kept 10 feet away from power lines, Mr. Fitzgerald said. A check of the agency's online violation records showed that neither company had been subject to an investigation in the past five years. Neither company had a listed telephone number, and attempts to reach them were unsuccessful. Attempts to contact the families of the victims were also unsuccessful. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Miller Ponders Forgoing Gold to Avoid Fame That Follows
description: If Bode Miller enters the 2006 Winter Olympics, he could win as many as five gold medals. Certainly, he would be a favorite to win two or three.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Monaco: Princess's Husband Hospitalized
description: The husband of Princess Caroline was in the hospital with a pancreatic infection, the news media here reported, just two days after the death of her father, the principality's sovereign, Prince Rainier III. Prince Ernst August of Hanover, 51, at left with Caroline, was admitted to a Monaco hospital with pancreas pains on Monday, according to the reports, and has been in a coma since Tuesday evening. Under the principality's revised succession rules, Prince Rainier's son, Prince Albert, now rules the tiny state. If Albert, who is unmarried, dies or abdicates without an heir, Princess Caroline would be next in line to succeed to the throne. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Just shoot, dock and print
Bellamy Road Carries Pinstriped Hopes
description: The George Steinbrenner who owns a stable of thoroughbred racehorses bears little resemblance to the George Steinbrenner who is the principal owner of a certain baseball team playing in the Bronx. He has never spent lavishly on free-agent horses at the various sales, has always operated under the radar and has never won anything of great significance in the racing game.

title: Misfortune and Recovery
description: Dawn Halfaker and Danielle Green, both former basketball players, were among the first women to lose limbs while earning Iraq campaign ribbons.

title: The Wait Is Over
description: Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles were married Saturday at the 17th century Guildhall.

description:
To help Staten Island singles looking for
a place to hang out, Island Girl (a k a
Lisa Shammas) offered these ratings of some of her North Shore favorites.

title: A Tax Increase That Bush Didn't Mention
description: WASHINGTON

title: Two Women Bound by Sports, War and Injuries
description: WASHINGTON - For 25 days at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, Specialist Danielle Green wondered if anyone could ever understand. But on the 26th day, a nurse told her: "A new female patient came in today. You have a lot in common."

title: His Last Name Is Scheme
description: More than 80 years after Charles Ponzi's spectacular rise and fall, his name is still synonymous with ''swindle.'' And although it is invoked to describe a variety of brazen, gargantuan rip-offs, it really applies only to swindles of a certain kind, longer than a one-shot deal but inherently limited in duration, in which people are promised windfall profits from can't-miss investments -- to be paid, when they are paid at all, only out of money collected from subsequent dopes and dupes.

title: In London, a Mean Street Turns Chic
description: AS one heads north, the elbow-to-elbow frenzy of flea market stalls, restaurants and shops that enlivens Portobello Road in west London abruptly ends just past the elevated Westway highway. Suddenly lined by undistinguished postwar housing, the road simply curves out of view. Yet continuing along this unpromising bend quickly yields a short stretch of shops that intersects with one of London's newly trendy addresses, Golborne Road.

title: Exotic but Cozy, a Moroccan Port Is a Second Home
description: IT'S the kind of place one first hears about in a yoga class, discussed in heated whispers between sun salutations. Or while eavesdropping on two model types with French accents in a cafe. About 10 years ago that place might have been Tulum, Mexico, but these days it's Essaouira, a tiny white-walled port city on Morocco's Atlantic coast.

title: 'Ponzi's Scheme'
Seeing Paris on $250 a Day
description: TALK about location. Our room would be in the absolute center of Paris, in a monumental building alongside the Notre-Dame cathedral. Even better, it would cost just 102 euros a day. The only catch: we'd be staying in a hospital. Welcome to Paris on $250 a day.

title: Bookshelf
description: THE PERFECT WIZARD: Hans Christian Andersen. By Jane Yolen. Illustrated by Dennis Nolan. Dutton. $16.99. (Ages 6 and up) A commendably candid picture-book biography, emphasizing the early years of the great Danish storyteller who was born in April 1805. The full-page illustrations soften the details of an anguished life. Each page of text also has an illustrated scene and quotation from one of the familiar tales like "The Ugly Duckling" and "The Emperor's New Clothes."

title: The Oracle of Omaha's Latest Riddle
description: OMAHA - WHEN Berkshire Hathaway shareholders gather here in three weeks for their annual meeting, they will be treated to another homespun video starring the company's chairman, Warren E. Buffett. This year's plot is still a secret, but Mr. Buffett's co-star in last year's video was Arnold Schwarzenegger, the governor of California.

title: On Fifth Avenue, Victims of Their Own Success
description: In recent years, as shops opened and rents soared on Fifth Avenue in Park Slope, the nonprofit Fifth Avenue Committee campaigned against landlords trying to evict lower-income renters. Now, the community group's own real estate tale has turned bittersweet.

title: That's Enterprise
description: Tim Brazeal has a dream: to raise enough money from fans to subsidize a fifth season of "Star Trek: Enterprise" (with Scott Bakula, above), currently scheduled to end on May 13. Mr. Brazeal, who lives in Marysville, Tenn., also has a number: $3,139,035.50. That's the amount that he said had been donated or pledged to his campaign, by more than 8,500 donors, by early last week. And he hinted that by this weekend, if a few anticipated pledges came through, "that figure will look small."

title: Wilson Carey McWilliams Dies at 71; Studied the Moral Basis of Politics
description: Correction Appended

title: A Disease Devastating to Sheep Threatens Spanish Bullfighting
description: MADRID, April 9 - Some Spaniards may soon have to prepare for the unthinkable: a summer without bullfighting.

title: Gauging That Other Company Asset: Its Reputation
description: AS regulatory issues keep troubling Wall Street, some investors are beginning to wonder: Are sound business ethics not only a sign of a morally good company, but of a good investment as well?

title: In Attempt to Oust Clinton, a Strategist's Comeback Bid
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 - Arthur J. Finkelstein, the political guru who helped engineer the defeat of one Democratic luminary, Mario M. Cuomo, has his sights set on another: Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: In Montauk, Once More Unto the Scrum
description: LAST summer, the Montauk Rugby Club, once nearly a national champion, appeared to be near extinction. More than a quarter-century of tradition and competition seemed to be coming to an end after the club forfeited games during the spring season and did not have enough players to field a team for the coming fall competition.

title: Esprit de Corps
description: Trisha Brown is a noble dancer and choreographer, unique in her vision. But that vision comes out of a context. She has been with us for a while -- not as long as Merce Cunningham or even Paul Taylor, but long enough to have made an indelible mark on modern dance. Legions of younger dancers have emerged from the ranks of all three choreographers' companies. And like Cunningham and Taylor, she has never stopped exploring or evolving.

title: The Tale Of the Tapes
description: PALMYRA - ON first impression, John Gural stocky and bespectacled -- hardly strikes a visitor as a secret agent, partisan revolutionary or news-media star.

title: A Ball Drops Just So, and the Yanks Waste No Time
description: Ruben Sierra's three-run homer was still resting in a net behind the left-field fence, Randy Johnson was not scowling as much in the clubhouse and the other Yankees seemed relieved about rumbling closer to rescuing Johnson and themselves against the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Using Graffiti as a Decorating Tool
description: HUGO MARTINEZ, a 54-year-old graffiti gallerist, has been living his work -- and living in his work -- since 1972, when as a philosophy major and student activist at City College he discovered Puerto Rican teenagers painting subway cars in railyards and helped organize them into a loose collective called United Graffiti Artists.

title: Corrections
description: A CD review on March 27 about works by the composer Robert Kurka, who died at 35, misstated the age of Felix Mendelssohn at his death in 1847. He was 38, not 41.

description: To the Editor:

GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: QUICK BITE/Jersey City; A Harmonic State Between Gooey and Runny
description: When properly executed -- using bread of the optimal thickness, texture and grain, buttered the exact amount to achieve the perfect toastiness, using the right kind of cheese to give you a gooey, but not overflowingly runny melt -- a grilled-cheese sandwich is one of the most enjoyable of simple culinary pleasures. But finding that balance can be a near-mythical venture, because many restaurants don't go through the trouble it takes to produce a sterling example.

title: At a 21st Century Clothing Store, Music From the Poodle-Skirt Era
description: Not long ago, the music that wafted through Century 21 on Cortlandt Street in Lower Manhattan was chosen in much the same way as it is at other department stores: a company was hired to provide a mix of songs -- everything from jazz to soft rock. However, because Century 21 sells designer clothes at slashed prices, and the scene is often jammed and noisy, store executives felt that their needs, musically speaking, were different.

title: Injured Knick Cringes From Afar
description: The losses piled up at a dizzying pace -- close calls mixed with blowouts, stout performances sandwiched by poor efforts -- until two losses became four, and four became nine, and soon the Knicks' playoff hopes were dead. It was an ugly scene for anyone to witness, made tougher for Penny Hardaway because he was helpless and hundreds of miles away.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Audiovox Is Now Back In Nasdaq's Good Graces

title: The Basics; Pius Work for You?
description: One perk of being pope is that you can pick your own name. This wasn't always the case. Originally, popes kept their given names, but in 532, when a priest named Mercury assumed the throne, he discarded his pagan name in favor of John II. By the early 11th century, new names were the rule. Marcellus II, elected in 1555, was the last pope to keep his given name.

title: 'Garlic and Sapphires': Food Critic in Funny Hat
description: GARLIC AND SAPPHIRES The Secret Life of a Critic in Disguise. By Ruth Reichl. 333 pp. The Penguin Press. $24.95.

description: PAISLEY Written and illustrated by Maggie Smith. Unpaged. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95. (Ages 3 to 6)

title: Richard Wagner, Musical Mensch
description: THERE are moments in "Die Walkre," Wagner's most humane opera, that never fail to dissolve me, even though I know they are coming. One occurs fairly early in the first act.

title: 'Market Forces': The Office
description: MARKET FORCES By Richard K. Morgan. 441 pp. Ballantine Books. Paper, $14.95.

title: Rally by Israeli Rightists Is Foiled
A Silk Road That Leads Somewhere Truly New
description: WHEN Yo-Yo Ma began work on the Silk Road Project seven years ago, the music world stood by with a mixture of curiosity and skepticism. Why was Mr. Ma, known for his cello interpretations of Bach and Brahms, suddenly jumping on the world-music bandwagon? Would the involvement of musicians from China to Turkey and everywhere in between be some kind of marketing gimmick, a "We Are the World" minus Michael and Tina? Would the classical -- ahem, Western classical -- music community be practicing cultural imperialism by experimenting with Eastern traditions?

title: Charity Begins at the Board. Just Ask A.I.G.
description: IT has to have been a bewildering few weeks for Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group. One minute his company is producing record revenues and he is high-fiving himself on Congress's passage of tort reform, one of his passions. The next minute he is dumped from the company he has run for almost 40 years and finds himself facing an under-oath interview with prosecutors from the Justice Department, Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York attorney general's office, the same guys he used to bully on a regular basis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REDDICK, JEANNE. (STAGE NAME JEANNE SHEPHERD)
description: REDDICK -- Jeanne. (stage name Jeanne Shepherd) died on her 84th birthday, March 16, 2005. Born in Verona, NJ, she graduated Bucknell College in 1943, and commenced her acting career on tour in "My Sister Eileen". Two Moss Hart productions followed, along with a lifetime friendship with his wife, Kitty Carlisle. After playing Laura in the first "Glass Menagerie" she landed contract with Warner Bros., starring in "Adventures of Don Juan" with Errol Flynn. She married Bill Reddick in 1952. They worked in television for many years. A career in California real estate followed until ill health intervened. A truly regal, sensitive, charming, witty lady has left our stage.

title: From Band-Aids To Biotech
description: NEW BRUNSWICK - FOR generations, Johnson & Johnson has been known for Band-Aids and baby powder. It invented the first-aid kit and created the universally recognized scent of a baby. But these days, the fortunes of New Jersey's largest company lie not as much in the nursery or drug store aisle as in high-tech medical devices and biotech drugs -- at once a more lucrative but riskier path.

title: Making Money When the Market Is Mistaken
description: NO one ever went broke underestimating people's intelligence, H.L. Mencken observed. Among managers of a group of mutual funds offered by J.P. Morgan, a school of thought holds that there is good money to be made underestimating people's capacity to act rationally.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LIEF, ARTHUR
description: LIEF--Arthur. December 22, 1908--April 10, 2002. Remembered with love every day.

description: To the Editor:

title: Savoring the Bounty of Vietnam
description: IT is 5 in the morning. The seaside town of Nha Trang is dark yet bustling, the beachfront street dotted with groups of people exercising in unison, fishing boats bobbing in time behind them. Your carriage, or more precisely your man-powered cyclo, whisks you past it all and deposits you at the fish market, where a sea of Vietnamese women in conical hats unload, clean and auction off their giant tuna, sea bass, swordfish and crabs.

title: Instead of Reading This, Maybe You Should Take a Nap
description: Isn't it just wonderful living in a 24/7 world? Why, the very term "24/7" connotes a giddy, thumping intensity. Just think of those poor, deprived pre-electricity humans, who, when darkness fell, had to either light up candles or gas lamps or -- what a novel idea -- go to sleep.

title: In Nation's 'Most Average City,' Uncommon Turmoil
description: WICHITA FALLS, Tex. - The exodus began last September when Police Chief Ken Coughlin, bristling over a crack by Mayor Bill Altman and already fighting with the city over police training, yanked off his badge and quit.

title: Strongman Training Helps Burt's Son Get to First Base
Bush to Shift His Social Security Focus to Solutions
description: CRAWFORD, Tex., April 9 - After spending months seeking to convince the nation that Social Security faces serious problems that demand immediate action, President Bush will pivot to a new message next month, working in coordination with Congressional leaders to begin setting out the menu of potentially painful solutions, White House officials said.

title: GIANTS SEEK FURTHER REVIEW
description: The New York Giants, angry that construction began last month on the $1.3 billion Meadowlands Xanadu project without their approval, went to court Tuesday to halt the work and to enforce a clause in their lease that requires the state to renovate Giants Stadium. "We needed to take action to protect our home," said John Mara, the football team's executive vice president, whose family owns 50 percent of the Giants. The Tisch family owns the other half.

title: Mexican Aide Is Freed
description: MEXICO CITY, April 9 - A former presidential aide who prosecutors say leaked information to drug dealers was released from prison on Saturday after a judge ruled there was not enough evidence to hold him, officials said.

title: File, File, File, Eh, Maplewood?
description: As a new nail salon prepares for its grand opening in downtown Maplewood -- the third in a cluster of such shops -- township officials are taking action. They are considering an ordinance that would regulate the number of nail salons in Maplewood's main shopping district.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRASKIN, LEON
description: KRASKIN--Leon. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Leon Kraskin of New York City, a former ATS vice president of finance. A devoted colleague, he served with distinction as a senior member of management, helping set the organization on its path to success during its formative years. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Grace and the entire Kraskin family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Stephen A. Laser, President Evelyn Berger, Chairman Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

title: Goodbye to Privacy
description: NO PLACE TO HIDE By Robert O'Harrow Jr. 348 pp. The Free Press. $26.

description: Deborah Kostroun, a daughter of Agnes and Jerry Kostroun of Cameron, Tex., was married there yesterday to Peter Rizzotti, a son of Virginia and Robert Rizzotti of Waldwick, N.J. The Rev. Thomas J. Hanus, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Monica's Catholic Church.

title: In Closed-End Funds, Watch That First Step
description: FEW investors would knowingly buy a newly issued stock that is likely to decline by more than 10 percent within three months.

title: Fighting for a Cause, and Injured Along the Way
description: Noah Budnick, projects director at the advocacy group Transportation Alternatives and one of New York's most visible bicycling activists, was well aware of the dangers of urban cycling. Even casual acquaintances say that he is never seen riding without a helmet, and that he is well versed in the nature and location of designated bike lanes.

title: Edward Hopper's Downtown Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Oh, to Be in England Now That April's There
description: "We're just princesses, all of us," said Anita Summer, her clipped Cockney twang still pronounced 50 years after she left her native London.

title: CLEARED FOR TAKEOFF
description: American Ecology will ask its shareholders to approve a new director next month. The company, which cleans up radioactive and other hazardous wastes, notes his close relationship with the federal government, a big customer. Stephen A. Romano, American Ecology's chief executive, added that the new director would bring "valuable ethics and oversight perspective" to the company.

title: A Warrior Conquers the Wood for the Boss
description: From his residence in Tampa, Fla., George Steinbrenner watched a dazzling performance by one of his most brilliant athletes yesterday. But it was not Randy Johnson.

title: Two Women Bound by Sports, War and Injuries
description: WASHINGTON - For 25 days at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, Specialist Danielle Green wondered if anyone could ever understand. But on the 26th day, a nurse told her: "A new female patient came in today. You have a lot in common."

title: India and China Are Poised to Share Defining Moment
description: NEW DELHI, April 9 - Wen Jiabao, prime minister of China, began a four-day visit to India on Saturday just as the two countries -- a third of humanity -- are coming into their own at the same moment, with the potential for a dynamic shift in the world's politics and economy.

title: Evoking France in Springtime
description: If Maurice Chevalier's rendition of "Thank Heaven for Little Girls" in "Gigi" were a fizzy ros, it would be Domaine Renardat-Fche's Vin du Bugey Cerdon. In springtime, cafe regulars in Lyon love to drink this nonvintage treasure, produced in Mrignat, a nearby village. A low-alcohol semisweet wine, it is both an aperitif and a dessert. Its lovely bouquet envelops the table.

title: Defense Contracts Fuel an Uptick in Jobs
description: SPARKED by a surge in military spending, Long Island's long-declining manufacturing sector is showing signs of new life. Since August, it has been adding more jobs than it has been shedding, reversing 45 consecutive months of net losses.

title: 'The Dog of the Marriage'
A Novel Perspective
description: Q: I see you will be participating in PEN's first festival of international writers, which will be held in New York next week. Do you find it helpful to meet other writers?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BUCHHOLTZ, SIDNEY SAMUEL
description: BUCHHOLTZ--Sidney Samuel. In the year since you passed your love, wisdom and kindness have been missed every day. We hold your humor and smile close to our hearts. Sheryl, Sheila, Michael and Families

title: The Wounded
description: Lynsey Addario's disturbing photographs (March 27) of our wounded young people should shake us all awake to war's reality. Especially shocking was the gurney holding the lake of Sergeant Butterworth's blood before his leg was amputated. It's time we acknowledged each soldier's loss with photos and stories, as your photographer has so ably done.

title: Questions for Michael Eric Dyson
description: Bill Cosby was not trying to be funny when he made comments about African-American culture (Deborah Solomon, March 27). His remarks were not geared solely to the poor. Cosby urged the black community to take personal responsibility. He stressed the importance of proper grammar, education and parenting. Michael Eric Dyson's insistence that the solution to the problems of the black community are embodied in the someone-has-to change-your-diaper example is not only demeaning but a continuation of a century's infantilizing of African-Americans. He is not giving black youth the message that the opportunity to change who they are is in their hands.

title: The Basics; What Was That?
description: Thirty-second commercials have been the common currency of television for as long as many viewers can remember. But with the news that Puma plans to begin using 15-second spots on Monday , and following recent Cadillac commercials that last just five seconds, it appears the currency is being revalued.

title: Ooh, Rice!
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK - I CAN moan over a hot wedge of dense chocolate cake as much as the next woman, but a sigh-worthy dessert based on black rice -- that's a challenge. And it's more than met at the Noodle House.

title: Debbara Dingman and Daniel DeNoon
description: Dr. Debbara Jean Dingman and Daniel John DeNoon were married last evening at the Commerce Club in Atlanta. The Rev. Grover E. Criswell, a Disciples of Christ minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: The Four Season Resort Costa Rica
description: THE BASICS -- The Four Seasons Resort Costa Rica at Peninsula Papagayo opened in January 2004, adding the first sprawling luxury resort to the country's list of eco-friendly retreats and beach lodgings. Designed by the Costa Rican architect Ronald Zrcher, the resort's earth-toned stucco buildings seem to grow out of a hillside that slopes down to an isthmus, surrounded by tropical dry forest and sandy beaches on both sides. From the moment the solicitous staff greets you with fresh fruit juice in the open-air lobby, and directs you to the property's three swimming pools, state-of-the-art fitness center, and the Arnold Palmer-designed golf course, any preconception of Costa Rica-as-a-developing-country fades away. Only occasional monkey- spotting provides a reminder of the wildlife beyond the resort's meticulously kept grounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIRE, DR. RICHARD O.
description: HIRE--Dr. Richard O., died April 6 of lung cancer. Beloved life partner of L.B. Williams. Brother of Jim & David Hire and of Sue Varallo. A dear friend, respected colleague and devoted psychiatrist, he will be deeply missed by the many people who loved him. Memorial Service April 30, 10AM at the Friends Meeting House, 15 Rutherford Place, Manhattan, between 2nd & 3rd Aves and 15 & 16 Sts. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Association of Gay & Lesbian Psychiatrists, The John Fryer Award, 4514 Chester Avenue, Philadelphia, PA. 19143.

description: A rainbow has settled over regional museums and art centers. It may just be a byproduct of the torrid economic storm they have weathered the last couple of years, or it may be a sign that positive changes are afoot. I think it is the latter.

description: LEWIS--Desiree. April 6. Beloved wife of the late Mortimer B. Lewis. Loving mother of Merry Lewis and Jane Lewis-Nichols and her husband Ned. Fondly remembered by nieces, nephews, cousins and friends for her great wit, charm and generosity. Services were held on Friday, April 8. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Heart Association would be appreciated.

title: The Wounded
description: I am only 26 years old, yet I am already older than all of the wounded soldiers whose ages were listed below their photographs. I surmise that I am also older than most of the other injured men. Too sad for words.

description: LUCK IS LUCK Poems. By Lucia Perillo. 98 pp. Random House. $19.95.

title: It's Curtains for the Brig, With Smiles All Around
description: For 11 years, the spooky old jail has been empty. Its barbed wire has rusted. Its cellblocks were lighted at night to keep trespassers at bay. Of the neighbors who noticed, most were pleased that last week, preparatory work for its demolition had quietly begun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FARBER, BEATRICE
description: FARBER--Beatrice. On April 9, 2005. Wife of the late Sol. Mother of Arlene and her husband Steve, Robert and his wife Marilyn, Sherry and her husband Michael. Grandmother of Simone, Peter, Bradley, Adam, David, Jamie and Jennifer. Great-grandmother of Jacob, Harry, Eliana and Samson. "A woman who lived by the Torah" and gave unconditionally to all who knew her. Service Sunday, 11:30 am, at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 2005 Toyota Tacoma and Nissan Frontier: Those Baby Pickups Are Grown Up and Ready to Move Out
description: FOR years, while the Detroit-based automakers groomed their cash cows, the full-size pickups and S.U.V.'s that generated much of their sales revenue, Japanese companies concentrated on cars. By the time the Americans turned their attention back to automobiles -- Ford called 2004 "the year of the car" -- the Japanese were deploying new trucks in their assault on Fortress Detroit.

Paid Notice: Deaths   STUTZ, GERALDINE
description: STUTZ -- Geraldine. The Board of Trustees and staff of Theatre Development Fund are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Geraldine Stutz. As a devoted Trustee, whose passion for the theatre inspired us all, she brought vision, style and flair to TDF for over 20 years. Her unique marketing skills and tireless advocacy helped the organization grow immeasurably. She will be deeply missed. John F. Breglio, Chairman Victoria Bailey, Exec. Dir. STUTZ-GIBBS--Geraldine. Died on April 8, 2005, peacefully at her home.

title: Kifaya!
description: As an Arabic speaker and language aficionado, I have to say that William Safire's On Language column (March 27) put a huge smile on my face. The word "kifaya" was commonly used on the streets of Cairo when I was there in 1993. Whether in the course of bargaining in the Khan al-Khalili or during a political discussion in a corner coffeehouse, "kifaya" was common linguistic currency, both in its literal meaning -- "enough" -- and in its slang meanings -- "O.K., O.K, I get it already" or "I've had it!"

description: Correction Appended

title: Those Hot Real Estate Funds Cool Off
description: AFTER years of stellar performances, real estate funds are finding it difficult to stage another encore in 2005. The funds ended the first quarter down by an average of 6.6 percent and ranked near the bottom of all mutual fund categories, according to Morningstar, the mutual fund research company.

title: Seeing Paris on $250 a Day
description: TALK about location. Our room would be in the absolute center of Paris, in a monumental building alongside the Notre-Dame cathedral. Even better, it would cost just 102 euros a day. The only catch: we'd be staying in a hospital. Welcome to Paris on $250 a day.

title: Riot Police Called In to Calm Anti-Japanese Protests in China
description: BEIJING, April 9 - Mass demonstrations here against Japan turned unruly late Saturday afternoon, with scattered vandalism and confrontations with the riot police intensifying what began as a fully legal and generally peaceful student-led protest.

title: Celebrities Opt to Be Heard Rather Than Seen
description: THE composer Carter Burwell was sitting next to his friends, the filmmakers Joel and Ethan Coen and the screenwriter Charlie Kaufman, in the soundproofed studio of his TriBeCa apartment. Their chairs occupied a narrow aisle of floor, skirting the massive mixing console of switches, audio signals and recording devices.

description: THERE are few stores in the city in which burnt cow feet, octopus and African snapper can be placed in the same shopping basket, but then not every neighborhood has a Latin 17 Meat & Provisions, in the middle of the staggering multiethnic bazaar that is the Bronx Terminal Market.

title: Anand Keeps His Game Sharp, Even With Little Time to Think
description: The 14th Amber Blindfold and Rapid Chess Tournament, at the Monte Carlo Grand Hotel in Monaco from March 19 to 31, was won by Viswanathan Anand of India. Anand scored 8-3 in the games without sight of the chessboard and 7 1/2 with the board in view.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSEN, MELVILLE
description: ROSEN -- Melville. Beloved husband of Elaine. Devoted father of Robin O'Leary, Barbara Messner and Alan Rosen. Dear brother of Muriel Stout. Adored grandfather. Services Monday, 1 PM, "Gutterman's," 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, LI.

title: Dole Discloses Emergency That Nearly Took His Life
description: Former Senator Bob Dole, whose life was shaped by a devastating war injury, suffered a medical emergency earlier this year that doctors told him nearly claimed his life.

title: Corrections
Beyond Gender, From Brooklyn to Bangalore and Back Again
description: SURUPA SEN, who became the artistic director of the Nrityagram Dance Ensemble in 1996, and Mark Morris, who founded the Mark Morris Dance Group in 1980, are both known for choreography that reaches beyond their traditions. They met in the early 90's, when Mr. Morris visited the Nrityagram dance village in Southern India, near Bangalore, where Ms. Sen was living and studying. The village, founded in 1990 by Protima Gauri Bedi to preserve the Odissi form of temple dance, provides free room, board and dance training for 30 full-time residents.

title: Diesel Wars
description: These have been trying times for people who want healthier, more breathable air in New York City. "The perfect storm," lamented Richard Kassel, a senior attorney at the Natural Resources Defense Council, who for years has been leading the charge against diesel engines, which contribute to asthma and other respiratory diseases.

title: Dancing in the Moonlight? Not Here, Residents Plead
description: On an inconspicuous fence between a Tropicana distribution plant and the Beechhurst Shores condominiums in Whitestone, Queens, a fading white sign indicates the presence of the Beechhurst Yacht Club. This seaside refuge, located at the end of a long, rocky road marked by piles of bricks and scattered buoys, once catered to boating enthusiasts from all over northern Queens.

title: Slam-Dunks Discouraged
description: Anyone who picked Fairleigh Dickinson to reach this year's Final Four knows as much about men's college basketball as I do about women's college bowling.

title: A $20 Million Town House in Brooklyn (No Fooling)
description: IT sounds like an April Fools' Day joke but it's not. A town house at 140 Columbia Heights overlooking the promenade in Brooklyn Heights went on the market on April 1 with the stratospheric asking price of $20 million. That is just down the street from a town house at 212 Columbia Heights that went into contract late last year for $8.5 million -- double the highest price ever paid in the neighborhood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TURTLETAUB, ALAN
description: TURTLETAUB -- Alan. title: Abe Lincoln (Museum) in Illinois
description: The Abraham Lincoln Presidential Museum, in Springfield, Ill., officially opens on April 19 with a four-day public celebration, 140 years after Lincoln's death. The museum will be part of a $150 million complex covering four city blocks that include the Lincoln Presidential Library, open since October 2004, and a restored 1890 train depot that will serve as a visitor center.

title: My Enemy, My Friend
description: One hot evening, toward the end of second grade in Cuba, I stood under the glare of street lights for a school play. With my back bent and a hoe in my right hand, I pretended to work in a rice field. A yellow work shirt, plucked from my father's closet, covered most of my body. A straw hat shielded my face, making my mother's deft makeup -- with black eyeliner she had made my eyes look elongated and narrow -- barely visible. When a chorus of my peers made the sound of helicopters, I looked up in mock terror and dived under the paper grass. Then I got up, wounded and stumbling, and recited a poem against the bad American pilots who were killing innocent children in the placid fields of Vietnam. At the end of the poem, I clutched my chest and collapsed. I did this for two nights.

title: On the Cover; Armageddon, And Not a Day Too Soon
description: IF the world is ending, there's not much point in pinching pennies. That seems to be the philosophy behind "Revelations," a six-hour NBC mini-series that begins Wednesday night, which is why David Seltzer (right), its creator and writer, was doing an interview by telephone from Prague instead of some studio back lot. "It's a big project," Mr. Seltzer said of the series, in which Bill Pullman and Natascha McElhone track clues that suggest Armageddon is at hand. That meant filming in far-flung locations. "If one wants to talk about the end of the world, the apocalypse, you're talking about the world itself," said Mr. Seltzer, who is also executive producer along with Gavin Polone. "It's not Southern California breaking into the sea. The story is global, and it requires that kind of approach." The sprawling tale involves a child struck by lightning in Florida, a miracle baby in Greece, an intrepid nun played by Ms. McElhone, a skeptical astrophysicist played by Mr. Pullman, and a satanic murderer. Pegged to the prophesies of the Bible, "Revelations" is working an area of intense public interest, as shown by the popularity of "The Da Vinci Code" and "The Passion of the Christ." For Mr. Seltzer, whose eclectic rsum includes screenwriting credits on both "The Omen" and "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory," the challenges have included shooting a project with the ambitions of a film on the accelerated schedule of a weekly television series. "I've learned to live without sleep," he said. Neil Genzlinger

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOTTESMAN, RABBI AARON
description: GOTTESMAN--Rabbi Aaron, 63, born in Brooklyn on September 27, 1941, died April 5 in San Diego, his home for the last several decades. Son of Rabbi Harold Zvi and Hadassah. He attended Eitz Chaim, Brooklyn Talmud Academy, and graduated from St. John's in Puerto Rico. He attended YU, JTS, and a got a BA from NYU. He was an NYC caseworker, volunteer firefighter and photographer in Yorktown Heights and worked for NYPD and FDNY in the 1960's. He was often seen at fires taking photos for NY newspapers, with his German shepherd, Sparky, by his side. In San Diego, he was a chaplain for the SDPD, SDFD, and hospitals, Burn Institute, FBI, state and federal prisons, SD Heart Association, and SD Eye Bank, SD Mayor proclaimed August 4, 2003, to be Rabbi Aaron Gottesman Day. He was the 2004 Man of the Year in SoCal's St. Patrick's Day Parade. He was chaplain for SD Chapters of Retired NYPD and FDNY. He was buried with full honors from the SDFD and SDPD. He is survived by his wife of 36 years, Elaine; daughters, Judith, Ziva and his beloved dog Tovah, brothers Uriel and Meyer. Donations may be sent to the Rabbi Aaron Gottesman Fund at SD Firefighters Federal Credit Union, 10509 San Diego Mission Road, Suite A, San Diego, CA 92108. Funds will go to the Israel Guide Dog Center for the Blind and the San Diego Zoo's Australasian Exhibit.

title: Inside the List
description: WARMING UP TO McEWAN: Ian McEwan's ninth novel, "Saturday," published by Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, enters the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 3. McEwan's icily gripping novels have long been best sellers in his native England, but it has taken American readers a while to warm up to him -- this is only his third novel to make the Times list. (His Booker Prize-winning novel, "Amsterdam," had an eight-week run in 1999, rising as high as No. 9, and "Atonement," published in 2002, hung on for 14 weeks, rising as high as No. 4.) The consensus opinion about "Saturday" seems to be, as Michael Dirda put it in The Washington Post Book World, that while the novel is "just a smidgen overcontrived," it reads like a rocket. McEwan's novel, as Jesse Kornbluth writes on Bookreporter.com, takes over your life: "You wish you didn't have to eat, you despise the ringing phone, you wouldn't mind if you had a catheter." McEwan has been hard to avoid in recent weeks -- he's been interviewed by Scott Simon of NPR and by Entertainment Weekly, among many others, and has been profiled in Time and Vanity Fair. McEwan prefers dealing with American journalists rather than those in Britain, where gossip about novelists is more prized than it is here. "I would say that American journalism is far less intrusive," he said in an interview in Publishers Weekly. "If I'm going to meet an American journalist in London, I'd quite happily have him come to my home, because he isn't going to focus on my private life. I wouldn't let a British journalist through the door."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARSHALL, DOUGLAS B., JR.
description: MARSHALL--Douglas B., Jr. 58, of Houston, Texas died suddenly and unexpectedly on the 30th of March 2005 in Houston. Mr. Marshall was born on the 6th of November 1946 in Houston. Mr. Marshall was preceded in death by his mother, Margaret Cullen Marshall. Mr. Marshall is survived by his father, Douglas B. Marshall of Sioux Narrows, Canada; his son, Douglas B. Marshall III of Cambridge, MA; brother, Hugh Roy Marshall and sister-in-law, Cynthia Marshall of Reno, NV; nephew, Hugh Roy Marshall, Jr. of Virginia City, NV; nephew, Benjamin Cullen Marshall and wife, Michelle Marshall, of Oceanside, CA; nieces, Margaret Ann Marshall and Sophie Celeste Marshall of Reno, NV; and the children of Cynthia Marshall, Tina Marshall and Andrew Marshall of Reno, NV. Mr. Marshall is also survived by many members of his extended family, viz., the family of Hugh Roy and Lillie Cullen. Mr. Marshall was married to Alexandra D. Redding on November 23rd, 1974 at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York City. They were married for eleven years. Their son Douglas B. Marshall III was born on July 4, 1977 in Houston. Mr. Marshall held a bachelor's degree from the University of Texas at Austin. He spent his professional career in the petrochemical industry and private investing. Mr. Marshall was a former Director of Quintana Petroleum Corp. and The Cullen Foundation. At the time of his death, he was a Founder and Director of the Douglas B. Marshall, Jr. Family Foundation, an Advisory Director of the North American Piedmontese Association and a current member of numerous Oil & Gas, Cattle, and Arabian Horse organizations. Outside of work, Mr. Marshall was an avid outdoorsman, a boatsman, and a talented fisherman. He enjoyed many trips to his ranches in Magnolia and Barksdale, TX, where he spent afternoons driving the fence lines and roads observing flora and fauna. He was a kind, sensitive, intelligent, generous man. His family misses him dearly. The funeral service for Mr. Marshall was conducted on Tuesday, April 5th at St. Luke's United Methodist Church in Houston, TX, with the Rev. Dr. Laurens A. Hall of St. John the Divine Episcopal Church officiating. The burial was conducted on Thursday, April 7th in Barskdale, TX. For further information, kindly telephone Geo. H. Lewis & Sons, Houston, 713.789.3005.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLFENDEN, GEORGE BUCHANAN, SR.
description: WOLFENDEN -- George Buchanan, Sr., the founding Headmaster of Tampa Preparatory School died peacefully in a hot tub in Duxbury, MA on April 1, 2005. The cause of death was respiratory depression from a Fentanyl transdermal patch. He was born on June 9, 1925 in Indiana, PA. He attended the Fessenden School, Phillips Exeter and Haverford College. He served with the U.S. Army during WWII in Newfoundland, Canada. He married Eleanor Houck of Brampton, Canada, and had three children. He worked in his family wholesale grocery business founded by his grandfather, George T. Buchanan for whom he was named. He was stationed with the Army in Japan during the Korean Conflict. In 1964 worked with the Presbyterian Church at the Interchurch Center in New York City where he managed the acquisition and disposition of overseas properties. He married Barbara Kirk in 1966 and had a daughter. At the age of 40 he resumed his education at Haverford College, graduating with a BA in History in 1968. He got his Masters degree from Brown. He taught history at Milton Academy, and was Housemaster of Wolcott House. He was recruited by a Milton parent to help start a preparatory school in Tampa, FL. In 1973 thanks to his endless zeal and charismatic enthusiasm, the school opened with 40 students. Three years later the school was fully accredited achieved with an enrollment of 260. He gave the school its motto, "A Higher Purpose Than the Self." In 1989, he married Carol Langford, M.D. and moved to Duxbury, MA. He was a lifelong voracious reader, avid skier, tennis player and golfer. He is survived by his wife, his brother Richard of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, his children George B. Wolfenden Jr., John H. Wolfenden, Elaine W. Cockroft and Linda L. Wolfenden and six grandchildren. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made in his name to Tampa Preparatory School in Tampa, FL, Haverford College in Pennsylvania or to the Friends Committee on National Legislation in Washington, DC.

description: Rye Brook - WHAT is the best way to deliver fire emergency service to lower Westchester? Some experts at the county's Career Fire Chiefs Association say the answer may be to consolidate several municipalities' services into a regional fire district. But changes this large require advance analysis, so late last year the association approached the Michaelian Institute for Public Policy and Management at Pace University to study the issue.

title: The Artist's Tale
description: A RAINBOW has settled over regional museums and art centers. It may just be a byproduct of the economic storm they have weathered the last couple years, or it may be a sign that positive changes are afoot. I think it is the latter.

title: Shakespeare's Globe
description: To the Editor: I read "Along the Thames, Bidding Winter Farewell," ("Going to London," March 13) by Jennifer Conlin with interest. I was more than a little surprised, however, that no mention was made of Shakespeare's Globe, where I am the director of communications.

title: Offerings for the Senses and the Palate
description: RYE - IN a town crammed with eating spots, RK, Rye's newest restaurant, makes an effort to offer dining that is beyond the common run.

title: Blues Clues
description: Rick Shannon, the Mississippi disc jockey who goes hunting for the lost tapes of a 1953 blues session that ended in murder in Bill Fitzhugh's HIGHWAY 61 RESURFACED (Morrow, $23.95), is not the only sleuth on the music scene. Nick Travers, the New Orleans blues historian in a series by Ace Atkins, has made tracks to Chicago, Memphis and the devil's own crossroads in Clarksdale, Miss., to investigate crimes involving legendary bluesmen like Robert Johnson. The amateur sleuth in Bill Moody's books is a modern jazz pianist, and the sassy heroine of Charlotte Carter's mysteries plays tenor sax in avant-garde jazz clubs. And that's not even counting newcomers like Ray Sherwood, the saxman-sleuth who stumbles on a case of espionage while on tour with his 1940's dance band in Rupert Holmes's "Swing."

title: Nicole Jacobs and Brett Wigdortz
description: Nicole Brill Jacobs, a daughter of Carole Jacobs and Dr. Anthony Jacobs of Birmingham, England, is to be married today to Brett Harris Wigdortz, a son of Judith Wigdortz and Lawrence Wigdortz of West Long Branch, N.J. Rabbi David Booth is to officiate at the Ocean Place Spa and Resort in Long Branch, N.J.

title: 'Luck Is Luck'
Israeli Troops Kill 3 Teenagers in Buffer Zone at Gaza Border
description: JERUSALEM, April 9 - Israeli soldiers shot dead three Palestinian teenagers and wounded another in southern Gaza on Saturday, medics and witnesses told news agencies, after a group of five young men approached a buffer zone near the Israeli border. Witnesses said the young men, from the Rafah refugee camp, had been playing soccer.

title: In London, a Mean Street Turns Chic
description: AS one heads north, the elbow-to-elbow frenzy of flea market stalls, restaurants and shops that enlivens Portobello Road in west London abruptly ends just past the elevated Westway highway. Suddenly lined by undistinguished postwar housing, the road simply curves out of view. Yet continuing along this unpromising bend quickly yields a short stretch of shops that intersects with one of London's newly trendy addresses, Golborne Road.

title: 'The Position': Children of Paradise
description: THE POSITION By Meg Wilitzer

title: School Lotteries (2 Letters)
Maynard J. Ramsay, Insect Expert, Dies at 90
description: Dr. Maynard J. Ramsay, an entomologist noted for his efforts to track and eradicate exotic parasites carried in flowers, fruits and other cargoes arriving from overseas, died on March 20 at a nursing home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 90.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday with the special report on executive pay, about those who collected the most in one year during the last 25 years, referred incorrectly to one of them, Alfred Lerner, who got $195 million from MBNA for 2002. He died that year; he did not retire. His son, Randy, now owns and runs the Cleveland Browns, the National Football League expansion franchise that Mr. Lerner bought in 1998.

title: Corrections
description: Two photographs with the "Going To" column on March 27, about Istanbul, carried an incorrect credit. One on the cover (of an Ottoman-style mosque) and one on Page 11 (an overhead view of people eating near the fish bazaar in Beyoglu) were taken by Ashley Gilbertson.

title: Chalmers Roberts, Journalist, Dies at 94
description: Chalmers M. Roberts, a retired chief diplomatic correspondent for The Washington Post who covered the cold war, the nuclear arms race and the seats of power in Washington in the 1950's and 60's, died Friday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 94.

title: Coquette of the Walk
description: As street fashion meets runway fashion halfway, young women in Paris are mixing eclectic pieces with classic Parisian polish and savoir-wear. Fabrics inspired by West African batiks look as if they flew right out of a Senegalese market. Embroidery offers a hand-wrought touch, and slouchy bags and dangly jewelry reinforce bohemian chic. Some designers sell their wares at American stores and Web sites, and others take orders by phone from Paris. Smart girls, of course, jump on a plane.

title: DATEBOOK
description: CAYMAN ISLANDS

title: Enhancing Pitchers
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Democrats Criticize Republican Moves to Ban Filibuster
'Alibi': A Death in Venice
description: ALIBI By Joseph Kanon. 405 pp. Henry Holt & Company. $26.

title: Lyrical Images of New York City, in Sunset and Shadow
description: THE African-American artist Romare Bearden (1911-88), who is the subject of a national touring retrospective, has long enjoyed a reputation as one of the most innovative photographic-collage artists of the 20th century.

title: Decision Time on Cement
description: Because the mills of bureaucratic procedure grind exceedingly slow and fine, the bitter struggle over a proposed cement plant on the east bank of the Hudson River just south of Hudson, N.Y., is now well into its sixth year without a resolution. On one side is St. Lawrence Cement, a Canadian-based company with majority Swiss ownership that wants to close an old cement plant west of the river and build a giant new plant that would announce itself with a 40-story smokestack and dominate an 1,800-acre tract (including a 1,200-acre limestone quarry) running to the town's waterfront.

title: Working Out to Einstein
description: AMONG the mysteries Albert Einstein was not able to explain to his or anyone's satisfaction was the thorny relationship between science and religion. "Science without religion is lame, religion without science is blind," he wrote in 1941. This sibling relativity was not as tantalizing to Einstein as other enigmas, though. He was more intrigued by where the two overlapped than where they diverged, comparing the scientist to the Puritan in the search for truth.

title: 'Baseball Before We Knew It'
Paid Notice: Deaths   THOMAS, DANA L.
description: THOMAS--Dana L. On March 21. Author and associate editor of Barron's Weekly. Beloved husband of Melba, loving father of Peter. He was gifted with eloquence and passionate about the mysteries of the human spirit. Commemoration April 16; 206356-8724.

title: When Rates Rise, Do Bank Stocks Have to Fall?
description: MUTUAL funds that specialize in financial services surprised a lot of people last year by returning nearly 13 percent. All the while, many investors were pulling money out of them.

title: Bellow's Democratic Nobility of the Intellect
description: In this country we have hotels that are democratized versions of European palaces. We have parks that are democratized versions of royal hunting grounds. And we have the novels of Saul Bellow, which are European novels of ideas adapted to the idiom of the American wisenheimer.

title: On a Train Back To a Golden Age
description: WHEN the people who run Metro-North leave Manhattan to inspect a new bridge or a renovated station, they don't climb aboard the same trains that you and I ride. They travel in relics of a golden age.

title: Adding Balance to Retirement
description: NEW investors are often told to buy a balanced mutual fund, perhaps something like the Vanguard Star fund, as they begin their investment lives.

title: Staying True to the Tar Heels
description: Among the people celebrating North Carolina's national championship in men's college basketball last week was Vaughn D. Bryson, the former chief executive of Eli Lilly -- and a former first baseman for the university's baseball team.

title: As Pilgrims Depart, Romans Again Do as the Romans Do
description: ROME, April 9 - For the first time in a week, Giuseppe Foti stepped outside his home, a stone's throw from the Vatican, and did not have to worry about tripping over a pilgrim.

title: For American Royal Watchers, Wink-Wink, Nudge-Nudge
description: Correction Appended

title: On Schools: Does One Size Fit All?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweetening the Pot
description: Drill a pencil-thin hole in the trunk of a maple tree in late March, when the nights are frigid and the days thawing, and you can collect a good quantity of sap to boil down and make maple syrup. All you need is a steel spout that costs a little more than a dollar. Hammer it into the hole, and the tap will begin to drip instantly.

title: Woods and Bonds Are Targets of Prying
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Closed Loophole Hasn't Cut Subsidies for Student Loans
description: Months after Congress unanimously passed a law to cut back on what it called excess subsidies to student loan companies, federal payments to lenders are as high as ever and will probably remain that way for months to come, according to federal records and officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REYNOLDS, ROBERT
description: REYNOLDS--Robert, 81, died peacefully after a long illness on March 31. Beloved father of Stafford. He was a talented interior designer, WWII Navy veteran as well as a gentleman, creative spirit and kind friend. Robert's passion and inspired gift for beautification left a fine aesthetic impression on the world.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DRUICK, AUDREY NEE GRIFFIN
description: DRUICK--Audrey nee Griffin How fragile, how ephemeral in flight This life/for instance: butterfly, alight. We miss you every day. Love, Deborah, Philip and Charlie Griffin

title: THE GUIDE
description: Lobby by LeWitt

title: Corrections
description: An essay in the Book Review on March 27 about Harvard's current difficulties misstated the date of Lawrence H. Summers's appointment as the university's president. It was July 1, 2001, not in October (when his ceremonial installation took place). The essay also misstated the date of a report on curriculum reform at Harvard; it was April 2004, not 2003.

title: An East-West Trade Route Where the Currency Is Music
Island's Commuters Among the Most Stalwart
description: If extreme commuting were a spectator sport, television cameras apparently would need to go no farther than the Long Island Expressway to get prime footage of the action, based on data released recently by the Census Bureau.

title: A Culture of Death, Not Life
description: IT takes planning to produce a classic chapter in television history. "We've rehearsed," Thom Bird, a Fox News producer, bragged to Variety before Pope John Paul II died. "We will pull out all the stops on this story."

description: To the Editor:
