description: Weeks

title: Exotic but Cozy, a Moroccan Port Is a Second Home
description: IT'S the kind of place one first hears about in a yoga class, discussed in heated whispers between sun salutations. Or while eavesdropping on two model types with French accents in a cafe. About 10 years ago that place might have been Tulum, Mexico, but these days it's Essaouira, a tiny white-walled port city on Morocco's Atlantic coast.

title: U.S. Seeks Access to Bank Records to Deter Terror
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 - The Bush administration is developing a plan to give the government access to possibly hundreds of millions of international banking records in an effort to trace and deter terrorist financing, even as many bankers say they already feel besieged by government antiterrorism rules that they consider overly burdensome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, SIDNEY E.
description: KLEIN--Sidney E., 92, of Pompano Beach, FL passed away on Wednesday, April 6. Beloved husband of the late Sonia Klein. Loving father of Jane Klein Paradise, Keith Klein and Lawrence Klein. Proud grandfather of Jeffrey and Gregg Paradise and thrilled great-grandfather of Noah Seth Paradise. Donations may be made to The American Stroke Association, a division of The American Heart Association.

title: Denver Wins Title Again, With Stastny Scoring 2 Goals
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 9 - Should he wish to play hockey in the Olympics, Paul Stastny might have a difficult decision. He was born in Canada. He grew up in the United States. And his father, Peter Stastny, a hockey legend on two continents, was the general manager of Slovakia's team in the 2002 Winter Games.

title: A Statistical Holy Grail: The Search for the Winner Within
description: A glance at ordinary statistics -- points, assists, rebounds -- suggests Jason Kidd and Dwight Howard are two of the league's better players. Kidd, the Nets' starting point guard, is considered one of the league's silkiest passers, and Howard, a rookie forward for the Magic, is one of the top rebounders.

title: Journeys Into the Past and the Imagination
description: EXTREMELY LOUDAND INCREDIBLY CLOSE By Jonathan Safran Foer Houghton Mifflin ($24.95, hardcover)

title: College Admissions: It's Not What You Know, It's 'Who Knows How?'
description: A WEEK ago Thursday, Dana Lazarus, a senior at Livingston High School, knew that the odds of her having a good night's sleep were slim. Friday, April 1, was the day that she, like thousands of high school seniors throughout New Jersey, would find out whether she had been admitted to some of the top colleges to which she had applied.

title: The Genocide and the Box Office: Africa's Sequel
description: WHEN it opened five months ago, "Hotel Rwanda" garnered admiring reviews, especially for the performances of Don Cheadle and Sophie Okonedo. It went on to receive three Academy Award nominations and a raft of prizes. And it has been credited with increasing awareness of the 1994 genocide that killed some 800,000 Rwandans, most of them Tutsi.

title: High and Higher: One More Way to Ride the Wind
description: GIVEN the hazards of hang gliding, it is a bit disquieting to hear Mike Meier, an owner of the glider manufacturer Wills Wing, say that the trial and error method is integral to the company's design process. Rest assured, however, that Mr. Meier was not implying that test pilots are placed in unnecessary peril. The minor errors to which he referred affect in-flight speed and handling, not safety.

title: Narrowcasting Nightlife
description: Flavorpill Last year, the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council was about to hold one of its regular open-studio events -- showcasing work by artists in its residency program -- in donated space in the Woolworth Building. Mark Vevle, the director of marketing and communication for the council, says that after the first six weeks or so of promotion efforts, R.S.V.P. e-mail messages were "trickling" in. But starting on the Tuesday before the weekend event, there was a "huge spike" -- around 500 by Wednesday afternoon. What happened on Tuesday afternoon was that an online newsletter called Flavorpill touted the event. Ultimately, around 1,800 people came by the open studios that weekend. "We were thrilled," Vevle says.

title: Tough on Togo, Letting Zimbabwe Slide
description: JOHANNESBURG - EVEN the heads of state who were its members called the old Organization for African Unity a dictators' club, one reason why it was replaced three years ago by a new African Union that was modeled, in name and purpose, on Europe's own union. The old O.A.U. fulminated about colonialism and liberation, but was often silent on human rights and the consent of the governed. The new group, bowing to a democratic breeze blowing from Mali to Mauritius, stood for the premise that the rule of law is in, and despotism out.

title: Corrections: For the Record
Questions for Michael Eric Dyson
description: Cosby had the guts to lay it all on the line, and here comes Dyson with the expected rebuttal! Cosby has been so exactly on target with his criticisms that it's hard to imagine a learned man like Dyson (teen father, brother serving life in prison, years on welfare) could dispute Cosby's argument.

title: The Name Is the Address
description: IT is both the name and the address of a new restaurant in East Setauket -- 316 East Main -- although the name reveals nothing about the place. When I called to ask what kind of food diners could expect, the voice on the phone replied, "Continental with an Italian flair." Make that standard Italian with a few exotic items like elk and ostrich.

title: Editors' Choice
A Long, Hard Road for Tsunami Relief (2 Letters)
BEATING THE ODDS
description: Talk about the proverbial three strikes. Five years ago, Thomson Financial, the financial information company, asked Sharon Rowlands in its London office to come to New York and shake up the headquarters.

title: Goodbye to All That
description: Barbara Jakobson sees collecting as "a form of autobiography, as evidence of the fact that I lived for most of the last century and then into the new century." Over the last few decades, her Upper East Side town house came to contain an idiosyncratic blend of art and objects: photographs by Diane Arbus (whom Jakobson met at a Central Park playground in the 1950's, when their children were small); a 1940's light fixture designed for the Barton's candy-store chain by Victor Gruen, the architect who is often called the father of the shopping mall; paintings by Julian Schnabel, Peter Halley and Kenny Scharf. But it is Jakobson's double-height living room that is her signature. The room, with its big, curved 1950's sofa by Vladimir Kagan and its sinuous chairs by Jean Prouv and Carlo Mollino -- presided over by a 1971 wall relief by Frank Stella -- illustrates a sensibility that roved way ahead of its time, and in the process became something of a landmark.

title: 'I Got Somebody in Staunton': Visible Man
description: I GOT SOMEBODY IN STAUNTON Stories. By William Henry Lewis. 202 pp. Amistad/HarperCollins Publishers. $22.95.

title: The Story of Government Forms: A Real Page-Turner
description: TAX filers may be surprised this week to hear that they have it pretty good: their I.R.S.-mandated paperwork load is actually not so heavy. Not compared to the elderly of Wisconsin, Medicaid providers in Florida or immigrants, among others.

title: Why Is Monaco a Country?
Boy, 10, Missing in the Bronx; a 2nd Child Returns Home
description: In two separate cases, two 10-year-old boys, one in Queens and the other in the Bronx, were reported missing on Friday, prompting more than 30 fitful hours of searching by family members, friends and the police in both boroughs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RITTER, HELEN
description: RITTER--Helen. We will miss your friendship, your wisdom and wit. Jane, Paul, Jill and Rick

title: Belly Dancing
description: Correction Appended

title: A Fleeting Era's Timeless Chronicle
description: FEW places that F. Scott Fitzgerald inhabited over a short and shallow-rooted life infused his writing the way Long Island did.

title: On Schools: Does One Size Fit All? (6 Letters)
Simple Hearts and Coronets
description: You wanted something low-key, according to all the official statements, and your mother did too. So. Some paperwork in Windsor's Guildhall. A prayer service in the chapel. A short royal poem and a one-minute processional fanfare. Done.

title: Whitney Burrell and Anthony Holds
description: Whitney Alexis Burrell and Anthony Arnold Holds were married last evening on a beach at Harbour Island in the Bahamas. The Rev. Oswald Pinder, an Anglican priest, officiated.

title: Paperback Row
description: AT THE TOMB OF THE INFLATABLE PIG: Travels Through Paraguay, by John Gimlette. (Vintage Departures, $14.95.) "Paraguay is not merely isolated, it is almost impenetrable," Gimlette writes in this evocation of the country's eccentric and bloody history. The author, a London lawyer who originally intended to write a novel about Paraguay, tracks down the successive waves of misfits who have found refuge there: conquistadors, Nazis, Mennonites and more. Our reviewer, Ben Macintyre, called Gimlette's account "colorful and meandering, by turns hilarious and horrifying." Jan Morris's THE WORLD: Travels 1950-2000 (Norton, $16.95) compiles nearly 50 years of her travel journalism, beginning in Nepal with Edmund Hillary's climb of Everest and ending in Hong Kong with Britain's handover of the colony to China.

title: Mets Can't Find a New Way To Lose in Falling to 0-5
description: ATLANTA, April 9 - The Mets will still not admit to any desperation, only some remorse that they are making Willie Randolph wait so long to harvest a souvenir for his first victory as a major league manager.

title: Revising the Patriot Act
description: When Attorney General Alberto Gonzales, who is not exactly a renowned civil libertarian, says the Patriot Act may need some adjustments, it clearly has serious problems. The act, which was rushed through Congress after the Sept. 11 attacks, gives government too much power to invade the privacy of ordinary Americans and otherwise trample on their rights. Congress, which is now reviewing the act, should rewrite the parts that violate civil liberties. But it is important to realize that most of the worst post-Sept. 11 abuses did not stem from the Patriot Act. If Congress wants to restore the civil liberties Americans have lost in the last three and a half years, it must also look more broadly at the problems that have emerged from the war on terror.

title: Jo Frances Kaplan and John Meyer
description: JO FRANCES KAPLAN is a hard woman to keep up with.

title: And Aviva Will Be Played by . . .
description: TODD SOLONDZ, the twisted mind behind "Welcome to the Dollhouse" and "Happiness," has gone to extremes in all his films. Think of the rape looming over the heroine of "Welcome to the Dollhouse," or the obsessive masturbation in "Happiness."

title: The Quarter When Nothing Worked
description: IT'S why investors are taught to diversify: When one asset class falls, others are expected to rise, thereby safeguarding portfolios from across-the-board losses. But in the first three months of 2005, stock and bond funds lost money in lock step for the first quarter in eight years.

title: Operation Cure
description: Somehow, somewhere, Westchester Medical Center must get an immense cash transfusion or face the nightmarish prospect of bankruptcy. Operation Cure, its latest and most awkwardly titled recovery plan, maps a route to stability that relies on an annual $20 million each from the county, state and federal governments, $20 million in union concessions and $20 million in cost savings.

title: Brand
description: When the New Yorker reporter Jeffrey Goldberg asked Senator John Kerry whether the Democrats had a credibility problem on defense controversies, the party's titular leader replied without equivocation, "Look, the answer is, we have to do an unbranding." As Kerry saw it, the political problem had to do with salesmanship: "We have to brand more effectively. It's marketing." An editor on the linguistic qui vive titled Goldberg's article about the Democrats' need to shuck off the appearance of weakness "The Unbranding."

title: PLAZA DORREGO, FEB. 27, 2005
description: Katharina Wiest, left , 21, from Stuttgart, Germany, with a friend, Claudia Manthey. "Last year, I did volunteer work in Santiago, Chile, in a kindergarten. Now I'm traveling for half a year before I start to study. I'm kind of addicted to South America and to the liberty that I've got here in everyday life. I love to speak Spanish, and I want to know all about this continent. There's so much life in the streets of Buenos Aires. The tango performances are every Sunday at the Plaza Dorrego. The tango dancers are young Argentinians who want to make the tango more popular. It's incredible that a dance can be so perfect in its moves, and with so much passion. I think every woman and every man wants to be like the two dancers, wants to fascinate a crowd of people, wants to dance and live in harmony." As told to Seth Kugel

title: In New Jersey, Lasting Effects From a Ruptured Water Line
description: More than 160,000 residents in central New Jersey must continue to boil water before drinking or cooking and take other precautions until at least today because of possible contamination following a huge water main rupture near the banks of the Raritan River in Bound Brook.

title: Will the Next Version of Windows Be Worth the Wait?
description: TEN years ago, Microsoft unveiled Windows 95 in a way that suggested that the product's arrival was no less momentous than when humans stood upright for the first time. The company spent about $200 million introducing the operating system. That paid for festivities on the Microsoft campus (with Jay Leno as M.C.), rights to use the Rolling Stones song "Start Me Up" in a global advertising campaign and permission to bathe the Empire State Building at night with the Windows logo. It also loaded The Times of London with Windows 95 advertising that day, making the newspaper a one-day freebie, a first in its 307 years.

title: A Tax Increase That Bush Didn't Mention
description: WASHINGTON - CYNICS have long predicted that the Bush administration, plagued by budget deficits, will eventually start raising taxes. But now it is becoming clear how it would do so: the alternative minimum tax.

title: Corrections
description: The Check In/Check Out column in the Travel section on March 20, about the Radisson Edwardian May Fair Hotel in London, gave an incorrect figure for the lowest possible room rate. A correction on Page 2 in some copies of the section today misstates the current rate; it is no less than $262 -- not $22.

title: In a Bid to Ban Cars, a Little Bit of Quixote
description: On a nice day, the stretch of Bedford Avenue that runs through Williamsburg, Brooklyn, resembles some combination of flea market and fashion runway. On weekend nights, it is a sort of linear nightclub. Other times, the exotic plumage of its inhabitants recalls the rare bird room at the local zoo.

title: Sara Guardino and Jeffrey Colket
description: Sara Daniele Guardino and Jeffrey Tristram Colket were married yesterday at the Castle, a Tudor-style mansion on the campus of Boston University. The Rev. Maddie Sifantus, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

title: 'Malraux'
Please Get Me Out of Here
description: LAST week, when the news broke that Ming Kuang Chen, a deliveryman for a Chinese restaurant, had emerged from a stalled elevator in a 38-story Bronx apartment building after some 81 hours in captivity, not a few New Yorkers skipped accounts of the city's usual mayhem to study the details of Mr. Chen's ordeal.

title: Potential Housing at a Former Psychiatric Hospital
description: To the Editor:

title: At a Subway Stop in Flux, Waiting to Exhale (and Exit)
description: They have a foggy sense of when it began -- January, perhaps? (It was actually September.) But subway riders in the Bronx who use the busy 231st Street station of the No. 1 and 9 trains, in Kingsbridge and serving many residents of Riverdale, are clearly annoyed by the continuing construction at their station, and wonder why, after all these months, the work hasn't been completed.

title: Marrying Outside the Box
description: Married or single? For most taxpayers, that's one of the easy boxes to check on the dreary 1040's. But for roughly 5,000 Massachusetts couples this year, deciding how to answer that question is both personally and politically troubling. On May 17, 2004, Massachusetts began applying the nation's first gender-neutral civil-marriage law, a gay rights breakthrough that launched a flotilla of giddy weddings. Since then, pundits have been warning of an imminent showdown between Massachusetts marriages and the national government's 1996 Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA). Passed by Congress and signed by President Bill Clinton, DOMA defined marriage for federal purposes as being between one man and one woman. As a result, Massachusetts couples face a peculiar double reality: they are married in Massachusetts and single in the United States.

description: The state law, conceived in Brooklyn and signed in 2003, was straightforward: "The use or placing of posters or stickers on windshields or rear windows of motor vehicles other than those authorized by the commissioner is hereby prohibited."

title: Questions for Michael Eric Dyson
description: 'It takes a village" is but one African proverb. Here's another, "The ruin of a nation begins in the homes of its people."

description: SUNDAY 4/10

title: 'No Place to Hide'
Australia Uneasy About U.S. Detainee Case
description: SYDNEY, Australia - The Australian government, which has been one of the strongest supporters of the Bush administration's policy on the detention and prosecution of people suspected of being members of Al Qaeda, is growing uneasy with the handling of the case of one its citizens who has languished in the prison camp at Guantnamo Bay for more than three years.

title: The Other Stem-Cell Debate
description: Except for the three million human brain cells injected into his cranium, XO47 is just an average green vervet monkey. He weighs about 12 pounds and measures 34 inches from the tip of his tail to the sutured incision on the top of his head. His fur is a mlange of black, yellow and olive, with white underparts and a coal-black face. Until his operation, two days before I met him, he was skittering about an open-air enclosure on the grounds of a biomedical facility on the Caribbean island of St. Kitts. Afterward, he was caged in a hut shared with half a dozen other experimental monkeys, all of whom bore identical incisions in their scalps. Judging from the results of previous experiments, the human neural stem cells inserted into their brains would soon take hold and begin to grow, their fibers reaching out to shake hands with their monkey counterparts. The green vervets' behavior was, and will remain, all monkey. To a vervet, eye contact signals aggression, and when I peered into X047's cage, he took umbrage, vigorously bobbing his head in a stereotypical threat display. Still, it was hard not to stare.

title: Up Front
description: FEW words are so frequently used -- and abused -- as "Orwellian." But Robert O'Harrow Jr.'s "No Place to Hide" and Patrick Radden Keefe's "Chatter" make the case that somebody is watching -- although as the recent articles about grand-scale identity theft show, it isn't necessarily who you think it is. In a long overdue return to our pages, William Safire, who recently ended his 32-year tenure as an Op-Ed columnist for The New York Times, lays out the threats to Americans' personal privacy from the secret world we know to be wary of, the high-tech realm of government eavesdropping, and the one we enter unsuspectingly every time we fill out a product warranty card.

title: 'Chatter'
Who Needs Two?

title: Our Ratings, Ourselves
description: The Mismeasure of TV One of the great contradictions of modern American life is that almost everyone watches television while almost no one agrees anymore about what it really means to watch television. True, we know that as spring gets under way, new episodes of "Desperate Housewives" and "C.S.I." and "American Idol" will battle for prime-time supremacy in the overnight Nielsen ratings. We also know that local broadcast stations around the country will begin scheming -- just as they do every April -- to win the May sweeps, the tense weeks when rival stations pursue a fierce one-upmanship of flamboyance and hype and the Nielsen-measured audience sizes determine future advertising rates. But when it comes to figuring out how many of us are watching these shows, and whether we're paying attention while we're watching and even whether we're actually noticing the advertisements among the shows we may or may not be watching -- well, this is where things get tricky.

He was also a crisis manager and corporate communications consultant for major companies, including Microsoft, Apple Computer, BristolMyers, Cybear and Andrx. Stoller co-founded eRaider .com, the only website dedicated to shareholder activism for the retail investor. The website received two "Best of the Web" designations from Forbes and the mutual fund launched the first Internet-based proxy contest. The Play Shakespeare Wrote for Plebes
description: BACK when Shakespeare was more reliably a fixture on the junior high curriculum, "Julius Caesar" was the play most students started out with. It was assigned for the same reason that Dickens's "Tale of Two Cities" was -- because it was shorter than most of the author's other work. And if it wasn't entirely representative of the rest, just as "Tale" is not, that was in this case actually a virtue. "Caesar" isn't sexy (unlike "Romeo and Juliet," the other play often assigned to ninth graders); it's not weighed down by a subplot; and it's set in ancient Rome, which to many Americans is a far more familiar place than Tudor London. "Caesar" isn't Shakespeare lite, exactly, but it can sometimes seem like Shakespeare on training wheels.

title: A French Director Who Specializes in the Horror Beneath the Hauteur
description: ARNAUD DESPLECHIN, who has directed six movies since 1991, is one of the most intriguing French filmmakers of his generation: those directors, mostly in their 40's, who came up in the long shadow of the new wave, too young to have participated in the tumult of the 1960's but too close to that decade to shake off its hangover. He is also among the most puzzling. His work, the subject of retrospectives starting this week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio, is always challenging, sometimes elusive and often difficult to categorize. Is he a moderate or an extremist? An exponent of civilization or an avatar of savagery? Are his movies meant to be brutally naturalistic or elaborately artificial? Comedies or catastrophes? title: Touring an America Tocqueville Could Fathom

Religious terror? Tocqueville, an aristocratic French lawyer, wrote his classic text after a nine-month visit to the United States in 1831. And far from being saturated with terror, it is a refined, detached series of reflections on the effects of American democracy on character, commerce, culture and belief: why the arts in America are more concerned with utility than beauty, why Americans tend to be restless, why democracy encourages a passionate spirituality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURPHY, GAVIN PALMER
description: MURPHY -- Gavin Palmer. May 26, 1926-April 7, 2005. Beloved husband of Margaretha. Devoted father of Palmer. Survived by brother Vincent B. Murphy Jr. of Bedminster, NJ, and wife Patricia; sister Sheelagh Masterson Castleman of New York and Watch Hill, RI; nine nephews and nieces, their spouses and many children. He was a charismatic persona with boundless curiosity and interests. A beacon of strength and character, as well as being a character, he shared his mischievous humor and keen insight and opinions enriching the lives of those he touched. He graduated from Tufts College (A.B.), Harvard Law School (J.D.) and was a member of Phi Beta Kappa (Magna Cum Laude). He was Counsel to J.P. Stevens & Co. Inc.; Standards Brands Inc., and Director and Counsel to Fiduciary Counsel Inc., having previously been associated with the law firm Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer and Wood. He was also Arbitrator and Mediator, The American Bar Association; Vice Chairman, American Bar Association Corporate Counsel Committee; President, Lawyers Association of the Textile and Apparel Industries; Chairman, Legal Committee, American Textile Manufacturers Institute; Trustee, Mercy College; Governor and Secretary, The West Side Tennis Club (Forest Hills); Founder and President, Friendly Homes Inc. (organization providing half-way homes for mentally disturbed adolescents); Program Producer, In Touch Networks; Vice President and Secretary, as well as Editor of The Recorder, American Irish Historical Society; Director, The Historical Records of the New York County Clerk, Inc.; Member of the United States 1968 Olympic Team. Taught international commercial law at New York University; textile and apparel related law at Cordozo Law School and mathematics at Northeastern University. He served in the Navy from 1943-1945. A Mass of Resurrection will be celebrated Friday, April 22, 3:30 pm, at the Church of St. Thomas More, 65 E. 89 Street, New York City.

title: Arts, Briefly; The Jobims Sue
description: The family of the Brazilian composer Antonio Carlos Jobim, whose undulating tunes helped begin the bossa nova movement, has sued Universal Studios, contending that the company illegally assigned ownership rights to the author of the English lyrics of some of his songs. The suit was filed Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan by Ana Beatriz Lontra Jobim, the widow of Jobim, who died in 1994, and their three children. The composer's heirs charge that Universal Studios, "in a remarkable display of hubris and overreaching," violated 1960's contracts when it recently granted the worldwide copyright of the English lyrics to four of Jobim's songs to their author, Norman Gimbel. The suit contends that Mr. Gimbel was hired to write the lyrics without receiving rights to them. The songs include "The Girl From Ipanema," which Jobim wrote with Portuguese lyrics in 1962 with Vincius de Moraes. Universal did not respond immediately to a telephone call seeking comment. JULIA PRESTON

description: FERENTZ--Leslie B. Died April 9th. Family and friends mourn the passing of this 87 year old master story teller and decorated WWII combat vet. A gifted salesman in the drug sundries trade, he was also the Secretary of the Rosedale Jewish Center and Independent Wizner Society. In 1958 he was Worshipful Master of Beethoven Lodge 661. He was a generous man who enjoyed a good joke, a good meal, a good book, and good classical music. He will be dearly missed by Sylvia, his wife of 65 years, his daughters Maris and Cheryl, and son Kevin, their spouses, his daughter-in-law Satu, his eleven grandchildren (and three spouses), and his three great-granddaughters. The funeral will be held today at Schwatz Bros, in Forest Hills. The family will sit shiva in Queens, Poughkeepsie and Baltimore. On the court, the sisters have won 11 major singles titles. Serena is currently ranked No. 4 in the world and Venus is No. 8. description: About 160,000 customers in central New Jersey no longer have to boil tap water before using it for drinking or cooking. The company that provides the water, New Jersey American Water, lifted an advisory yesterday that was put into effect after a water main ruptured here on Friday near the Raritan River. The advisory had been issued as a precautionary measure in Somerset, Middlesex and Union Counties because of the possibility of contamination, but no evidence of contamination was found in sample tests, officials said. The cause of the rupture remained unclear, according to a spokeswoman for New Jersey American Water. Workers said the rupture was probably caused by repeated river flooding in recent years shifting the ground around the pipe. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: More Spies, Worse Intelligence?
description: WASHINGTON - AS the Senate begins confirmation hearings today for John D. Negroponte as director of national intelligence, it would do well to ask his opinion of President Bush's decision in November to have Porter Goss, the director of central intelligence, increase by 50 percent the number of clandestine officers at the C.I.A. Certainly, we need more and better spies. But as a former operations officer at the agency, I would argue that a mandate to beef up the clandestine service -- also known as the directorate of operations -- by a rather arbitrary percentage within a short time is a potentially insurmountable task and could well result in hiring practices that hurt the agency rather than help it.

description: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners, the nation's second-largest energy pipeline partnership, has agreed to buy seven bulk terminals for $245 million to capitalize on increasing shipments of petroleum coke, a refining byproduct. The seller, Trans-Global Solutions, will receive about $184 million in cash and $46 million in partnership units at closing, which is expected by the end of this month, Kinder Morgan said yesterday. Closely held Trans-Global will get an additional $15 million in partnership units in two years. The terminals, all located in Texas, are expected this year to handle 10 million tons of petroleum coke, a residue from crude-oil refining used as a fuel for power generation and cement kilns. Kinder Morgan said the terminal purchase would make the partnership the nation's biggest handler of petroleum coke, with market share of about 33 percent. Both companies are based in Houston.

Gladys had deep compassion for all people and was always concerned about those less fortunate, struggling with poverty, family issues and childcare concerns. Her kindness and strong spirit will be missed. Natly Esnard, President Don Bluestone, Exec. Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAUPTMAN, PHILIP JONATHAN
description: HAUPTMAN--Philip Jonathan, died April 10 at the age of 63. A caring geriatric psychiatrist, devoted to his patients far beyond the call of duty. Surving him are his wife, Natalie, his sister Rabbi Judith, his brother-in-law, Milton Adesnik, and his three nephews, Ariel, Moshe, and Hillel. Funeral services at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Tuesday, April 12 at 12 noon, Amsterdam Ave. and W. 91st St. Philip loved life and loved people. He lived fully and with great joy. He leaves a legacy of tireless, unstinting efforts on behalf of others. May we follow in his footsteps. Contributions may be sent to Doctors Without Borders to honor a doctor who himself crossed over many borders-physical, spiritual, and psychological--to help others. He will be sorely missed.

title: Infant Care: Drinks Before Nursing? No Need
description: New mothers who want to breast-feed have long been advised, even by health care workers, to have a drink to help them relax and produce milk. The recommended drink varies -- often it is beer, sometimes it is wine -- but the advice has popped up in cultures around the world for centuries.

title: Wakefield Knows Disappointment, and He Likes Victory Better
description: BOSTON, April 11 - The exasperation at his team's collapse against the Boston Red Sox in a stunning blitz of four straight losses last October had sunk in for Joe Torre. He knew there were no more games for his Yankees, no more decisions for him and an eternity to dissect the most monumental choke in baseball history.

title: Columbia Revamps Process for Students' Grievances
description: Stung by students' complaints that it had not taken their charges of intimidation in the classroom seriously, Columbia University announced new procedures yesterday that offered a variety of ways for students to file grievances.

description: ROSENBERG--Ruth. On April 11th, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Melvin Rosenberg, DDS. Devoted mother of Nancy and Dr. William J. Chernack. Services Wednesday, 2 P.M. at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: New York and New Jersey
World Briefing | Asia: India: Dam Kills Hindu Pilgrims
description: The authorities reported that at least 54 Hindu pilgrims bathing last week in what is regarded as a holy river drowned when a dam 12 miles upstream unexpectedly let loose a barrage of water. The incident happened Thursday on the banks of the Narmada in Madhya Pradesh State. Officials said more than 200,000 Hindu pilgrims had gathered for immersion in the river, an annual ritual. The news came to light yesterday, as bodies were recovered. Reuters quoted an official of the state-run dam as saying that dam workers were unaware of the pilgrims downstream. The state government ordered an inquiry. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: AOL seeks more Web users with a radio tie-up
Paid Notice: Deaths   HALLENBECK, ELEANOR C.
description: HALLENBECK--Eleanor C., of Sarasota, FL, and South Dartmouth, MA., died April 10th 2005, at the age of 72. The great, great granddaughter of Corning Glass Works founder Amory Houghton, Mrs. Hallenbeck was born in Corning, NY in 1932 to Eleanor Houghton Cole and Glen Walker Cole, a former President of Corning Glass Works. She was the niece of Amory Houghton, who served as Chairman of Corning Glass Works and subsequently as U.S. Ambassador to France in the late 1950s. She was also the granddaughter of Alanson B. Houghton, the former U.S. Ambassador to Germany and to the Court of St. James. Raised in both Corning and Manhattan, Mrs. Hallenbeck married William Hallenbeck in September of 1960 and settled in Sarasota, raising three children, Wilson R. Page, Peter T. Page and William W. Hallenbeck, Jr. between homes in Florida and Massachusetts. She was actively involved in giving to charitable causes such as Sarasota Memorial Hospital, The United Way, The New Bedford Historical Society, The Salvation Army and The Triangle Fund. Mrs. Hallenbeck is survived by her three sons, her grandchildren Stephen Hallenbeck, Alex Hallenbeck, Justin Page, David Page, Sarah Page and Matthew Page, and her sister, Adelaide Griswold. "Our fear of death is like our fear that summer will be short, but when we have had our swing of pleasure, our fill of fruit, and our swelter of heat we say we have had our day." Ralph Waldo Emerson

title: Visa Job Is Said to Go to Shepardson Stern
Paid Notice: Deaths   SEBBA, SAMUEL
description: SEBBA -- Samuel. Yeshiva University and its Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies mourn the loss of this distinguished Jewish leader and philanthropist who was a founding member of the Board of Directors of BRGS. From his homes in London and Israel, Mr. Sebba generously supported many institutions of higher education under Jewish auspices over the course of his long and active life. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Mordecai D. Katz, Chairman BRGS Board of Directors Arthur Hyman, BRGS Dean

title: A Double Bill of Loves and the Inevitable Losses
description: It can be thrilling when one performance in an earthbound double bill abruptly takes off, pulling the enterprise into the realm of feeling and belief. Using little more than an accent and standing under a strategically placed spotlight, Kelli Holsopple persuades you that you are not in a restaurant bar in the East Village watching Romulus Linney's music-inflected one-act play "Can Can," but in France, with her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSE, HAROLD J., DDS
description: ROSE--Harold J., DDS, Dorset, VT, 90, died peacefully at his Miami Beach home on April 9. Graduated 1949 Temple School of Dentistry; member AO and John Kolmer Honorary Society; 25 year practice in Bayside; then 5 years in Manchester Center, VT. With the late Dr. Saul Kaman, he treated the developmentally challenged at Queens General and seniors at LI Jewish Geriatric Center. Leaving his loving wife of 55 years, Mildred, children Steve (Kathy), Martha, John; beloved granddaughter Julia; caring brother, Dr. Murray Rose. Devoted to his family, profession and world peace. Graveside service Sunday April 17, 10AM, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, LI.

description: WHERE Social Security is concerned, younger Americans are more likely to see the glass as half empty, while older Americans are more inclined to see it as half full, according to a recent nationwide New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Sentenced In Stabbing
description: A man was sentenced to 30 years in prison yesterday after a Manhattan jury convicted him of stabbing his ex-girlfriend in the neck in a jealous rage, leaving her partly paralyzed. The man, Trevor Frederick, was convicted in a retrial on charges of attempted murder, burglary and assault for the 2003 stabbing of Jenae Aragosa, a Fashion Institute of Technology student from Yonkers. On Nov. 7, 2003, Ms. Aragosa returned to her apartment on the Upper West Side with a date, Christopher Mariconi, and Mr. Frederick walked into her room and stabbed her in the neck, partially severing her spinal cord. Mr. Mariconi died after falling out a window of the apartment. Prosecutors charged Mr. Frederick with murder in Mr. Mariconi's death, but the jury deadlocked on that charge. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: The Modernist vs. the Mystics
description: The new exhibition "3 x Abstraction: New Methods of Drawing," at the Drawing Center, invites us to ponder the relationship between abstraction and spirituality in modern art. It's a beautiful and thought-provoking show, though one of the three artists presented is different enough from the others to create some philosophical confusion.

title: NCR, A MAKER OF A.T.M.'S, RAISES PROFIT ESTIMATES
description: The NCR Corporation, whose chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, left for the top job at Hewlett-Packard, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit would be at least 16 cents a share, higher than an earlier forecast of 2 cents to 5 cents a share, because of strong sales of its automated teller machines, checkout scanners and data warehousing products. NCR, which will report first-quarter results on April 28, also raised its full-year earnings expectations. NCR said it expected to report quarterly revenue of $1.34 billion, up 4 percent from the same quarter last year. Mr. Hurd, who was named chief executive of Hewlett-Packard on March 29, cut costs and increased sales of higher-profit software at NCR. The company is based in Dayton, Ohio.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Protesting In Pajamas
description: Nurses in North West Province have begun wearing pajamas and nightgowns to work to protest what they regard as a paltry uniform allowance, leading the provincial health department to threaten severe penalties "against those who continue to confuse our patients and turn our facilities into bedrooms." Members of the Democratic Nurses Association of South Africa began the protest two weeks ago by wearing street clothes to work, then escalated to nightwear after demands for a higher allowance went unmet. The national Health Department has said that it plans to address the problem with a higher nationwide uniform allowance. Michael Wines (NYT)

description: The Bush administration has mounted a surreptitious new attack on Title IX, the 33-year-old law that has exponentially expanded the participation of girls and women in sports.

Standoff Ends in Surrender in New Jersey; Hostages Safe
description: LOPATCONG TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 11 - A man abducted his 4-month-old daughter and her mother on Monday in Irvington, N.J., then led the police on a high-speed chase that ended in a tense seven-and-a-half-hour standoff with the police here in western New Jersey, the authorities said. He finally surrendered in the evening at the urging of his mother and his sister, officials said.

title: Halliburton Unit's Work in Iraq Is Called 'Poor'
description: Serious cost overruns and "poor performance" have plagued the Halliburton Company's continuing $1.2 billion contract to repair Iraq's vital southern oil fields, a new State Department report says.

description: MADISON Avenue's going for game shows, and quiz shows too, not to mention talent shows.

title: GOODYEAR SECURES LOWER-INTEREST LOANS AND CREDIT LINES
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it had secured $3.65 billion in new loans and credit lines to replace $3.28 billion of financing with higher interest rates. The new borrowings run through at least 2010, replacing debt with higher rates expiring in 2005, 2006 and 2007, Goodyear said. J.P. Morgan Chase, Citigroup, Deutsche Bank and BNP Paribas last month offered Goodyear lower interest margins on most of its loans after the tire manufacturer reported on March 16 its first full-year profit since 2000, people close to the transaction said last month. Goodyear is based in Akron, Ohio.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Middletown: Mayor Resigns After Misdemeanor Convictions
description: The mayor of Middletown resigned yesterday, days after he was found guilty of two misdemeanors in Orange County Court. Mayor Joseph DeStefano was cleared on 50 of the more-serious criminal charges by an Orange County judge last week, but the convictions required that he step down, the city's lawyer said. Mr. DeStefano, who became mayor in 1994, was indicted last year on charges that he steered $140,000 in federal money to benefit his own local businesses. He was convicted only for failing to disclose his financial interests on two ethics forms required by the town. The town's Common Council president, Marlinda Duncanson, was sworn in as interim mayor last night and has announced plans to run for mayor in November. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: 8 Guilty Of Taking Public Funds
description: Eight government officials, including two former deputy ministers, were found guilty of embezzling public money by a Kabul court in the first high-level corruption trial in Afghanistan in three years, according to national television. The officials worked for the Ministry of the Hajj, which organizes pilgrimages to Saudi Arabia. They received sentences of one year in prison to three, as well as fines. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

description: WALSH--Richard J., Jr. 92, retired book publisher, died April 7, 2005 in Bedford, MA. He was the President of the John Day Co. (NYC). He is survived by sister, Elizabeth Churchill, two sons: Jeremy A. Walsh, David H. Walsh, six grandchildren and three great grandchildren.

title: Strength in Number Crunchers
description: Every once in a while, an idea comes along that's so breathtakingly sensible it immediately demands support. Such is the case of a proposal from five professional associations that represent actuaries, which say the chief number crunchers hired by the federal government to crunch numbers should actually be bona fide number crunchers.

description: The Publicis Groupe in Paris said yesterday that it had formed a unit made up of all its public relations, public affairs and corporate communications operations, with 1,300 employees in 25 countries.

title: With Rings and Then a Rout, It's a Great Day for the Red Sox
description: BOSTON, April 11 - The Yankees have never debated the merits of the Boston Red Sox' achievement. To the Yankees, there was nothing cheap or fluky about it. The Red Sox stormed back to beat them in the playoffs last fall, then charged through the World Series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WARNER, ROBERT C.
description: WARNER--Robert C. Professor Emeritus, Molecular Biology and Biochemistry, School of Biological Sciences, University of California at Irvine, died March 25th, 2005. Beloved husband of Estelle; father of Peter, Jisho and Victoria and stepfather of Ruth Anderson. He did his undergraduate work at California Institute of Technology, received his PhD from NYU in 1941 and was Professor of Biochemistry at NYU Medical School from 1946 until 1969, and Chairman of the Department and Professor of Molecular Biology and Biochemistry at Irvine beginning in 1969. He did pioneering work in the mechanisms of genetic recombination.

title: Women Struggle for Parity of the Heart
description: Women are thought to be far more concerned about affairs of the heart than men. But when it comes to diseases of the heart, women and their doctors are paying far too little attention.

title: The Old Curiosity Mall
description: Just before the collapse of his childhood fortunes, Charles Dickens lived with his family in Ordnance Terrace in the shipbuilding town of Chatham, east of London. His boyhood was bordered, to the north, by the Medway River and the dockyards, but to the south and east the town quickly turned into open country. Those years, between the ages of 5 and 10, were among the happiest in Dickens's life. And so it has seemed fitting to the South East Development Agency to pay tribute to the role that Chatham (and nearby Rochester) played in Dickens's life by creating "Dickens World," an entertainment complex including rides with a Dickens theme on the site of the former naval docks. Construction will begin soon, and the opening is scheduled for 2007.

title: Issue for Cardinals: Islam as Rival or Partner in Talks
description: ROME, April 11 - One is from Nigeria, a man who grew up among Muslims and says there is no clash of cultures. Another is from Germany, and believes that it may be useful to talk to Muslims but that it is better to revitalize Christianity. Others speak of the need for Muslims in Europe to integrate better or even to become more secular.

title: Safety: More Child Golfers, More Injuries
description: More and more children are taking up golf. But as they do, a good number of them are ending their day in the emergency room instead of the clubhouse.

title: Pensions: Big Holes in the Net
description: JAMES McDONALD, a former New York longshoreman, worked for 23 years under a pension plan that greatly penalized people who took time off in midcareer. He himself had such a gap: he worked for 13 years, then took three years off for medical reasons before working another 10. When he retired in 1997, he began receiving a pension of $263 a month, an amount reflecting just his last 10 years of service. The plan said his first 13 years did not count.

title: In Kosovo, on the edge of disaster
Naming Train Station for Pope Brings Mixed Reaction in Rome
description: ROME, April 11 - Some popes have bridges named after them. Others have been remembered in the names of streets or piazzas. But to commemorate John Paul II, known for his travels, the city has settled on a more modern concept.

title: Notes From March Fed Meeting Show Concerns Over Inflation
A Political Dispute Puts a City in the Dark
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, April 8 - Looking to increase its cash flow in Brazil, the American energy giant, the AES Corporation, has been busy doing what power distributors everywhere do when customers fail to pay their bills: pulling the plug. But when it cut the lights recently at 85 buildings owned by the city government of So Paulo, it was dragged into the middle of an ugly political fight.

title: About These Listings
description: This page now carries listings for 29 additional channels and more program details for the existing ones. To accommodate the expansion, to 105 channels, the highlights section has been redesigned and lengthened, the Late Movies section discontinued and the daytime entries replaced by expanded listings of news and talk shows for today and tomorrow morning. These changes are a response to the increased offerings of cable providers in the New York area and the widespread availability of all-day programming guides on television and the Internet. Morning, afternoon and late-night listings for the entire week will continue to appear, with an expanded prime-time guide, in the Television section on Sundays.

title: Yale Ending Its Affiliation With a Church
description: NEW HAVEN, April 10 - After asking God to help two boys with cancer and a family that had just lost an uncle, the congregants of Battell Chapel at Yale University bowed their heads on Sunday and improvised a prayer for another group in need: themselves.

description: PARIS, April 11 - A deadline to take action before the World Trade Organization came and went Monday, with the United States and the European Union instead saying they would try again to agree on what constitutes acceptable government aid to Airbus and Boeing, the trans-Atlantic rivals.

title: Cleanup Plan Advances for Old Reactor at Brookhaven Lab
description: Several federal agencies approved a plan yesterday for cleaning up an old nuclear reactor at the Brookhaven National Laboratory, marking a significant turn in the history of one of oldest atomic research centers in the country and the Long Island community that wanted every trace of the reactor removed.

title: 'Extreme Textiles' Come of Age
description: A knitted bag holds a weakened heart, helping it pump blood. Electricity flows through the threads of a battery-powered fleece jacket, keeping the wearer warm. Carbon fibers are braided into structures that look like mushrooms, but are actually prototypes of automotive engine valves. Other fibers are shaped into bicycle frames and sculling oars.

title: Military Raid in Baghdad Captures 65, Officials Say
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 11 - Hundreds of Iraqi troops and commandos backed by American soldiers swept through central and southern Baghdad early Monday morning, capturing at least 65 suspected insurgents in one of the largest raids in the capital since the fall of Saddam Hussein, military officials said.

title: Bikinis Invade Ceylon, and Knives Hit the Floor
description: The new "Pearl Fishers" that arrived at the New York City Opera on Sunday afternoon came from the San Diego Opera, but it looks as if it came from the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games. Maybe it was the fluorescent hues; or the attempt to create local color with tinselly choreography; or the stylized patterns painted on the stage, like sun on sand, and the women's bikinis, which evoked a recent addition to the Games, beach volleyball.

title: New U.S. Coach Ready to Go
description: Greg Ryan, the new coach of the United States women's national team, does not want his players to relinquish their swagger or cede the high ground to the competition from Germany, Sweden and Norway.

title: Overdue Celebration Is Right on Time
description: BOSTON - GROWING up in the heart of Red Sox Nation except it wasn't called Red Sox Nation then -- Phil Dunlavey used to hear grim tales of terrible things that had befallen the Red Sox over the decades.

title: Arts, Briefly; Tiger Wins the Day, Not the Night
description: When Tiger Woods, below, wins, golf's television ratings jump. CBS's broadcast of the final round of the Masters, a tense contest between Mr. Woods and Chris DiMarco, was up 41 percent from last year's Sunday telecast of the tournament, won by Phil Mickelson. Though Mr. Woods's victory came down to a one-hole playoff that spilled into prime time on the East Coast, the resulting ratings spike was not enough to propel CBS into the top slot for the night. It placed second to ABC in viewers and among adults 18 to 49. A dark episode of "Desperate Housewives," in which Carlos (Ricardo Chavira) went from bully to abuser as he forced Gabrielle (Eva Longoria) to sign a legal agreement not to divorce him when he goes to prison, was the most-watched show of the night, bringing in an estimated 25.08 million viewers. Following "Housewives" was "Grey's Anatomy," the upstart medical show that stole away the "Boston Legal" time slot, bumping that show's remaining episodes to the fall. It got its highest ratings yet, and was watched by an audience of 18.36 million. KATE AURTHUR

The report, by Mark Washburn, was published in North Carolina on Sunday in The Charlotte Observer. title: Video Lottery Terminals in New York Are Not Paying Off as Planned
description: ALBANY, April 11 - New York State's plan to rely on gambling parlors full of slot-machine-like video lottery terminals to help finance increases in education aid is not paying off nearly as much as officials had hoped, state data shows.

title: Filing Offers First Look at Lazard's Books
description: Bruce Wasserstein laid bare guarded details of Lazard's finances in a new filing yesterday for the investment bank's proposed initial public offering. The filing offered a first look into the secretive bank's ledgers, including lucrative compensation packages for Mr. Wasserstein and others.

title: At deadline, EU and U.S. put off clash on air subsidies
MCI Said to Want Higher Offer From Verizon
description: MCI's board is likely to seek a sweetened takeover offer from Verizon Communications, an executive close to the company said yesterday.

title: Arts, Briefly; Webb and Campbell, Together Again
description: The songwriter Jimmy Webb, right, says that for the first time in years, he and Glen Campbell are recording an album together. In the late 1960's, Mr. Campbell's recordings of Mr. Webb's wistful country-pop compositions "By the Time I Get to Phoenix," "Wichita Lineman," "Galveston" and "Where's the Playground Susie" were Billboard Top 40 hits. They have remained staples on oldie and adult contemporary radio stations. The pair also recorded together at various times between 1974 and 1988. Of the hundreds of artists in various genres who have sung his tunes, from the actor Richard Harris on "MacArthur Park" to the Brooklyn Bridge on the underrated "Worst That Could Happen," Mr. Webb said that Mr. Campbell "was the best salesman of one of my songs." "It's just something I couldn't afford to pass up," he said in Nashville. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Biosource Board Rejects Unsolicited Bid
description: BioSource International, a provider of antibodies and other products used in biomedical research, said yesterday that its board had rejected Bio-Rad Laboratories' unsolicited offer to buy the company for $82 million. Bio-Rad had sent a letter to BioSource earlier this month offering to buy all the company's outstanding stock for $8.50 a share. BioSource said it postponed its annual meeting, set for May 24, after Bio-Rad announced plans to nominate six directors. BioSource's board concluded that the offer was too low, though the company hired UBS and Weil, Gotshal & Manges to advise it on a possible sale. BioSource, based in Camarillo, Calif., has rejected previous offers from Bio-Rad. BioSource shares gained 7 cents, to $9.55. Bio-Rad shares fell 28 cents, to $50.08.

title: For Bob Newhart, Dean of Deadpan, the Laughs Go On
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif. - Ever the gentleman, a tuxedoed Bob Newhart went one by one to each reporter's station along the red carpet of last month's TV Land awards. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   IAKOVOS, ARCHBISHOP
description: IAKOVOS--Archbishop. The Executive Commitee, Board of Trustees and members of the Archbishop Iakovos Leadership 100 Endowment Fund Incorporated express their deep sorrow at the passing of Leadership 100's founder on April 10, 2005, and exclaim profound appreciation for his extraordinary ministry and service. Archbishop Iakovos founded the Archbishop Iakovos Leadership 100 Endowment Fund in 1984 as an act of love and commitment to forward the mission of the Greek Orthodox Church in America. Today it has grown to 700 members and has given more than $18 million in grants for the National Ministries of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America. Archbishop Iakovos, who served for 37 years as the Archbishop of North and South America, retired in 1996, but remained an inspiration to Orthodox faithful and to Leadership 100. A towering religious figure over so many critical decades in the history of our Church and our nation, he was known worldwide for his dedication to human and civil rights, religious freedom and to ecumenical dialogue and interfaith relations. May his memory be eternal!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WELLING, KATHRYN T.
description: WELLING--Kathryn T. Our beloved angel Kate has joined the angels in Heaven much too soon. Having just celebrated her 21st birthday on March 30, she was excited and enthusiastic about life in general, but particularly about her impending semester abroad in Luxembourg. She embodied the concept of beauty, both on the inside and the outside. She was a loving, caring and giving person whose greatest joys were being with and caring for young children, as a Camp Counselor at Camp Fernwood, a Swim Counselor at Camp Mohawk, in a community service program in Fiji, and most passionately as an aunt to Reese and Chase Welling. Her death in a fire at an offcampus residence at Miami University in Ohio on April 10th has left a void that can never be filled. She was a loving daughter to Tom and Helen, a loving sister to Kurt and Thomas, a loving granddaughter to Evelyn, a loving aunt to Reese and Chase, a loving niece to more than 20 aunts and uncles, a loving cousin to dozens, and a loving and supportive friend to all who were fortunate enough to bask in her warming light. She will be missed and mourned by all who knew her, but will never be forgotten. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 6 to 9 PM Thursday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM Friday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Saturday, April 16th, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers or donations to charities, contributions may be sent to The Kathryn T. Welling Memorial Fund and mailed to Dennis Glazer, Esq. at Davis Polk & Wardwell, 450 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

The company, which is based in Cincinnati, agreed in January to buy Gillette, the world's largest razor maker, for $57 billion to lift sales in the personal care business and add products like Duracell batteries to its own brands.

Zoellick, left, on his way to a donors' conference on behalf of Sudan, warned that neither the United States nor other nations would be able to provide aid "if conditions in Darfur do not improve." The conference, which begins in Oslo today, is intended to provide money to support a peace agreement in January between rebels in the south of Sudan and the government in Khartoum. The conflict in Darfur, in the west, broke out while negotiations between the north and south were under way. Previously, the administration's position had been to separate the financing for the south from the problem in Darfur. Just $853 million of the $1.4 billion American pledge for projects in southern Sudan has been appropriated by Congress. Mr. Zoellick seemed to be reflecting the political difficulty of trying to persuade Congress and other countries to appropriate money for Sudan as long as violence continues in Darfur. BMC also said that earnings in the fourth quarter ended March 31 missed the company's February forecast. The company reported preliminary sales of $388 million to $400 million, unchanged or down from a year earlier. Profit before special items will be 8 cents to 12 cents a share, about half as much as originally forecast. After BMC's third-quarter sales and fourth-quarter profit forecast fell short in February, the chief executive, Robert E. Travelers can also continue to use the company's "name-your-own" price offering, in which consumers bid on discounted travel without being told which airline, flight times or hotels they booked until the bid is accepted. title: Switching Seats
description: SWITCHING SEATS -- In one of the most significant trends in air travel, major airlines in the United States are shifting large numbers of their seats to more lucrative international routes. Some examples from March traffic data: American Airlines' international seat capacity grew 14.1 percent over March 2004, while domestic capacity fell 3.1 percent; seating at United Airlines was up 14 percent overseas, down 9.2 percent at home; at Delta, it rose 23.1 percent abroad and 4.2 percent in the United States; at Continental, it increased 17.3 percent on international routes and 10.8 on domestic flights; and at Northwest, it was up 9.4 outside the United States and 7.8 percent at home. US Airways was the only major carrier to log a decrease -- 0.6 percent -- in international capacity, with a 7.1 percent rise in domestic seating. International travel, where domestic carriers are free from competition from low-fare United States airlines, is surging across the board, led by sharp growth in business travel to the Asia Pacific region. For example, Glenn F. Tilton, chief executive of UAL, United's parent, told the Asia Society last week that nearly 25 percent of United's capacity was dedicated to Asian Pacific routes. "We continue to add new and more frequent service to manufacturing and business centers in China -- Hong Kong, Shanghai and many other destinations," he said.

description: London theatergoers may soon be able to add an extra show to their weekend schedule, after labor and management reached an agreement that will pave the way for Sunday performances in the West End. The theater union Bectu, which represents technical workers, box-office employees and front of the house staff, reached a settlement with the Society of London Theater, the trade association for producers, theater owners and managers of more than 40 theaters in central London, that includes a 5.5 percent pay increase, double time for working on Sundays and other improvements. Richard Pulford, the chief executive of the society, said: "The agreement provides a settled basis for planning Sunday performances, something we've never had before. It means we don't have to negotiate specific terms for that particular performance." He said that the new agreement was applicable to shows entering the West End but would not apply to current productions. "It remains to be seen how individual producers will respond to it," Mr. Pulford added. "In broad terms, it is more likely to appeal to people who are putting on family shows." PAM KENT

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Blocked-Flight Concerns
description: The refusal by American authorities on Friday to allow a KLM Royal Dutch Airlines flight with 278 passengers on board to fly over the United States on a nonstop trip from Amsterdam to Mexico City has raised concerns here. The plane turned around near the Canadian border and headed back to Amsterdam after United States officials said two passengers would not be allowed to enter American airspace. Dutch politicians want to know how American authorities obtained a copy of the passenger manifest and why the passengers' names had not turned up on a KLM no-fly list. And some lawmakers want to know why Dutch officials did not detain the two passengers when the flight returned to Amsterdam. In Washington, a spokeswoman for Customs and Border Protection, Christiana Halsey, said that Mexico and Canada routinely provide passenger manifests to the United States for flights that go over American territory. There is no requirement for airlines to check passenger names against a no-fly list for flights not bound for the United States, she said, and thus no routine way for airlines to know before takeoff if they will be denied entry to American airspace, as the KLM plane was. The Bush administration is considering a requirement that names be checked for overflights, but some officials said this would raise privacy issues. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

description: Before the small, devoted audience of "Veronica Mars" could begin in earnest to petition UPN to keep the show on, the network announced on Monday that it was renewing it for a second season. In a telephone interview, UPN's entertainment president, Dawn Ostroff, said, "It's a show that feels unique and feels different, and we know we need to do those types of shows to bring attention to this network." With an average of 2.4 million viewers each week, "Veronica Mars," a high-school mystery show, has been the second-lowest-rated scripted drama of the 2004-5 season. Only "The Mountain" on WB fared worse, and it has been canceled. But Ms. Ostroff cited the appeal of "Veronica Mars" to the UPN demographic target of women 18 to 34 and said the network would broadcast repeats during the summer to try to find new viewers before its second season begins in the fall. KATE AURTHUR

title: World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank: Palestinian Youth With Pipe Bombs Held

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PETREK, JEANNE
description: PETREK -- Jeanne. The Boards of Overseers and Managers and staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center mourn the tragic death of Jeanne A. Petrek. Dr. Petrek, a breast surgeon at Memorial Sloan-Kettering, was Director of the Surgical Program at the Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center. Dr. Petrek first came to MSKCC as a surgical oncology fellow in 1978 and joined the medical staff in 1984, after a brief time at Emory University School of Medicine. Dr. Petrek was widely known for the care she provided to breast cancer patients, with particular focus on young women with the disease. Devoting her research efforts to the study of patient quality of life issues, she became an extraordinary advocate on their behalf. The leading expert in the United States on both lymphedema and pregnancy - associated breast cancer, recognized nationally for her skills as a physician and a researcher, Jeanne Petrek was a valued and respected friend and colleague who was beloved by her many patients. She played a major role in many aspects of our organization as clinician, scientist, institutional leader, and mentor during her 23 years with the Center. Her warmth, enthusiasm, expertise, and tireless dedication to the improvement of treatment for breast cancer will be profoundly missed. We extend our sincere condolences to her husband, children, and the rest of her family. Douglas A. Warner III, Chairman Boards of Overseers and Managers Richard I. Beattie, Vice Chairman Harold Varmus, President John R. Gunn, Executive Vice President Robert E. Wittes, Physician-in-Chief Memorial Hospital PETREK--Jeanne. The staff of the Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center and the members of the Breast Diseases Management Team at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center mourn with the deepest sadness the sudden, tragic loss of our beloved colleague and friend Jeanne A. Petrek. Her presence in our lives was, and remains, a constant reminder of the highest aspirations of medicine, a calling to restore and preserve health in spirit as well as body. She was not only a superb surgeon who helped refine the current management of breast disease, but she was a tireless advocate for the quality of life of breast cancer patients, a leading researcher in topics such as lymphedema after breast surgery, pregnancy-associated breast cancer, and the preservation of fertility after treatment. Despite her international renown, she made every patient feel that she was the most important person in the world to her. She was not only a trusted colleague and valuable scientific collaborator, but a warm, cheerful, encouraging influence in our lives. We, and the thousands of patients whom she helped in her career, miss her and honor her. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her devoted family. Patrick Borgen, MD, Clifford Hudis, MD, Larry Norton, MD PETREK--Jeanne, M.D. The New York Metropolitan Breast Cancer Group, Inc., mourns the sudden and tragic loss of our long-time member, friend, colleague and teacher, Jeanne A. Petrek. Throughout her too short career she inspired us with fresh insights into the management of breast cancer and its after affects and was a cheerful and tireless advocate for patients and for the highest possible quality of care for all. Her research changed our view of this disease and held the promise of more discoveries yet to come. We will miss her always, and extend our deepest sympathies to her family. The Members and Officers of The New York Metroplitan Breast Cancer Group, Inc. Murray Seltzer, M.D., Pres. Clifford Hudis, M.D., V.P.

title: An Enigmatic Virtuoso Keeps Audience Guessing
description: The pianist Evgeny Kissin has an ironclad technique and is the master of the fiery grand gesture. But those are qualities that other pianists offer in equal (well, nearly equal) measure, and they are probably not the only reasons he has built a large and loyal following in New York since he first played here, at 19, in 1990. More likely, there is something in his enigmatic persona that draws and engages listeners much in the way a mystery novel does: each concert challenges the audience to figure out what makes him tick. It is unlikely that anyone will succeed. Even guessing how he'll play a particular work is a loser's game.

title: Arts, Briefly; Beauty Proves Skin Deep
description: On Monday night, Chelsea Cooley of North Carolina, below, who said she strongly identified with Oprah Winfrey, won "Miss U.S.A 2005." But only 8.07 million viewers tuned in to NBC to watch the pageant, according to Nielsen's overnight estimates, a drop of 5 million from last year. For the night, NBC came in third place in households and among 18-to-49-year-olds. First place in both categories went to CBS, which featured the evening's most-watched show, a new episode of "CSI: Miami" (20.07 million). Fox was No. 2 in Monday's standings, as "24" brought in 11.35 million viewers to see whether the president survived the crash of Air Force One, which was brought down by terrorists at the end of last week's episode. He did. Barely. KATE AURTHUR

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Arraigned In Crash That Left Girl In a Coma
description: A man who prosecutors said was drunk when his car smashed into another car Sunday night, leaving a young girl in a coma, was arraigned in Queens Criminal Court yesterday on drunken driving charges and a felony charge of leaving the scene of an accident. The driver, Gerard Gormley, of Astoria, was driving on 35th Avenue in Astoria near 31st Street when he collided with a car carrying a Manhattan family traveling home from a wedding. The other car was sent spinning into a stanchion of the elevated subway line. Ymer Ujkaj, 42, was driving with his wife and his daughter, Ilda, 10, along with a cousin, Selma Purovic, 18. According to a criminal complaint, Mr. Gormley told detectives he had had four beers before driving. Mr. Gormley fled the scene and was later arrested at his home, prosecutors said. Ilda remained in critical condition yesterday. Mr. Gormley could face up to four years in prison if convicted, said the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. Mr. Gormley's lawyer, Michael P. Giampilis of Queens, said last night that he could not yet comment on the case. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVIN, WILBUR A.
description: LEVIN--Wilbur A., 84, died at home on April 12, 2005. He was County Clerk and Clerk of the Supreme Court and Commissioner of Jurors, Kings County, and former President, CEO and Chairman of Independence Savings Bank, and President of Martin's Department Store. Bill was a long-time board member of many institutions, including Brooklyn Law School, Helen Keller Services for the Blind, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Brooklyn Hospital Center, Prospect Park Alliance and the New York Organ Donor Network. He was a graduate of the Boston Latin School and Yale College ('41), and a First Lieutenant in the Army (1942-1946). In addition to his dedicated public service, Bill will long be remembered for the sense of humor and sound advice that guided his family and many friends through life, as well as for the candy and silver dollars he found in their ears. He is survived by his wife Phyllis; their four children: John Levin (and Louisa Swift), Peter (and Anna) Levin, Emme (and Jonathan) Deland, and Kate Levin (and Mark di Suvero); seven grandchildren: Dylan, Mariah, Rawle, Will, Ned, Kate and Veri; and his sister Jean Brenner. Memorial service Friday, April 15, 11 AM in the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please donate to any of the above charities. LEVIN--Wilbur A., 84, died at home on April 12, 2005. The Board of Directors and staff of the New York Organ Donor Network mourn the loss of a distinguished business and community leader. Mr. Levin served as County Clerk and Clerk of the Supreme Court and Commissioner of Jurors Kings County, and former president, CEO and Chairman of Independent Savings Bank, and President of Martin's Department Store. He was a longtime board member of many prominent institutions, including the New York Organ Donor Network, where he served as treasurer and oversaw a significant financial turnaround. Bill will be remembered as an advocate of organ donation who addressed the important issues facing our organization with dedication and intelligence, while never losing his great sense of humor. He approached life with great appreciation and joy, full of love for family and dedication to the many organizations and charities that he supported. Rocco F. Andriola, Chairman N.Y. Organ Donor Network LEVIN--Wilbur A. The Brooklyn Law School community records with great sorrow the loss of Wilbur A. Levin, a steadfast, devoted and beloved member of the Brooklyn Law School Board of Trustees. He was appointed to the Board in 1968, and was named Chairman of the Finance Committee in 1973, positions he held until his death. From 1980 to 2003, he served as Vice Chairman of the Board. Generations of Brooklyn Law School trustees, deans, faculty members and students have benefited from his thoughtful stewardship and compassion. His role in helping the Law School achieve its highest aspirations was indispensable, and his mark on Brooklyn Law School is indelible. Although his presence will be missed, his legacy will be long enduring. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Phyllis, his children, grandchildren and the entire family. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Joan G. Wexler, Dean LEVIN--Wilbur A. In sorrow, Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records the passing of our long time, distinguished and greatly admired member, Wilbur A. Levin. With his family, we share the grief and loss and bereavement. The beautiful qualities of his life shall endure forever in the hearts of those who loved him. Rabbi David M. Posner, Senior Rabbi Dr. Ronald B. Sobel, Senior Rabbi Emeritus Robert A. Bernhard, Pres. Herbert C. Bernard, Sec'y LEVIN--Wilbur A. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Prospect Park Alliance deeply mourn the passing of our friend and Trustee, Bill Levin. He was a consummate gentleman whose professionalism, warmth, and wit graced the Board of the Alliance since its founding, over 18 years ago. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Phyllis, and his family. There was no one like Bill, and we shall miss him greatly. Henry Christensen III, Chair Tupper Thomas, President LEVIN--Wilbur. Helen Keller Services for the Blind regrets the passing of our senior Board Member of 42 years, Wilbur Levin. Fred McPhilliamy President Lawrence Wizel Chairman

title: Packed Artistically for Passover

The Jewish Museum gift shop is selling tins, which are imported from Israel and come packed with a pound of matzos, decorated either with a fanciful painting of a goat, left, by Menashe Kadishman, or one of pomegranates by Reuven Rubin. description: HILLEMAN--Maurice R. The Board of Trustees and Scientific Advisory Council of the Albert B. Sabin Vaccine Institute note with great sorrow the loss of Dr. Maurice R. Hilleman, on April 11, 2005. A true giant among scientists, Dr. Hilleman is credited with developing more vaccines than any other individual in history, including eight of the ten routinely recommended vaccines. His selfless dedication to eradicating disease saved countless millions of lives and prevented suffering among millions more. His intellect, integrity, and unwavering commitment to serve society inspired two generations of scientific researchers worldwide. Dr. Hilleman, recipient of the 1997 Albert B. Sabin Gold Medal, leaves behind many friends and colleagues whose lives were enriched for having known and worked with him. His vision and his friendship will be deeply missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Lorraine, his children, Jeryl Lynn and Kirsten, his brothers, Victor and Norman, and his five grandchildren. H.R. Shepherd, DSc, Chairman William R. Berkley, Co-Chair Sabin Vaccine Institute Board of Trustees Dean D. Mason, Pres. & CEO Peter J. Hotez, M.D., Ph.D., Chair, Sabin Vaccine Institute Scientific Advisory Council

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Donors Pledge $4.5 Billion At Oslo Talks
description: Leaders from at least 50 nations at a donors' conference in Oslo pledged more than $4.5 billion to rebuild southern Sudan after more than 20 years of civil war, but one official after another warned that continuing violence in the western Darfur region would undermine the peace agreement they were there to support. The promised amount was almost $2 billion more than aid officials had said Sudan needed. The United States pledged from $1 billion to $2 billion; the range is a result of uncertainty over how much Congress will approve. "This is a time of choosing for Sudan," Robert B. Zoellick, the deputy secretary of state, said at the conference. "The leaders of Sudan must realize that the eyes of the world are on Sudan." German and Norwegian officials, among others, echoed the sentiment. Kjell Magne Bondevik, the Norwegian prime minister, said, "There is no peace in Sudan until the situation in Darfur has been solved." Joel Brinkley (NYT)
