title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 16-Year-Old Is Charged In Stepfather's Death
description: A 16-year-old boy stabbed his stepfather to death in their home in Cambria Heights on Monday night, the police said. The victim, Darrell Paige, 41, was pronounced dead at North Shore University Hospital shortly before 10 p.m., about an hour after the fight with his stepson, Christopher Drayton, 16. Mr. Drayton stabbed Mr. Paige in the arm, chest and back in their home at 118-27 228th Street, the police said. Mr. Drayton was arrested and charged with second-degree murder and criminal possession of a weapon, a knife, the Queens district attorney's office said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Services: Yahoo To Offer Free Web Sites
description: Yahoo said yesterday that it would start offering small businesses free Web sites as the competition between Internet companies that index local firms continued to escalate. Yahoo, Google, America Online, IAC/InteractiveCorp and others are battling to build online businesses that tap into the money now spent on yellow page advertising. The free sites will be limited to five pages and have a series of text ads along the right side. Yahoo said the advertisements would not be for competing companies. Yahoo has long offered paid Web site hosting, without advertising, to small businesses. The free offer is meant to draw in businesses that can be sold additional hosting and other Yahoo services like e-mail. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: A Dance and Its Digitized Echoes
description: TEMPE, Ariz., April 11 - Over the course of her dance company's 35 years, the choreographer Trisha Brown has worked with such independent-minded collaborators as the musician Laurie Anderson and the artist Robert Rauschenberg. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Revision To Freedom Of Information Law Advances
description: The State Senate unanimously passed a bill yesterday to set firmer terms and timelines for granting or denying access to government records under the state's Freedom of Information Law. The law is often used by newspapers and other media organizations to seek the release of government documents. But agencies can often drag their feet in releasing data. Most of the changes in the Senate bill apply to state agencies and local governments, not to the legislative branch. The proposed process sets a standard of "reasonable under the circumstances," which does not exist now. The standard, the bill's advocates say, will have the effect of speeding the release of information or uncovering reasons that documents are being withheld or delayed. The Assembly passed the same bill on April 4. The measure will now go to Gov. George E. Pataki. Al Baker (NYT)

Arts, Briefly; Another Head Rolls at La Scala
description: The contorted plot unfolding at the Teatro Della Scala in Milan took another twist on Monday with the resignation of Fedele Confalonieri as president of the Filarmonica Della Scala, the house's independently constituted orchestra. The Filarmonica, along with the theater's other workers, was a major player in forcing the resignation of Riccardo Muti as music director on April 2. The dispute arose in February, when the orchestra condemned what it saw as Mr. Muti's role in the ousting of the general manager, Carlo Fontana, in favor of Mauro Meli, who was a director of the theatrical division. Mr. Confalonieri is the president of Mediaset, a broadcasting company. His office there issued a statement yesterday confirming his resignation without further comment. Mr. Meli said on April 4 that he, too, was "open to resigning," but he has not resigned. Mr. Muti is in New York to conduct the New York Philharmonic, beginning tomorrow. He was replaced at Filarmonica concerts last week by Arild Remmereit, a young Norwegian-born conductor. JAMES R. OESTREICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   IAKOVOS, ARCHBISHOP
description: IAKOVOS--Archbishop. The Executive Commitee, Board of Trustees and members of the Archbishop Iakovos Leadership 100 Endowment Fund Incorporated express their deep sorrow at the passing of Leadership 100's founder on April 10, 2005, and exclaim profound appreciation for his extraordinary ministry and service. Archbishop Iakovos founded the Archbishop Iakovos Leadership 100 Endowment Fund in 1984 as an act of love and commitment to forward the mission of the Greek Orthodox Church in America. Today it has grown to 700 members and has given more than $18 million in grants for the National Ministries of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America. Archbishop Iakovos, who served for 37 years as the Archbishop of North and South America, retired in 1996, but remained an inspiration to Orthodox faithful and to Leadership 100. A towering religious figure over so many critical decades in the history of our Church and our nation, he was known worldwide for his dedication to human and civil rights, religious freedom and to ecumenical dialogue and interfaith relations. May his memory be eternal! IAKOVOS--Archbishop. Appeal of Conscience Foundation mourns the loss of our longtime Trustee, Archbishop Iakovos. A towering personality whose love and dedication reached out beyond the Greek Orthodox Community. We will miss him as a colleague who contributed much to advance religious freedom, human rights and interreligious cooperation. Rabbi Arthur Schneier, Pres. Cardinal Theodore E. McCarrick, Trustee Archbishop Khajag Barsamian, Vice President Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, SJ, Vice President IAKOVOS--Archbishop. The Board of Directors of HANAC, Inc. is saddened by the passing of Archbishop Iakovos, Primate of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America until 1996. In recognition for his extraordinary ministry and respect for Orthodoxy, HANAC in 1993 named their first senior residence "HANAC Archbishop Iakovos Senior Residence." His name will forever be remembered. Evangeline Douris, Chairman HANAC, Inc.

description: Before you try a slice of the St. Moritz walnut tart, first learn to speak its language, which includes words like Engadine, a Swiss valley; Graubnden, the canton where the recipe originated; and Engadiner Nusstorte, the official name of the pastry. The tart is a thick layer of caramel with walnuts densely embedded in it, wrapped in a buttery cookie-like crust. The St. Moritz company of Scottsdale, Ariz., makes the 12-inch tart and sells it for $55 plus shipping at www.stmoritzwalnuttart.com. A double-caramel version is also $55. Both are keepers that stay fresh for days and can be frozen. Because they are so rich, each will serve at least 12. Here's another thought: unsweetened whipped cream is delicious alongside.

title: She's 15 and Growing Up the Hard Way
description: Charlotte yearns to be famous, loved and beautiful, but most of all, she just wants to grow up because then, of course, everything will be different. Mark Schultz's exquisitely performed new drama, "Everything Will Be Different," plunges deep into the unsettled mind of a 15-year-old girl whose mother recently died.

title: National Magazine Awards Honor Journalism and Help Sell Ads
description: WHEN nominees for awards buy advertisements in trade publications, mail out media kits, postcards and other materials promoting their nominations, and distribute trinkets like View-Master toys preloaded with reels praising their merits, it must be nearing Oscar time, right?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Trade Deficit Hit $61 Billion As the Cost of Oil Increased The trade deficit expanded in February for the third month, reaching a record $61 billion, as the rising cost of oil and the appetite for foreign goods propelled imports to new heights.

A Viola da Gamba Star in More Ways Than One
description: The term "early-music superstar" is surely an oxymoron. But in the most understated of repertory, on the most subdued of instruments and in the most self-effacing way, Jordi Savall comes close to being one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COE, MICHAEL
description: COE--Michael. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Michael Coe, beloved father of Robert Coe, and extends deepest condolences to the family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President COE--Mike. Beloved husband of Corinne. Devoted father of Rob and Sara, L.P. and Christy, Doug and Elizabeth. Cherished grandfather of Danielle, Seth, Ben, Adam, Alison and Isaac and great grandfather of Zoe. Loving brother of Hope Arner. Services Wednesday 2 P.M. at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Mean Streets in the City of Brotherly Rivalry
description: "State Property 2" is the latest proof of the axiom that movies about organized crime are really about business. So while this brutal, chaotic chronicle of heavily armed drug dealers shooting it out in the streets of Philadelphia is likely to be cited as another example of hip-hop culture's irresponsible glorification of violence, or alternatively as an example of ghetto-outlaw authenticity, it is better appreciated (or disdained) as a raw, bracing expression of the spirit of capitalism. The title may refer explicitly to the prison system -- it's how the incarcerated hero bitterly thinks of himself -- but it also has a socialistic ring, an evident irony in a movie devoted above all to the celebration of free enterprise.

title: Recline Yourself, Resign Yourself, You're Through
description: Baby boomers' almost comic fear of aging reminds me of that silent movie scene in which Harold Lloyd hangs precariously from the hand of a giant clock, literally pulling time from its moorings.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Computer Associates To Double Dividend
description: Computer Associates International, the world's fifth-largest software maker, said yesterday that it would double its dividend and buy back as much as $400 million of its shares in fiscal 2006. The annual cash dividend will be increased to 16 cents a share, the company said. The dividend increase comes after similar moves by other software, semiconductor and computer companies to reward shareholders as their stocks have languished. Computer Associates' shares have fallen 11 percent this year, in contrast to a 2 percent loss in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. The company had $3.33 billion in cash and short-term investments as of Dec. 31. Shares of Computer Associates, based in Islandia, N.Y., rose 42 cents, to $27.65.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILMOUR, LLOYD STRAUBE
description: GILMOUR--Lloyd Straube, an artist, magician, investment banker and film producer, died of natural causes on April 7 at his home in Wellfleet, MA. He was 77 years old. Mr. Gilmour graduated from Harvard College in 1950. From 1951-1954 he served in the U.S. Army Counter Intelligence Corps (CIC) as an operations officer and linguist. Following his return from military service, he began a 20 year career on Wall Street including senior management positions at the investment banking and brokerage firm Blyth Eastman Dillon. Mr. Gilmour left the banking world in 1968 to devote himself to painting. His work was carried by several New York City galleries, The Gallerie Andre Weil in Paris and the Foster Harmon Gallery in Naples, FL. In 1975 Mr Gilmour co-produced the movie "Aaron Loves Angela", an inner city love story. He was a member of the Century Association of New York, the Academy of Magical Arts in Hollywood and the Magic Circle in London. Mr. Gilmour, son of Lloyd S. Gilmour and Margery B. Gilmour was born in New York City on September 17, 1927. His first marriage to Helen Reed Tower and his second marriage to Joan Thompson Stehli ended in divorce. He is survived by his wife Katherine Binger Gilmour, a sister Blyth P. Patel, four children of his first marriage, Julie G. Bowen, David L. Gilmour, Andrew S. Gilmour and Jennifer G. Deleplanque; four stepchildren Seth G. Eames, Alexandra Eames, Evan T. Eames and Gillian Eames Ricci and a total of 14 grandchildren and great grandchildren. A memorial service will take place at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, New York City on Satruday, April 16, at 3:30PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be offered to the Wellfleet Conservation Commission in Wellfleet, MA.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Man Arraigned In Hostage Standoff
description: A man accused of taking a woman and their baby daughter hostage, then leading the police on a chase that ended in a seven-and-a-half-hour standoff, was arraigned in Essex County Court yesterday on charges of attempted murder, kidnapping and other crimes, the authorities said. Prosecutors said the man, Almutah Saunders, 26, of East Orange, burst into the apartment of his ex-girlfriend, Erika Turner, on Monday morning and shot Ms. Turner's father in the leg. The father, Eric Turner, remains in fair condition at University Hospital in Newark. Mr. Saunders is being held in the Essex County jail in $2 million bail. John Holl (NYT)

title: I Am My Own Server, Porter, Bellhop
description: To the Editor:

title: Nominee Vows Tighter Control of Intelligence
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 - John D. Negroponte, nominated as the first director of national intelligence, promised Tuesday to bring "fundamental change" to the broad array of agencies he would oversee, and he said the American people were right to "expect more" after recent intelligence failures.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: APPLEBEE'S INTERNATIONAL, Overland Park, Kan., the restaurant chain, said it had agreed to buy the assets of 12 Applebee's restaurants in Missouri, Kansas and Arkansas from the Ozark Apples, an existing Applebee's franchisee. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEIN, MICHAEL
description: FEIN--Michael. A memorial service for Michael Fein will be held at 4 P.M. on April 14, 2005 at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Canadian Demand For Autopsy Is Rejected
description: The spokesman for the country's judiciary said the judges had rejected a demand by Canada to return the remains of Zahra Kazemi, an Iranian-Canadian photojournalist who died while in detention in Tehran in 2003, for an autopsy. "Even though she had Canadian citizenship, an Iranian court will investigate her case because she was an Iranian citizen," he said. An Iranian doctor, Shahram Azam, who is in exile in Canada, said this month that he had examined Ms. Kazemi in Tehran and had seen signs that she had been tortured and raped while in custody. Iran's position is that Ms. Kazemi, 54, died after falling and hitting her head. In Canada, a spokesman for Foreign Affairs Minister Pierre Pettigrew, denounced Iran's decision, saying it was consistent with its "pattern of cover-up and lies." Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about FreshDirect's impact on New York residents and grocery stores misstated the extent of its delivery coverage. The service is not available in every neighborhood in Manhattan. A picture caption misspelled the name of the Long Island City street where FreshDirect trucks are parked outside the company's building. It is Borden Avenue, not Border.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer's Forecast Steadies
description: Marks & Spencer Group, Britain's largest clothing retailer, said profit for the last fiscal year should be no worse than was previously forecast as a sales decline eased in the fourth quarter. Pretax profit for the year ended April 2 was 610 million to 625 million ($1.15 billion to $1.18 billion), the chief executive, Stuart Rose, said in a conference call. Sales at stores open at least a year fell 4.9 percent in the fourth quarter, compared with a third-quarter drop of 6 percent, he said. "It's gone from bad to less bad, but I accept it's still not good," Rose, 56, said in the conference call. Stock in Marks & Spencer, which is based in London, rose 4 percent.

title: The Former Chief of A.I.G. Is Silent Before Regulators
description: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the insurance giant American International Group, arrived at the New York attorney general's office in Lower Manhattan yesterday morning for a meeting with prosecutors and regulators that had forced his departure from the company last month.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Broken Subway Rail Disrupts Morning Commute
description: Subway service on Queens Boulevard was briefly disrupted yesterday after a broken rail was detected near the Woodhaven Boulevard station at 7:16 a.m. Service on the V line was suspended, and Jamaica-bound E and F trains ran locally between Jackson Heights and Forest Hills, until regular service was restored at 9:10 a.m. The City Council speaker, Gifford Miller of Manhattan, and Councilman John C. Liu of Queens charged the defect showed "declining investment" in the system over the past decade. But New York City Transit said it had recorded 63 instances of broken rails so far this year, down almost 40 percent from 102 rails in the same period last year. The detection of the broken rail proves the system is "not in a state of disrepair," the agency said. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BACOT, J. CARTER
description: BACOT--J. Carter. The Board of Directors and staff of the United Way of New York City are saddened by the loss of our friend and former Board Chairman and Chief Volunteer Officer, J. Carter Bacot. Carter was a devoted champion of the United Way movement and a tireless leader who cared deeply about the needs and conditions of the poor. Under Carter's direction, the organization hit new fundraising records and expanded programs to serve a growing number of people in need. We are grateful for his leadership and will profoundly miss his generous spirit, tenacity, and vision. BACOT--J. Carter. The Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation mourns the passing of one of its esteemed Directors, J. Carter Bacot. Mr. Bacot served for twelve distinguished years on the Board of the Macy Foundation and will be sorely missed for his insight and valuable services rendered. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mr. Bacot's wife, Shirley. Lawrence S. Huntington, Chairman June E. Osborn, M.D., President

title: The Untouchable Corps
description: Anyone who cares about responsible budgeting and the health of America's rivers and wetlands should pay attention to a bill now before the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works. The bill would shovel $17 billion at the Army Corps of Engineers for flood control and other water-related projects -- this at a time when President Bush is asking for major cuts in Medicaid and other important domestic programs. Among these projects is a $2.7 billion boondoggle on the Mississippi River that has twice flunked inspection by the National Academy of Sciences.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: U.S. Awards $42.1 Million In Homeland Security Aid
description: The New York City region will receive $42.1 million to improve security in its subway, commuter rail and bus systems, the Department of Homeland Security announced yesterday. The area is to receive $37.6 million for rail security, to be shared by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, New Jersey Transit and the Connecticut Department of Transportation. About $4.5 million will go for security on Metropolitan Transportation Authority and New Jersey Transit buses. The department provided the region with about a third of the $130.3 million in such funds provided nationwide. The department also said it would give Amtrak $6.4 million to improve security along the Northeast Corridor and at the railroad's Chicago hub and hold a grant competition for $5 million to improve security on ferry systems. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: At a Noodle Bar, the Noodles Play Catch-Up
description: GOOD restaurants don't always start off at the top of their game. The food steadily improves, servers hit their stride and the kitchen settles into a working rhythm. It can be nothing short of thrilling to watch one shake off its early awkwardness and come into its own.

title: End Is Expected, but There's Still Time to Debate Morality
description: "Revelations," NBC's six-hour mini-series about a nun and a scientist's search for signs that Armageddon is at hand, may not persuade skeptics to believe in God. But the timing alone suggests that a higher being favors the show: on the heels of the Terri Schiavo debate and the death of Pope John Paul II, the premiere includes a right-to-life battle over a coma patient and nuns in schism with the Vatican.

title: Wal-Mart Donates $35 Million for Conservation and Will Be Partner With Wildlife Group
description: Barely a week after environmentalists forged a broad alliance with organized labor and community groups to attack Wal-Mart and its business practices, the company announced Tuesday that it would donate $35 million over the next decade to an ambitious new conservation effort by the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation.

title: Study Finds Shortcoming in New Law on Education
description: The academic growth that students experience in a given school year has apparently slowed since the passage of No Child Left Behind, the education law that was intended to achieve just the opposite, a new study has found.

title: Senator Faults Briefing on Antiterrorism Law
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 - A senior Republican lawmaker expressed frustration Tuesday with the Justice Department's failure at a closed-door briefing to provide information about its use of the sweeping antiterrorism law known as the USA Patriot Act.

title: The Hard Stuff Now Includes Wine
description: NOT so many years ago, back when Americans sought out compact cars and calculated their gas mileage, most California wines clocked in at an economical 12 to 13 percent alcohol. It was perhaps a shade higher than what their European colleagues achieved, but California was blessed with generous sunshine that made ripening grapes an easier proposition than in the cooler climates of Bordeaux and Burgundy.

description: THIS is a make-or-break year for Sudan, Africa's biggest country. In Oslo this week, donor countries pledged $4.5 billion in aid to Sudan, but while I applaud the donors' generosity, promises alone are not enough.

description: When he ran Gucci, Tom Ford proved himself a master of the brand makeover. Now he's reinventing himself.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Chinese Journalists Denied Visas
description: The government said it would stop issuing visas to reporters from mainland China's official New China News Agency and People's Daily, the main Communist Party newspaper, complaining that both organizations had presented a distorted view of events on the island. The current visas expire this month. The Mainland Affairs Council, the Taiwan government agency that deals with matters concerning China, especially objected to coverage of Taiwanese and international reaction to China's new antisecession law, which authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" to regain control of Taiwan if it seeks formal independence. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

description: BOSTON, April 12 - For Richard L. Friedman, chief executive of Carpenter & Company here, redeveloping the historic Charles Street Jail into a $100 million four-star hotel is a dream project. In two weeks, he hopes to start construction on a major addition and renovation of the majestic stone structure, which has a prime location near the Charles River, world-class hospitals and the State House. It is at the foot of Beacon Hill, a neighborhood with 19th-century town houses, brick sidewalks and period lighting.

title: The Outsider, Staying Put at Morgan Stanley
description: At a memorial service in January, two men joined in a hard, awkward embrace: Philip J. Purcell, the chief executive of Morgan Stanley and Robert G. Scott, a former president of the firm who was forced out of his job by Mr. Purcell in 2003.

title: Research Worth Fighting For
description: OF the Pentagon's $419.3 billion budget request for next year, only about $10.5 billion -- 2 percent -- will go toward basic research, applied research and advanced technology development. This represents a 20 percent reduction from last year, a drastic cutback that threatens the long-term security of the nation. Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld should reconsider this request, and if he does not, Congress should restore the cut.

title: Tom Ford starts his comeback
Private Investment Firm Buys MusicNet Venture
description: MusicNet, a joint venture created by the music industry to provide a legal alternative to the illegal sharing of music files, has been sold to Baker Capital, a private investment firm in New York.

title: Summertime in Gaza
description: If the chatter among the Israelis and the Palestinians is anything to go by, this is going to be a July to remember in the Middle East. The Palestinian Authority is planning to hold local elections in just three months. Unlike the election in January that made Mahmoud Abbas president, these elections will include Hamas, the part-time terrorist and part-time civic organization that has been the bane of Israel for so many years.

title: Principal Fired for Failing to Report Sex Assault Case
description: A high school principal in Columbus, Ohio, has been fired and three assistant principals suspended without pay because they failed to notify the police last month about accusations that a 16-year-old special-education student had been sexually assaulted in the school auditorium by a group of boys, one of whom videotaped the incident, school officials said yesterday.

description: The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund called yesterday for a doubling of foreign aid to poor countries in five years, adding their weight to recent support from other development groups for such increases.

description: WASHINGTON, April 12 - Everybody in Washington knows that members of Congress cannot keep secrets. Now two of them are facing questions about whether they inadvertently blew a C.I.A. officer's cover.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Clashes Over Poppy Fields
description: Violent clashes broke out in southern Kandahar Province when anti-drug forces came under fire as they tried to eradicate a village's poppy fields. A villager was reported killed and several more were injured, Afghan news agencies reported. Four members of the anti-drug force were reported injured. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with a theater review of "The Audience," at the Connelly Theater in the East Village, carried an erroneous credit. It was by Carol Rosegg.

title: Arts, Briefly; New Portrait a Puzzler
description: Mystery surrounds the identity of the "naked admirer" in a new self-portrait (detail, below) by the 83-year-old painter Lucian Freud. Titled "The Painter Surprised by a Naked Admirer," detail below, it will go on view today at the National Portrait Gallery in London, where it will remain through May 8. The 50-inch-square painting, depicting the artist pausing while painting as an unidentified woman clutches his leg, will be the most recent work of more than 80 works in a Freud retrospective at Museo Correr in Venice from June 12 through Oct. 30. Mr. Freud said of the unveiling, "I like my work to be seen by Londoners." The identity of the naked admirer has not been revealed. PAM KENT

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Sunday with an article about tests by The Times that showed New York City stores sell farm-raised fish as "fresh wild salmon" referred imprecisely to the salmon shown. Although it was for sale at Eli's of Manhattan on the Upper East Side, where a sample tested as wild salmon, it was not the sample.

title: Showdown in the Kitchen
description: WHEN I started writing about food 25 years ago, I was made aware of the difference between chefs and home cooks. Editors said, "Write your story, but get a top chef's recipes." So I turned to Wolfgang Puck, Alice Waters and other exalted creators of the "new American cuisine." Ideas for home cooks came from chefs, Julia Child, James Beard and one or two writers. "Normal" home cooking barely existed in food journalism.

title: Flawed Arrests at the Convention
description: To the Editor:

title: Vintage New York
description: I took the GG, as it was called then, back and forth from Queens, where I lived with my parents, to Pratt Institute in Brooklyn during my college years. It was the first test of the day -- to survive rush hour and arrive at school with delicate dowel constructions or a wet canvas intact. In my junior year I also started carrying a camera, and it was then that I first began my fishing for lasting moments in the murky light of the underground. I beat myself up each time I missed, but what a thrill it was when I got a good one. It was on those rides that I first practiced my timing and the art of being invisible.

title: Greek Chefs Modernize the Classics
description: ATHENS - ATHENS was a culinary backwater when Yiannis Baxevannis returned to Greece after years of training in France to be a chef. Escoffier was his muse back then. But in his new restaurant, Hytra, he has found inspiration in the foods of his homeland.

title: Cables Show Central Negroponte Role in 80's Covert War Against Nicaragua
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 - Hundreds of newly released cables that John D. Negroponte sent to Washington while serving as ambassador to Honduras in the 1980's show that he played a more central and assertive role than previously known in managing the United States' covert war against Nicaragua's leftist government, which he called "our special project."

title: Robbery, No Problem. Spiders? Eek!
description: In the middle of "Bonnie Parker," at the John Houseman Studio Theater, Dixie Lee Sedgwick suddenly does a cartwheel. She also shrieks a great deal, usually at some horrible little discovery (cobwebs or a spider in her shoe). At one point she inexplicably gets down on the floor and poses like the young woman in Andrew Wyeth's "Christina's World."

title: Bin Laden Bribed Afghan Militias for His Freedom, German Says
description: BERLIN, April 12 - The head of the German intelligence agency, in an interview published here Tuesday, said Osama bin Laden had been able to elude capture after the American invasion of Afghanistan by paying bribes to the Afghan militias delegated the task of finding him.

title: Letters
Paid Notice: Deaths   BEACH, JOHN WARREN
description: BEACH--John Warren, 93, of Scarborough, NY, formerly of Mt. Kisco and Bedford Hills, NY, died on April 10. Former circulation manager for Guideposts Magazine. Husband of Josephine and the late Marion L. Beach. Father of John of Bedford, NY; Bennett of Bethesda, MD; Randall of New Haven, CT and Anne of Louisville, CO and the late Brooks Beach. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Memorial service on Saturday, April 16 at the Presbyterian Church of Mt. Kisco, NY at 2PM. Interment is private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the SPCA of Westchester, Briarcliff Manor, NY or the Boys & Girls Club of Northern Westchester, Mount Kisco, NY.

title: Case Dismissed for Principal in Bronx Clash
description: A popular Bronx principal who was handcuffed in front of his students two months ago will be back at school today, after charges that he pushed a police officer were dismissed.

title: DeLay Defends Effort to Rein In the Courts
BRAZIL APPROVES CITIGROUP MANAGEMENT SHAKEUP
description: Brazil's telecommunications regulator, Anatel, approved Citigroup's decision to hire a new investment manager in the country, paving the way for the bank to regain control of its stakes in three Brazilian phone companies. Citigroup fired the investment manager, Daniel Dantas, a controversial Brazilian financier mired in several lawsuits and shareholder disputes, last month as the general manager of its $728 million private equity fund in the country. The ruling should allow Citigroup to recover its stakes in Brasil Telecom, the country's third-largest fixed-line operator, and two wireless companies, Telemig Celular and Tele Norte Celular. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, DAVID GOT TSCHALK, DR.
description: SCHWARTZ -- David Got tschalk, Dr. Died On April 12, 2005, at the age of 87. Beloved husband of Phyllis Kess, father of Jonathan, Douglas and Thomas. Grandfather of Gregory, Andrew and Jennifer. Devoted to his family, medicine and his many patients. Attended Townsend Harris High School, Cornell University, and Louisiana State Medical School. He was an alumnus of Mt. Sinai Hospital, an associate attending physician at North Shore and Beth Israel hospitals and an associate A.F.A.C. A captain in the Medical Corps in World War II, serving bravely in North Africa, southern France, and Italian campaigns, earning a Purple Heart. A true family physician in the highest tradition on call day and night, year-round. He loved life and did all he could do to ensure long life for all under his care. He will be truly missed by all who had the honor to know him. Services Friday, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave (81st St)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WELLING, KATHRYN T.
description: WELLING--Kathryn T. Our beloved angel Kate has joined the angels in Heaven much too soon. Having just celebrated her 21st birthday on March 30, she was excited and enthusiastic about life in general, but particularly about her impending semester abroad in Luxembourg. She embodied the concept of beauty, both on the inside and the outside. She was a loving, caring and giving person whose greatest joys were being with and caring for young children, as a Camp Counselor at Camp Fernwood, a Swim Counselor at Camp Mohawk, in a community service program in Fiji, and most passionately as an aunt to Reese and Chase Welling. Her death in a fire at an offcampus residence at Miami University in Ohio on April 10th has left a void that can never be filled. She was a loving daughter to Tom and Helen, a loving sister to Kurt and Thomas, a loving granddaughter to Evelyn, a loving aunt to Reese and Chase, a loving niece to more than 20 aunts and uncles, a loving cousin to dozens, and a loving and supportive friend to all who were fortunate enough to bask in her warming light. She will be missed and mourned by all who knew her, but will never be forgotten. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 6 to 9 PM Thursday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM Friday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Saturday, April 16th, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers or donations to charities, contributions may be sent to The Kathryn T. Welling Memorial Fund and mailed to Dennis Glazer, Esq. at Davis Polk & Wardwell, 450 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

D'Amato "a fascist" -- and with that Mr. Abrams's campaign seemed to go off its rails. For all the time and money he had put into his run for the United States Senate, for all his years as the state's popular attorney general, Mr. Abrams's campaign in 1992 became defined largely by that one comment.

description: The Japanese government chose the Nomura Securities Company and UBS Securities Japan as lead managers for the sale of as much as $7 billion of stock that it holds in Central Japan Railway, operator of the country's busiest bullet train line, between Tokyo and Osaka. The stock sale, which the government plans to complete by March 2008, will probably be the largest in Japan since the government sold an $8.8 billion stake in the mobile phone company NTT DoCoMo four years ago. The agency that holds the shares said it had not yet decided on the exact size and timing of the sale. Todd Zaun (NYT)

Indeed, the composer himself abandoned his first attempt in Vienna in the early 1860's after no fewer than 77 rehearsals. Now, in a daring experiment, the Paris National Opera has invited the American video artist Bill Viola to accompany the work with his own visual commentary.

A Warehouse Full of Housewares To Grace Homes for Less
description: The owners of Gracious Home, the Manhattan housewares store, are holding a giant warehouse sale in Queens on Saturday and Sunday. Thousands of items will be reduced, in some cases by 90 percent. The sale includes 60 sets of stainless steel flatware in a traditional pattern. The sets, with 84 pieces, were $150 and are now $39.99. Two gold-leaf wall sconces, formerly $935 apiece, will be $175 each. And dark gray Le Creuset cookware will be marked down 50 percent. The sale runs from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. at 30-30 60th Street (off Northern Boulevard) in Woodside; (718)726-7872. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Sage Group Sales Increase 17%
description: Sage Group, Britain's biggest maker of accounting software, said yesterday that fiscal first-half sales increased 17 percent, to about 381 million ($721 million), in line with analysts' expectations. The company, which has been on an acquisitions spree in the United States and Europe, said that pretax profit rose 16 percent to about 101 million in the six months ended March 31. Both sales and pretax profit figures were calculated using average foreign exchange rates for the six months. Sage, which has a market value of 2.6 billion, has expanded through more than 1.5 billion of acquisitions since 1991. This year it bought the software company Symfonia, which is based in Warsaw, for 10.3 million and the Swiss company Simultan for 10.7 million. Shares of Sage, which is based in Newcastle, England, climbed 8.5 pence, or 4.2 percent, to close at 212.25 pence in London. The company is scheduled to announce half-year financial results on May 10.

title: F.D.A. Panel Backs Breast Implants From One Maker
description: GAITHERSBURG, Md., April 13 - Silicone breast implants made by a California company should be available to women who undergo cosmetic breast surgery, a federal advisory panel voted on Wednesday, rejecting arguments about serious health problems.

title: Afghan Leader to Propose Strategic Ties With the U.S.
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 13 - President Hamid Karzai said Wednesday that he would send a formal request to President Bush seeking a long-term strategic relationship with the United States, one that could include economic assistance as well as security guarantees and military cooperation.

description: A Congressional committee has a "good chance" of approving a bill that would direct a new regulator for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to reduce their $1.5 trillion loan holdings, the panel's chairman said yesterday.

title: Welcoming Spring, Recalling Old Friends
description: Sidling among the tables at the Cafe Carlyle on Tuesday evening as she entered singing "I've Got the World on a String," Barbara Cook made it immediately clear that her return to the scene of many past triumphs at a time of sorrow was not going to be a wake. With the death last October of Wally Harper, her longtime accompanist and collaborator, Ms. Cook, now 77, lost the musical equivalent of her right arm. At the same time, the recent death of Bobby Short, an irreplaceable symbol of cultural continuity in Manhattan, has left the cafe reeling with uncertainty about the future.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Bill Tightens Regulation Of Abortion
description: The state would monitor abortion clinics more intensively under a measure passed by the House of Representatives. A similar bill is moving toward a final vote in the Senate. Supporters say the measure, which would set an array of new standards for clinics, would make abortion safer. Opponents say that increased costs and other burdens would force many clinics to close. Abortion clinics are already licensed by the state and subject to annual inspections. Courts have blocked past efforts to tighten regulation of abortion clinics, but supporters of the new measure say it is constitutional because it focuses on those offering second-trimester abortions. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

description: As the date rapidly approaches for a big meeting where the leaders of the rich world are supposed to come up with a plan to help lift Africa's poor, tired and huddled masses out of poverty, things are starting to get interesting. Last week, Japan announced that it would double its aid to Africa. Granted, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi is doing so to better Japan's chances of getting a seat on the United Nations Security Council, according to Yomiuri Shimbun, a Japanese newspaper, but so what? Money is money.

title: Arts, Briefly; Fox Rules Tuesday Roost
description: Among the big three networks, only CBS has any luck holding up against Fox's Tuesday lineup of "American Idol" and "House." CBS's "NCIS" at 8 p.m. and "The Amazing Race" at 9 p.m. managed to draw audiences of 13.32 million and 13.05 million, respectively, to ensure a second-place finish for the night in Nielsen's estimates. ABC, which was a distant No. 3 on Tuesday, is being overwhelmed by Fox's combination of "American Idol" (25.01 million) and "House" (18.03 million). Three of ABC's sitcoms broadcast during that time -- "My Wife and Kids," "George Lopez" and "According to Jim" -- scored season-low ratings, and the fourth, "Rodney," also fared poorly. NBC doesn't even try at 8 p.m. against "Idol." As it has done for months, on Tuesday night it broadcast reruns to fill the time: "Will & Grace" (3.89 million) and "Scrubs" (3.55 million), and placed fourth in households. KATE AURTHUR

World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Consumer Prices Rise
description: Consumer prices in Spain rose the most in five months in March as stores began selling the new season's clothing and higher oil prices pushed up energy and transportation costs. Prices rose 0.9 percent in March from the previous month and 3.4 percent from a year earlier, the highest inflation rate since November, according to the government's statistics agency. Spain's inflation rate has exceeded the European Central Bank's goal of 2 percent since March 1999.

title: Arts, Briefly; Pop Charts
description: Despite steadily declining sales each week since its release, 50 Cent's "Massacre" (Interscope) has been invincible at the top of the Billboard album charts; last week, its sixth since it went on sale, the album sold 165,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. That figure would have landed the album in the middle of the Top 10 during a healthy sales season, but things are not looking good for 2005 so far. Overall sales are down 9 percent from last year at this time, at 155 million units, according to Billboard. Last week, only one album besides "The Massacre" sold more than 100,000 copies, the usual benchmark for a strong period: Faith Evans's "First Lady" (Capitol) sold 157,000 copies, reaching No. 2. Beck's "Guero" (Geffen) slid to No. 3 on a 50 percent sales drop, "Now That's What I Call Music!" Vol. 18 is at No. 4, and 112's "Pleasure and Pain" (Def Soul) also dropped about 50 percent to reach No. 5. Music industry speculators expect this week to be slow as well. BEN SISARIO

title: Chen Yifei, 59, Painter and Entrepreneur, Dies
description: SHANGHAI, April 13 - Chen Yifei, one of the China's most acclaimed and commercially successful painters and visual artists, died here on Sunday. He was 59.

title: School Pools, Now Dry Storage
description: Harry S. Truman High School in the Bronx has eight floors, seven gymnasiums, a football field and a planetarium. But there is one place off limits to its more than 3,000 students: the six-lane swimming pool, which has been dry for more than a decade.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: BHP Tempers Iron Ore Price Rise
description: The Australian mining company BHP Billiton said it had dropped demands that steel makers double what they pay for its iron ore, yielding to commercial and diplomatic protests by its Chinese customers as Australia prepares to start free trade talks with China. The company announced that it had settled for a 71.5 percent increase in ore prices, matching gains won in February this year by its rivals, Rio Tinto and Companhia Vale do Rio Doce of Brazil. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: NEWALLIANCE BANCSHARES TO BUY CORNERSTONE BANCORP
description: NewAlliance Bancshares agreed to buy Cornerstone Bancorp for $49 million in cash or stock to add branches in the southwestern part of Connecticut. Cornerstone shareholders will receive either $35 in cash or 2.518 shares of NewAlliance stock for each share they own. The cash price is a 10 percent premium over Cornerstone's closing price Tuesday. The deal will bring NewAlliance's assets to over $6.6 billion and help it expand. NewAlliance, based in New Haven, will have 71 branches after the deal. NewAlliance bought two banks in 2004, and last month said it would buy Trust Company of Connecticut.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Cosmetics Maker Restates Earnings
description: A cosmetics maker, Kanebo, said it overstated its net profit by 148 billion yen ($1.38 billion) over the four years ended March 31, 2003. The company, which is undergoing a government-administered reorganization, said its former managers padded sales figures and underreported expenses to hide actual net losses in each of the four years. The company said it discovered the accounting irregularities in an internal audit started by government-appointed managers who took charge of the company last year. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Suspect In Filmmaker Killing In Court
description: Muhammad Bouyeri, the Dutch-Moroccan who has confessed to killing the Dutch filmmaker Theo van Gogh last November on the ground that he had offended Islam, made his first appearance in a heavily fortified Dutch court. Mr. Bouyeri, 27, refused to answer any of the judges' questions. The start of his trial on murder charges has been delayed by a search for presumed accomplices in the case that has shaken the Netherlands. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Judge Voids Mafia Sentence
description: A federal judge has thrown out the prison sentence of a leader of the Boston Mafia, ruling that prosecutors failed to disclose evidence that potentially could have acquitted him. The man, Vincent Ferrara, pleaded guilty in 1992 to racketeering, extortion and other charges, including ordering a 1985 murder, and was sentenced to 22 years in prison. The federal judge, Mark L. Wolf, ruled that prosecutors failed to disclose that a witness tried to retract a statement that Mr. Ferrara ordered the murder, and that Mr. Ferrara felt he had to plead guilty to the murder along with the other charges. A resentencing hearing is scheduled for May 3. Katie Zezima (NYT)

description: MANN--Rabbi Jacob. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing in Israel of a distinguished and dedicated rabbinic leader who served 62 of his 70 years in the rabbinate as spiritual leader of Beth Israel Synagogue in Quincy, Mass. Revered by all who knew him, he was the beloved father of our alumni: Rabbi Dr. Jonah (and Tirzah) Mann; Rabbi Dr. Abraham Moses Mann (and Joan Ehrlich); Esther (and Chaim) Synder; and a cherished grandfather and greatgrandfather. Together with his late wife, Isabelle, he was a Yeshiva University Guardian who established scholarships at Yeshiva College and Stern College for Women. Following his funeral in Quincy Thursday afternoon, the family will observe Shiva from Friday morning to next Wednesday morning at 14017 69th Road, Kew Garden Hills, New York. title: World Briefing | United Nations: Treaty Against Nuclear Terrorism Approved
description: The 191-member General Assembly passed a nuclear terrorism treaty that would oblige governments to prosecute or extradite individuals possessing atomic devices or radioactive materials. The treaty, which was approved by consensus without a vote, was first introduced by Russia in 1998 to keep unaccounted-for nuclear weapons from falling into the hands of clandestine terror networks. The pact opens for signatures in September, and 22 nations are needed to ratify it. Signatories will be required to make the acts outlawed by the convention criminal offenses under their national laws. "By its action today," Stuart Holliday, a deputy United States ambassador, said, "the General Assembly has shown that it can, when it has the political will, play an important role in the global fight against terrorism." Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Connecticut Episcopalians Defy Bishop Over Gay Issues
description: DARIEN, Conn. - At a morning service on Tuesday in St. Paul's Church here, a worshiper read a poem urging his pastor to stand firm against the moral decay embodied by the local bishop and the church's national leadership. Fifty miles away in Watertown, a pastor drew chuckles when he asked his flock to pray for the bishop, who has threatened to silence him for his defiance.

title: Books and Hollywood: Views From Two Coasts
description: To the Editor:

title: Spring Ambles in, Along With the Curious
description: FROM penthouse apartments in Manhattan to 19th-century brownstones in Brooklyn, and from tiny backyard spaces to bulging community gardens, the spring season of show houses and house and garden tours has begun in New York City. This year's sampling includes private modern art collections, shiny new kitchens, lush plantings and antiques galore. Unless otherwise noted, the tours are self-guided.

title: Trading Scandal May Strengthen Stock Exchange
description: A scandal can destroy an institution. Or it can renew it. The good news for the New York Stock Exchange is that the scandal that led to the indictments of people who had been extremely powerful on the floor of the exchange bears a close resemblance to the one that shook the Nasdaq stock market a decade ago.

title: Bad Afternoon on L.I.R.R.
description: A series of mishaps in less than 70 minutes disrupted the evening commuting of tens of thousands of Long Island Rail Road riders yesterday. Shortly after 5 p.m., smoke was detected in one tunnel, Line 3, that is used by eastbound Long Island trains, according to a railroad spokesman. At 5:15, an Amtrak train broke down in another tunnel, blocking traffic in two tunnels, Lines 1 and 2, shared by the railroads. The Amtrak train was cleared to move at 5:25, and Long Island service was restored in Line 3 at 5:47. But at 6:10, another Amtrak train was disabled on Line 2 for nine minutes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERN, BRIGITTE (NEE SCHLOSS)
description: STERN -- Brigitte (nee Schloss). Of Paramus, NJ. Wife of the late Walter. Mother of Stephanie Tucker and Elise Stern. Sister of Leon Schloss. Grandmother of Nicole, Gabrielle, Corinne, Rachel and David. Services Thursday 10:30 AM, "Gutterman-Musicant," 402 Park St, Hackensack, NJ. Contributions to JCC of Paramus would be appreciated.

title: Young Catholics Seek to Restore Old Values on Sex
description: ROME, April 13 - No matter who is chosen as the next pope, John Paul II has left behind a generation of committed young Roman Catholics who are already shaping the church in a more conservative mold than did their parents. Church leaders call them Generation John Paul II.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article yesterday about the Bravo television series "Project Greenlight" misstated the broadcast date of the episode in which production of the film "Feast" begins. It will be shown tonight; it was not shown last night.

title: Thriving Ratings for a New Patient on ABC
description: Even before this week's announcement that the medical drama "Grey's Anatomy," originally scheduled for only a four-week run, would remain in ABC's Sunday-night lineup through the May ratings sweeps period and for the rest of the season -- bumping David E. Kelley's "Boston Legal" off the air until fall -- Shonda Rhimes, the show's creator and an executive producer, was getting the feeling that her life was about to change.

title: The Future of Television?
The Island of Lost Toy Fairs? Some Say It'll Be Manhattan
description: New York toy manufacturers, already stung by the sale of two Flatiron district buildings many of them call home, are bracing for the possibility that two lucrative trade fairs that bring a worldwide audience of buyers to Manhattan will move to other cities.

title: Federal Judge Strikes Down F.D.A. Ban on Ephedra
Falls tied to insomnia, not the sleeping pills
Senator Asks U.N. Nominee to Explain His Security Requests
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 - John R. Bolton, nominated to be the next ambassador to the United Nations, used his position as a senior State Department official to obtain details about intercepted communications involving other American officials that were monitored by the National Security Agency, according to Mr. Bolton's own account.

title: Ischgl Journal; Nation That Once Drew Guest Workers Now Sends Them
description: ISCHGL, Austria, April 11 - You would not tend to apply the term "guest worker" to Anna Hass, who is a 23-year-old waitress at the large mountaintop Panorama Restaurant in this Austrian ski resort, because for four decades, a guest worker -- Gastarbeiter in German -- meant a Turk or a Yugoslav who came to labor-short Germany in search of the sort of job Germans did not usually want to do.

title: The Press in America: Mirror Images
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ETTUS, MARTHA
description: ETTUS--Martha. Age 97, of Brooklyn, NY. On April 12, 2005. Beloved mother of Frank, mother-in-law of Sandra, grandmother of Pamela, Samantha, and Timothy, great-grandmother of Jaxon, and best friend to Lola. Martha's loved ones were blessed with her unfailingly positive spirit, humor, and charm. She was a gift to all who loved her.

World's first fusion reactor seeks home
Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the conclusion of the trial in Moscow of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the founder of the Yukos oil company, misstated the back-tax claim levied against Tyumen, another Russian oil company. It is more than $900 million, not $900 billion.

title: In a Shopping Frenzy
description: The "for sale" signs are everywhere: Neiman Marcus, Saks and Bill Blass.

title: The Press in America: Mirror Images
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fifth Avenue Matron Vamps It Up
description: IT may be a renovation in midstream, but with the changes that are taking place at Saks Fifth Avenue -- new designers on every floor, a more knowledgeable sales staff, less clutter -- the store is beginning to resemble its uptown rival Bergdorf Goodman. And that is no accident, for over the last few months Saks has been plotting to win back its upscale clientele.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: State To Shutter Mumbai's Dance Bars
description: The seedy and celebrated cabarets of Mumbai, formerly Bombay, India's entertainment capital, are to be shuttered under a new law passed this week. The government of Maharashtra State had already ordered the closing of dance bars in the rest of the state, on the ground that they encourage prostitution. The bars are a popular Mumbai institution, in which women dance to movie tunes and men shower them with money. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Livedoor and Fuji TV in Talks
description: TOKYO, April 13 - The Japanese Internet start-up Livedoor and the Fuji Television Network are discussing a possible alliance, signaling that a contentious two-month struggle for control of a Tokyo radio broadcaster may end amicably.

title: Vaults That Let You Store (and Show) Your Photos, and Keep Shooting
description: WHEN you really stop to think about it, memory cards are a pretty delicate storage format for something as important as your digital photos. So many things can happen to memory cards: they can get lost, stolen, corrupted or, in the case of those little tiny xD-Picture cards, blown into the next ZIP code when you sneeze.

title: Tax Cheat Sentenced to 6 Years for Defying I.R.S.
description: SACRAMENTO, April 13 - Al Thompson, the California businessman who stopped withholding taxes from the paychecks of his workers in 2000 and showed thousands of others how to do the same, was sentenced on Wednesday to six years in prison.

title: About These Listings
description: The replacement of the daytime listings by an expanded prime-time guide is a response to the increased offerings of cable providers in the New York area and the widespread availability of all-day programming guides on television and the Internet. Comments about the changes on this page may be e-mailed to tvdesk@nytimes.com or telephoned to (212) 556-7579.

title: Roundup: Nadal and top seeds advance in Monaco
It's time to renew the trans-Atlantic partnership
Union and Fund Join Forces in Bid for Canadian Steel Maker
description: OTTAWA, April 13 - The United Steelworkers of America and a reorganizing fund led by the Brascan Corporation of Toronto announced a partnership on Wednesday to try to take control of Stelco, the Canadian steel maker under bankruptcy protection.

title: Federal Prosecutor's Brother Among 20 Charged in Trading Scheme
description: Todd J. Christie, the brother of Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney for New Jersey, was among 20 specialist stock traders charged with civil fraud by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday, accused of cheating their customers to benefit their firms.

title: Just One of 9 Suspects Convicted in 2003 British Poison Plot Case
description: LONDON, April 13 - British authorities disclosed Wednesday that only one of nine North African men accused of conspiring to spread deadly poisons two years ago had been convicted, and that four had been acquitted. The charges were dropped against the remaining four.

title: Freddie Mac Purchased and Sold Faulty Loans
description: Freddie Mac, the nation's second-largest buyer of mortgages, said yesterday that it had unknowingly bought a small number of mortgages that had "unacceptable refinance" terms and then sold them in securities offerings to investors.

title: The New Peacocks
description: IT'S nice to know that American men haven't taken recent corporate scandals lying down. No siree. They sucked in their guts, bade farewell to their families and hurried to the mall. The urge to look corporate -- sleek, commanding, prudent, yet with just a touch of hubris on your well-cut sleeve -- is an unexpected development in a time of business disgrace. But surprising or not, sales of men's tailored clothing increased 23.7 percent last year to $4.3 billion, with suit sales alone jumping 34 percent. That halts an eight-year decline.

title: Uganda's failures
Attachable Screen Lets a Gamer Take That PlayStation 2 on the Road
description: Last year, Sony re-engineered its PlayStation 2 game console, shrinking it to the size of a thin hardback book. Now that the PlayStation 2 is so light and portable, Pelican has created an attachable liquid-crystal display that allows you to play games like Gran Turismo 4 or Xenosaga II in a car with the PlayStation 2 on your lap.

title: Berlusconi's Family to Reduce Shares in Broadcast Company
description: ROME, April 13 - Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's family said on Wednesday that it was selling a 2 billion euro ($2.58 billion) stake in the broadcasting company Mediaset, a move intended in part to dilute accusations that the holdings constitute a conflict of interests.

title: Love Their Neighbor, for His Police
description: HE has not popped over to her penthouse to borrow a cup of sugar or a spoonful of Grey Poupon, she has yet to be invited to one of his meatloaf soirees, and during the Persian Gulf War armed law enforcement agents camped in a voluminous tent on his roof at eyeball level with her terrace. (That's because, talk about small worlds, the Iraqi Consulate is directly across the street.) Still, Pamela Jenrette is a convert to the maxim that good neighbors make good mayors. And vice versa.

title: Bomber Offers Guilty Pleas, and Defiance
description: ATLANTA, April 13 - Declaring himself "bloodied but emphatically unbowed," Eric Robert Rudolph on Wednesday issued his first public explanation for a series of abortion clinic bombings and an attack at the 1996 Olympics, gloating that his plea deal with prosecutors "deprived the government of its goal of sentencing me to death."

title: Meteorite flashesover skies of Spain
LIONS GATE TO SPIN OFF CANADIAN DISTRIBUTION UNIT
description: Lions Gate Entertainment, whose films include "Fahrenheit 9/11" and "Monster's Ball," said it would spin off its Canadian distribution unit into a new company called Maple Pictures in a plan to cut costs. Brad Pelman and Laurie May, who have served as executives of Lions Gate, will lead Maple Pictures, Lions Gate said yesterday. Mr. Pelman and Ms. May, along with two undisclosed Canadian private equity firms, will be shareholders in the new company. Lions Gate will hold a minority stake. Lions Gate, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, did not disclose financial details of the spinoff.

title: Intense Competition for Top Students Is Threatening Financial Aid Based on Need
description: CONSIDER the awkward decision confronting the admissions director of a highly selective university that is trying to move forward in the academic pecking order (one of, say, 50 institutions that would have landed in the top 10 this year, except for various flaws in the rankings formula).

title: Returning to a Hornet's Nest
Microsoft and Europeans Argue Over Ruling
description: BRUSSELS, April 13 - A year and a month after the European Union's landmark antitrust ruling against Microsoft, the software company has still not carried out either of the resulting orders, and this week the two sides argued over when a progress report might be forthcoming.

title: Lottery Numbers
Guantnamo Detainee's Suit Says Prison Guards Beat Him
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 - A lawsuit filed in federal court on Wednesday says guards at the Guantnamo Bay detention center beat a detainee frequently, leaving him with visible scars and partial facial paralysis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELL, PEARL (LEVIN)
description: BELL--Pearl (Levin), 96, died April 12, 2005, in Boulder, Colorado. Mother of Alan and Jackie, wife of the late Harry Bell (nee Belitsky), grandmother of Benny and Andy, "mother-in-law" to David Ziff, and mother-in-law to Phil Swan. An avid piano player, who continued to bang on the eighty-eights until the final days. We'll miss her humor, kindness, and inability to find anything bad in anyone she ever met. Services Riverside Memorial Chapel, Friday 11:30 A.M.

title: BHP relents on boost in price of iron ore
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Abercrombie & Fitch, New Albany, Ohio, said its chief financial officer, Susan Riley, had resigned after 14 months with the company.

title: Beginning Today
description: This is the first Thursday Styles section, a weekly cousin of Sunday Styles. The section will incorporate fashion news that previously appeared on Tuesdays, including the Front Row column and reviews. It will also include reports on social trends, and coverage of fitness, skincare and shopping in stores and online.

title: NASD Fines Ex-Broker for Unsuitable Advice
description: A former broker with First Command Financial Planning, a brokerage firm that specialized in selling investments to military personnel, was fined $25,000 and suspended for 10 months for recommending unsuitable investment strategies to clients, NASD announced yesterday.

title: Reviving and Reinventing an Ancient Art of India
description: There were many striking moments in the Nrityagram Dance Ensemble's program of Indian Odissi dance at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, but the most striking came right after the intermission.

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Campaign Seeks To Reduce Infant Deaths
description: City health and child welfare officials are beginning a campaign to reduce the number of accidental infant deaths, such as the crushing of some babies who sleep with their parents, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The campaign will rely mostly on a $1.5 million advertising campaign promoting the use of window guards to prevent falls and special electrical outlets to avoid shocks. The advertisements also warn parents not to shake their babies or have infants sleep with them in their beds. Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the commissioner of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, said that 15 children died in 2004 when parents crushed or suffocated their babies while tossing and turning in bed. That was double the number in 2003. The city will also identify families in need of cribs and other products, all of which will be donated by a national children's charity, Kids in Distressed Situations, and the Juvenile Products Manufacturers Association. Jim Rutenberg (NYT)

title: Senate Leaders Postpone Vote on F.D.A. Chief
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 - Citing new concerns about Dr. Lester M. Crawford, President Bush's nominee to head the Food and Drug Administration, Senate leaders postponed a vote on his nomination pending more investigation.

title: In Pursuit of a Total Art, the Paris Opera Adds Video to 'Tristan und Isolde'
description: PARIS, April 13 - Huge, dense, taxing, with almost all the action taking place in the heart, Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" is notoriously difficult to stage. Indeed, the composer himself abandoned his first attempt in Vienna in the early 1860's after no fewer than 77 rehearsals. Now, in a daring experiment, the Paris National Opera has invited the American video artist Bill Viola to accompany the work with his own visual commentary.

title: If Building Web Sites Has You Puzzled, Try These Handy Ones Right Out of the Box
description: Do-it-yourself layout programs can take the fear out of creating a Web site without knowing a lick of HTML coding. But Homestead Technologies has made site construction even simpler with QuickSites, a service for people who want a nicely designed Web site as fast and easy as possible.

title: A Lightning Rod for the U.N. Post (4 Letters)
The New Peacocks
description: IT'S nice to know that American men haven't taken recent corporate scandals lying down. No siree. They sucked in their guts, bade farewell to their families and hurried to the mall. The urge to look corporate -- sleek, commanding, prudent, yet with just a touch of hubris on your well-cut sleeve -- is an unexpected development in a time of business disgrace. description: Manhattan

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 3 Arrested In Subway Killing
description: Three people have been charged in the killing of Marviel Martinez, 17, of the Bronx, who was attacked with a machete Tuesday morning on a subway platform as he waited with two friends for a train to school, the police said early this morning. The three, all Bronx residents, were identified as Alex Ramirez, 15, who was charged with murder, assault and criminal possession of a weapon; Bolivar Pichardo, 17, who was charged with murder; and Lucas Denis, 18, who was charged with murder. The two friends of Mr. Martinez were also stabbed in the attack around 8 a.m. on the uptown No. 4 platform at 183rd Street and Jerome Avenue, the police said. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Artists Rally to a Defense
description: More than 50 artists, including Cindy Sherman, Sol LeWitt and Kiki Smith, have donated works to be auctioned on Sunday in New York by the legal defense fund of the Critical Art Ensemble, an arts collective, the group announced yesterday. With Wallace Shawn as the master of ceremonies, the auction will raise money for the legal defense of Steven Kurtz, right, a founding member who was indicted last June on charges of mail fraud and wire fraud. After an investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Joint Terrorism Task Force, Mr. Kurtz, an assistant professor at the State University of New York at Buffalo who has used biological agents in his politically charged artworks, and Robert Ferrell, a University of Pittsburgh scientist, both face as much as 20 years in prison for illegally obtaining such materials. In a telephone interview, Gregg Bordowitz, an associate professor at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and a member of the C.A.E. Legal Defense Fund, said: "The Critical Art Ensemble is openly critical of the government and industry. I can only assume this is about ideas." The viewing and silent auction will be held at Paula Cooper Gallery in Chelsea from 2 to 8 p.m., with a live auction from 5 to 7. JOEL TOPCIK

title: Mother of Jackson Accuser Tells of Bizarre Goings-On
description: SANTA MARIA, Calif., April 13 - The mother of Michael Jackson's accuser sassy, sarcastic and dressed in pink -- broke down on the witness stand at one point on Wednesday, asking those in the courtroom, "Please don't judge me."

title: Apple Beats Outlook on IPod and Mac Sales
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 - Continuing a trend that has run for several quarters, Apple Computer on Wednesday reported a profit for the second quarter that beat even its expectations based on continued brisk sales of its iPod portable music player, as well as improving sales of Macintosh computers.

title: Executive at WPP Unit To BBDO Worldwide
description: A well-known senior executive will leave the Young & Rubicam Brands division of the WPP Group to join a competitor, BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: School Guard Arrested In Burning Of Student
description: A school safety agent has been accused of setting a student's hair on fire, the police said. The student, a boy, was not seriously injured. The safety agent, Albert Blacks, a seven-year veteran, was arrested at 3 p.m. Tuesday, the day of the incident. He was charged with reckless endangerment and endangering the welfare of a child. According to the police, Mr. Blacks used a disposable lighter to ignite the back of the student's hair at Springfield Gardens High School. Mr. Blacks could not be reached for comment yesterday. Susan Saulny (NYT)

Volcanoes rumble as quakes hit Indonesia

description: GEER--Major. The entire St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center family acknowledges with sadness the passing of our dear friend and longtime colleague, Major Geer, MD, former member of St. Luke'sRoosevelt's Department of Medicine and Division of Cardiology. To his family, friends and all of those who loved him, we extend heartfelt condolences. Richard F. Daines, MD President and CEO Carl W. Braun, MD President, Medical Board Michael Lesch, MD Chairman, Dept. of Medicine Jonathan S. Steinberg, MD Chief, Division of Cardiology
