description: A note in The Arts yesterday about a review of the Dresden Staatskapelle at Carnegie Hall online at www.nytimes.com/artsextra, misstated the timing of its publication in print. It will appear tomorrow.

title: A Message in a Coffin for Baseball
description: SOMETIME around 11 o'clock this morning, a coffin will be delivered to 245 Park Avenue. Major League Baseball has its headquarters there, and the people delivering the coffin, Hispanics Across America, want to deliver a message with it.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stock Indicators Decline, Erasing Tuesday's Gains Oil shares, along with stocks that would be hurt if the economy slows, led the stock market lower as the three main market gauges fell 1 percent or more. The declines wiped out all the gains from Tuesday.

title: Siebel chief leaves post abruptly
The Haunting of Emile Griffith
description: The ex-champ was a few inches shorter than I'd imagined, and he had put on a few pounds. At age 67, all of his hair and some of his memory were gone. Absorbing blows over several years from the hardest-hitting people on the planet can cause confusion.

title: The Press in America: Mirror Images
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
Congress's Deepening Shadow World
description: When it comes to lobbying Congress, Washington is now a $3-billion-a-year company town. The influence industry is multiplying so fast that no one really knows how many lobbyists are at work these days. Ten years after a law was passed to register and track lobbyists, the Capitol staffs charged with the task are woefully short-handed and lack proper auditing and investigative powers, according to a study by the Center for Public Integrity.

title: Realty Agent Who'll Work for 0%
description: WHEN a West Village town house went on the market recently, the owners were told by real estate agents and appraisers that they would never get more than $5 million for it. The house sold for well over $6 million, within spitting distance of the asking price that everyone said they wouldn't get. Milla Jovovich, the actress, who viewed it with her boyfriend, Sean Lennon, the musician, bought it on a second visit.

title: Williams Moves Down, Steps Up
description: BOSTON, April 13 - Bernie Williams did not sulk, pout, become angry or complain about his demotion to the ninth spot in the Yankees' batting order. His way of responding was to turn in his best game of the young season.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the "Arts, Briefly" column on April 6 about recordings selected by the Librarian of Congress, James H. Billington, for the National Recording Registry referred incorrectly to the album "Fear of a Black Planet." It was by Public Enemy, not Chuck D, who is the group's leader.

title: France allows terminally ill to choose death
The Drummer's Possessed, but Now the Act Is a Hit
description: Love is not an emotion. No one needs protection from the vagaries of life, because life "is an experience, not an attack." There is no heaven, there is no hell, and it's not important to know whether God exists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DWORKIN, ANDREA
description: DWORKIN--Andrea. On April 9, in Washington D.C. Survived by John Stoltenberg, beloved partner of 30 years. Memorial service to be announced. Donations to Andrea Dworkin Fund at Schlesinger Library, Cambridge, MA, or to Domestic Violence Shelter, or Rape Crisis Center of your choice.

title: Entr'acte: For Algerians in France, what future memories?
National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Support For Civil Unions
description: Gov. Theodore R. Kulongoski, a Democrat, announced he would press for passage of a measure allowing same-sex couples in the state to form civil unions as a way to promote "social justice, tolerance and diversity." The bill, now before the legislature, would give same-sex couples many of the rights that married heterosexual couples enjoy. Oregon voters decided in November to amend their Constitution to ban same-sex marriage. Eli Sanders (NYT)

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 p.m. (7) JAKE IN PROGRESS -- Tonight's double feature starts with a rerun of the pilot, introducing Jake (John Stamos, above), young urban single publicist to the stars; wacky supporting characters include his pregnant, middle-aged boss, Naomi (Wendie Malick) and a depressed performance artist (Rick Hoffman) who wants to be Jake's best friend. At 8:30, Jake goes on a date with the boss's sister (Mdchen Amick).

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Sought In Girl's Kidnapping And Assault
description: Detectives were looking for a man yesterday who kidnapped and sexually assaulted a 15-year-old girl in Brownsville early Tuesday, the police said. Investigators said the girl, whose identity was not disclosed, was approached near Eastern Parkway and Utica Avenue about 6:30 a.m. by a man with a gun who forced her into a four-door sport utility vehicle with silver trim. He drove to a spot near East New York Avenue and East 94th Street, where he assaulted the girl, who fought back and fled. She was taken to a nearby hospital, where she was reported to be in stable condition, the police said. They said the suspect was a black man in his 30's, about 6 feet tall, with a medium build, a scar near his right eye and a chipped tooth. The police asked that anyone with information about the case contact the Crimestoppers hotline at (800) 577-TIPS. A reward of up to $2,000 has been offered. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: 2 sides meet in Aceh talks
Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZBURG, SIMHA (NEE VALERO)
description: SCHWARTZBURG -- Simha (nee Valero), 88, of San Juan, PR, originally of Jerusalem. Died April 12. Beloved wife of the late Alexander. Survived by son Ori, daughter-in-law Deborah, grandchildren Alexander and Rosa. She enjoyed life to its fullest and will be sorely missed. Services on Friday, April 15, 10 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Closer Look at Falluja Finds Rebuilding Is Slow
description: FALLUJA, Iraq, April 13 - Robert B. Zoellick, the deputy secretary of state, wanted to see Falluja for himself instead of relying on dry reports from the "interagency process," as he put it.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Storage Technology Says Profit Missed Estimates
description: The Storage Technology Corporation, a maker of tape and disk drives that manage computer data, said yesterday that first-quarter profit and revenue missed analysts' estimates because customers held off signing contracts. Sales were $500 million and net income was 18 cents to 21 cents, based on preliminary results, the company said. Storage Technology was expected to report profit of 26 cents, the average estimate of 13 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial, on sales of $519.5 million. The company, which is based in Louisville, Colo., said it expected to report final results on April 25. A year earlier, Storage Technology reported net income of $23.3 million, or 21 cents a share, and sales of $515.1 million. Storage Technology shares rose 9 cents, to $29.10.

title: Alternative Strategies for Keeping Faces Looking Fresh
description: THE Fraxel laser may be the newest way to erase tiny wrinkles and discolored skin, but for some people older strategies that are time-tested and less expensive often work well enough. There are three main procedures.

title: Lebanon's Prime Minister Resigns, Putting Parliament Vote in Doubt
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April 13 - Lebanon's pro-Syrian prime minister stepped down Wednesday, raising doubts that parliamentary elections would be held before the end of May, when the current legislature's term ends.

title: I'll Be Right Back, She Lied
description: IT never seems so bad in the beginning. A few of us -- the nonshoppers -- actually agree to accompany the wife (or girlfriend) for a day in the stores. Maybe the kids have to be watched, maybe it's just about doing things together, trying to keep the union reasonably healthy.

title: Arts, Briefly; Honored for Toughness
description: Bruce Willis, below, has been awarded France's highest cultural honor. Mr. Willis, 50, was formally inducted yesterday into the French Order of Arts and Letters. The French culture minister, Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres, said the award paid tribute to an actor whose work "epitomizes the strength of American cinema, the power of the emotions that he invites us to share on the world's screens, and the sturdy personalities of his legendary characters." Mr. Willis, 50, who was in France to promote his latest movie, "Hostage," said that the honor "proves that film has no borders and that we all belong to the same artistic community." Mr. Donnedieu de Vabres said that the actor's roles could not be reduced to a simple struggle between good and evil, yet he added, "You really have killed a lot of bad guys." JOHN TAGLIABUE

title: Germans go abroad for work
CITIGROUP SEEKS DAMAGES FROM EX-MANAGER IN BRAZIL
description: Citigroup is seeking at least $300 million in damages from its former investment manager in Brazil, Daniel Dantas, accusing him of working against the bank's interests while overseeing its private equity fund there. According to documents filed this week in federal court in New York, Citigroup said Mr. Dantas tried to sell the bank's stakes in two wireless companies without authorization, obstructed auditors and entered into agreements in the fund's name for his own benefit. Last month, Citigroup severed ties with Mr. Dantas, a financier who is also facing legal problems in Brazil. Federal police in Rio de Janeiro charged Mr. Dantas yesterday with criminal conspiracy, breach of confidentiality and corruption for his role in a espionage scandal. Mr. Dantas has denied any wrongdoing. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Date Set For Chambers's Drug Trial
description: A judge in Manhattan Criminal Court refused to dismiss drug charges yesterday against Robert E. Chambers Jr., left, who was convicted of manslaughter in the 1986 strangling of Jennifer Levin, 18, in Central Park. The judge, Melissa C. Jackson, set a summer trial date. Hearings will begin on June 20 on evidence, probable cause and statements made by Mr. Chambers, and a trial is scheduled to follow, said Barbara Thompson, a spokeswoman for the Manhattan district attorney's office. Mr. Chambers was arrested in November on misdemeanor charges of driving with a suspended license and possessing a small amount of cocaine. Colin Moynihan (NYT)

Pole-wielders burn up to 40 percent more calories than regular walkers, physiologists say, and because users engage their upper bodies and abdominal region, they work out 90 percent of their body's muscles.

description: Watching "Murder in the First," it's easy to imagine Christian Slater as the young lawyer and Kevin Bacon as the psychologically damaged defendant. Dan Gordon, who wrote the screenplay for the 1995 movie of that title with those stars, has adapted his work for the stage, and it's still a fairly engaging 1940's-style drama.

title: At Kips Bay, Madame Is at Home
description: A FEW years ago, after a particularly fruitful flea market expedition in Paris, I returned home with a pair of canister-shaped 1930's crystal and amethyst chandeliers, which I was inspired to hang not over my dining room table but by my sofa, with the intent of using them as reading lamps. That they could barely illuminate a turkey sandwich, let alone the text of a Penguin classic, seemed inconsequential, given how often guests remarked on the originality of the fixtures and my terribly clever deployment of them. Eventually one guest came along who held a different view, and because I am about to marry him, I imagine the chandeliers will soon be relocated to some obscure corner of our new home. A few other beloved objects also stand in jeopardy, I suspect, among them a white mink and lavender suede cushion, which I had converted from an evening stole, and a pillow made of kangaroo hide.

description: ARMSTRONG--Thomas E. II, 67, died April 12, in Greenwich, CT. He was a Director and Executive Vice President of Brant-Allen Industries in Greenwich, CT. He is survived by his wife Maxine K. Armstrong, and daughters Elizabeth & Amanda; sister, Christy McKenzie. Services will be Friday, April 15, at 11 AM at the Greenwich Polo Club in Conyers Farm, Greenwich, CT. Donations may be made in his memory to Reach Prep, 115 East Putnam Ave, Greenwich, CT 06830. His warmth and friendship will be deeply missed. He, along with his wife, Maxine K. Armstrong, Founding Chairman of REACH Prep cared profoundly about its mission to enrich the lives of under-represented children. We are grateful for his family's immeasurable contributions. We extend our deepest sympathies to Maxine and her daughters, Bette and Amanda. His noble qualities will endure forever. Linda G. Ortwein, REACH Prep, Inc.

His work benefited all humanity, and we will especially miss his tireless leadership, his humor, and his devotion to the singular task of saving human lives. Dr. Jerald C. Sadoff, President and CEO, Aeras Global TB Vaccine Foundation Dr. Seth F. Berkley, President and CEO, International AIDS Vaccine Initiative (IAVI)

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Computer Horizons To Buy Analysts International
description: The Computer Horizons Corporation, which provides personnel to install computers and manage networks, agreed yesterday to acquire the Analysts International Corporation for $88 million, doubling its customer base and annual revenue. Analysts International shareholders will receive 1.15 shares of Computer Horizons for each share they own. The offer valued Analyst International at $3.62 a share, or 1 percent less than its closing price Tuesday. The purchase will create a company with about 5,000 consultants in 50 offices in the United States, Canada, Britain and India. Computer Horizons, based in Mountain Lakes, N.J., said there was overlap in just eight of the combined company's top 50 customers. Computer Horizons' shareholders will own 52 percent of the combined company, which will be based in Minneapolis. The Computer Horizons' chief executive, William J. Murphy, will be chief executive of the combined company and Jeffrey P. Baker, president of Analysts International, will assume that role in the new company. The company's board will include five directors each from Computer Horizons and Analysts International.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSTROW, BARNET
description: OSTROW--Barnet. Formerly of Roslyn, L.I. Passed away April 12, 2005 after a long illness. Devoted husband of Annette Glassman Ostrow, loving father of son Ronald and daughter-in-law Beth and son Bono Yvertes and daughterin-law Nancy. He will be deeply missed by his cherished grandchildren Alonna Ostad and husband Michael, Sharone Gilbert and husband Richard, Jonathan Ostrow and Juliette Yvertes and great grandchildren Hannah, Alexandra, Ari and Benjamin. Barnet Ostrow was a creative and innovative chemical engineer who invented and developed many electroplating processes used in the electronics, industrial and decorative industries. He co-founded LeaRonal, Inc. which was started in a garage in Long Island City in 1953 and grew to become a major global supplier of specialty chemicals. He served as President until 1983 and as Chairman of the Board of Directors until 1995. The company, listed on the New York Stock Exchange was sold to Rohm & Haas in 1999. A kind and gentle man, Barnet was philanthropic to numerous Jewish organizations and was honored by the Solomon Schechter Day School of Nassau County before the onset of his illness. OSTROW--Barnet D. The Board of Governors and the members of Glen Oaks Club express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our esteemed member of 23 years, Barnet, and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Annette, and his family. Board of Governors Alan Goldberg, President OSTROW--Barnet. Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights, New York, mourns the passing of our beloved member, Barnet. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Annette and son Ronald. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas Dr. Steven Zeldis, President OSTROW -- Bernard. We mourn with deep sorrow the loss of our Uncle Barney. He was a distinguished scientist and we are grateful for all of his accomplishments. He will live in our hearts forever. The Glassman Family

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suspect In Cab Robbery Tackled In Park
description: A cabdriver was stabbed last night by a passenger who robbed him of $20 and fled into Central Park, only to be chased down by an off-duty police lieutenant, the authorities said. Investigators said the driver, Jersen Fernandes, 50, of Elmhurst, Queens, was stabbed once in the neck and cut severely on his hands about 8:30 p.m. before the robber fled from the cab at Central Park West and Cathedral Parkway. Lt. Chris Schmidt, 32, a member of the force for 12 years who had refereed a lacrosse game nearby, heard screams, spotted a man running away and gave chase. The police said he tackled the robber and took him into custody in the park near West 108th Street. Mr. Fernandes was in stable condition last night at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. The suspect, Jamal A. Harris, 30, of 1246 Park Avenue, was charged with robbery, assault and criminal possession of a weapon. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Change May Keep View Of Statue Of Liberty
description: A landlord whose proposed building would be tall enough to block a Brooklyn view of the waterfront and the Statue of Liberty said he might reconsider the building's design. "We are discussing this, and hope to have some resolution in a few days," said Elan Padeh, a sales agent for Chaim Nussencweig, the owner of the National Produce Company warehouse at 614 Seventh Avenue, which is being demolished. As currently planned, the proposed 70-foot-high, five-story condominium would block the view of the Statue of Liberty from the 1920 Altar to Liberty monument atop Battle Hill in Green-Wood Cemetery. Community groups and preservationists have protested the proposed construction because the altar and its 9-foot-high bronze statue of Minerva, the Roman goddess, was intended as a counterpart monument to the Statue of Liberty. Glenn Collins (NYT)

title: Using Advanced Physics to Find Concealed Weapons
description: Three companies are racing to market a new form of technology for detecting concealed weapons, using physics borrowed from radio astronomy and manufacturing techniques from cellular phone makers.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Bank In China Venture
description: The European bank UBS said China had approved its proposal to take a 49 percent stake in China Dragon Fund Management, a midsize Chinese mutual fund manager. UBS, based in Zurich, said it would take the stake from a government-owned investment firm, the State Development Investment Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Foreign banks are allowed to take stakes of up to 49 percent in Chinese fund mangers under a measure approved by the Chinese government in December. Tom Wright (IHT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israeli And Palestinian Mayors Pledge Peace

Eli Moyal, the mayor of Sederot, in southern Israel, which has often been a target of Palestinian rockets, was quoted by Agence France-Presse as saying, "We have come here today to extend the hand of peace." title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILLECK, ROBERT BOSWORTH
description: SILLECK--Robert Bosworth, 87, of Greenwich, Connecticut, died peacefully at Greenwich Hospital on April 10, 2005. Mr. Silleck was born on June 5, 1917 in Brooklyn, New York. He graduated from The Hill School in Pottstown, Pennsylvania and from Yale University in 1939. He attended OCS at Annapolis, and after his graduation was commissioned an officer in the United State Nave. He served as captain on destroyers throughout World War II, participating in many of the major naval battles in the Pacific, including the Battle of the Coral Sea, Midway and Okinawa. After returning from the war, he joined the First National Bank, and eventually became a Vice President of First National City Bank. Following his retirement from Citibank, he joined Bradford Corporation. Mr. Silleck remained an active sailor throughout his life. He was a member of the American Yacht Club, and a former member of the Bronxville Field Club and the Racquet & Tennis Club of New York. He met his wife, Patricia Phillips Silleck, in Hawaii shortly after the Pearl Harbor attack. She survives him as do his son, Robert Yadn Silleck, of Denver, Colorado and his daughter, Patricia Ranlet Conway, of Greenwich, as well as four grandchildren. He was predeceased by his son, John Howland Silleck, and his grandson, John Phillips Conway. A memorial service will be held this summer at Kimogener Point on Long Island. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Hill School, 717 East High Street, Pottstown, Pennsylvania 19464.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 3 Wounded Near School
description: Three people were wounded, including a 12-year-old girl, when gunfire erupted about 3 p.m. yesterday near Public School 191 in Crown Heights, just after students had been released for the day, the police said. The girl, whose identity was not disclosed and was believed to be a student at the school, was shot once in the lower back and was in stable condition at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center. The other victims were a 25-year-old-man in stable condition at Brookdale with a wound to his torso, and a 21-year-old man with a minor wound to the torso, the authorities said. Five shell casings were found near the corner of Sterling Place and Buffalo Avenue. The motive for the shooting was unclear and there were no arrests last night. Chelice Harris, 14, who was returning home from another school, heard several shots. "I don't know how many because I was too scared," she said. "I saw kids running and hitting the floor." Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WELLING, KATHRYN T.
description: WELLING--Kathryn T. Our beloved angel Kate has joined the angels in Heaven much too soon. Having just celebrated her 21st birthday on March 30, she was excited and enthusiastic about life in general, but particularly about her impending semester abroad in Luxembourg. She embodied the concept of beauty, both on the inside and the outside. She was a loving, caring and giving person whose greatest joys were being with and caring for young children, as a Camp Counselor at Camp Fernwood, a Swim Counselor at Camp Mohawk, in a community service program in Fiji, and most passionately as an aunt to Reese and Chase Welling. Her death in a fire at an offcampus residence at Miami University in Ohio on April 10th has left a void that can never be filled. She was a loving daughter to Tom and Helen, a loving sister to Kurt and Thomas, a loving granddaughter to Evelyn, a loving aunt to Reese and Chase, a loving niece to more than 20 aunts and uncles, a loving cousin to dozens, and a loving and supportive friend to all who were fortunate enough to bask in her warming light. She will be missed and mourned by all who knew her, but will never be forgotten. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 6 to 9 PM Thursday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM Friday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Saturday, April 16th, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers or donations to charities, contributions may be sent to The Kathryn T. Welling Memorial Fund and mailed to Dennis Glazer, Esq. at Davis Polk & Wardwell, 450 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

World Briefing | Europe: Spain: 11 Pakistanis Charged In Terror Plots
description: The National Court indicted 11 Pakistani men on charges that they raised money for Al Qaeda sympathizers and conspired to commit terrorist acts in Spain. All were arrested last year on suspicion of forming a terrorist cell in Barcelona. Court documents say the recipients of the group's money included Rabei Osman Sayed Ahmed, known as Muhammad the Egyptian. He is charged with helping to carry out the Madrid train bombings in March 2004 and has boasted that he was their architect. The documents also say the group sent money to the Islamic militants suspected of killing a Wall Street Journal reporter, Daniel Pearl, in 2002 in Pakistan. Renwick McLean (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Premier Cancels Moscow Visit
description: Diplomatic tension between the new Ukrainian government and the Kremlin surfaced anew as Yulia V. Tymoshenko, Ukraine's prime minister, postponed a visit to Moscow amid indications that she remained wanted in Russia on allegations of white-collar crime. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVIN, WILBUR A.
description: LEVIN--Wilbur A., 84, died at home on April 12, 2005. He was County Clerk and Clerk of the Supreme Court and Commissioner of Jurors, Kings County, and former President, CEO and Chairman of Independence Savings Bank, and President of Martin's Department Store. Bill was a long-time board member of many institutions, including Brooklyn Law School, Helen Keller Services for the Blind, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Brooklyn Hospital Center, Prospect Park Alliance and the New York Organ Donor Network. He was a graduate of the Boston Latin School and Yale College ('41), and a First Lieutenant in the Army (1942-1946). In addition to his dedicated public service, Bill will long be remembered for the sense of humor and sound advice that guided his family and many friends through life, as well as for the candy and silver dollars he found in their ears. He is survived by his wife Phyllis; their four children: John Levin (and Louisa Swift), Peter (and Anna) Levin, Emme (and Jonathan) Deland, and Kate Levin (and Mark di Suvero); seven grandchildren: Dylan, Mariah, Rawle, Will, Ned, Kate and Veri; and his sister Jean Brenner. Memorial service Friday, April 15, 11 AM in the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please donate to any of the above charities. LEVIN--Wilbur A. All of us at Independence Community Bank mourn the death of Wilbur A. Levin, 84, a friend, business leader, and generous public citizen. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Phyllis, his children, grandchildren and the entire family for their loss. "Bill" Levin joined the Bank's Board of Trustees in 1965, was elected Executive Vice President in 1972 and became our 10th President in 1973, a post he held until 1985 when he became Chairman of the Board, retiring in 1995. During his tenure Mr. Levin had a pivotal role in creating a strong bank despite the deregulation of interest rates that led to economic upheaval in the banking industry. He also played an industry leadership role with the Community Bankers Association of NY State, frequently representing the Bank and the industry in Washington and Albany on regulatory issues and other challenges. Bill Levin set a high personal standard for community service and made it part of the Bank's business philosophy. In addition to many other civic activities that have enriched the life of the city and its people, Bill Levin was instrumental in the renaissance of the Downtown Brooklyn commercial district and the revival of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and Prospect Park. He continues to be the inspiration for the active involvement of Independence and its executives in the civic and economic life of the communities where we live and work. Bill Levin also brought a high moral tone to everything he did which stands as an example to everyone in business. As a friend, a business leader and an extraordinary public citizen, all of us will miss him. Charles J. Hamm, Chairman Alan H. Fishman, President & CEO and The Board of Directors of Independence Community Bank LEVIN--Wilbur A. The Brooklyn Hospital Center is profoundly saddened by the passing of its esteemed Trustee, Wilbur A. Levin. Bill Levin has been a Trustee of The Brooklyn Hospital Center since June of 1964. Over his tenure of forty-one years, he served as Chairman of The Governance Committee (formerly Nominating Committee), the Development and Community Relations Committee, and the Joint Conference Committee. He was currently a member of the Executive Committee, and had previously served on the Operations Committee, and Financial Development Committee. In 1986, he was the first Trustee to receive the Hospital's Founder's Medal at the First Founders Ball event, and in 1999, he was recognized as the Hospital's Distinguished Trustee at the United Hospital Fund Annual Distinguished Trustee Luncheon. His integrity, thoughtfulness, and sense of humor will be greatly missed. The Board of Trustees, and the entire Brooklyn Hospital family extend deepest sympathy to the Levin family. LEVIN--Wilbur A. The Brooklyn Academy of Music mourns Bill Levin, lifelong champion of all things Brooklyn. Karen Brooks Hopkins, President

title: The Listings; MICHAEL TILSON THOMAS
description: The music director of the San Francisco Symphony has a theatrical flair that is, one could say, in the genes. His grandparents, Boris and Bessie Thomashefsky, were legendary pioneers of New York's once-booming Yiddish stage. As celebrity actors, producers and entrepreneurs, they helped create the famed Second Avenue milieu that reflected and refracted the fears, anxieties and longings of the newly arrived. But while the impact of this theater on Tin Pan Alley and the American musical is readily acknowledged, few theatergoers today have had direct contact with the original materials of the early Yiddish stage. Enter Mr. Thomas (above), who for the last seven years has been assembling scores, scripts and memories in an attempt to preserve his grandparents' history and the broader impact of their immigrant theatrical world. This weekend at Zankel Hall, he will present the fruits of his foraging in "The Thomashefskys: Music and Memories of a Life in the Yiddish Theater," directed by Patricia Birch. The semistaged program promises readings from memoirs, restored musical numbers and, one can hope, a sensibility that moves beyond nostalgia to recover a cultural moment often evoked but seldom appreciated on its own terms. (Tomorrow night at 7:30 and Sunday at 4 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212)247-7800. Tickets: $38 and $50.) JEREMY EICHLER

title: The Listings; ROBERT GLASPER
description: The jazz pianist Robert Glasper, who is 26, worked slowly and doggedly when he came to New York in 1999 after growing up in Texas. He moonlighted with hip-hop and R&B performers like Mos Def, Meshell Ndegeocello and Bilal. But he kept playing his piano-trio gigs, honing a history-minded and slightly hyperactive approach that blasts through piano styles from Erroll Garner to Keith Jarrett to Herbie Hancock; in every tune, his music sprawled. The trio's interaction, and its incredible momentum once the tunes got rolling, was obviously something special. Persistence finally paid off, and in February he was signed to Blue Note records, the label's first new-artist signing in five years. Mr. Glasper's trio -- Vicente Archer on bass and Damion Reid on drums -- already sounds well prepared for its big recording, but the musicians are getting in a few last weekends in New York's small clubs. He performs this weekend at Fat Cat, and then a few dates next month at Smalls. He'll record after the Smalls dates, and the record comes out in October. (Tonight and tomorrow night at 10:30, midnight, 1:30 and 2:30, Fat Cat, 75 Christopher Street, West Village, (212)675-7369; cover charge is $10. description: The European Commission said it would decide by April 25 whether to begin a formal investigation into a surge in textile products from China, after analyzing import data from the first quarter of this year. The company, based in Natick, Mass., said that it would start selling the Liberte product for implanting stents immediately in the United States. Stents are small tubes used to prop open cleared arteries. Separately, Boston Scientific said that it had agreed to buy the 46 percent of the Rubicon Medical Corporation, another maker of medical devices, for about $71.7 million. Rubicon is based in Salt Lake City.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Get This Monkey Off His Back
description: A male chimpanzee at Bloemfontein Zoo is wrestling to break a nicotine addiction after picking up the smoking habit from visitors who tossed lit cigarette butts into his enclosure, zoo officials said. The adult chimp, named Charlie, probably acquired the butts by mimicking zoogoers' smoking as they passed by, leading them to toss him cigarettes. Charlie now hides his cigarettes when zookeepers approach so that they will not be confiscated, officials said. Nor is it his only bad habit. Charlie has three bad teeth, said a zoo official, Daryl Barnes, blame for which goes to visitors who continue to feed him sugary soft drinks. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WELLING, KATHRYN T.
description: WELLING--Kathryn T. Our beloved angel Kate has joined the angels in Heaven much too soon. Having just celebrated her 21st birthday on March 30, she was excited and enthusiastic about life in general, but particularly about her impending semester abroad in Luxembourg. She embodied the concept of beauty, both on the inside and the outside. She was a loving, caring and giving person whose greatest joys were being with and caring for young children, as a Camp Counselor at Camp Fernwood, a Swim Counselor at Camp Mohawk, in a community service program in Fiji, and most passionately as an aunt to Reese and Chase Welling. Her death in a fire at an offcampus residence at Miami University in Ohio on April 10th has left a void that can never be filled. She was a loving daughter to Tom and Helen, a loving sister to Kurt and Thomas, a loving granddaughter to Evelyn, a loving aunt to Reese and Chase, a loving niece to more than 20 aunts and uncles, a loving cousin to dozens, and a loving and supportive friend to all who were fortunate enough to bask in her warming light. She will be missed and mourned by all who knew her, but will never be forgotten. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 6 to 9 PM Thursday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM Friday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Saturday, April 16th, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers or donations to charities, contributions may be sent to The Kathryn T. Welling Memorial Fund and mailed to Dennis Glazer, Esq. at Davis Polk & Wardwell, 450 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

The Board of Trustees, staff and auxiliary of Brooklyn Botanic Garden are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and former Trustee Wilbur Levin. A much-loved leader in the Brooklyn Community, Bill gave over 35 years of dedicated service to the garden. His charm, wonderful sense of humor, genuine kindness, love of culture and the arts, and deep commitment to the garden and Brooklyn will be truly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Phyllis, his children, John, Peter, Emme and Kate, and to his entire family. Earl D. Weiner, Board Chairman Judith D. Zuk, President Katherine Doran, Aux Pres LEVIN--Wilbur A. The Zeitz Foundation mourns the loss of our fellow officer and director. He was a compassionate individual whose wise counsel to family, friends and the many organizations with which he was associated was always valued and relied upon. Bill's sense of humor and sage guidance were a gift remembered and cherished by all who knew him. His intellect, integrity and strong commitment to serving his community are reflected in the many charitable oganizations he served as a supporter, leader and advisor. title: The Listings; JULIO SARMENTO: 'SOME LIMITS OF REASON'
description: Over the last two decades, this Portuguese painter has stayed true -- obsessively, some might say -- to his signature image of a sexy woman in a simple black dress, her head cropped at the chin like that of a store window mannequin. In his latest paintings Mr. Sarmento enlists this enigmatic figure in the service of an oddly academic exercise. Drawn on expanses of loosely applied white paint in a schematic, sometimes smudgy black line, the woman appears sitting on, standing among or kneeling under various pieces of furniture. Lines about sexuality and transgression from an essay about Georges Bataille by Michele Foucault have been silk-screened onto the surfaces along with titles like "Kiss Me" and "I Love You." One typically portentous and grammatically doubtful caption reads, "Sexuality points to nothing beyond itself, except in a frenzy which disrupts it." Mr. Sarmento has also translated his headless woman into three dimensions in the form of life-size sculptures -- translucent shells of flesh-colored cast resin. She crouches under a table naked, stands in a real black dress among rows of antique chairs (above) and otherwise enacts the role of an alluring but inaccessible love object. Mr. Sarmento's art exudes a certain poignant yearning but it is frozen by its own icy elegance. Might the headless woman be an unconscious symbol of arrested creative development? Maybe she needs a little sexual frenzy to warm her up and get her moving. (Sean Kelly, 528 West 29th Street, Chelsea, (212)239-1181, through April 23.) KEN JOHNSON

description: Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey yesterday signed into law a bill requiring many homes and apartments to be equipped with a fire extinguisher upon sale, lease or transfer. State Senator Joseph Coniglio, a Democrat from Paramus, first drafted the bill two years ago, when an elementary school student suggested it. Senator Coniglio was visiting Cliffside Park School when a fifth grader, Christopher Keethe, asked why homes were not required to have a fire extinguisher. A Teenager Collects Adult Wisdom From a Simple-Minded Janitor and a Woman in Jail
description: The reasons to avoid "House of D," David Duchovny's earnest, unwatchable coming-of-age drama, can best be summarized in a simple declarative sentence. Robin Williams plays a retarded janitor. For some reason, Mr. Williams, a comedian of prodigious gifts who occasionally shows himself to be a more than capable character actor, is fatefully drawn to a particular kind of sentimentality. The character of Pappass, a wise, kindly, mentally disabled man who helps guide a troubled boy on life's difficult journey, must have been irresistible to him, given his track record of crinkly, heartfelt mugging. "House of D," for its part, will be irresistible to those hardy, wet-eyed souls who cherish "Patch Adams," "Bicentennial Man" and "Jakob the Liar." Enough said.

SOUTHWEST AIRLINES QUARTERLY PROFIT NEARLY TRIPLED
description: Southwest Airlines said yesterday that first-quarter profit almost tripled as the airline added flights, carried more passengers and paid less for jet fuel than rivals. Net income increased to $76 million, or 9 cents a share, from $26 million, or 3 cents, in the year-earlier period. The profit, aided by a gain on accounting for fuel hedging, was almost double the 5 cents forecast by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Sales rose 12 percent, to $1.66 billion. Southwest, the only major United States airline to remain profitable since the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, attracts customers with low fares. The company is based in Dallas.

He is survived by his wife Maxine K. Armstrong, and daughters Elizabeth & Amanda; sister, Christy McKenzie. Services will be Friday, April 15, at 11 AM at the Greenwich Polo Club in Conyers Farm, Greenwich, CT. Donations may be made in his memory to Reach Prep, 115 East Putnam Ave, Greenwich, CT 06830. ARMSTRONG--Thomas E. The Board of Directors, administrators, faculty and students of REACH Prep note with great sorrow the loss of Thomas E. Armstrong. His warmth and friendship will be deeply missed. He, along with his wife, Maxine K. Armstrong, Founding Chairman of REACH Prep cared profoundly about its mission to enrich the lives of under-represented children. We are grateful for his family's immeasurable contributions. We extend our deepest sympathies to Maxine and her daughters, Bette and Amanda. His noble qualities will endure forever. Linda G. Ortwein, REACH Prep, Inc.

Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Three Face Charges In Attack
description: Three teenagers were charged yesterday in the machete attack at a Bronx subway station that left one high school student dead and two injured, law enforcement officials said. The three, Alexander Ramirez, 15; Bolivar Picardo, 18; and Lucas Denis, 19, were charged with second-degree murder in the death of Marviel Martinez. Mr. Martinez, 17, a DeWitt Clinton High School student, was stabbed with a machete while waiting on the uptown No. 4 platform at 183rd Street and Jerome Avenue on Tuesday morning. Two of his friends, Fernando Ramales and Danilo Valiente, were injured in the attack. Mr. Denis is also facing charges of attempted murder, assault and criminal possession of a weapon. Mr. Picardo is being charged with criminal possession of a weapon. Mr. Ramirez was charged with attempted murder. The dispute was apparently over a girl, the police said. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

Metro Briefing | New York: Valhalla: Union Official Removed
description: A union official at the Westchester Medical Center who gave $500 to a newspaper reporter has been removed and is barred from holding office for three years, state union officials said. The official, Dunbar John, the hospital's unit president, gave a reporter for The Journal News five $100 bills inside a greeting card in February. He denied it was a bribe and said it was his way of thanking the reporter, Melissa Klein, for fair coverage of the hospital. The money was returned to Mr. John. The judicial board of the Civil Service Employees Union ruled this week that Mr. John's actions were detrimental to the union and violated his oath of office. A lawyer for Mr. John said yesterday that he planned to appeal the judicial board's decision. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Income Surges At Infosys

The company said increased business from companies in the United States fueled the increase in sales, which totaled 19.87 billion rupees in the period. Excluding income from the sale of the stake, Infosys earnings rose 53 percent, to 5.13 billion rupees. The company said it added 37 customers in the quarter, giving it 438. Saritha Rai (NYT)

Arts, Briefly; More 'Idol' Worship
description: NBC and Fox shared Wednesday night's No.1 slot in Nielsen's estimates. An hourlong "American Idol" brought in 24.09 million viewers, enough to put Fox in first place for the night in the 18-to-49 demographic and total viewers. Also on Fox was the series premiere of the Pamela Anderson comedy, "Stacked," below. Though it nearly tied NBC's "Dateline" for first place among adults 18 to 49, it drew a middling 8.1 million viewers even though its main competition for a male audience, ABC's "Lost," was a repeat. NBC won Wednesday in households. Its entire lineup -- a "Dateline" special (yet another exploration of the mythology of "The Da Vinci Code"), the premiere of "Revelations" and "Law & Order" -- performed well. In the time period usually occupied by "The West Wing," which concluded its season last week, "Revelations" scored better ratings than any "West Wing" episode this season: an audience of 15.35 million. With that strong lead-in, "Law & Order" (16.72 million) easily beat "CSI: NY" (10.64 million) at 10 p.m. in an episode in which Jesse L. Martin's character was shot so that Mr. Martin could take a leave from the show to perform in the movie version of "Rent." KATE AURTHUR

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Court Acquits Two British Reporters
description: Two British journalists accused of illegally reporting on Zimbabwe's March 31 parliamentary elections were acquitted by a rural Zimbabwe court after the judge ruled that the government's evidence was so confused that it actually helped the defense. The journalists, from The Sunday Telegraph of London, were arrested outside a polling station and accused of working without state accreditation, an offense that carries a two-year prison sentence. But the judge said the pair's digital camera held no incriminating photographs, and their shorthand notes were indecipherable to prosecutors. Their lawyer had argued that they were in Zimbabwe on a vacation. They still face charges of overstaying their seven-day visa, an offense punishable by a year in jail. Michael Wines (NYT)

description: The mystery surrounding the identity of the "naked admirer" in the new Lucian Freud painting, "The Painter Surprised by a Naked Admirer," unveiled on Wednesday at the National Portrait Gallery in London, appears to be solved. Although the gallery and the artist remain mum, a reporter from The Times of London quoted Sir David Williams-Wynn, the father of Alexandra Williams-Wynn, as saying: "I saw her last week. She doesn't in any way deny that she is in his painting." Ms. Williams-Wynn, 32, a sculptor and student at the Royal Academy of Arts, is known to be a friend of Mr. Freud, who is 82. PAM KENT

title: Bush Disarms, Unilaterally
description: One of the things that I can't figure out about the Bush team is why an administration that is so focused on projecting U.S. military strength abroad has taken such little interest in America's economic competitiveness at home -- the underlying engine of our strength. At a time when the global economic playing field is being flattened -- enabling young Indians and Chinese to collaborate and compete with Americans more than ever before -- this administration is off on an ideological jag. It is trying to take apart the New Deal by privatizing Social Security, when what we really need most today is a New New Deal to make more Americans employable in 21st-century jobs.

description: Geezers often say how little is being done to bring along the next generation of leaders, but Us Weekly, the celebrity-wrangling confection of a magazine, finally did something about it on Wednesday night. Amid a crush of paparazzi and a brace of searchlights panning the Los Angeles sky, the magazine held its Young Hot Hollywood Style Awards. Those who were worried about where the next cadre of fashion leadership is coming from would have been heartened by the sight of Jessica Simpson, Paris Hilton and Jessica Alba, right, all tirelessly and fearlessly working the red carpet in front of Element, a nightclub not far from Grauman's Chinese Theater. On a night when people famous for being famous got their due, Ms. Simpson, a host of the event, was named Style Icon of the Year, while Ms. Hilton set the pace as Trendsetter of the Year and Ms. Alba won Best Movie-Star Style. (Ms. Hilton's partner in reality, Nicole Richie, had a subcategory, Best Red-Carpet Style, locked up.) Janice Min, the editor in chief of US Weekly, said the party was just an amusing way of "capturing who is hot right now." DAVID CARR

title: UNIT OF PARMALAT THAT SELLS MILK EXITS BANKRUPTCY
description: The United States unit of Parmalat Finanziaria, Italy's biggest food company, exited bankruptcy yesterday with a plan to continue selling milk in New York, New Jersey and Michigan. The subsidiary, Farmland Dairies, will pay creditors and expenses with a $56 million loan from LaSalle Business Credit and a $45 million loan from the General Electric Company's GE Commercial Finance unit, according to court papers. In exchange for $39 million in financing provided to Farmland and its Parmalat USA Corporation affiliate during bankruptcy proceedings, General Electric will receive a 70 percent stake in Farmland, all of its preferred stock, $11.6 million in litigation proceeds and up to $2 million in additional payments. Parmalat USA is liquidating its assets and will no longer exist. Farmland and Parmalat USA filed for bankruptcy protection in February 2004, two months after Parmalat Finanziaria, based in Milan, sought bankruptcy protection in Italy.

And as she sings in a deep, slightly eerie alto that hovers in the same register as Carly Simon's, strong emotions send tiny seismic shocks through her lean, well-toned body. Meanwhile, her face, crowned by a helmet of dark red hair, remains an ageless mask, enigmatic, flawless.

description: A beluga whale spent a third day yesterday cruising back and forth in the Delaware River south of Trenton, the Department of Environmental Protection reported. Belugas often migrate into estuaries and rivers, though marine mammal rescuers could not recall ever spotting one so far up the Delaware. Biologists generally hesitate to interfere with the behavior of healthy animals, but state officials said they might intervene if it appeared the whale was ill or otherwise impaired. Meanwhile, the Group for Research and Education on Marine Mammals, which is based in Quebec, said the whale might be from a group identified near the St. Lawrence River in Canada in 1986. title: The Listings; DAVID KORINS
description: A theatrical set designer who doesn't stop at the footlights, David Korins, 28, likes to create total environments that start at the point where the audience walks in. He did this most recently with an empty space at Theater for the New City in the East Village (above), where he has built a pristine wood-paneled theater for Craig Wright's drama "Orange Flower Water," directed by Mr. Korins's wife, Carolyn Cantor. In 2001 the couple founded the Edge Theater Company, which is presenting the play, about two marriages coming apart. The designer said recently that he had envisioned "a warm and welcoming place, a wooden womb -- so we could rip your heart out." The story unfolds like a boxing match: when any of the four actors portraying the spouses are not in a scene, they sit on wooden chairs at the four corners of the performing space and watch. It's both intimate and public, like life in the fictional small town of Pine City, Minn., where the play is set. Benches for the audience surround the performers on three sides to emphasize "the communal experience of the bench rather than the separateness of the chair," Mr. Korins said. It is part of his plan: the whole room is a set and the audience the townspeople. In his free time, Mr. Korins, who also designs furniture and lofts, has done the production designs for the forthcoming Ed Harris/Will Farrell film by Adam Rapp, "Winter Passing," and 13 episodes of HBO's "Family Bonds." Last year, for his environmental set for Mr. Rapp's play "Blackbird," an Edge production Off Broadway that took place in a squalid apartment, Mr. Korins won the Henry Hewes Award for best scenic design from the American Theater Wing, beating out several Broadway designers. Before and after shots of the dingy Canal Street digs are on his Web site: www.davidkorinsdesign.com. Asked if he was hands-on for "Orange Flower Water," Mr. Korins said: "I have so many splinters, I can't even tell you." (This weekend's schedule: tonight and tomorrow at 8 p.m.; Sunday, 7 p.m., Theater for the New City, 155 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, (212)868-4444. Tickets: $19.) ANDREA STEVENS

description: A group of Upper East Side condominium owners, locked in a long dispute over repairs at their luxury apartments, filed a federal lawsuit yesterday against the condominium developer using a law more typically employed against mob bosses. The civil suit filed under the racketeering law known as RICO seeks tens of millions of dollars in damages. Apartments at the building at 188 East 78th Street, known as the Empire, sold for as much as $4.5 million. The board of managers of the Empire say that apartments are often sweltering in summer and freezing in winter. They said that the 31-story building has suffered extensive water damage since it opened in 2000 and that owners of the approximately 70 condos have had to contend with buckling floorboards and ill-fitting windows. In 2003, a settlement brokered by the state attorney general's office called for the builders to make repairs. The suit filed yesterday claims the work was not done. One of the developers, Aby Rosen of RFR Holding, who said he had not seen the suit, said that the dispute was settled and "the work has been in progress." title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Film Studios Settle Suit On DVD Copying
description: Hollywood studios said yesterday that they had settled a lawsuit against ESS Technology, a multimedia chip maker accused of illegally allowing its products to be used in DVD copying devices. The Motion Picture Association of America had contended that ESS violated a contract by selling DVD decoding chips to manufacturers that did not have licenses to the studios' antipiracy technology. A California state court judge blocked ESS from selling any of its DVD chips to other unlicensed manufactures last July. ESS said that the settlement was amicable, and that it had agreed to respect all copyright provisions. "ESS totally supports the enforcement of all parties' valid intellectual property rights and is committed to being a leader in enabling content protection features," the chief executive, Robert L. Blair, said. The suit was part of a recent wave of Hollywood enforcement actions against hardware makers that studios believe are contributing to piracy.

Daiei, the victim of a long slump in consumer spending and an overly ambitious expansion plan, is selling off a professional baseball team, hotels and other businesses in a government-administered reorganization that began last year. Daiei forecast a net profit of 403 billion yen for the fiscal year ending Feb. 28, 2006. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VARET, GUSTER V
description: VARET -- Guster V, died peacefully at home on April 13th at age 96. He was the beloved husband of 68 years of his adored wife, Frances, who survives him. Born in Russia in 1908 he immigrated to the United States as a young child and grew up in Freehold, New Jersey. He attended New York University from which he graduated in 1931. For many years before he retired, he was a certified public accountant practicing in New York. He was the beloved father and father-in-law of Ellen and Charles Bock and Michael and Elizabeth Varet; and, cherished grandfather of Lauren and Adam Schwartz, and Joseph, Sarah and David Varet. Funeral will be private. The family will observe shiva at the home of Elizabeth and Michael Varet beginning Sunday. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to either Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale, 475 West 250th St, Riverdale, NY 10471, or New York University (Varet Family Fund), Room 910, 100 Washington Square East, New York, NY 10003-6688.

title: Arts, Briefly; The Pope on Screen
description: A mini-series that is billed as presenting Pope John Paul II as a down-to-earth kind of guy and not as a saint will be broadcast on Italian television on Monday and Tuesday. Tracking his life from Krakow in 1939 and the Nazi invasion of Poland to his election as pope in 1978, "Karol, the Man Who Became Pope" is fiction and not a documentary, the director, Giacomo Battiato, told the ANSA news agency, though he said it was based on historically accurate events. The young Karol Wojtyla, portrayed by Piotr Adamczyk, right, is presented as a patriot in occupied Poland, and as a committed priest. The series apparently skirts any suggestion of romantic entanglements. The screenplay was reportedly vetted by the Holy See, the daily newspaper La Repubblica said. The newspaper also wrote that when the producer, Pietro Valsecchi, informed the pope of plans for a film about his life, John Paul warned him: "Careful not to make mistakes." A second series, tracking the years of John Paul's papacy, is to be filmed in the fall. The $14.2 million project was previewed at the Pontifical Lateran University in Rome on Thursday, and ANSA reported that many tears were shed. ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

title: Arts, Briefly; Reality: She's In, He's Out
description: On a typical Thursday, CBS was No.1 in all key measures in Nielsen's estimates, as new episodes of "Survivor," "CSI" and "Without a Trace" swept every hour of the night. On "Survivor," Stephenie LaGrossa, below, the last remaining member of her tribe, was sent to the other group and was able to integrate herself well enough to avoid elimination; 20 million viewers watched the show. "CSI" was Thursday's most-watched program, as its audience of 27 million more than doubled the number of people who watched Donald Trump fire Chris Shelton on NBC's "Apprentice" (12 million). Earlier this week, the Web site thesmokinggun.com reported that Mr. Shelton had been arrested in Tampa, Fla., on Sunday for disorderly conduct. During his "Apprentice" run, Mr. Shelton lost seven challenges in a row, was forced to give up chewing tobacco because Mr. Trump found it disgusting and was accused of having an anger-management problem. Upon his "Apprentice" ouster, Mr. Shelton cried, and Mr. Trump comforted him. KATE AURTHUR

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Brussels: Animal Feed Rules Stiffened
description: The European Union agreed to impose stricter tests on animal feed originating in the United States after a mix-up resulted in the entry of tons of unapproved genetically modified corn over the last three years. The United States government said that Europe was overreacting, and the producer of the corn, Syngenta, said there was no threat to humans, animals or the environment from the corn, known as Bt-10. The company, which is based in Basel, Switzerland, warned that tests of animal feed were unlikely to reveal much because the Bt-10 corn was mixed into approved corn varieties in tiny amounts. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Russia: Bombs In Caucasus, Shots In Chechnya
description: Violence flared anew in the restive Caucasus region as a pair of bombs destroyed a prosecutor's office in Dagestan and the authorities engaged in a gun battle with insurgents in an apartment building in Grozny, Chechnya's capital. Three people were hurt but no one was killed by the bombs, which appeared to have been tossed onto the prosecutor's building from a taller building, igniting a fire. It was not immediately clear who was responsible. In Grozny, six Chechen fighters were killed in the standoff, including at least one camouflage-clad woman, whose remains were shown on national television beside a portable antiaircraft missile. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Never a Dull Moment
description: Gloria Trevi, left, the Mexican pop star who was released from prison in September, has canceled her concert in Manhattan tonight because she is pregnant and needs rest, a spokesman for her record company, Sony BMG, said yesterday. Ms. Trevi, left, was arrested in Brazil in 2000 over charges that she and Sergio Andrade, then her husband and manager, had abducted and sexually abused a number of teenage girls, and she became pregnant with Mr. Andrade's child while in prison. Ms. Trevi was cleared of charges, but in March a judge in Mexico sentenced Mr. Andrade to more than seven years in prison for the rape, kidnapping and corruption of an under-age girl. Ms. Trevi announced last week that she was pregnant again and that the father was her boyfriend, Armando Gomez. Her concert, at the United Palace Theater at Broadway and 175th Street in Washington Heights, has been postponed until fall, said Miguel Garrocho, the record company spokesman. But Mr. Garrocho said she would continue with selected dates on her tour and might perform -- seated -- at a radio station-sponsored concert in New York in June. BEN SISARIO

He and his wife Katherine Iriving Baxter, who died in January, 2005, were formerly residents of Rye and Southampton, NY. He was a graduate of Harvard College and NYU Law School, and was with the firm of Duer, Strong and Whitehead in New York City until his retirement. Its title has gone from "Born & Bred" to "Second Nature" to simply "Untitled," for now. (It stars Joely Fisher and Matt Letscher, below.) title: Inside the List
description: GETTING HER YA-YAS OUT: It's not uncommon for a pop novelist -- Patricia Cornwell is a good example -- to have the No. 1 books on both the hardcover and paperback fiction best-seller lists at the same time. For nonfiction writers, however, this kind of domination is practically unheard of. Malcolm Gladwell has pulled it off -- his new book, "Blink," is No. 1 on the hardcover list again this week, and his previous book, "The Tipping Point," sits atop the paperback side. "The Tipping Point" was about "social epidemics," about how ideas and trends spread the way viruses do. Interestingly, one of the word-of-mouth "epidemics" Gladwell explored in his book was the slow, up-from-the-bottom success of Rebecca Wells's 1996 novel, "Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood." Wells's book sold modestly for a year or two before it "tipped" in 1998, becoming a paperback best seller for 84 weeks and spawning a Sandra Bullock movie. For Wells's fans, it's been a long, lonely wait for a follow-up, but nine years later that book is finally here: "Ya-Yas in Bloom" (HarperCollins) makes its debut on the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 3. What took her so long? According to her Web site, Wells has been ill with a variety of mysterious and increasingly dire symptoms; she was finally told she had advanced Lyme disease. At times she was so weak she was forced to dictate portions of "Ya-Yas in Bloom" into a tape recorder. Wells, a former actress, is said to be a sprightly reader of her work at bookstore appearances, but this time around she has nixed a potential book tour. She is getting better, she writes, but will sorely miss "dressing up and prissing across the stage."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MELIS, JOSE
description: MELIS--Jose, formerly of Bronxville, NY, passed away in Sun City, AZ on Tuesday April 7th, 2005. Best known as the Musical Director for Jack Paar's Tonight Show, Jose was born in Havana, Cuba on February 27th, 1920. A child prodigy, he began studying piano when he was three years old, with his first performance at the age of four. He was a professor of Solfeggio and Theory at eight years old and graduated from the Havana Conservatory of Music when he was ten. In Paris, he studied with the eminent Alfred Cortot under a Cuban government scholarship. Jose arrived in the U.S. at the age of 16 to study under the tutelage of the distinguished Erwin Bodky in Cambridge, MA, where he graduated from the Longy School of Music. From there he went to New York to study at the Julliard School of Music when, in 1943, he was drafted. Jose served in the US Army and was stationed in Corpus Christi where he met the love of his life, Sue Renfrow. In 1944, he married Sue in a civil ceremony in Nashville, TN while on tour with the USO, at which time he served as conductor and musical arranger of a 40 piece band. While in the army, Jose met Jack Paar and joined him through the run of the CBS Morning Show, the CBS Afternoon Show and, finally, the Tonight Show, for which he wrote the theme song "I-M-4-U". He cut many records under contract with SEECO and Mercury Records, and performed with or conducted for numerous artists, from Frank Sinatra to Clark Terry to Tito Puente. He has been feature performer for the Boston Pops, and the Saint Louis, Rochester, and Miami Symphonies, to name a few. In later years, though blind and almost completely deaf, he performed benefits for various civic organizations and institutions. Jose lived less than two years after his beloved wife died. He leaves his daughter and son-in-law, Suzanne and John Golembieski, his son and daughter-in-law, Michael Melis and Carmen, as well as seven grandchildren, with an eighth predeceased, and three great - grandchildren. Surviving as well is his brother, Rafael Guiu; a sister, Rosita Dinsmore died not long ago. Jose Melis was a fine husband and father, a great talent, and an honorable man. As his life ebbed, his fingers played melodies on the counterpanes. In the end, he was still making music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISLER, ROBERT PARKE
description: FISLER--Robert Parke, 84, in Newburyport, MA, died April 10 while in the company of his loving family. He was preceded in death by his wife, Elizabeth (nee Parker) of 45 years who died on December 14, 2004. Mr. Fisler is survived by his children and extended family including Barbara and her husband Charles Sturtevant (RI), Janet Dutton (CA), Helen Fisler (TX), Peter Fisler (CA), Parke Fisler and his wife, Christine Fisler (MA), and a loyal troupe of grandchildren and step-grandchildren. He was born and reared in Brooklyn, NY and graduated from Peekskill Military Academy. A defiant cadet, he ultimately learned how to harness his fierce energy and intellect. He became a voracious reader (of history, in particular), an agile lacrosse and soccer player as well as an astute student. He went on to Brown University (and remained a vocal fan and supporter). His academic career was interrupted by WWII as he joined the Army and flew the Burma India hump. Post War, he initially worked at St. John Associates, a direct mail advertising firm started by his aunt, Helen V. Fisler, but he soon moved forth to his Camelot--Time, Inc. This, he repeatedly proclaimed, was the luckiest move of his life for it provided him the perfect fit and forum for his multiple talents. "Time, Inc", he always said, was a "great club"--an amazing group of people who were bright, verbal, energetic, spirited, curious, and creative. Informed and informative, he adored Time Inc, and the cerebral challenges that arrived daily. Over a period of some 35 years, he played a pivotal role in nurturing the eclectic, and rather formidable, magazine group: Time, Life, Sports Illustrated, People, Fortune, and Money. His title was VP and his domain was Circulation and Promotion. He was a wordsmith who spun wellcrafted letters that invariably hooked casual readers and turned them into committed subscribers. In addition to his pithy direct mail pieces, he was often the "house" orator/ emcee as he had a talent for writing his signature incisive and memorable odes, poems, songs, and speeches. He was awarded the "Brown Bear Award" for his lifelong contributions to Brown University and numerous professional recognitions throughout his career including the Irving Wundermann and Silver Apple Awards. After retirement, Mr. Fisler received his Master's Degree in American History from Manhattanville College. A diverse mind, he also reveled in numerous diversions. He was an avid golfer, an enthusiastic curler, a formidable and competitive gin player, and later in life, a renewed aviator. His most treasured pleasure was sweeping across a dance floor with elegance and with, of course, his beloved graceful Betsy. He enjoyed good cigars, fine wines, aged scotch, and most importantly, loyal friends and family. He will be missed by them all.

description: HICKMAN--Minnie Cassatt. There is no adequate way to honor Minnie Cassatt Hickman, 73, who passed peacefully on April 10, 2005. She lives on through her three daughters, Mimi, Mary, and Rosie; her six grandchildren; and the many students she mentored in her years teaching at The Lenox School. Her generosity, kind spirit, and wit will be missed by all who knew and loved her. A memorial service will be held on April 29th, at St. Thomas on 5th Avenue, at 4 pm. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Intensive Care Unit of the Good Samaritan Hospital of West Palm Beach, FL.

title: A Radical Feminist Who Could Dine With (Not on) Conservatives
description: It's not surprising that feminists lamented the death last weekend of Andrea Dworkin, the antipornography campaigner and author of such feminist tracts as "Woman Hating." But a few conservatives marked her death, as well. It turns out that Andrea Dworkin and conservatives could agree on at least a couple of issues -- Bill Clinton's presidency, for instance, and pornography. Most surprising of all, the fierce feminist in overalls and the conservatives in suits even shared a meal and some tea. A few excerpts:

title: Learning Self-Discipline and Karate, Too
description: MIDDLE ISLAND - ON one of the nicest days so far in April, after a winter that had shown little mercy, 25 Longwood High School students were eager to finish the day's classes and get into the cafeteria. Wearing gis, the traditional white karate uniforms, they formed straight rows and waited to begin. Honors students, special-education students, students with discipline problems -- all of them quiet and respectful, full of anticipation.

title: UP FRONT
description: IN this week's cover essay, David Gates, a regular contributor to the Book Review, explores what it means -- and what it doesn't mean -- to be considered a literary outlaw. Gates, a senior editor at Newsweek, has some experience in this area. His own novels ("Jernigan," "Preston Falls") and story collection ("The Wonders of the Invisible World") are dark, dangerous rides, filled with characters who skirt the fringes of polite society. Yet Gates said in a telephone interview that he has "conflicted feelings and divided loyalties about literary outlawry -- if there is such a thing anymore. Shakespeare has as much wildness as William Burroughs, Dickens has as much rant and bombast as any overearnest outlaw. Why is Whitman respectable and Ginsberg forever an outsider? The whole thing makes my head hurt, and I guess my piece is an attempt to make readers' heads hurt too."

description: IF you are hard-pressed at this late date to think of anything new anyone could possibly do with the most exhaustively fetishized fabric of the last century -- denim, if you have to ask -- you are just not using your imagination. There have to be new ways to spin that blue fiber, its hardy practicality now hilariously offset by dry-clean-only labels, astronomical price tags and studious rinsing, fraying and fading. Not since Marie-Antoinette played milkmaid at Le Hameau de la Reine has looking simple and honest been so fake and complicated.

To be sure, it was smack in the middle of a pastoral stretch of the neighborhood's historic district -- but you'd imagine that even seasoned renovators would recoil from its wasted systems and its squalor.

title: Sleeping Beauty
description: Every dress has a story, a narrative that illuminates the necessary elements of fabric and cut. Like people (or dogs or any work of art), some dresses are simply more interesting than others: their history is complex or they are particularly revealing of a moment or just heartbreakingly beautiful. Some combination of these traits was immediately apparent when I saw what first looked like a big pile of navy netting spread on the wooden table in my dressmaker's workshop. Irene Cherniakhovsky, along with her associates at Silhouettes and Profiles, is a brilliantly gifted seamstress, able to imagine, and then restore, a garment's shape and character. Among more mundane alterations like hems and side seams, she has rebeaded 20's flapper dresses and repaired the delicate lace on 30's gowns. At first it was hard for me to figure out what she was doing with this small mountain of net until Cherniakhovsky smoothed it out to show off the contours of what was in fact a dress.

title: The Souped-Up, Knock-Out, Total Fiction Experience
description: WHEN it comes to art, we are a nation of extremists. American writing, painting and music have always swung between the minimal and the maximal, the Apollonian and the Dionysian. We believe with equal fervor in artistic self-effacement and artistic self-aggrandizement. We like tiny, well-made stuff and also great sprawling messes; art that is full of feeling and also art that aspires to a kind of icy perfection.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: PRIME. By Poppy Z. Brite. (Three Rivers Press, paper, $13.95.) This is Brite's third novel about the gay New Orleans chefs Rickey and G-man -- partners in business and love -- and we are told that she is at work on a fourth. Can the franchise sustain itself? The answer is yes. To begin with, a high-end restaurant is -- for any competent novelist -- a gift that keeps on giving. The heat, the bickerings and intrigue, the pursuit of perfection, the dodgy money keeping it all afloat: the setting spawns plots. Further, the gentle G-man and his more highly strung partner, Rickey, are distinct but mutually dependent characters, fervently monogamous but with a restlessness in their relationship that keeps things moving. Here, the boys are knocked off balance when their restaurant, Liquor, is given a terrible review, then maintained in their disequilibrium by a curious invitation for Rickey to go to to Dallas and help organize the menu of a troubled fellow chef named Cooper. A decayed charmer and sexual predator, Cooper is a figure of some interest; his palate may still be acute, but his taste for life has coarsened. His rueful but too forgiving sense of himself and his collapsible morals are well caught by Brite.

title: The Right to Remain Silent and Stay Behind the Counter
description: At Donuts Unlimited, a combination doughnut shop and Subway franchise in Queens Plaza, the store manager, Raj Gautam, was going about his usual business on a recent morning: fielding phone calls, ringing up orders for egg-and-cheese sandwiches, and lavishing his customers with napkins. title: Boot the Fake Parties
description: If New Yorkers need another reason to get rid of all these pretend political parties cluttering the ballot, Lenora Fulani provided it last week. Dr. Fulani is in the middle of a firestorm about ugly remarks she made about Israel two decades ago and reaffirmed just last week. She said in the late 1980's that the Jews "had to sell their souls to acquire Israel" and were then forced to "function as mass murderers of people of color" to help their nation survive. She defended the comments last Wednesday on a local television station.

title: The Tner Desert, March 2, 2005
description: Jrme Muller from Montbliard, France: I'm a painter. I went to the desert to capture the lights that change little by little throughout the day, the way the colors change in the paintings of Monet, to try to accurately capture the reality of these colors, to render them more faithfully in my desert paintings -- a series I began a year and a half ago. After about 15 paintings, it seemed indispensable for me to go to see the desert for myself. So I went to southern Morocco. And three months later, I left again for Niger -- this time to Tner, the great desert, which is really, for me, a type of garden where everything is immense and without end. There were these huge dunes in the middle of the journey, where I climbed all the way to the top and took a photo every five minutes to capture the gradations in color over time. Everything was so immense. You have this sort of feeling of flying because the dunes are so high. As told to Austin Considine

title: Trendy Artists Pick Up an Old-Fashioned Habit
description: THE mood was relaxed, even familial, on a recent Tuesday evening as the painter Will Cotton welcomed visitors to his Lower East Side loft. As he set out bowls of chocolate Easter candy, the artist Inka Essenhigh, who first made her name with paintings of anime-like creatures, pinned paper to an easel. Delia Brown, an art world provocateur who specializes in society scenes starring herself, relaxed in a chair with a drawing pad at the ready. The multimedia and performance artist Guy Richards Smit handed Mr. Cotton the first CD of the night -- a post-punk mix -- and unpacked his watercolor kit.

Former Board Member of the Great Neck Synagogue, past President of the Great Neck Synagogue Men's Club and past Deputy Grand Chancellor of the Knights of Pythias, Levittown Lodge 774. title: It's a Flat World, After All
description: The headline for Thomas L. Friedman's insightful article is meaningful in another sense (April 3). I refer to the increasing encroachment of religious extremism and biblical literalism into the realm of science. First in biology, then spreading to physics and onward, it seems there are forces at work trying to bring us back to the flat earth of the Middle Ages. Like Galileo, we are in the midst of a battle between scientific progress and dogmatic belief. Is there any better gift we could hand to the rising scientific forces in China and India than the compromising of our future scientific achievements in this manner? We must assure the integrity of our scientific education or yield to others who do.

title: Towns That Are The Envy Of the I.R.S.

It's an exhausting process that involves threatening letters, phone calls, marshals and sometimes tax liens on property. Just once, tax collector's must think, why can't everyone just pay their bills?

title: The Avant-Garde Goes to Clown School
description: THE old stereotype about theater in New York was that you went uptown to forget your troubles and downtown to be reminded of them. But by the looks of the current season, the reverse seems to be true. There are still plenty of musicals and one-man shows on Broadway, but the classic boulevard comedy -- once the backbone of commercial theater -- has become scarce. By contrast, Off Off Broadway, home base for the avant-garde of Big Ideas and Serious Intentions, is filled with vaudevillian high jinks and lowbrow satire.

title: In Japan's New Texts, Lessons in Rising Nationalism

Seldom does it crystallize as perfectly as it did last week, in the biggest anti-Japan protests in China since the two countries re-established relations in 1972. Oddly, to Westerners at least, the focus of Chinese fury was Japan's approval of junior high school history textbooks that critics say whitewash Japanese aggression in Asia.

title: Ecuador's President Revokes Protest Curbs

The embattled president had faced thousands of furious protesters who had taken to the streets of Quito, defying the decree, which was limited to the capital, and demanding that he resign.

title: Communions

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEINART, MELVIN
description: BEINART--Melvin. Died April 11, 2005 at the age of 81, ravaged by Alzheimer's Disease. Beloved husband of Joan for twenty-five years and, before his terrible illness, her great and loyal companion, joyous mate and best friend. Cherished and generous father and stepfather of Stephen Beinart, Daniel Beinart (Phyllis), and Amy Beinart (Gary Marcus); and Kerry Hurwitz (Jules), Tracey Hyams (Andrew), and Peter Stelzer (Tress Ahles). Devoted grandfather of Gabriel Beinart St. John (Desiree), Roxanne Beinart, Nina Beinart, Benjamin Hyams, Joshua Hyams, Rebecca Hurwitz, Jeanette Hurwitz, and Milo Stelzer. Also survived by loving sisters Lillian Golden, Bernice Turkel and Arleen Cohen, and brother Sidney Beinart. Mel was proud of his service overseas during WW II as a Weather Forecaster in the U.S. Army Air Corps. Later, he graduated from NYU School of Law where he was on Law Review and was elected to Order of the Coif, the national legal society which recognizes outstanding academic achievement. He was Partner for many years in the law firm of Hahn & Hessen which he joined in 1960, and was subsequently Of Counsel until his retirement in 1994. His family and friends will remember Mel as a man of intellect and compassion, and unwavering and uncompromising integrity.
