title: The Karma of the Killing Fields
description: ON April 17, 1975, I was a young man working for CARE in Phnom Penh. As I drove to my office on the Avenue de France at 7 a.m., I saw a group of heavily armed black-clad zombies walking toward the city center and me. I reversed quickly and went to the Hotel Le Royal, which had been turned into a Red Cross neutral zone. A doctor friend signaled for me to go to the side entrance opposite the National Library. He waited inside while I climbed over the locked gate. He and his colleagues had set up an emergency room at one of the bungalows to treat the wounded. They asked if I could be the interpreter. I said yes.

title: ROAD AND RAIL SPENDING
description: New Jersey transportation officials have unveiled a $2.7 billion plan to repair the state's roads and rails, while hoping that it will not be the last big spending they have the chance to do. The officials fear that their well of money for improvements will run dry next year because lawmakers have not settled on a way to replenish the state Transportation Trust Fund. The fund, fed by a 14.5-cent-a-gallon tax on gasoline, is expected to be drained by June 2006. Without a gasoline-tax increase or a new source of revenue, the fund will barely cover its hefty debt payments, leaving nothing for road paving or bridge building. A lack of state contributions would be compounded by a loss of $1 billion in federal matching funds. Jack Lettiere, the state commissioner of transportation, said he could not predict whether the entire program will stop at the end of the next fiscal year, June 2006. Patrick McGeehan

title: How Smokers' Ills Saved a Hospital, Twice

The act was akin to giving newlyweds a blender, except that the source was more interesting: the county offered its share of a national legal settlement with tobacco makers. And so it was that the fruits of trial lawyers' labor went toward health care, whose costs keep rising in part because of trial lawyers' labor.

title: Get Tom DeLay to the Church on Time

That's why Monica Lewinsky trumped Whitewater, and that's why of all the story lines ensnaring Tom DeLay, the one with legs is the one with the craps tables. It's not just easy to follow, but it also has a combustive cultural element that makes it as representative of its political era as Monicagate was of the Clinton years. As the lies and subterfuge of the go-go 1990's coalesced around sex, so the scandal of our new "moral values" decade comes cloaked in religion. The hair shirt is the new thong.

In contrast (especially because of the events of Sept. 11), employees find the barricades for moving from country to country higher than ever. While investors can go to countries where little or no employee benefits are the norm, employees cannot move to places that provide better benefits. When comparing the rights of investors to the rights of employees, the playing field is, unfortunately, now more tilted than at any other time in my life.

title: On the Cover; Out of the Shadows Slowly
description: BOXERS know the importance of pacing themselves, not spending all their energy in the first round, and so apparently do Dan Klores and Ron Berger, whose documentary, "Ring of Fire," about the welterweight and middleweight champion Emile Griffith (shown on cover), unfolds with great patience. The film, which has its television premiere Wednesday at 9 p.m. on USA, builds gently to its pivotal event, a televised fight in March 1962 at Madison Square Garden in which Mr. Griffith administered a beating to Benny (Kid) Paret that turned out to be fatal. But it is just as restrained in following the threads that extended from that grisly event, one that stunned the country and, more than a year before Lee Harvey Oswald was shot on camera, showed the frightening powers of live television. Perhaps that pacing reflects the film's long gestation period. "I was always interested in this, way before I even knew how to make a film," said Mr. Klores (near right, with Mr. Berger), who remembers watching the fight on television as a 12-year-old. "What stayed with me was more than what happened," he said. "What effects did this have on Emile and the Paret family?" His exploration of that led in surprising directions -- to a subtheme of homophobia; to people who had not been interviewed about the fight in four decades; to vignettes of regret and reconciliation. "I tried to make a story about violence and love," Mr. Klores said. "I feel like it is a love story on a number of levels." NEIL GENZLINGER

And now there is Tom DeLay, the House majority leader, whose hunger for power has grown so insatiable that it has detached him from the nation's business, the principles of electoral democracy and even the mainstream of his own party.

title: Stalin's Reading List
description: IN the early fall of 1940, The New York Times Book Review was probably not the gravest threat facing the Soviet Union. But Moscow was dead serious about literature, and when The Times published a laudatory lead review of a novel about the Spanish Civil War that was critical of Stalin, Communist spies jumped into action. "The book review section of The New York Times," the Press Section of the Comintern Executive in Moscow wrote in a confidential report, includes "a prominently placed review of Gustav Regler's book, 'The Great Crusade,' which deals with the war in Spain. . . . The review shows that the book is anti-Soviet in character." The report was prepared for the Cadre Department, a sinister branch of the Comintern that kept files on leading Communists and coordinated its actions with Stalin's secret police.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUONY, MADAME LIANE C.
description: KUONY--Madame Liane C. Of Fond du Lac, WI, passed away on Thursday, April 7, 2005. Madame Kuony was the proprietor of the Postilion Restaurant, School of Culinary Arts and Studio of Interior Design. She was renowned for her unwavering high standards, sense of style, and her ever present hat. Madame Kuony's energetic spirit and passion for life, coupled with heartfelt appreciation for family, friends, students, artisans, nature, and animals are how she will be most remembered. The pioneer of organic cooking, her commitment to educate all on the necessity of using only organic/unadulterated ingredients was her life-long mission. Madame Kuony's dedication to assist the disadvantaged was evident through her contributions to the Broken Bread program, Salvation Army, and the Fond du Lac Humane Society. A cherished mother, grandmother, teacher and friend to the community, this Wisconsin icon's sense of purpose will live on in the many lives she has touched. Madame Kuony was born in Antwerp, Belgium. Having completed her schooling in Switzerland, where she majored in interior decorating and the culinary arts, she made her way to the United States in 1937. A merchandising position brought her to Milwaukee, where she met and married her late husband, John H. Kuony, Jr. Appropriately, Madame Kuony fell in love with Fond du Lac, as it was reminiscent of the French countryside of her youth. She and her husband moved to the area in 1947 and opened an antique shop on Merrill Avenue, bringing a European flavor to the community. Upon the purchase of the Darling home at South Park Avenue in 1949, Madame Kuony set her sights on and was successful in bringing unique dining experiences to the people of the community through the opening of the Postilion Restaurant. Other business ventures over the years included the Postilion line of gourmet prepared foods, condiments, and compotes, in addition to the Four Winds restaurant in Greenbush, WI. Between 1980 and 1984, the Postilion expanded to include the Postilion II School of Culinary Art and supply shop along with the Great House Restaurant in Milwaukee, WI. Madame Kuony is survived by her two children: daughter, Suzanne (Hilton) Smack of Santa Ana, CA and John (Jeanine) Kuony of Pleasanton, CA; grandchildren Jennifer (Jonathan) Senften of Santa Ana, CA, Stephen Casey of Tustin, CA, and brother-in-law Frank (Mary Jane) Kuony of Pleasanton, CA. She was preceded in death by her husband, John H. Kuony, Jr. A private family service is being planned. In lieu of flowers, memorials in Madame Kuony's name may be directed to: The Fond du Lac Humane Society, 173 W. Pioneer Rd, Fond du Lac, WI; The Historic Third Ward Association, Milwaukee Public Market, The Madame Kuony Demonstration Kitchen, 219 North Milwaukee Street, 7th floor, Milwaukee, WI 53202; The Fond du Lac Area Foundation, 384 N. Main Street, Fond du Lac, WI 54935.

title: One Way Out

We had no food or water, and soon we realized we were walking toward oblivion.

title: Gonzo Nights
description: Last fall, I traveled to Woody Creek, Colo., to talk to Hunter S. Thompson for what turned out to be one of his final interviews. For years, Thompson had been trapped in the persona he created in his 30's, forever forced to play Hunter S. Thompson. More than drugs, this was the monkey on his back: he was frozen in the role of the insider's outsider, on call for every would-be rebel who wanted to party with the madman. At the end, he was writing a column for ESPN.com and the occasional article, but mostly he was just being Hunter S. Thompson, a show that began each night in his house outside Aspen at around 5 with the first stirrings of bedsheets. A groan. A string of expletives. An assistant who hurries into the kitchen like an emergency room nurse. "He's awake! He's awake!"

Quiet as can be back then, the area is now waking up, thanks to a winegrowing industry, but some have always sought out this secluded place, as my parents did.

title: Going, Going . . . That Ball Is . . . Out of Here!
description: My husband and our 11-year-old son attended a Red Sox game last season at which our son coaxed a player to toss him a ball. A man sitting nearby offered him $30 for the ball to give to his own son. My husband told our son to ask for $50. They settled on $40, and all parties were pleased. My husband said it was a good lesson in "supply and demand," but I am uncomfortable with the transaction. What do you think? Susan Robel, Westwood, Mass. I understand why this makes you uneasy. It looks a bit as if your son exploited the generosity of that Red Sox player who presumably thought he was responding to the enthusiasm of a young fan, not supplying raw material to a young entrepreneur. And yet, I think your son did no wrong. In ethics, intent counts: your son did not ask for the ball hoping to resell it. If that opportunity came along later -- whether a year or a few minutes -- there's no reason that your son shouldn't respond to it. He has no ethical obligation to maintain a permanent collection of Red Sox memorabilia. And while he would have been generous simply to give the ball to that other fan, he wasn't required to.

title: There's Nothing Deep About Depression
description: Shortly after the publication of my book "Listening to Prozac," 12 years ago, I became immersed in depression. Not my own. I was contented enough in the slog through midlife. But mood disorder surrounded me, in my contacts with patients and readers. To my mind, my book was never really about depression. Taking the new antidepressants, some of my patients said they found themselves more confident and decisive. I used these claims as a jumping-off point for speculation: what if future medications had the potential to modify personality traits in people who had never experienced mood disorder? If doctors were given access to such drugs, how should they prescribe them? The inquiry moved from medical ethics to social criticism: what does our culture demand of us, in the way of assertiveness?

description: Like Friedman, I traveled to Bangalore last year. I covered much the same ground he did, right down to the tour of the Infosys campus. The lesson I drew resembles the one he relayed to his daughters: "finish your homework -- people in China and India are starving for your jobs." However, we won't close a national "ambition gap" with sermons about dedication or the virtues of majoring in engineering. We must take a stiff dose of the priorities that drive India and China: a relentless focus on achievement. Our schools must raise the bar, without hesitation or sentiment. Traditional academic disciplines and rigorous assessment of performance within them must become the alpha and the omega.

title: Amanda Scheer Demme: Queen of the Hollywood Night

"I want a little girl drink tonight," she said to a waiter at the Chateau Marmont last Monday night. "Like a Shirley Temple but strong. Let me get a sea breeze." It was 8, and Ms. Scheer Demme was seated in the center of a long table for 12 on the garden patio. She looked slightly twitchy, like the popular girl who sits down alone in the high school cafeteria and awaits her clan. "You never know who's going to show up," she said. "I always get a big table and see what happens."

title: Now the Dead Will Always Be With Us
description: TEN years ago, Jerry Garcia -- morbidly obese, addicted to heroin and increasingly disconnected from both the other members of the Grateful Dead and the outside world -- died in his sleep at Serenity Knolls, a drug treatment facility in Northern California. As the Dead's zealous fans mourned Garcia's loss, few people predicted a robust future for the rest of the band. Since its acid-drenched inception, Garcia had been the central force behind the world's most famous traveling psychedelic road show. He wrote the music for classic songs like "Uncle John's Band," "Eyes of the World" and "Terrapin Station." Garcia's wide-ranging, pointillistic guitar playing defined -- for the outside world, anyway -- the Grateful Dead's restless approach to live performances, and his Buddha-like stage presence and reedy tenor anchored what had become one of the biggest touring draws in the rock 'n' roll world.

It appeared in London in two folio volumes. Like most dictionaries, there is a rigorous serenity in the look of its pages. The language has been laid out in alphabetical order. The etymologies and definitions bristle with italics and abbreviations. The quotations that exemplify the meanings of the words present a bottomless fund of good sense and literary beauty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VARET, GUSTER V
description: VARET -- Guster V, died peacefully at home on April 13th at age 96. He was the beloved husband of 68 years of his adored wife, Frances, who survives him. Born in Russia in 1908 he immigrated to the United States as a young child and grew up in Freehold, New Jersey. He attended New York University from which he graduated in 1931. For many years before he retired, he was a certified public accountant practicing in New York. He was the beloved father and father-in-law of Ellen and Charles Bock and Michael and Elizabeth Varet; and, cherished grandfather of Lauren and Adam Schwartz, and Joseph, Sarah and David Varet. Funeral will be private. The family will observe shiva at the home of Elizabeth and Michael Varet beginning Sunday. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to either Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale, 475 West 250th St, Riverdale, NY 10471, or New York University (Varet Family Fund), Room 910, 100 Washington Square East, New York, NY 10003-6688. VARET--Guster V. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Guster V. Varet, beloved father of Michael Varet and father-in-law of Elizabeth Varet. Elizabeth and Michael's dedication, expressed through their leadership and boundless generosity, profoundly impacts our community and enriches the lives of millions in New York, Israel, and around the globe. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Michael and Elizabeth, and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

description: Larchmont - SINCE last fall, Peter Hand, a guitarist and co-founder of the Westchester Jazz Orchestra, has been holed up in his second-story office here, writing new arrangements for a dozen songs by Harold Arlen. Mr. Hand, who left the jazz orchestra in March 2004, shortly after it was founded in October 2003, has established his own group, the Peter Hand Big Band, which is to have its debut at Irvington Town Hall Theater on Friday night. The program is a celebration of the centennial of Arlen's birth, and will feature Mr. Hand's new arrangements.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE MADONNA OF EXCELSIOR, by Zakes Mda. (Picador, $14.) Based loosely on apartheid's "immorality trials" (in which South Africans were prosecuted for miscegenation), this lyrical, unsparing novel explores the shared cultural history of an Afrikaner settlement and its adjoining black township. Niki, a black woman left destitute by the trials, earns money posing as the Madonna with her mixed-race daughter for a white artist. Mda, a South African playwright, follows his characters through 30 years of their country's history, deftly weaving issues of racial identity, rape and revenge. Our reviewer, Neil Gordon, praised Mda as a "writer who can seduce us through beautiful language and unfailing humor" and "has the power to shock and frighten us."

title: Camp Sensibility
description: Moosejaw Apparel Moosejaw Mountaineering was founded a dozen years ago by two recent college graduates who were also serious outdoorsy types. Outdoorsy types almost always seem serious, and the stores and brands that cater to them generally go out of their way to appeal to that seriousness by stressing the authenticity of their gear. Catalogs invariably show someone not just wearing or using some high-performance outfit or equipment but doing so while scaling "a super-crimpy 5.12 outside Moab, Utah." Whatever that means. The most recent edition of the Moosejaw catalog includes many pictures of your standard rugged adventurer in harsh wilderness settings. But a typical caption reads: "A perfect example of the importance of looking good in the outdoors. When you're in extreme conditions, matching your pack to your vest really makes a difference."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ATKINSON, ROBERT MILO
description: ATKINSON--Robert Milo, of Rye, NY, formerly of Manhattan. Adored by his many, many friends. His contagious personality drew people to him and his loyalty made him a friend not easily forgotten. Survived by his two loving nieces, Susan and Laurie, and two loving nephews, John and Robert. Those shows, along with its popular weeknight double feature of "CSI" repeats, helped put Spike in a tie for first among adults 18 to 49 in the week's Nielsen estimates. The channel shared that No. 1 slot with TNT, which won the week in total viewers on the strength of its "Law & Order" reruns. Wrestling and crime were not the only ratings winners: the Discovery Channel's "Supervolcano" (5.14 million) placed a close second behind the WWE, and Lifetime's "Odd Girl Out" (5.1 million) was third. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bill For Night Workers

The bill comes less than a month after three janitors filed a lawsuit against two C-Town supermarkets in the Bronx, accusing them of endangering their lives by locking them in while they cleaned overnight. The Fifth Avenue Committee, a south Brooklyn immigrant advocacy group, held a rally with Mr. Yassky at City Hall yesterday. description: CHICUREL--Captain Michael M. Of Long Beach, NY, passed away on Friday, April 15. He was 86 years old. Born in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, NY, Captain Chicurel developed a love of the ocean that ushered him into a distinguished career in maritime affairs. He graduated from the United States Merchant Marine Academy in 1943, and served in the United States Navy during World War II. He was an instructor at the Merchant Marine Academy, Fleet Manager and Port Captain for Marine Transport Lines, Inc; Chief of Merchant Marine Personnel for the Bureau of Maritime Affairs/Republic of Liberia; President of Atlantic Mace Corporation; and Ministry of Transport for the Commonwealth of the Bahamas. In addition, Captail Chicurel maintained numerous affiliations within the industry. He was selected to be a member of the Council of American Master Mariners; a member of the Order of the Top of the World, signifying he had crossed the Arctic Circle; and a member of the Domain of the Gold Dragon, for crossing the International Date Line. He was proud that in 1963 he communicated via Syncom II, the world's first synchronous orbit communications satellite, which he thought of as the start of the communications revolution. Captain Chicurel will now join his beloved wife, Anne, deceased in August, 2004, and is survived by his children, Judith Chicurel Kritt and David Kritt of Brooklyn, NY, Joseph Chicurel and Carri Chicurel of Oceanside, NY, and three grandchildren, Jessica, 17; Michael, 12; and Robert, 7. The family will sit shiva from Monday, April 18, through Wednesday, April 20, at 25 Neptune Blvd, #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHMIED, JOSEPH
description: SCHMIED--Joseph. 97, Richmond Hill, NY. Best known as "Uncle Joe", died Friday, April 15, 2005. Born June 3, 1907, in Brooklyn, NY. Started his career with the Consolidated Edison Electric Company in the 1930s. Later created his own company called (Schmied Neon Signs) at 852 Wyckoff Avenue, Brooklyn, which endured for more than 50 years. During his long and ambitious lifetime aspired to many high level positions at non-profits and fraternal organizations, some of which include Trustee - Wyckoff Heights Hospital, member of the Shriners and respective hospitals, Masonic Fraternity-(America Lodge), Honorary New York City Fire Chief, F.D.N.Y. Steuben and St. George Associations, NYC Police Square and Cycle Clubs, Glendale and Ridgewood Kiwanis and Rotary Clubs, The Bushwick Club, The Elks Club, and many more. He was a people magnet, gifted with the charisma of making and keeping longtime friendships. His charity work will be long remembered. He had no children, but did have a priceless commodity (close friends). Viewing Monday, April 18, 2005, 2-4, religious and fraternal service, 7-9 p.m. at Simonson Funeral Home, 119 - 04 Hillside Avenue, Richmond Hill, NY, 718-847-0300. Funeral ceremony Tuesday, April 19, 2005, 9:45 a.m. at funeral home. Interment at Evergreen Cemetery, 1629 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, NY, 718-455-5300.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Shot In West Side Break-In
description: A 24-year-old man was shot three times by a robber who forced his way inside the man's Upper West Side apartment yesterday, the police said. The shooting occurred about 11 a.m. when the robber followed the victim's girlfriend, whom the police did not identify, as she was returning to their apartment on West 108th Street, and demanded money, credit cards and an iPod, the police said. The commotion awoke her boyfriend, the police said. The victim confronted the gunman, who stole the man's wallet before shooting him and fleeing. Another roommate said the victim was struck in the chest and stomach. He was taken to St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, where he was in stable condition last night. The police described the robber as a black man in his 20's who was wearing blue jeans, a black shirt and a dark bandanna. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: 2 Shot In 2 Incidents
description: A 9-year-old girl and a man were injured in two separate shootings last night in the Concourse Village and Highbridge sections of the borough, officials said. In the Concourse Village shooting, which happened around 8:45 p.m., a man standing outside a Bank of America branch at 200 East 161st, near Grant Avenue, was fired upon three times, Firefighter Charlie Markey, a spokesman for the Emergency Medical Service, which is part of the Fire Department, said. The victim, whose name and age were not released by the authorities, was taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center with life-threatening injuries, Firefighter Markey said. In Highbridge, the girl was struck in the thigh shortly before 7 p.m. during a gun battle outside 1196 Nelson Avenue and was also taken to Lincoln, where she was in stable condition, Firefighter Markey said. The police said last night that both shootings were under investigation. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

Paid Notice: Deaths   TAYLOR, ELLEN M.
description: TAYLOR--Ellen M. Died at her home in Port St. Lucie, FL, on April 14, 2005. Born in Pittsburgh, on August 22, 1928, she was a graduate of the University of Pittsburgh and a member of Kappa Kappa Gamma. She was a flight attendant for Capital Airlines during the glamour age of air travel. In recent years she lived in Manhattan, and was a docent at the JP Morgan Library, a position she loved because of her lifelong passion for art and literature. She is survived by her husband of 54 years, Roger, her children Mark, of Los Angeles, Noel of NYC, James of Satellite Beach, FL, and her grandchildren Gabrielle and Sean. Joining in grieving her death are her daughters-in-law Mary Lynn and Marissa, and son-in-law Michael Whitlow. All who knew her will remember her for her beauty, grace, dignity, kindness and humor, qualities which she maintained even in the face of fatal illness. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ATKINSON, ROBERT MILO
description: ATKINSON--Robert Milo, of Rye, NY, formerly of Manhattan. Adored by his many, many friends. His contagious personality drew people to him and his loyalty made him a friend not easily forgotten. Survived by his two loving nieces, Susan and Laurie, and two loving nephews, John and Robert. Bob was an avid tennis player and devotee of Fordham Athletics, particularly football and basketball. He graduated from Fordham University in 1950 and NYU Law School in 1956 and went on to practice law in Manhattan for 50 years. Bob served as a lieutenant in the USAF from 1950 to 1952 in Bermuda. A celebration of his life will be held in the formal dining room of The Osborne, Rye (914-925-8000) on Sunday, April 17th, at 3 PM. description: The Episcopal bishop of Connecticut and six dissident, conservative priests met for nearly four hours last night but made little progress toward reconciliation, officials of the diocese said. The priests have rejected the bishop's authority because of his support for gay rights and for a gay bishop.

title: Keeping the Dead's flame alive
Arts, Briefly; Here Comes the Next TV Season
description: Fox's "Prison Break" is the first of the new crop of network pilots to receive a series order for next season. The show will follow the adventures of a man (Wentworth Miller) who robs a bank to be sent to the prison that is holding his brother (Dominic Purcell) on death row. His efforts to break his brother and himself out and exonerate them will play out over the show's first season. Paul Scheuring, one of the drama's executive producers, wrote the pilot, which Brett Ratner ("Red Dragon") directed. Fox has ordered 12 more episodes of "Prison Break." The series was in development at 20th Century Fox Television for a year and a half. KATE AURTHUR

title: New Evidence Gives Defense Hope in '90 Case
description: The murder case has crawled along for years, with two men claiming they were wrongfully convicted in the 1990 shooting death of a bouncer outside the Palladium nightclub on East 14th Street. On Friday, a third suspect was arrested and charged with second-degree murder in the case, and yesterday another bouncer who was present on the night of the killing testified at a dramatic court hearing.

title: Amtrak Says Brake Trouble Will Not Hurt in Long Run
description: The chairman of Amtrak said yesterday that the brake problem on the Acela Express trains would not seriously hurt the railroad in the long term, but that no one knew when the trains would be back in service because no one was sure what it would take to fix them.

description: For adolescent girls, the best predictors of obesity in adulthood are suffering from depression, engaging in radical weight-control behaviors and having obese parents, researchers have found.

title: An Enlightened Kind of Musical Provincialism
description: Take away one piece by Alexander Zemlinsky and the two days of concerts by the Ensemble Wien-Berlin at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday and Sunday were an all-Czech-music, all-wind-playing weekend jamboree. Quintets of flute, oboe, clarinet, bassoon and horn draw from a Central European tradition of village bands and Sunday music-making. If that past is disappearing, Germany and Austria, for example, preserve them in metaphor. One finds few superstar international orchestras, but every province or small city has its own symphony and opera season.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about a provision in the energy bill passed by the House that could significantly alter the Clean Air Act misattributed a statement about the merits of any changes. The quotation -- "Some people think it's a good idea. Most don't" -- was from a high-ranking official in the Environmental Protection Agency, who commented on the condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to speak for the agency. It was not from John Millett, an E.P.A. spokesman, who said the agency had taken no position on the provision.

title: Hostile Takeover Bid Ends Civilly in Japan
description: TOKYO, April 18 - A contentious Japanese takeover battle ended amicably on Monday as an Internet start-up, Livedoor, agreed to sell most of its stake in the target radio broadcaster to a rival bidder, the Fuji Television Network.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Boston Scientific, Natick, Mass., a maker of cardiac stents, said it had bought TriVascular, Santa Rosa, Calif., a manufacturer of devices that patch and bypass weak spots in blood vessels. Terms were not disclosed.

title: BLACKSTONE ACQUIRES CONTROL OF GLOBAL TOWER
description: The Blackstone Group, the investment firm founded by Peter G. Peterson and Stephen A. Schwarzman, acquired control of Global Tower Partners for a total of about $225 million. Blackstone, based in New York, purchased a 93 percent stake in Global Tower with a $125 million equity investment, Ben Jenkins, a principal at Blackstone's buyout unit, said yesterday. The seller was Great Hill Partners of Boston. Management of Global Tower, which is based in Boca Raton, Fla., will hold a 7 percent stake, Mr. Jenkins said. Global Tower last month agreed to acquire 563 wireless communications towers from the Dobson Communications Corporation, almost doubling the company's total. It also owns 1,800 rooftop antenna facilities throughout the country.

description: When my patient Jackie, who had incurable lung cancer, came to my office, she would regale me with her latest physical accomplishments. "I'm doing great, doctor, right?" she would ask.

title: Pitcher Gone Wild as the Mets' Ishii Loses Control
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 18 - Mets starter Kazuhisa Ishii tied his shoes, then retied them, took off his cap, then put it back on, adjusted his right pants-leg and then adjusted his left. He kept rubbing the baseball with his hands until he had no choice but to throw it.

World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bookmaker In Acquisition Talks
description: The British bookmaker William Hill said it might buy Stanley Leisure's betting shops for more than 500 million ($946 million) as it seeks to supplant Ladbrokes as the country's industry leader. William Hill said it was discussing the purchase of about 600 betting shops in Britain and Ireland to create a chain of about 2,200 bookmakers. Ladbrokes runs about 1,900 bookmaking shops in Britain. William Hill, which has about 1,600 betting outlets, is focusing on bookmaking after the government limited opportunities to expand into casinos. The company said it would return capital to shareholders if the talks were unsuccessful. Stanley's stock rose 17 percent.

title: A Senior Vice President at A.I.G. Is Put on Leave
description: An executive at the American International Group, the insurance giant, has been put on leave amid a sweeping investigation into the company's accounting.

title: Landfall in Manhattan, After a 70-Foot Wave
description: More than 2,000 passengers of a cruise ship that was pummeled by a seven-story wave off the coast of Georgia came ashore in Manhattan yesterday, some vowing never to sail again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUZICKA, MARLA
description: RUZICKA--Marla. The Open Society Institute mourns the loss of human rights activist and friend Marla Ruzicka, who was killed by a car bomb in Baghdad on Saturday. She lost her life while working to arrange medical care and compensation for the civilian victims of the war in Iraq. The Open Society Institute, a private foundation created and chaired by George Soros, is one of a host of organizations and people hard hit by her loss. We are proud to have supported Marla's work and are confident that she made a huge difference in the lives of so many people devastated by the war. We will miss her greatly.

Arts, Briefly; Who's Who
description: The BBC has announced who will play Doctor Who in the next 13-part series of the cult science-fiction television show of the same name, scheduled to start filming this summer. David Tennant, below, who turned 34 yesterday, will take over from Christopher Eccleston, whose adventures through time and space with Billie Piper as his sidekick, Rose, are being broadcast in a revival of the series, seen for 26 years after its introduction in 1963. Mr. Tennant, who recently played Casanova in a BBC drama series, was Ginger in the film adaptation of Evelyn Waugh's "Bright Young Things," Reverend Gibson in a television adaptation of Trollope's "He Knew He Was Right" and Katurian in the National Theater production of Martin McDonagh's "Pillowman" in 2003. PAM KENT

title: Baseball May Appoint Independent Investigator
description: Commissioner Bud Selig is considering appointing an independent outside party to investigate steroid use in baseball if Congress defers its own investigation, according to a person who was briefed on a private meeting in Washington last Thursday between baseball officials and leaders of the House Government Reform Committee.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ralph Lauren Store Sold
description: The Rhinelander Mansion, the Madison Avenue building that has housed Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation's flagship store since 1986, has been sold to Irish investors. The price was almost $80 million, more than double its 1997 sale price, according to brokers involved in the deal. The buyer was Sloane Capital Group, an investment company based in London but owned largely by Irish investors. The seller was a German investment group that in 1997 paid $36.25 million for the five-story building at 72nd Street and Madison Avenue. One of the unsuccessful bidders was Mr. Lauren himself, the brokers reported. "The two of them went head to head," said William M. Shanahan, an executive vice president of CB Richard Ellis, who helped to broker the transaction. "In the end Sloane put a better number on the table." The Lauren company did not return calls for comment. John Holusha (NYT)

Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Manville: Bikers Accused Of Homicide
description: Two members of the Pagans motorcycle gang have been charged with killing a man in a Manville sports bar on Sunday, the Somerset County prosecutor announced yesterday. The suspects, Peter James Ciarletta, 28, and William Martin, 33, both of Somerset County, were charged with first-degree murder and various weapons charges in the shooting of John Grover, 40, of Hillsborough, who was wearing a Hells Angels T-shirt at Gatto's Sports Cafe, said Jack Bennett, a spokesman for the prosecutor. The three exchanged words, then Mr. Grover followed the other two as they left, and Mr. Martin shot him twice, the authorities said. The Hillsborough police stopped the two as they drove away. Tina Kelley (NYT)

description: UGE, Angola, April 18 - The coffin was too small. Too small because a baby should not die, too small because the men who had carefully built it, after measuring her body, had not taken into account the thick, adult-size vinyl body bag her body would be placed in, to prevent the spread of the Marburg virus that had killed her.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: A Blow To Basque Autonomy Plan
description: Juan Jos Ibarretxe, the president of the northern Basque region, on Sunday led his coalition to victory in parliamentary elections that he had cast as a referendum on his plan to sever the region's constitutional ties with the central government in Madrid, but fell short of the mandate he was seeking, according to political analysts. "The elections showed that the plan may have had the support of the last Parliament, but it did not have the support of society," said Mara Silvestre, the director of the political science department at Deusto University in Bilbao. The 29 seats won by Mr. Ibarretxe's coalition fell 9 short a parliamentary majority. Renwick McLean (NYT)

Rod R. Blagojevich ordered pharmacies to fill prescriptions for women wanting the new "morning after" pill, even if it meant putting aside their employees' personal views.

title: The Missing Energy Strategy
description: The House is moving quickly and with sad predictability toward approval of yet another energy bill heavily weighted in favor of the oil, gas and coal industries. In due course the Senate may give the country something better. But unless Mr. Bush rapidly elevates the discussion, any bill that emerges from Congress is almost certain to fall short of the creative strategies needed to confront the two great energy-related issues of the age: the country's increasing dependency on imported oil, and global warming, which is caused chiefly by the very fuels the bill so generously subsidizes.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: F.B.I. Informer Sentenced
description: A federal judge yesterday sentenced the government's main informer in a terrorism financing case to five years' probation for writing thousands of dollars of bad checks while he was helping the F.B.I. investigate a Yemeni sheik, Mohammed Ali Hassan al-Moayad. The informer, Mohamed Alanssi, set up a sting that led to Sheik Moayad's conviction in United States District Court in Brooklyn last month, but Mr. Alanssi's checkered history, including setting himself on fire outside the White House, caused problems for the prosecutors. Nonetheless, the chief prosecutor, Kelly A. Moore, said yesterday that Mr. Alanssi had endured hardships to help in the war on terrorism and was a "phenomenal cooperating confidential informant." William Glaberson (NYT)

But Strauss was a prolific composer, and there is always a bit more left to uncover. On Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall, Mr. Botstein brought the American Symphony Orchestra's season to an end with a program of Strauss's works for chorus and orchestra, with the choral singing provided by the Concert Chorale of New York.

And last week the House majority leader, Tom DeLay, called for an investigation of the federal judges in the Terri Schiavo case, saying ominously: "We set up the courts. We can unset the courts."

World Briefing | Europe: Italy: 4 Charged In Banker's 1982 Death
description: A Rome judge ordered four people to stand trial on murder charges in the death of Roberto Calvi, left, who was president of Banco Ambrosiano, one of Italy's largest banks, and a financial adviser to the Vatican when he was found hanged under Blackfriars Bridge in London in 1982, a death once officially ruled a suicide. Charged were a convicted Mafia boss, Giuseppe Cal; an associate of Mr. Calvi, Flavio Carboni; a former girlfriend, Manuela Kleinszig; and a suspected Rome mobster, Ernesto Diotallevi. Prosecutors now believe that Mr. Calvi, known as "God's banker" because of his Vatican connections, was killed for mismanaging Mafia funds and for fear that he would disclose details of extensive money laundering operations. Elisabetta Povoledo (IHT)

title: Lehman Is Said to Agree to Buy 20% of Ospraie Management

World Briefing | Europe: France: U.S. Court Refuses Holocaust Case
description: The United States Supreme Court turned away an appeal filed in Washington by a group of Holocaust survivors and family members against France's government-controlled railway for transporting more than 76,000 Jews to Nazi extermination camps in World War II. Their lawyers say the railroad, the S.N.C.F., charged the German occupying authorities the standard commercial fare for train tickets paid by ordinary travelers, even though many of the deportees were moved in cattle cars. After France was liberated, the S.N.C.F. charged the French government, and received payment, the appeal contended. The group sought to overturn a federal appeals court decision in November that said the railway was shielded by American legislation recognizing the immunity of foreign governments and their agencies. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Caxton-Iseman Will Buy Manchester Technologies
description: Caxton-Iseman Capital agreed to acquire Manchester Technologies yesterday for about $56 million in cash to take the distributor of plasma displays and home electronics private. Manchester shareholders will receive $6.40 in cash for each share they own, the companies said. The price values Manchester at a 36 percent premium to its closing share price Friday. Manchester's wholly owned subsidiary Electrograph Systems distributes plasma displays, home electronics and projectors and had about $150 million in revenue in its fiscal year ended July 31, the companies said. Caxton-Iseman is a leveraged buyout firm based in New York. Manchester shares rose $1.48, or 31 percent, to $6.19.

Some entrances will emphasize a gradual ascent from the grit and congestion of the city's streets to an oasis of pastoral calm. description: Eurotunnel, the operator of the rail tunnel linking Britain and France, said first-quarter sales rose 4.1 percent as the number of cars and buses being carried through it increased. Revenue rose to 130.8 million ($247.5 million), from 125.6 million. Excluding exchange rate fluctuations, sales rose 2 percent, according to the company, which is based in Paris and Folkestone, England. Eurotunnel offered long-term rates for trucking companies, helping increase train revenue from carrying vehicles through the tunnel by 9.2 percent, to 70 million.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Autodesk To Acquire Colorfront For $15 Million
description: Autodesk, whose programs are used to design buildings and movie effects, agreed yesterday to purchase closely held Colorfront for $15 million to add technology used to adjust color in films. Colorfront, which is based in Budapest, and Autodesk co-developed the Discreet Lustre system, which helps technicians digitally manipulate color in film in ways not possible during shooting, an Autodesk spokesman, Martin Vann, said. The digital color system, introduced in April 2003, has been used in films like "The Polar Express" and "Pirates of the Caribbean." Autodesk said the purchase would add expertise in film laboratory processes, digital postproduction of movies and color science.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Wins Dismissal Of Lawsuit
description: A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit filed by Los Angeles, San Francisco and other California municipalities accusing Microsoft of overcharging them for Windows software. Judge J. Frederick Motz of Federal District Court in Baltimore granted Microsoft's request to dismiss the case, which was filed last year after a series of settlements by Microsoft to resolve consumer antitrust suits in 14 states. The judge said the cities could file an amended complaint. The lawsuit filed by six California municipalities sought to represent all government agencies in the state. Microsoft settled a California consumer suit that made similar legal claims. Government entities were excluded from that $1.1 billion settlement. Judge Motz said the cities lacked standing to sue Microsoft under unfair competition laws because only individuals can sue under those laws. As for the cities' antitrust claims, Judge Motz said they could only sue for claims going back four years. The cities had sued for conduct going back more than 15 years. Eugene Crew, a lawyer representing the California cities, did not return a message left on voice mail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHURMAN, PETER T.
description: SCHURMAN--Peter T., 74, entrepreneur and philanthropist of New Canaan, CT, died April 13, 2005. Son of Kersten Taube Schurman and George Munro Schurman, grandson of Jacob Gould Schurman, philosopher, President of Cornell University and Ambassador to Germany. Mr. Schurman grew up in Bedford, N.Y. He graduated cum laude from Exeter Academy in 1948, and Phi Beta Kappa from Cornell University in 1952. He married Judith Calhoun that same year. After serving as 1st Lieutenant during the Korean War, he worked for Suburban Propane and Union Carbide. In 1960, Mr. Schurman started Airmold Plastics, which he sold to W.R. Grace. In 1965 he founded the Plastic Forming Company and introduced a new concept to the blowmolding industry by designing and producing doublewalled carry cases. He garnered fifty patents in plastics machinery and packaging. The company expanded to include licensees thoughout the U.S. and in France, Spain, Canada and Taiwan. Mr. Schurman was actively involved in church affairs, SCORE and the Senior Men's Club of New Canaan, CT. He and Judy established an educational fund with the New Haven Foundation and scholarships at Northfield Mount Hermon School and Cornell University. Besides his wife Judy, he is survived by sons George Schurman of Taos, New Mexico, Mark Schurman of Corvallis, Oregon, daughter Jane Cosgrove of Derry, NH and eight grandchildren. Services April 29th, 2PM at the First Presbysterian Church of New Canaan,Ct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIORDANI, JOHN E.
description: GIORDANI--John E. (age 63), born June 10, 1942, in the Bronx, New York, passed away April 16, 2005 in Newport Beach, CA. A resident of Orange County since 1986, John was the son of Benvenuto Giordani, who immigrated to America from Italy in 1929, and Louise Landi. John grew up in the Bronx and later served as a Lieutenant in the Army. A self-made man, John worked as a taxi driver in order to attend the City College of New York. He became a Certified Public Accountant with Peat Marwick, and he was later recruited to Revlon where he served as controller and interim-CFO. In 1986 John moved his family to Newport Beach when he accepted a position as CFO and EVP at ICN Pharmaceuticals, a Costa Mesa based NYSE company. John was a private man who always stressed the importance and sanctity of family. His compassion and unending generosity touched many. He is survived by his loving wife, Margaret, and his three sons, John, Justin, and Joseph. He will be greatly missed by his brother, Peter, and his sister, Rita, both of New York. A mass will be held this Friday, April 22 at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in Newport Beach. A reception celebrating John's life will follow.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Cognizant Buys Fathom Solutions For $19 Million
description: The Cognizant Technology Solutions Corporation, which helps companies manage software and technical needs, said yesterday it had agreed to buy Fathom Solutions for $19 million in cash and stock to add services for telecommunications and financial-services companies. Cognizant will pay as much as $16 million more for Fathom, a consulting firm in Chicago founded in 1999 by former executives at Accenture, if certain conditions are met two years after the transaction closes. Cognizant, based in Teaneck, N.J., is trying to expand the number of consulting services it offers as more businesses cut costs by sending some operations overseas, the chief executive, Lakshmi Narayanan, said in a telephone interview. The company, which has two-thirds of its work force in India, said in February that it would add 7,200 jobs to meet rising demand for its computer and software management services. Shares of Cognizant, which was spun off from Dun & Bradstreet in 1998, rose $1.23, to $41.17.

title: Justice on Trial in Russia
description: The trial of the former Russian tycoon Mikhail Khodorkovsky is nearing a verdict. Assuming, as everyone does, that he will be found guilty of fraud and tax evasion and left in prison, let's take stock: Russia has one fewer oligarch. Most of his Yukos company, which used to pump 2 percent of the world's oil, has been gobbled up by companies connected to the state. Russia's image and the standing of President Vladimir Putin have taken a major beating because the trial had the air of politically motivated vengeance and looting. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Subway To South Ferry Is Halted
description: A miscalculation by a contractor halted subway service yesterday to South Ferry, the southern terminus of the Nos. 1 and 9 lines. Over the weekend, as part of the reconstruction of the South Ferry terminal, the contractor, Schiavone Construction Company, chipped away the concrete roadbed and installed temporary track on about 200 feet of the line. The company was unable to complete the work and reopen the lines by 5 a.m. yesterday, as scheduled, officials said. The project's work schedule, according to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which is overseeing the work, had been "overly aggressive." As of last night, there was no service at South Ferry and less frequent service on Lines 1 and 9. Shuttle buses were operated between Chambers Street and South Ferry and passengers were urged to use nearby subway stations at Whitehall Street or Bowling Green. Full service was expected to be restored by this morning. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Union Bill Is Introduced
description: A bipartisan group of senators and House members introduced a bill that is organized labor's chief legislative goal. The bill, co-sponsored by 33 senators and 119 House members -- most of them Democrats -- would increase the fines on companies that illegally fire workers for supporting a union. The bill would also give workers the right to a streamlined unionization technique; as soon as 51 percent of employees at a workplace signed cards saying they wanted a union, the company would have to grant them union recognition. The chief sponsors are Senators Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts; and Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania; and Representatives George Miller, Democrat of California, and Peter T. King, Republican of New York. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KROON, ANDREW RICHARD
description: KROON--Andrew Richard, 24, of Rumson, NJ, died Saturday in New Haven. He was a committed environmentalist, interested in the Amazon's sustainable forestry. As a Yale student, he helped create a sustainable food initiative, co-authored a study on university energy use, spoke at the UN World Summit in 2002, and was the copresident of the Yale Student Environmental Coalition. Fluent in Spanish and Portuguese, he studied in Spain and Brazil. He graduated from Deerfield Academy and was accepted to the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies Masters Program. He is survived by his parents, Mary Jane and Rick; siblings: David, Sarah Kroon Chiles, Molly, Stephen and Michael; grandmother, Helen. The family requests no flowers but suggests tax-deductible donations to "Yale University" for the Andrew Kroon Environmental Fund, Yale University Office of Development, P.O. Box 2038, New Haven, CT. 06521-2038. A memorial gathering will be held at 102 W. River Road, Rumson at 3PM, Friday, April 22.

Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, EUGENE W. M.D.
description: FRIEDMAN -- Eugene W. M.D., 86. On April 18, 2005, from complications of prostate cancer. Beloved husband of Geraldine (Gerry) Gewirtz Friedman, devoted father to John and Robert Friedman, brother to David Friedman and grandfather of Elizabeth, Katie, Caroline and Meredith. A noted New York surgeon specializing in head, neck and breast surgery, Dr. Friedman spent more than 30 years as a clinical professor at the Mt. Sinai Medical Center and School of Medicine. In 1952, he was named Chief, Division of Head and Neck Surgery at Mt. Sinai, and treated an estimated 100,000 patients over the course of his career. Dr. Friedman was recognized as a pioneer in the use of the CO2 laser in clinical surgery. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, April 20, at 9:30 AM, at Central Synagogue at 55th St. and Lexington Avenue, 212-838-5122. The family will welcome friends at their Sutton Place residence on Wednesday, April 20, from 5 to 9 PM, and on Thursday, April 21, from 2 to 9 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Eugene W. Friedman, MD., and Geraldine Gewirtz Friedman Fund for the Mt. Sinai Medical Center, c/o Mt. Sinai Development Office, 1 Gustave Levy Place, Box 1049, New York, NY 10029.

Her husband, Marc, an engineer who kept his day job, is her partner. The homey shop specializes in brownies ($2.50) and about a dozen kinds of cookies ($1 each or 3 for $2.50), including snickerdoodles, pecan-maple, chocolate-mint and classic chocolate chip. Ronnybrook Farm Dairy milk is served ice cold or blended with fresh fruit like strawberries ($2.50 and $3.50). Next month, milkshakes will be added: (212)243-1640.

description: Since almost all of the cardinals who met to choose a new pope were appointees of John Paul II, it's probably not all that surprising that they chose someone as close as possible to the late pontiff. Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, the new Pope Benedict XVI, worked in close partnership with his predecessor and shared a belief in staunchly defending orthodox Catholic doctrine. There is no reason to expect any change, of course, for the church when it comes to matters like birth control, priestly celibacy or homosexuality. Those are issues of faith, properly left to the faithful. On matters of public policy, however, all of us have reason to be concerned about the opinions of the leader of more than one billion Catholics.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Avaya Income Falls Below Estimates
description: Avaya, the nation's largest maker of office telephone equipment, said yesterday that second-quarter net income fell to $36 million, below analysts' estimates. Avaya shares declined 17 percent after the company said that it would not meet its annual revenue and profit goals. Profit in the quarter ended March 31 was 7 cents a share, the company said, compared with $125 million, or 27 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 21 percent to $1.22 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected a profit of 17 cents a share on sales of $1.29 billion. The chief executive, Donald K. Peterson, facing declining revenue in the United States, is trying to increase sales by focusing on the market for Internet-based telephone calls and expanding overseas. The company, based in Basking Ridge, N.J., will not meet its revenue, operating income and operating margin goals for the year, Mr. Peterson said. Avaya shares fell $1.89, to $8.80 in extended trading following the report.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Human Remains Found In Trash Bin Identified
description: The decomposed human remains found in a Manhattan trash bin on Friday were identified yesterday as those of a 47-year-old woman, Lydia Frazier, who was reported missing on March 20, 2004, by her sister, the police said. The woman had not been seen since March 12. On Friday her remains were found in a large plastic storage container in a trash bin at the Marble Hill Houses, where Ms. Frazier had lived. The city medical examiner's office said Ms. Frazier died of blunt trauma to her head. Ms. Frazier was identified by her fingerprints, the police said, which were on record because she was arrested on June 19, 2002, on a charge of disorderly conduct and pleaded guilty that day, according to the Bronx district attorney's office. Ms. Frazier was widowed, but lived with a son, Lamar, neighbors said. He still lives in the apartment. When Ms. Frazier disappeared, her family posted fliers, neighbors said. Because she was on dialysis, she did not often leave the neighborhood. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Rice Tells Putin U.S. Is No Threat in Region
description: VILNIUS, Lithuania, April 20 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice offered reassurances on Wednesday to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and to listeners of a popular Moscow radio station that the United States would not supplant Russia's influence in its neighborhood despite growing American friendship with other countries in the region.

title: Sometimes, the West Side Is Just Plain Grouchy
description: THE Upper West Side, like all New York neighborhoods, moves to its own rhythms, fueled in large part by population density, acute parenting, entitlement and retail. Some weeks, you feel there is something in the air, a pinched intensity pushing everyone within a 20-block radius just an inch off the platform of reasonable behavior.

title: The Little Company That Could
description: Molly Pearson's first advertisement in the trade magazine Backstage read, "Forming Theater Company: Seeking a small group of actors and actresses in their 20's " She got more than 300 responses, but one, brimming with enthusiasm and almost painful sincerity, stuck out. "I realize that your fledgling theater company is exactly what I've been looking for," Chad Beckim wrote, "and I can offer you everything I have."

title: GM posts loss but sees sign of rebound in China
Stocks: Markets shaken by U.S. inflation fears
J.P. Morgan Profit Jumps 17%
description: J.P. Morgan Chase & Company said yesterday that first-quarter profit climbed 17 percent to a record as investment banking fees, bond trading and the $58 billion purchase of the Bank One Corporation lifted revenue.

title: Sweet Catomine Is Retired
description: Although the controversy surrounding Sweet Catomine's performance in the Santa Anita Derby may continue for some time, her racing career will not. The owner Marty Wygod announced yesterday that the filly, who won the Eclipse Award earlier this year, had been retired. Wygod said Sweet Catomine would be bred to the 1992 Horse of the Year, A.P. Indy.

title: Elegant, Full-Featured, Resists Stains. High Fashion? No, a PC Laptop.
description: A thin and light laptop with a full complement of features is a rare find. Apple has scored high marks for its PowerBook, but PC devotees still lack a front-runner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NOYES, CAROL ROTHSCHILD
description: NOYES--Carol Rothschild. Died April 18, 2005, at her home in Cold Spring Harbor, New York. She was the widow of Charles P. Noyes. Born Carol Warburg Rothschild, the daughter of Walter and Carola Rothschild, she served on the Board of Directors of the Natural Resources Defense Council, Planned Parenthood of New York City, the Rocky Mountain Institute, the Woods Hole Oceanographic Center and Inform Inc. She was also on the Boards of Trustees of the Brearley School, Concord Academy and Vassar College. She had also been a member of the International Council of the Museum of Modern Art. In the late forties she and her friend Dottie Noyes owned New Design, a contemporary furniture store in New York which showcased the emerging work of Aalto, the Eames brothers, Saarinen and others. On an Aalto-centered pilgrimage to Finland many years later, Carol wept in an exhibition of objects he had designed. It was her church. She was the mother of David, Deborah, Madhavi and Peter Bradford and Carola Lea. She was the grandmother of Arthur, Laura, Eve, Emily, Jacob and Emma Bradford and of Creston and Erika Lea. A celebration of her life will be scheduled for the fall.

title: House Passes Energy Bill, but Fate in the Senate Is Uncertain
Real Estate Sales Drive Up Consumer Prices in Region
description: The Consumer Price Index in the New York City area rose 1.7 percent last month, the largest month-over-month increase in 23 years, the federal Department of Labor said yesterday.

title: Gaming With the Ghosts of Wellington and D'Orsay
description: Originally opened in the 19th century, the casino at 50 St. James's Street, near Piccadilly Circus -- once the preferred hangout of the Duke of Wellington and the Count D'Orsay -- has recently been renovated by London Clubs International, in a bid to bring back its glamour.

title: Pavano and Offense Finally Click Together
description: TORONTO, April 20 - The requirements for a quality start are simple: at least six innings pitched, no more than three earned runs allowed. It does not tell the whole story, and baseball does not officially tabulate it. But it is useful enough as a tool to gauge the general effectiveness of a starter.

title: For Marla, No Sacrifice Too Great
description: "She was born with a passion to help somebody, and she never wavered."

title: Ecuador's Leader Flees and Vice President Replaces Him
description: BOGOT, Colombia, April 20 - President Lucio Gutirrez of Ecuador fled his presidential palace on Wednesday after the Congress, meeting in special session, voted to remove him. The Congress then swore in Vice President Alfredo Palacio, a 66-year-old cardiologist, to replace Mr. Gutirrez, 48, a former army colonel who had faced mounting street protests against what critics called an illegal overhaul of the Supreme Court.

title: Closing the Copyright Door
New Papacy Stirs Some Concern in the Arab Middle East
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April 20 - The elevation of Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger to the papacy as Pope Benedict XVI is stirring some uneasiness in the Arab Middle East, where many remember Pope John Paul II as a champion of some of their causes and fear that his successor will not be as sympathetic.

title: Morgan Stanley Exodus Continues as 8 Traders Leave
description: Morgan Stanley was shaken by another round of defections yesterday as eight senior traders left the firm for Deutsche Bank, adding to a stream of executive departures in recent weeks.

title: Transit Officials Say Recovery From Jan. 23 Fire Is Complete
description: In the latest stage in New York City Transit's efforts to recover from the Jan. 23 fire that interrupted service to two subway lines, officials announced yesterday that full service was now restored.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: More Arrests In Attack On Energy Chief
description: Two more men were detained on suspicion of involvement in the attempted murder of Anatoly B. Chubais, chief of Russia's electricity monopoly and the architect of Russia's privatization in the 1990's. Mr. Chubais, one of Russia's most controversial men, was ambushed in his armored BMW outside Moscow last month and survived both a roadside bomb and gunfire. A former military intelligence colonel was already under arrest in the case, and the Interfax news agency reported that the new suspects had served with him. The authorities released few other details. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Advanced Micro Aims to Out-Elegant Intel in Chip Race
description: Advanced Micro Devices is hoping to one-up Intel, the Goliath of the chip industry, with a new line of microprocessors based on the latest technology -- even if David is entering the battlefield a few days behind.

title: Time to Ban Ephedra
description: The recent disappointing federal court decision that the Food and Drug Administration lacks the authority to issue a blanket ban on ephedra, a dangerous herbal supplement, is a clarion call to the Bush administration and Congress to change the 1994 law on dietary supplements. The law should be amended to give health regulators clear and unambiguous power to take harmful products off the market, and to require supplement makers to report any adverse reactions.

title: Baseball: Hernandez gets tough
Grand Jury Is Said to Consider Case of Slain Woman in River
description: A grand jury is considering forensic and circumstantial evidence linking a former boyfriend to the case of a pregnant woman found shot to death and floating in the Hudson River this month, a law enforcement official said yesterday.

title: Where Vibrant Movement and Mysterious Music Share the Stage
description: Mark Morris doesn't fight music, and for that deceptively simple approach to his art, he is equally adored and reviled. But his musical candor is usually delightful: Mr. Morris breathes life into complicated scores with an earthy movement palette and unaffected dancers, who are as individual onstage as they must be in life. For his annual season at Brooklyn Academy of Music, which opened on Tuesday night, he presents the New York premiere of "Rock of Ages," a rambunctious title for such an elegant triumph of a dance.

title: Jets Trade First-Round Pick to Fill Void at Tight End
description: The Jets traded their first-round pick in this weekend's N.F.L. draft, the 26th over all, to Oakland yesterday for tight end Doug Jolley and a second-round pick, according to a person who was briefed about the deal.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Council Backs Pesticide Notice
description: New York has acted to apply an optional state law that requires lawn-care companies to give neighboring property owners 48 hours' notice before applying pesticides. The City Council voted unanimously yesterday to join seven counties in the state, including Nassau, Suffolk, Rockland and Westchester, that already follow the pesticide law. The Council also voted to direct city agencies to reduce the use of harmful pesticides on municipal property, and substitute, whenever possible, nontoxic pest-control methods. The Council also passed a package of five bills intended to reduce harmful emissions and increase fuel economy in the city's car, truck and bus fleet. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

description: Boston - THE headlines this morning will shout that the Nets completed a furious run to the playoffs. They beat Boston last night and snatched the final Eastern Conference playoff berth from the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: With a PC's Power, That's Entertainment
description: Personal computers increasingly fill home entertainment needs. And why not? They are already the repositories for digital photos, music and video collections. With an attached TV or radio tuner and digital video recorder and encoder, they can replace nearly every entertainment device in the house.

title: Going With the Flow
description: MILD or diffident are words that might describe Elizabeth Huey, an artist in her 30's who was combing the racks at Saks Fifth Avenue last Saturday. Just don't get her going on the subject of style. "I'm tired of all those tight little skirts and pants I have to keep pulling up to get them to cover my rear," Ms. Huey said as she held up several alternatives she considered more compelling. They were breezy, colorful skirts redolent of Woodstock, midnight hayrides and prom nights: the sort of thing that she once could find only at vintage stores. "Now they're everywhere," she said. "It's exciting."

description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 20 - European dance seems to be growing ever more distant from its American counterparts. Or so one might conclude after a three-day immersion in Springdance, a lively new-dance festival in Utrecht seen Saturday through Monday, with a footnote of one more performer seen on Tuesday in Rotterdam and appearing at Springdance this weekend.

description: WASHINGTON, April 20 - Markets go up and markets go down. But the slide over the last month on Wall Street is hardly good timing for President Bush, who now finds himself with another issue to explain as he struggles to win over public opinion -- and the votes he needs in Congress -- for his proposal to add investment accounts to Social Security.

title: Innovation Moves From the Laboratory to the Bike Trail and the Kitchen
description: WHEN most people think about where new or improved products come from, they imagine two kinds of innovators: either engineers and marketers in big companies trying to "find a need and fill it" or garage entrepreneurs hoping to strike it rich by inventing the next big thing.

description: Let's not pretend it is some sort of trend. Let's just acknowledge that through some strange coincidence, this seems to be the season of the European chanteuse. A handful of them are washing up (rather elegantly) on American shores, bringing their breathy albums with them.

title: A Struggle in Exploring Mendelssohn
description: Light, elfin, mischievous, sparkling. These adjectives could all be applied to the music of Felix Mendelssohn, the epitome of classical music for those who like things pretty and just substantive enough. They did not, however, apply to the Emerson Quartet's playing of it.

National Briefing | Washington: Appeals Court Declines Rehearing
description: A federal appeals court declined to reconsider a ruling that barred the government from seeking $280 billion in past profits as part of a civil racketeering case against the nation's largest tobacco companies. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit voted 3 to 3 on the government's appeal of a divided opinion for the companies in early February. Only a majority vote in favor of the government would have allowed the appeal to be argued again. Three other judges did not participate in the request for a rehearing. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Fears of Rising Inflation Send Shares to New Lows for '05
description: Fears of rising inflation sent stocks to new lows for the year yesterday after the government reported a sharp increase in consumer prices that all but guaranteed that the Federal Reserve would continue to push interest rates higher even as the economy may be slowing.

title: INSIDE
description: Carter Helps Push Nets Into the Playoffs With Vince Carter scoring 37 points in a game they had to win, the Nets rallied from an 11-point halftime deficit to beat the Celtics, 102-93, and advance to the playoffs for the fourth straight year. SPORTSTHURSDAY, PAGE D1

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TEIDOR, ESTHER
description: TEIDOR--Esther, age 91, died April 19th with the courage and beauty that always defined her. Mourned by loving sister Lillian Hack, adoring nieces and nephews Joel Park, Patti Kenner, Madeline Dreifus, Dennis Askwith, Jessica Hack, Stephanie Swoveland, Kathy Franklin, devoted brother-in-law Bert Askwith, caring nephew-in-law Charles Dreifus. She was a blessing and inspiration to her family and friends. Her heroes were Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr, Dr. Benjamin Spock, Golda Meir, Mahatma Gandhi. She marched in Selma. She spoke against injustice. She loved us unconditionally. She now joins in eternity her older sister Rose Teidor Park, her twin sister Sylvia Teidor, her younger sister Miriam (Mimi) Askwith. We feel emptiness with the loss of her physical presence in our lives, yet we give thanks for how her spirit will forever fill our souls. She has bequeathed us a precious legacy. Private services were held.

title: Blame China?
description: Members of Congress, egged on by American manufacturers, are threatening to slap punitive tariffs on Chinese goods unless China increases the exchange rate of its currency, the yuan, thus raising the price of Chinese imports here. Some Senate Democrats are even threatening to block President Bush's choice for the United States trade representative, Rob Portman, unless the administration also espouses get-tough tactics. This is protectionism raising its ugly head, and an all-around dreadful strategy. That's only in part because Mr. Portman, one of the president's better nominations, deserves confirmation. Worse, it's based on a misunderstanding of both China's financial situation and the cause of American economic woes.

description: A federal bankruptcy judge cleared the way last night for Time Warner and Comcast to proceed with the acquisition of Adelphia Communications.

description: WASHINGTON, April 20 - As the Senate moves ever closer to a partisan showdown over confirming President Bush's judicial choices, the Judiciary Committee is expected to vote along party lines on Thursday to approve at least two nominees certain to attract a Democratic filibuster in the full Senate.

title: In Jersey City, Religious Leaders Vow Healing
description: JERSEY CITY, Apr. 20 - Following months of vitriol in the Egyptian community here between Muslims and Coptic Christians after the slaying of a Coptic family in January, leaders of more than a dozen religious groups met in City Hall on Wednesday to sign a pledge of solidarity.

Paid Notice: Deaths   WEYMULLER, LILLIAN S.
description: WEYMULLER--Lillian S. on April 18, 2005 of Manhasset, NY. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Ernest Weymuller. Dear mother of Dr. Ernest Weymuller Jr. and Jean Beatty. Also survived by four grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. Memorial Service 12PM Saturday at the Congregational Church in Manhasset. In lieu of flowers donations to the Congregational Church Memorial Fund would be appreciated.

title: Big Board to Acquire Leading Electronic Trading System
description: The New York Stock Exchange, whose shouting traders and frenzied activity have become a global symbol of capitalism, announced yesterday that it would acquire a leading electronic trading system in a deal that allows the exchange to become a public company but casts doubts on its 213-year-old system of auction trading.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Fire On Plane Kills Child
description: A Boeing 707 carrying 157 passengers caught fire as it tried to land at Tehran airport. State-run television said that a child was killed and that several people were hurt when the Saha Airline plane, traveling from the southern island of Kish, skidded into a river at the end of the runway. The IRNA news agency reported that emergency slides failed to work and that passengers had to jump from the plane to escape the fire. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teacher Faces Weapons Charges
description: A New York City teacher was arrested on the Lower East Side on Tuesday evening after he was found with two illegal knives, officials said. The teacher, Robert Walker, 53, who most recently taught machine shop at Transit Tech Career and Technical Education High School in Cypress Hills, Brooklyn, was arrested at 11 Essex Street, the police said, although they did not say what led to the arrest. Mr. Walker had an outstanding warrant for a disorderly conduct charge, they said. He was charged with two counts of criminal possession of a weapon. A Department of Education spokesman said Mr. Walker had already been reassigned from teaching duties after an earlier arrest, details of which could not be determined last night. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

description: BOSTON, April 20 - With all their playoff hopes riding on it, the Nets' final game of the regular season was a microcosm of the season itself.

World Briefing | Africa: Tunisia: Americans Warned Of Potential Attack
description: The State Department has issued a warning to Americans considering travel to Tunisia, saying it had "strong indications that individuals there may be planning imminent terrorist actions." No specific information was provided about possible targets or the timing of the attack, but the announcement speculated that it might occur around a religious holiday. "Americans in Tunisia are urged to remain vigilant with regard to their personal security and to exercise caution," the statement said, adding that the alert would remain in place through the middle of July. Tunisia has been the site of previous terrorist attacks, including the bombing of a historic synagogue on the island of Djerba in April 2002, which killed more than 20 people and for which a Qaeda-related group claimed responsibility. Eric Lipton (NYT)

title: Few See Taint in Service By Pope in Hitler Youth
description: MUNICH, April 20 - The day after Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger became Pope Benedict XVI, some headlines were already drawing attention to a supposedly dark moment in his past, when the first German pope in 482 years was briefly a member of the Hitler Youth.

title: Stock Market Surges, Bouncing Back From Recent Losses
