BLACK HILLS TO SELL FIBERCOM UNIT FOR $103 MILLION
description: The Black Hills Corporation, an owner of utilities in South Dakota, Wyoming and Montana, plans to sell a communications unit for $103 million to focus on the energy business. Closely held PrairieWave Communications agreed to buy the unit, FiberCom, Black Hills said. The sale, which is expected to close before June 30, will result in a one-time loss for Black Hills of about 9 cents a share. Black Hills, based in Rapid City, S.D., started operating the unit in November 1999, a spokesman, Dale Jahr, said. FiberCom provides telephone service, digital cable television and high-speed broadband Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROSENBERG, HERMAN
description: ROSENBERG--Herman. April 21, 1902 - April 1, 1998 Daddy--How you would have loved to celebrate your 103rd Birthday today. How I would have rejoiced in sharing the occasion with you. Missing you. Carla

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Sunday with an article about George Steinbrenner and his horse farm misstated the surname of the jockey who rode Bellamy Road to victory in the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct. He is Javier Castellano, not Castello.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 4 about a New Year celebration by Turkey's Assyrian minority, permitted by the Turkish government for the first time, misstated the title of an official who suggested that the government might have been trying to atone for past persecutions of minorities. The official, Haluk Akinci, is manager of the forestry department in the Nusaybin region of southeastern Turkey, not the regional governor.

title: Everybody Loves a Whale; Sea Turtles Need a Press Agent
description: BRIGANTINE, N.J., April 19 - The last time all three phone lines at the Marine Mammal Stranding Center lighted up all at once was in 1994, when a right whale drew crowds as it swam free in Delaware Bay below Philadelphia. This time it was the beluga whale that followed the spring shad run up the Delaware as far as Trenton.

title: Daley Remembered as Last of the Big-City Bosses
description: CHICAGO, April 20 - Outside Chicago, the image of Mayor Richard J. Daley that comes to mind is one of a flushed, jowly old man on the floor of the Democratic National Convention in 1968, shaking his finger and cursing at the rostrum while his police force manhandled demonstrators on the streets.

title: Snuffling for Pork in the Trenches
description: A taxpayer might ask what the pending "emergency" budget bill dedicated to paying for the Iraq war has to do with oil drilling in Mississippi, flood repairs in Utah and a stadium for Washington's new baseball team. The answer is that the expensive war effort provides fast and reliable, if shameful, cover for these goodies and more. Approval of the spending bill for Iraq and Afghanistan seemed so certain in the Senate that unscrupulous members of Congress larded it with favored boondoggle projects that would get booted if put to a vote on their own merits.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about Sam Mills, a former National Football League player, referred incorrectly in some copies to his distinction in the Carolina Panthers' Hall of Honor. He was the first player to be included, not the only member.

title: JDS UNIPHASE TO CUT 850 JOBS IN PRODUCTION SHIFT
description: JDS Uniphase, the world's largest maker of parts for fiber optic networks, said yesterday that it would cut 850 jobs as it consolidated its manufacturing in the United States. Production now handled in Ewing, N.J., and Melbourne, Fla., will be shifted to the company's plant in Shenzhen, China, and to two manufacturing partners, the company said. JDS Uniphase, which has not had a profit in almost six years, is shifting operations to cut costs, its chief executive, Kevin Kennedy, said in a statement. The consolidation, which also includes reducing manufacturing at a plant in Santa Rosa, Calif., will be completed by the end of the year. JDS is based in San Jose, Calif.

title: Arts, Briefly; Pop Charts: Trumping 50 Cent for the Top Spot
description: After six weeks, 50 Cent has finally been unseated from the top of the Billboard album charts by Mariah Carey, whose eighth studio album, "The Emancipation of Mimi" (Island), left, sold 404,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It was the best opening sales week of Ms. Carey's career, and her first time at No.1 in eight years, Billboard reported. This week's chart features two other notable debuts: Mudvayne's "Lost and Found" (Epic) opened at No.2 with sales of 152,000, and Garbage's "Bleed Like Me" (Geffen) is at No.4. 50 Cent's "Massacre" (Interscope) dropped to No.3, with sales of 140,000. Down the chart, Green Day continues to hold strong with "American Idiot" (Reprise), which sold 57,000 copies and is now in its 30th week in the Top 10, at No.8, and the Killers have moved up one spot to No.10, with 55,000 sales for "Hot Fuss" (Island). BEN SISARIO

description: NBC introduced new leadership yesterday at its troubled "Today," promising new energy and fresh ideas to reinvigorate what some network executives conceded had become a stale program.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Charged With Theft From Cemetery
description: A Queens man was arrested late Tuesday night on the grounds of Mount Carmel Cemetery in Glendale after police officers found that he had taken a stained-glass window and an urn from the cemetery, the police said. The man, Michael Delfino, 35, was arrested about 11 p.m. after someone reported a trespasser on the cemetery grounds. Mr. Delfino, who lives at 77-25 79th Street in Glendale, was charged with possessing stolen property and trespassing, the police said.

description: Dr. Saunders Mac Lane, a mathematician at the University of Chicago who helped to develop category theory, an abstract branch of algebra that has applications in computer science and other fields, died on April 14 at a hospice in San Francisco. He was 95.

title: The British Visit Milan, Bearing Tips on Design
description: DESIGN from Britain was everywhere at the Milan fair this year, particularly in several shows devoted to young exhibitors. Tyler Brl, the founder of Wallpaper magazine and of Winkreative, a design agency, said the country's design schools were part of the reason for the growing British presence.

title: Arts, Briefly; The Art of Winning
description: Organizers of the TriBeCa Film Festival don't want its winners to take home yet another useless trophy. So in addition to a cash prize, which can range anywhere from $5,000 to $25,000, the eight winners will receive original artworks, primarily by neighborhood artists like Eric Fischl, Matthew Barney and Richard Prince. The prizes will be on view at the Gallery VietNam, 345 Greenwich Street, near Harrison Street, from April 22 to 29 before they are given out on April 30. "Artists are so much a part of the TriBeCa community," said Jane Rosenthal, one of the festival's founders. CAROL VOGEL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINSTEIN, HARRY
description: WEINSTEIN--Harry. September 10, 1910-April 14, 2005. Manhattan native. Farm boy. ASCAP songwriter. Semi-pro golfer. Lifelong Times reader and crossword master. Survived by beloved wife Lillie, daughter and son-in-law Janet and Bill Epstein and daughter Martha Alpert. He always seemed larger than life, and now he truly is.

title: Fashion Gets Serious in a New Documentary
description: PITY today's poor young fashion designers. The perks of waltzing with supermodels in a $6,000-a-month apartment and Sarah Jessica Parker knocking at the door to borrow clothes must be tempered by the reality that the ride can end at any moment. Theirs is a vastly more sober industry than the one on display in Douglas Keeve's 1995 documentary "Unzipped," which was populated by chain-smoking eccentrics who treated fashion as one big party.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israeli Army Begins Removing Equipment From Gaza
description: The Israeli military packed up furniture, uniforms and computers and transported them out of the Gaza Strip in one of the first practical steps linked to an Israeli withdrawal from the territory. The equipment was moved from a military base in Neve Dekalim, the largest Jewish settlement in Gaza, to another just outside Gaza, the army said. The base in Gaza will continue to operate until all of the nearly 9,000 Jewish settlers in the territory are removed this summer. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Bad Reviews Doom 'Good Vibrations'
description: The beach balls are being deflated at the Eugene O'Neill Theater, where "Good Vibrations," the critically mauled Beach Boys musical, has given up a losing fight to find an audience and will close on Sunday. The show, which opened in early February to a wave of bad reviews, is just the latest box office disappointment for Dodger Theatricals, the respected Broadway company entrenched in a long losing streak that includes its 2004 "Dracula, the Musical," which closed in January at a loss of $7.5 million. The other producer of "Good Vibrations" was NCJ Productions/Michael Watt. The show features more than 30 songs with music and lyrics by Brian Wilson and the Beach Boys and cost $7 million; most of it will be lost by the time the show closes. It will have played 144 performances. JESSE McKINLEY

Ms. Mason, 63, formerly a principal dancer with the Royal Ballet, has been with the company since she was 16. She was assistant to Kenneth MacMillan and Anthony Dowell, and she took over when Ross Stretton resigned in September 2002 after a troubled 18-month tenure. An American tour by the Royal Ballet is planned for June and July 2006. The new laws increase penalties for bid-rigging and other cartel activity and give the Fair Trade Commission increased powers to investigate suspects, including the right to search their offices. The revisions also allow the commission to offer immunity from fines to companies that blow the whistle on cartels. Todd Zaun (NYT)

Patrick Donaghey, one of about 25 protesters, said he and his teammates "can't easily get a cab to the Garden," where they have played wheelchair basketball. Only one-quarter of 1 percent of the city's cabs are wheelchair-accessible, according to the Taxi and Limousine Commission. Matthew W. Daus, the commission's chairman, said the city planned to auction special taxi medallions to increase the number of such cabs to 83 from 29 by June 2006. Sewell Chan (NYT)

Thus was born an idea: start a magazine providing high school athletes with training tips and other pointers for revving up their skills.

MONSANTO RECEIVES SUBPOENA FOR PRICING DOCUMENTS
description: Monsanto, the world's biggest developer of genetically engineered crops, said the Illinois attorney general had subpoenaed information about pricing and licensing of gene-modified seeds. Some of the requested documents pertain to a 1999 federal antitrust lawsuit in which courts consistently ruled for Monsanto, a company spokeswoman, Lori Fisher, said. The suit contended that Monsanto conspired with other companies to manipulate some seed prices. Documents in that case are under court seal, Ms. Fisher said. Monsanto, which is based in St. Louis, licenses technology for seeds that can resist herbicides or pests.

description: Accenture, the consulting company, agreed to buy Cap Gemini's North American health practice unit for $175 million to expand its services to hospitals and health systems. About 600 employees of Cap Gemini, Europe's largest computer services company, will join Accenture's Health & Life Sciences practice. Cap Gemini is cutting jobs, shedding assets and eliminating management to reverse three years of losses. The acquisition will allow Accenture, which works mostly with health plans and public health organizations, to add more hospitals and health systems to its list of clients, a spokeswoman, Stacey Jones, said. Accenture is based in Hamilton, Bermuda.

The subpoena follows a scathing report the city's inspector general issued in late February concerning the accountant, Pietro Barberi, 24. description: The decomposed body of a man found last week in an abandoned car in the Bronx was identified yesterday as that of a 45-year-old Bronx man, the police said. The man, Vernal Colin Scott, was discovered last Thursday in the trunk of a green Toyota Camry with Maryland plates parked on Wright Avenue, a cul-de-sac west of the New England Thruway in Eastchester. Mr. Scott's body, with feet bound in duct tape, had been wrapped in a blanket that had been set ablaze. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUSHTON, MRS. RACHEL
description: RUSHTON -- Mrs. Rachel Rushton, age 41 of Atlanta, GA died Tuesday, April 19, 2005. Born in Albany, GA, Rachel was a 1981 graduate of The Westminster Schools. She was a 1986 Magna Cum Laude graduate of Wellesley College and a member of Phi Beta Kappa. Rachel was a founding consultant of Southern Living at Home, and developed a very large and successful home-based business. Prior to her marriage she had been employed in investment banking in New York City. Rachel is survived by her husband, Richard Rushton and her sons, James Richard Rushton, William Todd Rushton and Jonathan Smith Rushton, all of Atlanta; her mother, Sylvia S. Griffin of Atlanta; her father, James J. Griffin of Atlanta and her sister and brother-in-law, Laura Griffin Farrell and Kirby Farrell of Charlottesville, VA. Our memories of Rachel will shine brightly in our lives forever. Funeral services will be held Friday April 22 at 11 A.m. at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. Philip in Atlanta. The family will receive friends Thursday evening April 21 from 5:30-8P.M. at Patterson's Spring Hill Chapel. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to Wellesley College, 106 Center St., Wellesley, MA 02481 in memory of Rachel Rushton. For information contact H.M. Patterson & Son, Spring Hill Chapel, 1020 Spring Street, NW Atlanta, GA 30309. Call 404-876-1022.

Technology Briefing | Hardware: Imation Raises Full-Year Forecast
description: The Imation Corporation, which makes disks and tapes for storing computer data, raised its full-year forecast for profit from continuing operations to $2.10 to $2.17 a share after a $12 million tax adjustment. An income tax audit was resolved during the first quarter for a gain of 35 cents a share, Imation said yesterday. The company, based in Oakdale, Minn., had forecast in January that its full-year profit would be $1.75 to $1.82 a share. Including the tax benefit, first-quarter net income rose 47 percent, to $31.4 million, or 92 cents, from $21.4 million, or 59 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell 4.2 percent, to $325.2 million, because of declining prices of recordable CD's and DVD's. The company reaffirmed its forecast for revenue growth of 3 percent to 5 percent because of more stable prices and the introduction of new products. Shares of Imation rose $2.71, or 8 percent, to $35.49.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Tellabs Profit Drops, But Sales Soar
description: Tellabs, the maker of telecommunications equipment, said yesterday that reorganization costs limited its first-quarter profit, but sales jumped 65 percent with the help of a major acquisition. Tellabs, based in Naperville, Ill., said net income fell to $700,000, or break-even per share, from $13.4 million, or 3 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding $27.1 million in charges, earnings came to $26 million, or 6 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of 2 cents a share. Sales rose to $435.6 million, from $263.8 million a year earlier, aided by the purchase of Advanced Fibre Communications. Advanced Fibre, which makes fiber optic gear used by local phone companies, contributed $127.8 million to revenue, Tellabs said. Shares of Tellabs rose 71 cents, or 10 percent, to $7.77.

title: BEARINGPOINT FINDS ERRORS IN FINANCIAL REPORTS
description: BearingPoint said yesterday that nine executives would leave the company and that it had found errors in financial statements spanning the last two years. The Securities and Exchange Commission began an investigation into its accounting and requested documents on the company's internal controls. The company, formerly known as KPMG Consulting, said its financial reports should not be relied on, and it canceled its May 11 shareholders' meeting. The company also said it would postpone financial statements for the first three quarters of 2005. BearingPoint is making adjustments to its reports and will likely write down the value of some good will by as much as $400 million and record changes of as much as $65 million this year.

title: With Spain in Mind, a Trio Makes Room for Romance

His choices tend not to be fearsome or trailblazing: the audience for this series at the 92nd Street Y is fairly conservative, and Mr. Laredo's choices take that into account. But there is no shortage of composers who write interesting and even provocative works in a style that owes more to the Romantics than to the serialists, and for the closing program of the season, on Tuesday evening, Mr. Laredo drew from this well to reasonably good effect.

National Briefing | Science and Health: Telescope Detects Dust From Asteroids
description: In another sign that the universe beyond the solar system is both familiar and strange, astronomers using NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope said they had detected dust probably produced by the grinding of alien asteroids in a belt around a star about 40 light-years away, in the constellation Puppis. The asteroid belt, the first to be discovered around a star the same age and brightness as the Sun, is 25 times as large as the solar system's asteroid belt and hugs its star more tightly. The resulting constant bombardment of asteroids would discourage the evolution of life on any nearby planets, the astronomers said. The team leader, Dr. Charles Beichman of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, said it was also possible, though unlikely, that the dust was left by a giant comet orbiting the star. The spectrum of the dust, he said, was a perfect match to Comet Hale-Bopp, which passed spectacularly by Earth in 1997. Both are made of a magnesium-rich silicate called Forsterite, also found on the Green Sand Beach on Hawaii. Dennis Overbye (NYT)

description: In a case that could raise new questions about the conditions of Russian soldiers, four conscripts were found hanged in a forest near Saratov, in the south. Official statements compounded the mystery, including one suggesting a group suicide. Later, the authorities said the soldiers might have been witnesses to a crime committed by others. But Anatoly Gorshkov, a regional prosecutor, said on national television that investigators had found no signs of self-defense or a fight. Russia's largely conscripted military has been sullied by allegations of extensive hazing, abuse, brutality and professional incompetence. title: Anguilla on the Cheap

At Maundays Bay the sand sifts through the toes as fine as powder, as white as snow; at Shoal and Rendezvous Bays, it shines iridescent, with a slightly gritty sheen; at Little Bay and Sandy Ground, it turns from basic beige to pink at sunset.

title: In Oak Park, Ill.
description: ON spring weekends, people from all over the world can be seen walking slowly down the streets of Oak Park, clutching their maps, guidebooks, audio-tour wands and cameras. Spotting a celebrity - a Prairie-style house designed by Frank Lloyd Wright - they stop, stare and snap photographs. Then they move on to the next Wright house scattered among the historic district's Victorians. Oak Park, which is graced not only with Wright's former home and studio but with the world's largest collection of his buildings (25) and many houses by other Prairie School architects, has long attracted design pilgrims. But it isn't just Wright. In the town, some 10 miles from the Chicago Loop, and its environs, you will also find galleries, boutiques, restaurants, live music and a world-class zoo, as well as the painstakingly restored homes of two -yes, two -famous former residents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TREGOE, BENJAMIN B. JR.
description: TREGOE--Benjamin B. Jr. Co-founder and chairman emeritus of Kepner-Tregoe, Inc., died on April 20, 2005 of complications from nonHodgkins lymphoma. He was 77. In 1958, Dr. Tregoe and Dr. Charles H. Kepner left the RAND Corporation, where they worked as systems researchers, to found KepnerTregoe and Associates, Inc. Innovative pioneers, the two social scientists conducted original research with major corporations and discovered a core set of analytical problem-solving and decisionmaking processes that continue to be recognized as universally valid. Today, 400 of the 1,000 largest corporations worldwide use Kepner-Tregoe management methods. Their company, which later became Kepner-Tregoe, Inc., is headquartered in Princeton, NJ and conducts business in over 50 countries and 20 languages. Since its inception, Kepner-Tregoe has transferred its problem-solving, decision-making, and planning approaches to millions of managers. Dr. Tregoe and his colleague, John W. Zimmerman, also developed a process for strategic decision making that has helped many top management teams set and implement strategy. Dr. Tregoe provided the inspiration and leadership for Kepner-Tregoe over many years. He held a firm belief in the quality and depth of development for every associate as they delivered Kepner Tregoe's services to clients. He was conceptionally brilliant, a tough questioner, and a sensitive counselor. Dr. Tregoe and his company have been a significant force in organization development, pioneering both the train-thetrainer approach and process consulting, both of which have become common practice. He was elected to the Human Resource Development Hall of Fame. Dr. Tregoe was a leading lecturer and published extensively in journals throughout the world. His first book, The Rational Manager, which was co-authored with Dr. Kepner in 1965, is recognized as a landmark publication in the field of management methodology. He also co-authored The New Rational Manager: An Updated Edition for a New World (1997); Top Management Strategy: What It Is and How to Make It Work (1980); Vision in Action: Putting a Winning Strategy to Work (1989); The Culture of Success: Building a Sustained Competitive Advantage by Living Your Corporate Beliefs (1997); and Analytic Processes for School Leaders (2001). In 1993, Dr. Tregoe realized a long-held dream when he established the Tregoe Education Forum. This nonprofit organization provides students in middle and high schools with the critical-thinking skills needed to effectively solve problems, make decisions, and work together. Dr. Tregoe was born in San Francisco on December 23, 1927. He graduated from Redondo Union High School in Redondo Beach, California in 1945. After serving in the U.S. Marine Corps, he received his bachelor's degree from Whittier College and a Ph.D. in sociology from Harvard University. He also received an honorary LL.D. from Whittier College, where he served as a trustee and a board member. He was a member of the board of directors of The J.M. Smucker Company, the National Alliance of Business, The World Affairs Council of Philadelphia, and the Princeton Day School. He served as chairman of an advisory committee to the dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences at Harvard University. He is a past member of the Young Presidents' Organization, where he served as international education chairman and a member of the board, and a member of the Chief Executives' Organization. Dr. Tregoe is survived by his wife, Jeannette Tregoe; two daughters, Cynthia Richetti and Elizabeth Gonzalez; one son, Benjamin B. Tregoe III; and two grandchildren, Kaleigh and Gavin Richetti. For information contact the Mather-Hodge Funeral Home, Princeton, NJ (609924-0242). A memorial service will be held at the Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton, NJ at 11 a.m. on Monday, April 25th. Following the service, a luncheon reception will be held at the Nassau Club, 6 Mercer Street, Princeton. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Benjamin Bainbridge Tregoe Fellowship Fund, The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, Harvard University, University Hall 3 North, Cambridge, MA 02138-3654 or to the Cancer Support Group and Programs of Care of the Nassau Presbyterian Church, 61 Nassau Street, Princeton, NJ 08540.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: Last Round Of Voting
description: The third and final round of voting in Saudi Arabia's landmark, if partial, municipal elections unrolled in the western regions of the country, including the holy cities of Mecca and Medina. As in the previous rounds on Feb. 10 and March 3, only men over 21 were voting for a total 244 council seats in contention. Nationwide, the decision to elect nearly 600 members of the 178 councils, with the other half appointed, was seen as a first, limited step toward meeting demands for greater public participation in decision-making in the absolute monarchy. Candidates backed by prominent Muslim clergymen dominated the elections in major cities in the previous rounds. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Still Trapped Outside Prison
description: Andrs Manuel Lpez Obrador, above at center, the popular left-wing mayor of Mexico City and front-runner for president, may be the only politician in the world trying to have himself put in jail. Yesterday he went with supporters -- and a throng of reporters -- to the courthouse where the federal case against him on contempt-of-court charges is being heard and demanded that his bail be revoked so he could be imprisoned. A judge refused. On Wednesday, federal prosecutors presented the charges -- that he ignored a court order in 2001 -- but robbed him of the chance to look like a martyr for democracy by having two allies of President Vicente Fox pay his bail. Mr. Lpez Obrador says the charges are trumped up and intended to knock him off the presidential ballot next year. He has vowed to run from jail if necessary. Meanwhile, he seems to be holding his own in polls. A poll by the newspaper El Universal indicated that his lead over candidates from the other two major parties had grown by three percentage points, to 38 percent over all, from 35 percent in February, which was before the government announced it would prosecute him and possibly push him out of the presidential race next year. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; La Scala Appoints New Manager
description: The board of La Scala opera house in Milan appointed Stephane Lissner (below) yesterday as the theater's new general manager and artistic director, dropping the curtain on a bitter backstage drama that has pitted disgruntled workers against an increasingly besieged management. Mr. Lissner, a Frenchman in charge of the Aix-en-Provence festival, will replace Mauro Meli, who resigned on Thursday after less than two months on the job. For weeks, La Scala's workers had been walking out of performances to express their dissatisfaction with Mr. Meli, who was perceived as not being up to the task of managing the famous opera house. The unrest at the theater led to the resignation of the conductor Riccardo Muti this month after 19 years on La Scala's podium. Mr. Lissner will take up his new job, which runs five months short of five years, in May. "My absolute priority will be music," he told reporters. La Scala union representatives said they were pleased with the turn of events. They will meet with workers next week to decide whether to revoke the strikes that have canceled the premieres of all operas and ballets this year. ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

He is also survived by six beloved grandchildren--Malvina, Julian, Lorenzo, Andres, Serena and Christina. title: Arts, Briefly; Fox Populi
description: Fox News placed first in Nielsen's estimates among the three cable news channels in Tuesday's coverage of the announcement that Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger had become Pope Benedict XVI. Fox, CNN and MSNBC all began live broadcasts at around 11:50 a.m. Eastern time and continued to report on the news of the announcement for more than two hours. During that period, Fox was No. 1 in both total viewers and the 25-to-54 demographic most important to advertisers that buy time on news programs. Fox drew an average audience of 1.1 million, 404,000 of whom were adults in that category. CNN was second to Fox, attracting 984,000 viewers. MSNBC trailed with an audience of 399,000. The next day, for the second Wednesday in a row, Fox was No. 1 in viewers and among 18-to-49-year-olds, while NBC was first in households. Fox was led by "American Idol," the night's most-watched show (21.79 million). On NBC, "Revelations" fell off from its premiere last week. An audience of 11.47 (versus last Wednesday's 15.35 million) watched Dr. Massey (Bill Pullman) and Sister Josepha Montafiore (Natasha McElhone) search for the new messiah. KATE AURTHUR

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Anger After 50 Die In Chinese Plant
description: Zambians vented their anger toward China as the toll in an explosion at a Chinese-run munitions plant in the nation's copper belt rose to 50, with an undetermined number of laborers unaccounted for. The minister of mines, Kaunda Lembalemba, said that the owners of the Bgrimm explosives plant had not provided a list of workers at the factory, apparently because many were casual workers with no records. He accused the owners of "treating workers like pigs" and urged families in the area, 180 miles north of Lusaka, to notify the government if loved ones did not come home. Zambia's economy has struggled since copper prices crashed in the 1970's, and Indian and Chinese companies have snatched up many of the area's mines. The explosives plant supplied munitions for mining. Michael Wines (NYT)

description: Malawi, one of the world's poorest nations, said it was putting off this year's local elections to 2006 because it lacked the $20 million needed to pay for them. description: The Bloomberg administration said yesterday that it would support a bill making it harder for the city to tow cars for unpaid parking tickets. The bill, introduced by Councilman Erik Martin Dilan, a Brooklyn Democrat, would increase the threshold of accumulated fines to $350 from $230. In 2002, the city raised fines on the most serious violations, including double parking, to $100 from $50. In 2003, the state raised its surcharge on all parking violations to $15 from $5. "It now takes an average of about two tickets to reach the tow threshold of $230, whereas it used to take three tickets," said Sam Miller, an assistant commissioner in the Department of Finance. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ULICH, GEORGE F.
description: ULICH--George F. Was called home to his eternal rest on April 19, 2005. He died at the Homles Regional Medical Center in Melbourne, Fl. He was born in the Bronx, NY on January 29, 1924 to Anna (nee Dehn) and Adam Ulich. He graduated from Herman Ridder Jr. High School, James Monroe High School and Pace College. He was a veteran of the 104th Timberwolf Infantry Division and saw combat in Europe during WWII. He received the bronze star for heroic acheivement. His business career was spent largely at the Williamsburg Savings Bank in Brooklyn where he became President and CEO. He retired in 1987 after 46 years. Mr Ulich served on various boards including Hellen Keller Services for the Blind, The Wartburg Home in Mt Vernon and San Simeon on the Sound in Greenport, NY. He is survived by his wife of 49 years Eleanor (nee Bauer), 2 children and 4 grandchildren. His daughter Christa Lorraine and her children Andrew Paul, Caroline Grace and Christopher Adam of New Hyde Park. His son Glenn Adam, daughter-in-law Sara Marsden and their daughter Gwendolyn Grace of Richmond, VA. He and his family lived in Brookville, NY for many years and he and his wife moved to Manhasset Hills in 2004. He was a summer resident of East Marion, NY since 1969. In 1992 he started to winter in Vero Beach, Fl. He was a member of Good Shepherd Lutheran Church in Plainveiw, NY where the services will be held on Saturday, April 23, 2005 at 10:00 AM. He was an associate member of St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Greenport, NY and Our Saviour Lutheran Church in Vero Beach, Fl. Burial will be in Orient Cemetery, Orient, NY. Funeral services will be held at R. Stutzmann & Son Funeral Home, 2000 Hillside Ave, New Hyde Park, NY. Visiting Friday, 2:00-4:00 PM and 7:009:00 PM. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to Hellen Keller Services for the Blind, Good Shepherd Lutheran Church, St. Peter's Lutheran Church or a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINANS, CHARLES FRANCIS
description: WINANS -- Charles Francis. Died Tuesday, April 19th at NYU Medical Center at the age of 85. Born New Year's Eve, 1919, of Irish and Belgian descent, "Charley" knew no bounds of nationality, race or creed. English teacher extraordinaire, drama coach, master of the A.P. exam, bon vivant, fearless advocate for the poor, champion of the American Indian, forgiving foe of Philistines everywhere and "the most fully realized Christian I have ever known," according to a prominent friend and colleague quoted last year. Associated as a lay instructor with the Society of Jesus (Jesuits) for half a century, he was the Jesuits' "Mr. Chips" and, along with the late Rev. Jack Farrand, S.J., almost single-handedly transformed Brooklyn Preparatory School from a 1950's jock redoubt to a creditable institution of learning in the 60's. Marched with the Rev. King, Jr., in Selma, Alabama and elsewhere in the Deep South in the summers of 1964-1965. Tried valiantly with Fr. Farrand to save Brooklyn Prep from extinction in 1972. Friend and co-worker of Mother Teresa at her AIDS Hospice in Greenwich Village for more than a decade of his retirement. He would have chuckled at the notion of dying on the first day of the papacy of Benedict XVI, his doctrinal adversary. Among his favorite "reads": Yeats' "Wild Swans at Coole" and Joyce's "The Dead". Your heart has not grown old, dear mentor, even while snow falls on "all the living and all the dead." Let's clink glasses in the next life's "Casa Laredo". "How do you like your blue-eyed boy, Mr. Death?" Good-bye for now, old friend. John M. McGowan Brooklyn Prep, Class of 1969

title: MBNA ISSUES WARNING ON PROFIT FOR YEAR
description: The MBNA Corporation, the nation's biggest independent credit card company, said yesterday that its profit would be significantly below its 10 percent growth target for 2005 because customers are paying off more debt. Shares of MBNA fell 17 percent. Payments were especially high on credit cards carrying MBNA's highest interest rates, the company said, adding that more borrowers were paying off cards in favor of less expensive sources of credit like home equity loans. Stock in MBNA, based in Wilmington, Del., fell $3.83 to $19.28 a share. MBNA said that first-quarter profit fell to $31.7 million, or 2 cents a share, from $519.7 million, or 40 cents, a year earlier. The company said that it would have earned $514.1 million without costs for a revamping.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRAENDEL, FELIX W.
description: BRAENDEL--Felix W. 92, died on April 15, 2005. He was born on June 9, 1912, in Palisades Park, NJ. A graduate of Stevens Institute of Technology in 1934, he was chief mechanical engineer and then President of GroovPin Corporation (located at that time in Ridgefield Park, NJ) for most of his working life. He designed, patented, and oversaw the production of vital small machine parts used in both peacetime and in jeeps, tanks, and airplanes during World War II. As chief engineer he was often found, shirtsleeves rolled up, adjusting and repairing machines on the shop floor, machines that he had custom designed. The men on the floor, all of whom he knew, liked him for that. As President he was cut off from the workshop, which pained him, as did negotiations with the union. The prestige and increased salary were only partial compensation for what he had relinquished. At 65 he captained the last of several cabin cruisers down the Atlantic Inland Waterway to a pleasant retirement in Florida with his wife, Tullia, who survives him. Their marriage thrived for 66 years. He is also survived by a younger brother, Arthur; his two children, Fips and Meryl; three grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A kind man of decisive character, he is remembered with respect and fondness by everyone who knew him.

title: Arts, Briefly; Authors' Accolades
description: It was prize time for authors in London this week, where Publishing News, an industry publication, bestowed its annual British Book Awards. Dan Brown's "Da Vinci Code," which has sold more than 20 million copies, was voted book of the year, the top prize, and the author took the occasion to reply to critics, including the Vatican, who have objected to its story of a plot by the Catholic Church to suppress knowledge of a marriage between Jesus and Mary Magdalene. Although not present to accept his award, Mr. Brown (right) was heard at the ceremony on Tuesday in a recorded speech that emphasized that his book is purely fiction. "For the record, it is a novel," he said. Bill Clinton's book "My Life" was named biography of the year, and David Mitchell's "Cloud Atlas" won best read. When the bus accelerated and moved to the left, it squeezed the man between the vehicles and rolled over his bike, witnesses said. The police said neither vehicle was at fault. The bicyclist was in critical condition in Bellevue Hospital Center. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: In Oak Park, Ill.
description: ON spring weekends, people from all over the world can be seen walking slowly down the streets of Oak Park, clutching their maps, guidebooks, audio-tour wands and cameras. Spotting a celebrity -- a Prairie-style house designed by Frank Lloyd Wright -- they stop, stare and snap photographs. Then they move on to the next Wright house scattered among the historic district's Victorians. Oak Park, which is graced not only with Wright's former home and studio but with the world's largest collection of his buildings (25) and many houses by other Prairie School architects, has long attracted design pilgrims. But it isn't just Wright. In the town, some 10 miles from the Chicago Loop, and its environs, you will also find galleries, boutiques, restaurants, live music and a world-class zoo, as well as the painstakingly restored homes of two --yes, two --famous former residents. BETSY RUBINER

title: Arts, Briefly; Tom Waits Objects to Another TV Ad
description: Tom Waits (right), who has successfully sued in the past over the use of impersonations of his voice and musical style, is now taking on Opel, a European subsidiary of General Motors, in response to a new ad. "I have a longstanding policy against my voice or music being used in commercials," Mr. Waits said in a statement this week, "and I have lawyers over there investigating my options." Mr. Waits has sued Audi over imitations of his voice in commercials, and in 1993 he won a $2.5-million suit against Frito-Lay for a Doritos ad. In a statement, Opel responded, "We actually are surprised about the fact that Tom Waits considers the music that goes with the current TV commercial 'Lullaby' for a range of Opel cars as a potential misuse of his voice and style of singing." Opel said that the underlying music was by Brahms, that it had not approached Mr. Waits and that the only celebrity singer it had considered was Steven Tyler of Aerosmith. "But before even starting any negotiations, a Frankfurt-based singer was found who delivered an excellent rough voice interpretation for the 'Wiegenlied' theme in English," the company added, referring to the Brahms "Lullaby." Mr. Waits said: "If I stole an Opel, Lancia or Audi, put my name on it and resold it, I'd go to jail. But over there they ask, you say no, and they hire impersonators." BEN SISARIO

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Jamdat Shares Surge After Announcement
description: The stock of Jamdat Mobile surged yesterday after it announced a deal to buy Blue Lava Wireless, acquiring rights to publish the popular Tetris game on mobile phones. title: The Listings; THE SHINS
description: Nearly four years ago, an unknown indie-rock band called the Shins (above) released "Oh, Inverted World" (Sub Pop), a beguiling but confounding little album that wasn't as little as it first seemed. The summery tunes and close vocal harmonies made the music seem somehow slight, and yet the singer-songwriter James Mercer packed each song with sharp turns and sharper lyrics: this was an album that stayed mysterious long after you memorized the words. In the years since then, the album's sweetly melancholy single "New Slang" became a sort of secret hit single, infiltrating pop culture through commercials and soundtracks. And in 2003, the group released the successful follow-up, "Chutes Too Narrow" (Sub Pop), by which point the Shins looked less like an anomaly and more part of a booming indie scene that also included Death Cab for Cutie and the Postal Service. "Chutes Too Narrow" is another unlikely delight, a half-hour album so breezy you almost forget it's overstuffed with words. The album ends with "Those to Come," a hushed acoustic love song so lovely you might almost miss the rather unsentimental biological refrain: "They are cold, still/Waiting in the ether to form, feel, kill/Propagate only to die." At these two concerts, expect the Shins to put on a casual but thoroughly engrossing show -- and here's hoping Mr. Mercer has had enough time to write some more deceptively slight songs. (Tomorrow through Monday at 8 p.m., with the Brunettes, Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212)533-2111; $22, sold out but returns may be available.) KELEFA SANNEH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENEDICT, COLEMAN H.
description: BENEDICT--Coleman H. Coleman Hamilton Benedict, 93, Professor Emeritus of Columbia University, where he taught generations of undergraduates and graduate students for three decades, died of complications from pneumonia at New York University Hospital on April 20, 2005. He was the only child of Cleland and Florence Righter Benedict and a descendant of an illustrious old New York and New England family, which included his ancestor, the second president of Harvard University, Charles Chauncey, and the first mayor of Bridgeport, Connecticut, Lemuel Coleman. His grandfather, Coleman Benedict, entered Wall Street in 1864, and joined the New York Stock Exchange a year later. in 1890 he founded Benedict, Drysdale and Company and transferred his seat on the Exchange to Coleman's father Cleland. His uncle Lemuel, who also became a member of the Exchange, is incidentally renowned as the eponymous creator of "Eggs Benedict" for his breakfast order at the Waldorf Hotel in 1894, which the famous chef, "Oscar of the Waldorf," prepared at his request, and named in his honor. Enrolled in Riverdale Country School in 1918, his love for the ancient classics and for teaching was imbibed from his Latin teacher, Marc M. Baldwin. Coleman matriculated at Princeton University in 1930, where he earned AB (cum laude) and MA degrees in Classics, and a Ph.D. in 1939. He began his teaching career as a Teaching Fellow at Western Reserve University in 1940, and was teaching Greek and Latin at the University of Vermont when he was called up for military service in 1942. Enlisted in the US Army Counterintelligence Corps (CIC), he rose to the rank of Technical Sergeant, received a battlefield commission as Second Lieutenant in November 1944, was promoted to First Lieutenant in September 1945, and was honorably discharged in January 1946. During this tour of duty, he made security checks of Army installations in the United States, and conducted investigations of suspected subversion, sabotage and espionage, in Britain, Wales, Belgium, France and Germany. His war journals include memorable accounts of his experiences in the landing at Normandy, in the Battle of St. Lo, the Battle of the Bulge, and with the first contingent of the US Army to enter Soviet-controlled Berlin. His CIC team was assigned to debug the villa occupied by President Truman and to protect him during his Potsdam conferences with Stalin and Churchill. In an early letter to his mother, he wrote "The practical benefits of true education are going to show in the months to come. Moderation, self-control, and thinking are going to stand us in good stead. It will not be pleasant to watch the world go mad, but we shall, at least, have the satisfaction of not following it. We can't have Socrates' keen mind, but we can have his courage. He, too, lived in a world that fell apart." Dr. Benedict resumed his academic career at New York University during 1946-50, and continued at Columbia University for three decades from 1950 to 1980, retiring as Professor Emeritus. During most of those years from 1953 to 1975, he was the Departmental Representative of Columbia College and its School of General Studies, and its Chairman during several years in the 1970's. In that capacity, but especially in the classroom, his self-deprecating wit, enthusiasm, and astonishing breadth of knowledge, endeared him to and often motivated countless Columbia undergraduates, whose development was his priority as an educator, while depth of knowledge about all languages, literatures, and cultures was his prime personal goal. His early interest in the Romans in Southern Gaul resulted in several publications, including A History of Narbo (Lancaster Press). His insatiable search for knowledge led to articles ranging from Herodotus to Demosthenes, ancient coins in the Columbia University Library, and the ability to read in at least 14 foreign languages, including Russian, Arabic, Hebrew, Persian, Sanskrit, and Egyptian hieroglyphics, and of course all the Classical and Romance languages. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Ethyle R. Wolfe Benedict, Emeritus Provost and Vice President for Academic Affairs, former Dean of Humanities, and longtime Chairman and former Professor of Classics at Brooklyn College of the City University of New York. Service Saturday, 1 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

Out of those disparate life experiences -- and the rich traditions of Cambodian classical dance -- has come "Seasons of Migration: An Odyssey of Transformation," which will be performed with excerpts from the traditional "Ream Eyso and Moni Mekhala (The God of Thunder and the Goddess of Lighting)" by the university ensemble, which is based in Phnom Penh. In "Seasons," each of four sections corresponds to a stage in culture shock. In the world imagined by the dance, heavenly spirits come to earth to live among mortals and are horrified and transformed by the experience. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   UVILLER, H. RICHARD
description: UVILLER--H. Richard. Dean David Schizer and the faculty, students and staff of Columbia Law School mourn the death of our friend and colleague, Richard Uviller, the Arthur Levitt Professor Emeritus of Law, after a battle with cancer that began last fall. We will always remember Professor Uviller's kindness, optimism, good humor, and the generosity he showed to all in the Columbia community. Our hearts go out to his wife Rena, our graduate of the Class of 1962, and to their daughter Daphne; Daphne's husband, Sacha Spector, and their daughter Talia. Professor Uviller was a 1953 graduate of Yale Law School. Before coming to Columbia, he spent the bulk of his distinguished career as an Assistant District Attorney's in the Manhattan District Attorneys Office. Richard was an outstanding public servant in that highly respected office becoming chief of its Appeals Bureau for 14 years. He joined the Columbia faculty in 1968 and soon became widely recognized as one of the nations foremost authorities on criminal procedure and evidence. Professor Uviller was the author of four books and numerous essays, articles, and case comments. He was a leading advocate in numerous cases before the Supreme Court. Richard made an invaluable contribution to Columbia over the last four decades. His teaching touched innumerable lives and his scholarship has built the School's reputation as a center of learning about the criminal justice system. This is a great loss for Columbia and for the legal academy. There will be no funeral, but plans for a memorial service on the Columbia campus are pending.

description: The 1699 Stradivarius known as the Lady Tennant (being played, below, by Adela Pea of the Eroica Trio last Friday) will be auctioned at Christie's at Rockefeller Center, in a sale that starts this morning at 10. Also on the block will be a 1701 Gofriller cello, several guitars, a harp and a 1795 flute. The Strad's first recorded owner was the French violinist Charles Philippe Lafont, an archrival of Nicolo Paganini and the owner of two other Strads. It got its name in 1900 when a Scottish industrialist, Sir Charles Tennant, bought it for his wife, an amateur violinist. "Such violins never come into the sale room," wrote the London dealer who handled that sale. But Christie's, which says that since 1981 the Lady Tennant has been in the hands of a collector it did not identify, estimates that it will go for $800,000 to $1.2 million. The cello, which Gregor Piatigorsky praised in the 1940's, is expected to sell for $400,000 to $600,000. JAMES BARRON

title: Arts, Briefly; Shakespeare's Image Problem
description: On the day widely observed as the birthday of William Shakespeare -- today, April 23 -- his true likeness continues to be elusive, especially now that experts have called fake a familiar image thought to have been painted in his lifetime (1564-1616). An investigation commissioned by the National Portrait Gallery in London subjected the so-called Flower portrait, right, frequently used to illustrate his plays, to examination by curators, conservators and scientists. Their tests included X-rays, ultraviolet examination, macro and micro photography, and the examination of microscopic paint samples. These, the gallery said, revealed that although the portrait is dated 1609, a pigment, chrome yellow, which became available only in the early 19th century, was well integrated into the paint layers. As a result, the National Portrait Gallery concluded, "It can be categorically stated that Flower portrait of Shakespeare is a 19th-century painting." The painting, which hangs at the Royal Shakespeare Company, based in Stratford-on-Avon, is named for the Flowers family, who donated it to the troupe. Research on it and two other images of Shakespeare, the Chandos painting and the Grafton portrait, was undertaken in preparation for an exhibition next year, "Searching for Shakespeare," to celebrate the National Portrait Gallery's 150th anniversary. It says the results of new technical analysis and research "will cast new light on the search for Shakespeare's authentic appearance." PAM KENT

title: Arts, Briefly; CBS's Sweet Thursday
description: All three shows in the CBS Thursday lineup are in Nielsen's top 10 for the season in households. On Thursday, "Survivor" (No.5) brought in 18.66 million; 26.67 million watched "CSI" (No.1); and an audience of 16.36 million tuned in for a repeat of "Without a Trace" (tied for sixth). "CSI," which focused on the relationship between the homicide detective Jim Brass (Paul Guilfoyle, below) and his wayward daughter, was the evening's most-watched show. The combination of its three hourlong hits gave CBS a first-place finish for the night in both total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. NBC was second in both categories, but its leadoff show, "Joey," delivered its lowest rating of the season for an original episode. Thursday's offering of "Joey," the "Friends" spinoff, which has been renewed for next season, drew 7.36 million viewers and barely beat Fox's "OC" for second place behind "Survivor" in the 18-to-49 demographic. description: HALL--Evelyn A.J. (Mrs. Melville Wakeman). The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art and its International Council mourn the loss of Evelyn A.J. Hall, who had been a member of the Council since 1970 and a Trustee of the Museum since 1979. At the Museum she chaired the Library Committee and served on the Education Committee, as well on the Trustee Committee on Prints and Illustrated Books. She enriched the Museum's collection with work by Pierre Bonnard, Pablo Picasso, Joan Miro, Ellsworth Kelly, Louis Valtat, Edouard Vuillard, and, in a particularly notable gift made with her late husband, William Jaffe, with a selection of sixteen prints by Edvard Munch. Her gentle graciousness, quiet generosity, and sparkling presence will be missed. We extend our sympathies to her entire family. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY Brian Urquhart, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

title: Arts, Briefly; Warner Brothers Rides Out a Storm
description: The Supreme Court of Florida has ruled that Warner Brothers did not violate a state law that prohibits commercial use of someone's name without consent when it released "The Perfect Storm," the 2000 film based on Sebastian Junger's best seller about the 1991 sinking of the Gloucester fishing boat Andrea Gail and the death of its crew. In a 6-to-1 decision, the high court said that Warner Brothers did not use the name of the families of Capt. Billy Tyne, played by George Clooney, left, and the crewman Dale Murphy Sr., known as Murph (John C. Reilly), to promote the film; therefore it concluded that the law that prohibits commercial use of someone's name or likeness without his consent was not violated. The suit was filed by relatives of Mr. Tyne and Mr. Murphy, who are Florida residents. They argued that not only did the studio not obtain permission but that Warner Brothers also fictionalized the events to help boost the film's profits. Viewers are told that the film is based on a true story, but it carries a disclaimer saying, "Dialogue and certain events and characters in the film were created for the purpose of fictionalization." Arts, Briefly; Communist Palace to Fall
description: The ruins of the Palace of the Republic, once the home of the Communist legislature in the former East Berlin, will be torn down by the end of this year, according to a German news agency. The 1970's glass-and-steel structure, which housed not only the East German Parliament but also a concert hall, several restaurants and spaces for leisure, was closed for asbestos removal shortly after the Communist government collapsed in 1989. Since August 2004, when the palace reopened as a cultural complex, offering theater, modern dance, concerts and art installations, many Berliners have been fighting against removal of the historic building. Others favor demolition because they want to reconstruct the Prussian Palace of the Hohenzollern, which occupied the same site for 300 years before it was damaged in World War II and was blown up by the Communists in 1950. It remains unclear what will become of this contested piece of ground after the Palace of the Republic is razed. KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

description: Parliament's lower house adopted legislation to end direct elections for half its members and tighten election rules for smaller parties to enter the body. President Vladimir V. Putin proposed the changes after a wave of terrorist attacks, including the school siege in Beslan. Under the legislation, all lawmakers will be elected based on the proportional success of party tickets; until now half were elected to seats representing individual districts. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

description: Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian leader, phoned Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel to wish him well over Passover, which begins today, and they promised to hold talks on an unspecified date in the near future, according to a statement from Mr. Sharon's office. They last met in Egypt on Feb. 8, when they announced a truce that has largely been holding. Greg Myre (NYT)

description: LONDON, April 22 - Profit at Ericsson, the Swedish telecommunications equipment giant, soared 73 percent in the first quarter, the company said Friday, building on a recent run of healthy reports in the telecommunications industry.

description: The government announced that it had secretly buried the remains of Aslan Maskhadov, the Chechen separatist leader. He was killed in Chechnya last month in circumstances that remain unclear. Russian officials declared him a terrorist and said that as such his remains would not be returned to his family, which pleaded unsuccessfully for their release. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Internet Cannibal To Be Retried
description: A federal court ordered the retrial of Armin Meiwes, the computer technician who killed and ate a willing victim he found through the Internet, saying his 2004 conviction for manslaugher -- and eight-and-a-half year sentence -- were too lenient. Prosecutors had argued that Mr. Meiwes, 43, should have been given a life sentence for murder. With the manslaughter conviction now overturned and the retrial set for a Frankfurt court, they will get a chance for a tougher sentence. Kirsten Grieshaber (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Mugabe Says He'll Go In 2008
description: Zimbabwe's 81-year-old president, Robert G. Mugabe, who joked this month that he planned to stay in office until he reached 100, told the Indonesian newspaper The Jakarta Post that he plans to retire when his term ends in 2008. He said the next president should come from his party but insisted he would not anoint a successor. Mr. Mugabe has often moved to quash potential successors, most recently in November, when a vice presidency was denied to a party official seen until then as his heir apparent. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Cement Maker's Earnings Rise
description: The cement maker Cemex said sales and profit each rose 43 percent in the first quarter as it incorporated the March results of the British concrete maker RMC Group into its earnings report. Cemex, based in Monterrey, acquired RMC last year for $4.2 billion. Sales increased to $2.6 billion while profit climbed to $444 million. But the RMC purchase raised net debt 87 percent, to $10.4 billion. Cemex executives told analysts that they expected sales to almost double this year from 2004. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Another Serb To Surrender
description: Gen. Nebojsa Pavkovic, a former Yugoslav army chief indicted by the United Nations war crimes tribunal in 2003 for his role in what it called a "widespread and systematic campaign of terror and violence" against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, has agreed to surrender, the Serbian government said. He is to arrive in The Hague on Monday, when European Union foreign ministers are scheduled to discuss closer ties with Serbia, and would be the 12th war crimes suspect sent by the Serbian authorities this year. In a statement, Serbia said it "highly appreciates" General Pavkovic's decision, a "patriotic gesture towards the state and people." Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: On First Day on Job, Intelligence Director Sizes Up His Challenges
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 - On his first day as the first director of national intelligence, John D. Negroponte sent greetings from his makeshift headquarters to the thousands of spies and eavesdroppers, satellite technicians and bureaucrats whose $40-billion-a-year labors he is charged with hammering into a stronger bulwark against terrorism.

title: Scrutinizing Four American Sources With a Distinctive Eye
description: It's silly to say that song recitals require no acting ability. Schubert's "Erlknig" famously calls on a singer to play three different roles (father, child and demonic otherworldly specter). Still, Andrew Garland, a young baritone from Massachusetts, went a step further in his recital on Wednesday night in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. In Jake Heggie's cycle "The Moon's a Mirror," he impersonated both a horse and a snowman -- a show-biz snowman with definite Frosty antecedents.

description: WASHINGTON, April 22 - In April 2003, as American troops were entering Baghdad and looters roamed the streets, Gen. Peter Pace was asked in a television interview what the United States military could do to help democracy take root in Iraq.

title: Cliff Montgomery, Who Starred at Columbia, Dies at 94
description: Cliff Montgomery, the quarterback who called and executed the hidden-ball play known as KF-79 that propelled Columbia to a 7-0 upset of Stanford in the 1934 Rose Bowl, died Thursday at Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola, N.Y. Montgomery, who lived in Roslyn Heights, N.Y., was 94.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAY, ANDREW JEFFREY
description: MAY--Andrew Jeffrey. The Board of Trustees, management and staff of the Jewish Home & Hospital extends its deepest sympathies to longtime trustee, Harold May, and his wife, Millicent; daughter, Clarice, and the entire family on the passing of their beloved son, Andrew. Harold has been a valued trustee of the Jewish Home for 19 years and serves on the Bronx Division's Regional Board. He is a strong, generous supporter of Kittay House, the System's housing for independent seniors, where he has endowed the Harold and Millicent May Solarium, as well as other rooms for recreation and socialization. These spaces have brought much pleasure to Kittay's residents and has certainly enhanced their quality of living. We are grateful to Harold and Millie for their many contributions to the Lifecare System and are privileged to have Harold as a friend and trustee. Our thoughts will be with them in their time of loss. Fred M. Lowenfels Chairman Jewish Home & Hospital System Board David Haas, Chairman Jewish Home & Hospital Bronx Regional Board

title: Young Europeans Seek a Papal Dialogue
description: LOUVAIN-LA-NEUVE, Belgium, April 21 - The medieval theology class at the Catholic University here has a message for Pope Benedict XVI: Listen to us.

At other times its cast, the Flea's repertory company, known as the Bats, seems like a sleek, postmillennial downtown version of the original Not Ready for Prime Time Players. The truth, I suppose, lies somewhere in between.

description: And now, something new for pro football fans in New York to complain about: The only city that fields two N.F.L. teams does not even have one first-round draft pick.

Beloved husband of the late Marian and devoted father of Barry, Loren and Lisa and loving grandfather of Marc, David, Sarah, Tal, Elan, Tova and Benjamin. He was CEO of Spellman High Voltage Electronics; past chair for North Shore Campaign UJA; member of the Boards of Trustees Long Island Jewish Medical Center and Worcester Polytechnic Institute and President of Gurwin Geriatric Foundation. Funeral services were held on April 22nd.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Top Fugitive Arrested In Italy
description: The authorities announced the arrest in Italy of Apostolos Vavilis, one of Greece's most wanted men. On the run for more than a decade, he is wanted for drug trafficking, but the authorities also regard him as a central figure in a series of scandals that have engulfed the Greek Orthodox Church this year. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

description: Diane Knippers, a religious strategist who helped conservative Christians raise an increasingly loud and unified voice in the traditionally liberal bastions of mainline Protestantism in recent years, died on Monday in Arlington, Va. She was 53.

title: Briefly
Paid Notice: Deaths   JACOBY, ARTHUR W.
description: JACOBY--Arthur W., MD, 78, on Thursday, April 21, 2005 in Sarasota, FL, formerly of Old Tappan, NJ. Beloved husband of Barbara for 50 years and loving father of Andrew and his wife Laura, Nancy and David. Also adoring grandfather of Dale, Sarah and Rachel. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Contributions may be made to Senior Friendhip Center, 1888 Brother Geenan Way, Sarasota, FL. 34236.

title: Malcolm, in the Middle of Some Loutish Schemes
description: The desperately unfunny kidnapping farce "King's Ransom" is the cinematic equivalent of trampled chewing gum on a subway platform. Like that spat-out detritus, the movie is so negligible that you barely notice it under your feet until it gets stuck to the soles of your shoes, and you find yourself spending the next hour and a half scraping it off.

title: METLIFE DROPS PLAN TO SELL STAKE IN REINSURER
description: MetLife said yesterday that it had dropped a plan to pay for part of its $11.5 billion acquisition of Citigroup's life insurance business by selling its stake in the Reinsurance Group of America. MetLife is no longer considering the sale because the company raised more cash than expected by selling two New York office buildings, including its headquarters, a MetLife spokesman, John Calagna, said. MetLife said on Jan. 31 that it planned to buy the Travelers Life and Annuity unit of Citigroup and that it would pay for about $3 billion of the acquisition with asset sales. MetLife has since sold its Manhattan headquarters at 200 Park Avenue as well as a skyscraper at 1 Madison Avenue for a total of $2.6 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SALZMAN, LOUIS
description: SALZMAN--Louis. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Loving father of Nancy and father-in-law of Les. He was to the very end funny, witty and charming, with all his intelligence intact. Former Director of the New York State Department of Vocational Rehabilitation. Thoughtful and helpful friend to many. He will be greatly missed by all including the ladies on the bench.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALLEGRETTI, VERA
description: ALLEGRETTI -- Vera. On April 22, 2005 age 90, of Pt Washington, NY. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset on Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Religious services Monday, 10:00 AM, The United Methodist Church, Middle Neck Rd, Pt Washington. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery. Donations in her memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Arts, Briefly; Bad Blood
description: Even though Wesley Snipes was a producer and the star of the 2004 vampire film sequel "Blade: Trinity," he is unhappy about the way it turned out. How unhappy? More than $15 million worth. Mr. Snipes, who portrayed Blade, the Vampire Slayer, in three films based on the Marvel Comics series by Marv Wolfman and Gene Colan, is suing the distributor of "Blade: Trinity," New Line Cinema Corporation, and others for breaches of contract. The suit, filed in federal district court in Los Angeles, states that the defendants blocked Mr. Snipes from active preproduction involvement, including the choice of director and principal casting, acts that he contends led to the film's critical and commercial failure. In court papers, he complains of racially motivated treatment and also says he was not consulted on the casting of the actress Jessica Biel, whom he considered too young, or Kris Kristofferson, who appeared to him too old, choices that he says led to plot inconsistencies. The reduced screen presence of the Blade character, the pumping up of juvenile-level humor and the inexperience of the director, David S. Goyer (also named as a defendant), in filming action scenes also led to the film's commercial failure and the undermining of Mr. Snipes's reputation, the suit says. A spokeswoman for New Line declined to comment. CATHERINE BILLEY

title: Ax in Hand, a Hendrix Sings of Jimi's Legacy

In 1998, he was part of a team that lost a bid to build a new concourse and ticketing area for Pennsylvania Station within the General Post Office.

description: New York police officers routinely inform federal immigration authorities whenever they arrest a noncitizen, even a lawful permanent resident, a police official said yesterday at a hearing of the City Council Committee on Immigration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINANS, CHARLES
description: WINANS--Charles. For a generation of students at Brooklyn Prep, he was a dazzling teacher, a wise mentor, a guide to parts unknown, and an insightful mystic. To us, he was simply and always "Charlie", and forever the name and the thought of him will conjure for us the noblest aspects of life. The embodiment of the ideal of the great Jesuit tradition, Charlie will be missed by us all, even as we feel his presence always in our lives. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family and with the Jesuit community that so lovingly sustained his magnificent spirit in the last year of his lifeHis Brookyn Prep Students. Viewing: Sunday, April 24 at 2-4PM and 7-9PM, A. Vigliante & Sons, 171 Court St, Brooklyn, NY. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Service Company's Profit
description: The Indian software and services company Wipro said that its profit for the quarter ended in March rose 38 percent, to 4.5 billion rupees ($102 million), as sales increased 30 percent, to 23 billion rupees ($525 million). Wipro, which writes software code and handles customer service calls for global corporations, said that it added 41 customers during the quarter and it projected increased sales in the coming quarters. Its share price rose 6 percent. Saritha Rai (NYT)

description: BRIAN L. ROBERTS stood out on his very first day at Comcast, and not just because he was 12 years old. His father, Ralph J. Roberts, who founded the company, took him along to a meeting nearly four decades ago, when Comcast was planning to go public. Around midnight, executives produced a new draft of the offering document and pored over it for accuracy. It was the boy, however, who noticed that one of the charts read backward, and excitedly told his father.

description: A RULING by a New York State Supreme Court justice that an existing tenant is not automatically required to give a landlord his or her Social Security number has led to uncertainty among lawyers who represent landlords, tenants and even co-op boards in New York.

title: Following Fads in Tokyo
description: Staying on top of the latest trends is no simple feat in Tokyo, a city where fads come and go with eye-popping speed. For some, retail shopping is practically an art form, but those who can't be bothered to keep their finger on the pulse can turn to RanKing RanQueen, a small chain of stores that takes the idea of the best-seller list to new heights.

title: Promises ($60 for Instance) Fail to Rouse Iran's Voters
description: TEHRAN, April 23 - With elections less than two months away, Iran's presidential hopefuls are scrambling to lure voters, promising everything from lowering the soaring prices of fruit and vegetables to normalizing relations with the country's longtime foe, the United States.

description: I'VE been in leadership positions ever since failing kindergarten. My mother was taking my sister, who's a year older, to register her for kindergarten when the woman there said, "What about him?" My mother said, "He's only 4," but the registrar said, "We have plenty of room."

title: Surprise Terror Plea Leaves Unresolved Issues
Stop Shopping (Except for This CD)
description: Tower Records: yes. Wal-Mart: no. That was where some large music retailers were coming down last week on the question of the Reverend Billy, the make-believe evangelist who has inveighed against the evils of consumerism and big-box stores in parodic "retail interventions," books and, now, a CD, "Reverend Billy and the Church of Stop Shopping" (Tomato Records, May 10). The disc, featuring the Reverend Billy (actually the Manhattan-based performance artist Bill Talen, left) and his Stop Shopping Gospel Choir, includes songs with titles like "Remove Starbucks & Disney." Coincidentally or not, some large chains had not picked up the CD, according to Mary Eggers, president of Tomato. "They don't like his philosophy," Ms. Eggers said. A spokeswoman for Wal-Mart, Karen A. Burk, wrote by e-mail: "We make the decisions on what items to carry based on what we believe the majority of our customers want and, at this time, have no plans to carry this selection."

title: Children Celebrate Opening of Stadium
description: If there is one thing any self-respecting fifth grader will not tolerate, it is being called a fourth grader. So when Jaime Bing, the co-captain of the track team at Public School 63 in the South Bronx, found himself falsely introduced -- maligned, really -- he stood up for himself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRENNAN, HENRY JOSEPH
description: BRENNAN--Henry Joseph. Beloved brother of Eileen Cranmer and Kenneth Brennan. Uncle of Michelle McManus and Michael George Cranmer. Also great uncle to Olivia and Jack McManus. He graduated from St. John's University with a Master's in Finance, worked for Chase Manhattan Bank as an Assistant Treasurer, and served in the U.S. Air Force for four years. Beloved friend of all. Funeral was on April 17, from Scotto Funeral Home. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAUBMAN, JOSEPH L.
description: TAUBMAN--Joseph L., age 81, died April 21st, 2005. Devoted husband of Sylvia of Boynton Beach, FL, beloved father of Edward and Paul J., cherished father-in-law of Nancy, adored grandfather of Michele and Brendan, loved brother of Isaac and dear uncle of his many nieces and nephews. A veteran of W.W. II who served in Europe, he went on to become a highly respected and accomplished CPA. To us, he was our patriarch, who proudly passed on his Jewish heritage. He was a man whom we all loved and admired, respected and treasured. He was, is and will always be our hero. A private service was held. Contributions can be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCIORTINO, DR. VINCENT G.
description: SCIORTINO--Dr. Vincent G., on April 19, 2005. Lifelong resident of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Beloved husband of the late Patricia. title: Gobbling the Landscape a Mile a Minute
description: AN alien plant is on the loose on Long Island, and it's not loosestrife.

title: Corrections

title: The Scars Makeup Can't Cover
description: ONE wall of the Stage II lobby at the Long Wharf Theatre is currently papered with magazine pages. They show beautiful young models and offer tips for the less than perfect women and girls who want to look like them. Audiences, on their way in to see Julia Cho's "BFE," may find the display puzzling. On their way out, no problem. "BFE," a family drama that tackles the agonies and comforts of isolation, is about more than the tyranny of physical beauty, but that tyranny is a powerful metaphor.

title: Much Fun, for Credit
description: IT isn't frivolous, it isn't gimmicky, and it doesn't pander to college students who love their Xboxes more than they love their mothers. Most of all, they would like you to know, it is not trendy. The new course of study in digital games at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute is "profoundly conservative," says James Watt, chairman of the college's language, literature and communication department and a specialist in human-computer interaction.

title: Bus Pact Brings Relief
description: WITH the Bee-Line bus strike settled last week after nearly seven weeks, a sense of relief fanned out across Westchester, but it was tinged with anger. The strike affected students who take public buses to school, the elderly and businesses, disrupting the lives of the 50,000 daily riders.

title: Jorie Graham, Superstar
description: IN the cloistered world of American poetry, the revolutions are never televised -- which can make them awfully hard to distinguish from coups d'tat. For the average reader, nothing is likely to demonstrate this peculiar phenomenon so much as the delicate, secretive, enigmatic process through which a contemporary poetic reputation is consummated (or if you prefer, "attained"). One day, the poetry fan is dozing under a tree with Elizabeth Bishop's "Collected Poems" on his lap; the next thing he knows, the road signs have been changed, the post office is now a Banana Republic, and the name of a new Major Poet has been quietly etched into the stones of Parnassus -- or at any rate, into the syllabuses of a thousand M.F.A. programs.

title: Art That Escapes The Tyranny Of 'Isms'
description: SOUTH ORANGE - IN the history of modern art, scant room is accorded the work of artists of non-European or American heritage. This is grossly unjust, even wrong-headed, for it defies logic to think that the sum of the world's creativity is confined to a handful of wealthy nations.

title: Schoolhouse Rock
description: DANCE your way to an 800 in reading comprehension. Kaplan Test Prep and Defined Mind, an educational publisher, have produced a CD that melds hip-hop, alternative, rock and R&B with advanced vocabulary. With study guide, it sells for $25. Each of the 12 songs was composed by a little-known singer/songwriter, using 20 to 30 words from a list of 2,000 most frequently seen on the SAT. title: THE WEEK AHEAD: April 24-30; FILM
description: In 1933, a year before Hollywood began to strictly uphold "the sanctity of the institution of marriage" and crack down on "lustful kissing, lustful embracing, suggestive postures and gestures" (marriage and lust apparently being mutually exclusive), Warner Brothers tried to slip its terrifically sordid melodrama "Baby Face" past the censors. Directed by Alfred E. Green and starring the 25-year-old Barbara Stanwyck, the film tracks the rise of a hard-drinking, tough-talking, low-rent schemer into high society. What principally inflamed the New York Censor Board that rejected the original cut, forcing cuts and re-shoots, was that Stanwyck's aptly named Lily Powers sleeps her way to the top. The bluenoses also didn't like that the engine driving Lily's ferocious will to power is none other than Nietzsche. The German philosopher didn't make it past the censors and neither did the film's more salacious "postures and gestures." Preserved by the Library of Congress from an uncut negative, the version screening at Film Forum on Tuesday in an encore presentation includes a number of crucial, forbidden moments, among them an image of Lily's father pocketing cash in exchange for her sexual services and a scene in which she thumbs through Nietzsche's "Thoughts Out of Season." Although most famous for their unabashedly adult attitude to sex (everyone seems to be having a very good time after hours), what is most shocking about both "Baby Face" and "The Sin of Nora Moran," the second feature on this racy double bill, is their unblinking attitude to class. Both Lily and the Nora Moran, an orphan turned adulteress played by Zita Johann, are forced into extenuating circumstances not because they are born bad, but because they scramble out of poverty -- on their backs.
