description: ROBINSON--Arthur Paul, 64, on April 13, from cancer. Born in New York City January 30, 1941. Graduated Wagner College. M.A. (NYU). M.S. (Rutgers). Taught at Wagner six years, then moved to California. In 1967, he married Carole White. They went to the U.K., where he was a Publican in Bristol and Bath, returning to California in the 80's. Upon seeing a man eating garbage from a dumpster, he and Carole started taking nightly meals to the local Martinez homeless. This led to his founding a more extensive endeavor: People Feeding People, Inc. His deep faith in God brought him great comfort. His love of learning never flagged. His intellect was bolstered by a sharp wit and keen sense of humor. He enjoyed life, loved to hike, run marathons, philately, sail, garden and be with his wife and family. He is survived by his loving wife; children Melanie Martinoff and James Fisher; brothers Stephen and John; sister Maureen; grandchildren Michael, Nicholas, Morgan and Madeleine.

Nearly 2,000 couples have entered the contest in the last five years. Last year's winners -- Kris Murray, now a senior, and Caitlyn Waters, a junior, of Oklahoma City -- tore through 54 rolls of red, yellow, blue and white tape as well as bed foam, plastic bags, fabric and serving platters to become Cinderella and Prince Charming (above right). Both students are home schooled, and their prom was sponsored by the Oklahoma Christian Home Educators Association. Caitlyn spent 50 hours on their outfits, plastering tape on an old suit and prom dress; some contestants put the sticky sides of two pieces of tape together to form a fabric. Laura Murphy and Jim Longely of New Knoxville, Ohio, logged 200 hours on their homage to rock stars, whose faces are made of tape (below). What's it like to actually wear duct tape? title: THEATER

That will be the major question along Broadway this week as Mr. Reilly, known for playing such lovable misfits as the porn star Reed Rothchild in "Boogie Nights," attempts the brutish Stanley Kowalski -- a role forever linked with Marlon Brando's classic 1951 film turn and his 1947 Broadway debut -- in a new revival of Tennessee Williams's "Streetcar Named Desire." Mr. Reilly should have plenty of help, what with the powerhouse Natasha Richardson playing Blanche, the troubled vixen at the heart of Williams's classic potboiler. But like Bill Irwin, the clown who was an equally unlikely choice as George in the current revival of Edward Albee's "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?," it is Mr. Reilly who will have the most to prove. After word leaked that he'd play Stanley, Broadway jokesters commented that Mr. Reilly -- soft-spoken and seemingly kind -- would have been a better fit as Mitch, Blanche's sensitive suitor. Mr. Irwin proved most doubters wrong when he turned in a dynamite performance as George; the success of this "Streetcar" depends in part at least on Mr. Reilly's doing the same. The show opens Tuesday Studio 54, 254 West 54 Street, (212) 719-1300.

title: Buried Answers

Let her rest.' But I told them: 'No, something seems funny to me. An autopsy is the only way to be sure."' Schiller prevailed. A tanned, quick-minded, gregarious man in his 60's, he is naturally persuasive, and as chairman of pathology at Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York, he carries a certain authority regarding autopsies. The word "autopsy," he reminded his siblings, means to "see for oneself," and they should see what happened to their mother. Schiller's mother died in Miami, so he called his friend Dr. Robert Poppiti Jr., chairman of pathology at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach. She was on the table the next morning.

For the last 15 years, on a nearly weekly basis, they have invited friends and colleagues to their Brentwood home to share in an unusual predinner ritual. The action takes place in the backyard inside a "skyspace" by the artist James Turrell. From a distance, it looks like a cutting-edge mausoleum. In fact, it's a celestial viewing room designed to create the rather magical illusion that the sky is within reach -- stretched like a canvas across an opening in the ceiling. Southern California's record rains this year have aggravated damage from the Northridge earthquake in 1994, and the once commanding house is in visible decline. The base on which it appears to rest has deteriorated, and great chunks of the south retaining wall have sheared off. The house, a milestone in Wright's career (and a frequent set for fashion shoots and movies, including "Blade Runner"), has been placed on the World Monument Fund's most-endangered list, and inspectors have tagged as unsafe parts of the retaining wall, the motor court and chauffeur's quarters. Franklin De Groot, executive director of the nonprofit foundation that owns the house, said that it had raised about $3 million, but that the cost of stabilizing the structure is estimated at $5 million.

title: On the Cover; Swimming With F.D.R.
description: THE respected actor Kenneth Branagh spends a lot of time being slung ignominiously over other actors' shoulders in "Warm Springs," a new HBO film in which he portrays Franklin Delano Roosevelt during the pre-presidential years when F.D.R. came to grips with his polio. Was that really Mr. Branagh being unflatteringly upended, or was some double brought in to endure the manhandling? "Oh, I was definitely the sack of potatoes," Mr. Branagh said with a laugh. Giving a convincing portrayal of a man who has no use of his legs required a good bit of learning on Mr. Branagh's part, some of it done at Warm Springs, the natural wonder in Georgia that, in Roosevelt's time and now, drew people seeking some measure of healing from the mineral-rich water. Staff members and clients schooled him in things like how a person with no abdominal muscle strength would swim. "People were unbelievably generous as I was in there trying to pretend how to walk with leg braces and they were there with their leg braces and having to deal with very practical issues," he said. "People seemed very keen that we get it right." The film, which has its premiere Saturday at 8 p.m., depicts Roosevelt's struggle to regain his sense of purpose after he was stricken by polio in 1921, just as his political career was about to hit high gear. Cynthia Nixon (above, with Mr. Branagh) plays Eleanor Roosevelt, who had adjustments of her own to make. Mr. Branagh, who is Irish, said he had some trepidation about portraying an American political giant. "What made it seem more doable," he said, "was the idea that this was a sort of secret part of F.D.R.'s life and that in fact I wasn't playing the great American icon, I was playing the man who then developed into the great American icon." NEIL GENZLINGER

title: Muito Chic
description: Gisele Bndchen and Leonardo DiCaprio are regulars there. When Naomi Campbell visits, she stays in a palatial beach house owned by Donata Meirelles, the buyer for Daslu, the S-o Paulo boutique that sells more Chanel than any place in the world (except at Chanel itself). The Brazilian interior design star Sig Bergamin has a house there, as do Swiss bankers with low profiles but high balance sheets. Waiting in an eternal passport control line at Guarulhos International Airport in S-o Paulo, I ran into Kai, one-fourth of the downtown New York design collective As Four, and the stylist Victoria Bartlett. Guess where they were headed? So what if reaching its white shores takes three flights, a short ferry and a bumpy hour in the back of a taxi? In recent years she lived in Manhattan, and was a docent at the JP Morgan Library, a position she loved because of her lifelong passion for art and literature. She is survived by her husband of 54 years, Roger, her children Mark, of Los Angeles, Noel of NYC, James of Satellite Beach, FL, and her grandchildren Gabrielle and Sean. Joining in grieving her death are her daughters-in-law Mary Lynn and Marissa, and son-in-law Michael Whitlow. All who knew her will remember her for her beauty, grace, dignity, kindness and humor, qualities which she maintained even in the face of fatal illness. title: Fiction Chronicle
description: MOTHER OF SORROWS. By Richard McCann. (Pantheon, $20.) Richard McCann's first collection of short fiction has been a long time coming. (The widely anthologized "My Mother's Clothes: The School of Beauty and Shame" first appeared in 1986.) These lushly detailed linked stories -- which traverse post-World War II, middle-class America -- have a complexity that feels expertly distilled. The narrator, gay and H.I.V. positive, recalls a youth of misapprehensions, secret pleasures and frequent humiliations in the suburbs of Washington, as well as a fraught, yearning-filled trip to Morocco, an AIDS-decimated circle of friends and, most memorably, his narcissistic mother and dissolute, provocative brother. McCann's pointillist approach -- his stories tend to accumulate incidents rather than depict sustained events -- has surprising momentum, and together the stories acquire a rare thematic richness. Thus the perfectly engineered payoff to "My Brother in the Basement," in which the narrator's hidden sexuality is contrasted with his brother's tormented openness, reverberates in the next and final story, "The Universe, Concealed," about the narrator's ostensibly invisible illness.

title: Taxinomics
description: Is it ethical for a cabdriver to charge more for a ride during a snowstorm? The cabs that operate out of my busy train station have no meters; passengers are normally charged a set amount per person based on distance from the station. What few buses there are don't run past 8 p.m., so unless you have a car or have arranged a pickup, the only way home is by taxi. Anonymous, Woodbridge, N.J. It is not unethical for cabdrivers to charge whatever passengers are willing to pay -- an amiable word, "willing" -- but it can produce unfortunate results. It is called supply and demand, and you're seeing it in the form its partisans find most romantic: an unregulated marketplace. From that perspective, what you experienced is not only ethical; it is ideal -- free people making free choices freely (except for the inability to get home without big bucks or cross-country skis).

description: When the government unveiled its updated food pyramid last week, it offered diets pegged to a person's level of fitness, age and so forth. In keeping with this spirit of individualism, the Op-Ed page asked five chefs with New York restaurants what they ate on a typical day, and very roughly calculated how their menus would fit into the new pyramid. On one end of the spectrum, the raw-food chef Matthew Kenney said, "I eat simply to feel good," while on the other, Anthony Bourdain, whose menu included a breakfast cigarette and beer, said, "I don't think I've omitted any vital food group."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENNETT, JOHN J., JR.
description: BENNETT--John J., Jr. On April 22, 2005. John was a lifelong resident of Brooklyn, graduate of Xavier High School (1944), Fordham University (1950), and Columbia Law School (1953). A US Navy veteran of WWII and member of the Catholic War Veterans. He was past president of the Catholic Child Care Society and St. John's Residence for Boys. John also was a Board member of the Bay Ridge Day Nursery, St. Giles Foundation and Lutheran Medical Center. A devoted family man, he was an active member of St. Anselm's Parish for 53 years, member of the Parish Youth Council, the Holy Name Society, the Finance Committee and Trustee of the Parish. He was a member of the Knights of Columbus and the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick of Brooklyn. With his wife Angela, he was received into the Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem. He was a partner in the firm of Baar, Bennett & Fullen for over 25 years; currently of counsel with Brauner, Baron, Rosenzweig & Klein, LLP. Beloved husband of Angela (nee Amorosi) for 53 years. Loving father of John, Leo, Thomas (Jacqueline), Carolyn (Martin Clark) and Jeanne, and grandfather of Gavin. Cherished brother of Mary Lou Reese, Joan Carey and Evelyn Vitale. Dear son of the late Evelyn (nee Cogan) and John J. Benett, New York State Attorney General (1932-1944). Visiting Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 pm, at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Bklyn. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Anselm's RC Church, Tuesday, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Anselm's RC Church.

title: Bruckheimer's Sitcom Strategy

These offerings -- the most from any producer this season -- look beyond the carpet fibers of "CSI" for their material: one takes place in the Pentagon, two are set in the courtroom, and in the biggest departure from the Bruckheimer norm, two are sitcoms. Information about them is hard to come by -- edited cuts of Mr. Bruckheimer's pilots are kept under lock and key until they go to the networks -- but Kate Aurthur was able to glean these details.

title: Movies
description: THE PRIVATE LIFE OF SHERLOCK HOLMES (1970) Sunday at 8 p.m. on TCM. In 1887, it seems, Holmes, London's most brilliant deductive detective, posed as the husband of a Belgian woman whose real husband was missing, traveled with her (and with Dr. Watson, posing as their valet) to the Scottish Highlands and had a very close encounter with the Loch Ness monster. But someone in this story is really a German spy. The brilliant Billy Wilder directed, but his usual wit goes missing less than halfway through the film, which turns into a standard mystery case. There's real Wilder style in the early scenes, though, particularly when an aging Russian ballerina decides she wants him to father a child with her. Holmes (Robert Stephens, above) gets out of it by saying he's gay.

title: The Other Stem-Cell Debate

Humanized animals are the ideal breeding ground for pathogens that can jump from animal species to humans.

title: The Wild Child of French Cinema
description: AT 22, the gifted and singular actress Isild Le Besco can already claim an extensive career in French cinema. At 14, she starred in "La Puce," Emmanuelle Bercot's short film about a girl's first sexual experience. A couple of years later, she was playing the love interest in Benot Jacquot's "Sade" and Cdric Kahn's "Robert Succo." And by 18, Ms. Le Besco, was writing and directing "Demi-Tarif," shot with a digital camera mostly in the apartment where she grew up, in a working-class Paris neighborhood. Opening here this summer, it follows three children, largely abandoned by their mother, who make do on their own. A portrait of childhood by someone still close enough in age to hear its echo, "Demi-Tarif" ("Half-Price") was hailed upon its French release by the pioneering avant-garde filmmaker Chris Marker as the "Breathless" of its generation.

title: You've Been Sold

About $2.10 in the marketplace of secret Internet chat rooms where stolen credit-card and Social Security numbers are bought and sold.

title: The Other Stem-Cell Debate
description: Underlying the squeamish ethical questions surrounding the creation of chimeras is the uncomfortable fact that we would be performing experiments on these creatures (Jamie Shreeve, April 10). The larger debate is not just whether it is ethical to create a human chimera but also whether it is ethical to experiment on the chimera. Is it acceptable to experiment on a monkey with a human foot? If so, do we draw the line at a monkey with a human cell that allows it to sob in its cage? Why should the "humanness" of an animal species determine its appropriateness for invasive medical experimentation? Nonhuman species feel physical pain, loneliness and anxiety; they have consciousness, memory, maternal feelings and social hierarchies. For many of us, the idea of using any sentient being for experimentation has already crossed the "squirm" threshold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRUENNER, FREDERICK HERMAN
description: BRUENNER--Frederick Herman. Died on April 19, 2005 at his home in Port Washington, N.Y. He was born February 27, 1920, the only child of Adolf and Marie Bruenner. After graduating Phi Beta Kappa from Princeton University in 1941, Mr. Bruenner served in the Pacific as an officer aboard U.S.S. Straus DE 408. Following the war, Mr. Bruenner studied law at Columbia University where he was a member of the Law Review and a Harlan Fiske Stone scholar. In 1947, Mr. Bruenner joined the firm of Breed, Abbott & Morgan in New York City where he practiced for his entire career and served as senior partner. Mr. Bruenner also served as a Director of the Dime Savings Bank and National Distillers, and as an Advisory Director to Greylock, a venture capital firm. Mr. Bruenner was also an advisor to The Mashomack Preserve on Shelter Island, N.Y. and the Shelter Island Library, and a benefactor of several educational institutions. He founded the Grandparents Fund at The Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, CT. Mr. Bruenner's first wife, Euphemia M. Bruenner, predeceased him. He remarried in 1993 and is survived by his wife, Nancy Allen, his children, David F. Bruenner, Carol B. Parker, Eric W. Bruenner, four stepchildren, Tayler Neville, Leslie Schechter, George H. Oestreich III and Jeannie Loeb, seven grandchildren and two great grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Francis Hospital, 100 Port Washington Blvd, Roslyn, N.Y. 11576. A memorial service will be held at 1PM on Friday, April 29th, 2005 at Saint Stephen's Episcopal Church, Port Washington, N.Y. Another service will be held on Shelter Island, N.Y. at a later date.

title: Absolutely, Power Corrupts
description: In February 2004, a 24-year-old minor-league baseball player named Steve Stanley sat down and wrote a letter to President Bush. He had no talent with a pen, and he wanted badly to be understood, so he asked his wife, Brooke, to put what he had to say into words. He wanted to thank the president, whom he admired, for mentioning steroids in his State of the Union address, but he was also hoping to use his own case to advance the discussion. He was a small-boned, 5-foot-7, 155-pound center fielder who, even as he wrote, was succeeding in baseball because of his speed and his abilities to play defense and get on base. Even so, just over a year into his pro career, he was beginning to feel like a freak. He could live with being the least likely player on the field to hit the ball over the wall; what drove him nuts was the thought of bigger players using drugs to widen the power gap even further between him and them. The season before, he'd actually watched some hulking bomber taking batting practice hit a high fly ball to the warning track, turn to a teammate and, referring to a steroid, say, "One cycle of Deca and that's out." And he had no doubt that the slugger would make sure that, next time, the ball left the park.

title: The Rapper Moms
description: Since they met as students in 1984 at the Rhode Island School of Design and started writing songs together, Yvonne Force Villareal and Sandra Hamburg have shared an ear for witty lyrics and an affinity for showstopping clothes. Those interests merge on their new album, "Mother Inc.," a collection of electropop rap songs about plastic surgery, breast-feeding and society galas at the Whitney and the Museum of Modern Art. The Italian design house Fendi helped pay for the record. "We've always been influenced by the 60's and 70's," said Ms. Hamburg, an artist, photographer and mother of a 2-year-old girl. (Another baby is due in July.) "I've always been a big fan of Courrges and Yves Saint Laurent." Ms. Villareal, who has a 2-year-old son and is president of the nonprofit Art Production Fund, which helps artists stage works in public places, described her style as "heavy, sexy, disco-inspired, French existential gigolo." Backstage before a recent show in Miami, Ms. Villareal, near right, wore a Dolce & Gabbana dress covered in lace and rhinestones ($11,500, 212-249-4100) with a sheared weasel fur coat from an earlier collection, handbag ($3,160) and white sheared mink sandals ($545, all by Fendi, 800-336-3469). Ms. Hamburg wore a leopard-print mousseline gown with nude slip by Tuleh ($2,250 at Bergdorf Goodman) with a Fendi evening bag ($2,350) and Pucci stocking boots she bought last fall. "We don't want to look too staged when we perform," Ms. Villareal said. "We take our own aesthetics and exaggerate them." JENNIFER TUNG

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEEMAN, MORTON H.
description: LEEMAN--Morton H., 78, died April 21 of pulmonary fibrosis in South Paris, Maine. He was born July 13, 1926, and raised in New York City. He was the son of Irving and Estelle Lieberman Leeman. A graduate of the prestigious Townsend Harris High School, he double majored in English and Economics at NYU. He served in WWII in the Pacific. His ship, the USS Enoree, was present at the Armistice. After the War he served as Vice President at Ambassador Factors, the family business. He divided his time between NYC and Remsenberg, L.I., where he designed and built a house on the Moriches Bay. Morton lived in Harrison, ME, the last 14 years of his life, and played on a prize-winning bocci team there. He was an avid Times crossword puzzler and kept his sense of humor through the last days of his life. He is mourned by his loving family--brother Paul Leeman; children Lisa Leeman, Alison Clay-Duboff, Susanne Heim and Jonathan Leeman; grandchildren Baxter, Anna and Rosie; niece Cathy Stiers & nephew Larry Leeman; his first wife Lea Leeman, his second wife Anita Leeman--who tended to him with great devotion in the final month of his life, and longtime companion Vicki Larson. A memorial service will take place in Harrison, ME, April 24. A celebration of his life will be scheduled in New York later this year. Memorial donations may be made in his name to the Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation, 1332 N. Halsted St., Ste 201, Chicago, IL. 60622.

Platt, Mark Gartenfeld and the late Ellen Gartenfeld and David Gartenfeld. Grandmother of nine, greatgrandmother of nine.

title: Greg Jordan, Who Designed Homes for the A-List, Dies at 48
description: Greg Jordan, a prominent Manhattan designer who created interiors for socialites like Blaine Trump and Elizabeth Johnson, with whom he formed close friendships, died on Wednesday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 48.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: April 24-30; ART
description: If you think of Minimalist art as ascetic and colorless, then head to the roof garden of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where five sculptures and a wall drawing by Sol LeWitt will go on view on Tuesday. True, one of the tall, narrow fiberglass sculptures is solid black. (It provides an echo of Cleopatra's Needle rising up behind it in Central Park.) Another is all white. But the rest are colorful, blindingly bright in the spring sun, and look something like smooth stalagmites.

title: Corrections
QUICK BITE/Montvale; Admitting That Sushi and Pizza Don't Mix
description: The sushi pizza is gone. When Jimmy Cheng took over Yuki in December, he replaced the ill-wrought special with a sophisticated culinary sensibility and quality fish bought from some of the area's leading purveyors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRODZINSKY, SILVIA GELLINOFF
description: BRODZINSKY--Silvia Gellinoff. Predeceased by husband Raymond Fink. Survived by husband Michael Brodzinsky, nieces Francesca Lack, Judith Levy, Alexandra Gross and Joan Masket. Rest in peace, Aunt Silvia.

description: Krabi and Phuket, four months after the tsunami, and tours to chateaus in the Loire Valley Ed Alcock

title: Bar Bait
description: At 3 p.m. on a Wednesday in Rio de Janeiro, all of the stools and plastic chairs at Bracarense, a bar near the beach, are occupied. A mild roar of Portuguese and laughter rises from the crowd -- a mix of graying regulars, beachcombers and straight-from-the-office refugees. A team of gruff waiters keep the beer flowing. They also assemble sandwiches and distribute Bracarense's signature bar delicacies, which are devoured while piping hot.

description: Architectural Visions

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PLOTTEL, MARILYN
description: PLOTTEL--Marilyn. Family and friends mourn with sorrow your sudden death on April 21.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIRSCH, CHARLOTTE
description: HIRSCH--Charlotte. Age 87 of Yonkers, NY, died peacefully at home on April 22, 2005. Devoted wife of 54 years to the late Sol Hirsch. Loving and cherished mother of Gerald Hirsch, Cecelia Hirsch Gedinsky and Lawrence Hirsch and daughter-in-law Susan Zimmerman Hirsch. Adored and revered grandmother of Ilyse, Kelly, Ari, Stephany, Emily, David, Hillary and Howard. This beautiful woman of unyielding courage, strength and devotion forever leaves a void in our hearts only to be filled with the rich memories of her laughter, joy, compassion and unconditional love. Services to be at Riverside Chapel, NYC.

Brookhaven Lab's $97 Million Cleanup
description: UPTON - A YEAR ago, public protest helped kill a Department of Energy proposal to leave Brookhaven National Laboratory's graphite reactor standing. Now, a new plan to remove most of the contaminated parts, 5,700 tons in all, seems to have satisfied environmental groups and members of Congress from Long Island.

description: Correction Appended

title: Like Matzo, This Gentile Is Now a Passover Staple
description: Correction Appended

title: After Long Wait, Jets Make Kicker Their First Choice
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., April 23 - In the weeks before the N.F.L. draft, many so-called experts predicted that the Jets would select a defensive back or an offensive or defensive lineman with their first pick, the 47th over all.

title: The Basics; Trading In The Stock Traders
description: Will the New York Stock Exchange's trading floor and its traders survive? It seemed a fair question after two huge deals swept Wall Street last week and reconfigured the landscape on which trillions of dollars of stock are traded daily.

title: Our Ratings, Ourselves
description: Sure, the concept of targeting ads to tiny clusters of TV viewers, 300 households at a time, holds a certain appeal to marketers and consumers (Jon Gertner, April 10). But here's the rub: This kind of ad targeting requires dozens if not hundreds of 30-second commercials for every single advertising campaign, each spot racking up hundreds of thousands of dollars in video-production costs. In other words, creative costs could quickly outpace the media costs to place those spots on the air. Likewise, the investment in the staff required to plan, place and track dollars spent across hundreds of channels, Web sites and radio networks could put agencies out of business overnight.

title: Released E-Mail Exchanges Reveal More Bolton Battles
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 - Recently declassified e-mail messages provide new details of the bruising battle that John R. Bolton, then an under secretary of state, waged with analysts at the State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency in 2002 as he sought to deliver a speech reflecting a hard-line view of Cuba and its possible efforts to acquire biological weapons.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Back in the early 90's, criminals wanted those Rambo-type weapons they could brandish. Today they are much happier with a 9-millimeter handgun they can stick in their belt."

title: Ezer Weizman, Former President of Israel, Dies at 80
Berlusconi Fills New Cabinet With Familiar Faces
description: ROME, April 23 - Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi appointed a new cabinet on Saturday that included most of the same faces that had left office three days earlier after a crisis in the governing coalition.

title: Rebels With a Cause
description: To the Editor:

title: Charities Are Silent on Loss of Estate Tax
description: Charities stand to lose roughly $10 billion a year if the federal estate tax is repealed permanently, according to a study conducted by the Brookings Institution and the Urban Institute. That is roughly the equivalent of all the grants made by the country's 82 largest foundations in 2003.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 10 about a circle of London jazz musicians centered on the bassist Gary Crosby misstated the name of his band. It is Nu Troop, not Nu Group.

title: Our Teachers and Principals
description: To the Editor:

title: The Basics; Wendy's Copycats
description: It seems just too gross to imitate, but you can never underestimate the allure of the yucky.

title: Behind the Bush Budget: a Pell-Perkins Switcheroo
description: WHAT would you do if someone had been giving you money for years, lots and lots of it, then suddenly wanted it all back? Nearly half of the nation's colleges and universities will have to do just that under President Bush's proposed budget for fiscal 2006. In it, the administration seeks to eliminate the Perkins Loan program, a $7.5 billion pool of money that low-income students use to make ends meet. In a coda of sorts to the program, the government would get back its share -- as much as $6 billion -- as students repay their Perkinses in coming years, instead of the money being recycled into future loans.

title: Air on a Game Boy
description: Beck, pop music's foremost scavenger, has dug his way through marginalized genres like lounge music, disco and bossa nova, among others. But on "GameBoy Variations," a four-song Internet-only collection released shortly before his new album, "Guero," Beck unveiled his latest, and weirdest, discovery: chip music, a new electronic genre that prefers obsolete video-game gear to the latest technology. "GameBoy Variations," which was the best-selling album on iTunes in its first week, is Beck's salute to musicians who are retooling vintage Nintendos, Ataris and Game Boys into makeshift synthesizers, squeezing unlikely, boisterous pop from primitive bleeps and blips.

title: Editors' Choice
Jackson Will Meet Knicks, Somewhere
description: The well-documented mutual interest between Phil Jackson and Knicks officials will soon culminate in a face-to-face meeting, although where, when and to what end are questions that no one will yet answer.

title: Letters to the Editor
Lindsay Radford and Sutton Wheeler
description: Lindsay Brooke Radford and Sutton Wynn Wheeler were married last evening. The Rev. Robert M. Brearley, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at St. Simons Presbyterian Church in St. Simons Island, Ga.

title: Sir John Mills, Actor Who Played The English 'Everyman,' Is Dead at 97
description: Sir John Mills, the celebrated British actor who portrayed war heroes, Dickensian upstarts and an extraordinary pantheon of English characters in a film, stage and television career that spanned much of the 20th century, died yesterday at his home in Denham, west of London. He was 97.

title: New Pope, Same Crisis
description: New Orleans - ALTHOUGH his papacy is not yet a week old, Benedict XVI is already assured a prominent place in the culture wars. Admirers and critics alike will pay close attention not only to his pronouncements on issues like bioethics and birth control, but also to his response to the crisis of sexually abusive priests.

title: What Winds of Change?
description: So there's a benefit in riding together, and some staff member at Columbia and Yale think there's a benefit in striking together. On Monday, teaching and research assistants at Columbia and Yale started a weeklong strike, demanding the creation of a union in the hope that better wages and benefits would follow.

title: DATEBOOK
description: PARIS With traditions dating back to 1891, the French Open is the only one of the four Grand Slam events in tennis that takes place on clay courts. From May 23 to June 5 this year, the tournament will have the world's top players, including last year's singles winners, Gaston Gaudio and Anastasia Myskina (above), competing for total prize money of around $6 million.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on this page last Sunday inaccurately described the parameters proposed for the residential redevelopment in Greenpoint-Williamsburg in Brooklyn. Developers could build up to 40 stories with affordable housing. Those who choose to build only luxury or market-rate units alone could build up to 35 stories.

title: 60 Years Later, Recalling the End of World War II
Europeans Less Leery to Return
description: AS hotels and tourist boards try to lure tourists back to southern Asia with publicity campaigns and half-priced rooms, how quickly are worldwide travelers returning? It's been a slow four months, for the most part, but the rebound has been better in Europe than in the United States.

title: Awaiting an Economic Smoke Puff
description: A REPORT due Thursday on the gross domestic product will serve as more than just a reading on the strength of the economy during the first three months of the year.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side parking rules are suspended today and tomorrow for Passover. All other rules, including parking meters, remain in effect.

title: Finding Space, Sky and Sun, in Manhattan
description: A MEDICAL residency lasts only three years. Surely, for that relatively short time, Bert Vargas and his wife, Lynn Gudhus, could endure a less-than-ideal living situation.

title: McFashion? Bargains Sell
description: The estimated cost of staging a fashion show with 150 models in a gigantic tent with ivy-covered walls and a curtain of purple orchids in the middle of Central Park, with dinner and a concert thrown in, is $7.5 million. At least that was the number circulating at what may have been one of the most expensive fashion presentations ever staged in the city, held on Wednesday night by a retailer of some of its least expensive clothes.

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: LAS VEGAS PACKAGE -- The Ritz Carlton, Lake Las Vegas, which is 17 miles southeast of the Strip, has a Vegas Family Vacation package of three nights for the price of two from May 29 to Sept. 7. A room with a view of the resort grounds costs $249 a night (excluding a 10 percent tax). Guests can also choose the Good Things Come in Twos package -- $189 a night weekdays and $209 a night weekends ( resort view) and 50 percent off a second room. Details: (800) 241-3333.

title: A Black-Latino Coalition Emerges in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, April 23 - Mayor James K. Hahn thought he was doing a service to the people of Los Angeles when he engineered the removal of Bernard C. Parks as chief of police in 2002. He may have: police morale appears to be up and crime is down by many measures under the popular new police chief, William J. Bratton.

title: Watch Your Back! It's Another C.E.O. Heading for the Exit
description: Many directors, once meek lambs who often followed a chief executive's will, have cast off their submissiveness with a vengeance, propelled into vigilance by a wave of corporate scandals. And when you toss in added scrutiny by shareholders, how do you stay at the head of a company these days?

title: A Million-Year Plan for Those Million-Dollar Views
description: After learning 10 days ago that a planned condominium might not, after all, block the view between the Statue of Liberty and a statue of the goddess Minerva in Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, cemetery officials and local activists are breathing easier.

title: Rights Group Cites Rumsfeld and Tenet in Report on Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 - A human rights group issued a report on Saturday calling for a special prosecutor to examine the conduct of Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld and the former director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, in issues related to the abuse of detainees.

title: 'Omaha Blues'; 'The ConfederateBattle Flag'; Spoiler Reviews
Healthy Again, McDyess Finds a Place in Detroit
Surprise Terror Plea Leaves Unresolved Issues
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 - Zacarias Moussaoui's sudden decision this week to plead guilty to being part of a plan by Al Qaeda to crash planes into American buildings provided administration prosecutors with an unassailable victory.

title: A Setback for Mexico Case
description: MEXICO CITY, April 23 - A judge cast into doubt a politically explosive case against Mayor Andrs Manuel Lpez Obrador on Friday when he rejected a prosecution request for charges to be brought, citing the government's attempt to press the case without having Mr. Lpez Obrador arrested.

title: Thanks to Allen and James, Sonics Hang On
Memory of John Paul II Surrounds Installation
Asking Again if Father Is a Killer
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINSTEIN, HARRY
description: WEINSTEIN--Harry. Brilliant, witty, loving, and much adored father of Martha W. Alpert, the sister I was meant to have. Married 69 years to his beloved Lillie, "Boppa" to Lori and David Stratton and Alan and Tikvah Alpert. Great-grandpa of seven. A great man who will always be remembered with love. Your sister, "Auntie Merle"

title: A Generation Gap, a Workplace Chasm
description: MY new dentist is 12 years old. O.K., not technically. The diplomas on his walls indicate that he is more than twice that age, and the photos on his desk hint that he is even old enough to have young children, but we're talking impressions, not hard facts. And my impression -- maybe because I just had a birthday and I am cranky -- is that he is oh, so young. He has the baby face and slightly blustery manner of someone on the upward slope of the career curve.

title: Gwen Parker and Eugene Mazo
description: AS first dates go, Eugene Mazo and Gwen Parker's was, well, unusual. In October 2002, Ms. Parker, who tends to be reserved, contacted Mr. Mazo, a fellow law student at Stanford University, writing in her e-mail message, "When I meet someone interesting, I'm too shy to follow up. But would you have lunch or dinner with me?"

title: 'Peter Brook': The Empty Stage
description: PETER BROOK A Biography. By Michael Kustow. Illustrated. 334 pp. St. Martin's Press. $27.95.

title: Come Shine or Come Shine
description: "WHY doesn't somebody bring back the parasol?" asked Peggy Levee, who owns Rain or Shine, a boutique on West 55th Street off Fifth Avenue that carries umbrellas, parasols and contraptions that fall in between. Parasols, by the way, distinguish themselves by having both a petite build and a purpose; the word is French for "for the sun."

title: More Ham, Less Wry
description: FICTION and poetry readings are as much a New York staple as takeout menus wedged under apartment doors. Like those menus, they illustrate just how available almost everything is in our city.

title: None Of the Above
description: TWO years ago, fifth graders taking Texas's annual standardized science test faced this multiple-choice question: "Which two planets are closest to Earth?" The four choices were "Mercury and Saturn," "Mars and Jupiter," "Mercury and Venus" and "Venus and Mars."

title: The Film About the Show Behind the Show
description: FROM the summer of 2003 through the spring of 2004, Dori Berinstein, a filmmaker and theatrical producer, shot hundreds of hours of meetings, rehearsals, work sessions and backstage kvetch festivals that went into the creation of that season's 39 new Broadway productions. In "Show Business," the documentary that resulted, she focuses on four musicals ("Avenue Q," "Wicked," "Taboo" and "Caroline, or Change") as they face their first performances, their opening-night reviews and their hopes for Tony awards. Among the many interlocking (and sometimes antagonistic) constituencies represented -- authors, performers, producers, publicists, critics and audiences -- perhaps the least understood, and yet most central, are the directors. So the Arts & Leisure section invited Jason Moore, director of "Avenue Q," Joe Mantello, director of "Wicked," and George C. Wolfe, director of "Caroline, or Change" to watch a screening of the movie (which will have its premiere at the TriBeCa Film Festival tomorrow and also be shown on Wednesday and Friday) and talk with Jesse Green about their role in the process.

title: It's a Flat World, After All
description: I found Thomas L. Friedman's notion that the outsourcing of information-technology jobs is symptomatic of a failure of America's educational system specious (April 3). In the years leading up to the bursting of the dot-com bubble, Americans were encouraged to train in the fields of computers and the Internet, where, it was claimed, the opportunities were virtually unlimited. Many followed this advice. A scant few years later, we are witnessing a headlong race by corporate America to ship these very jobs overseas in a quest for "greater efficiencies" and "more productivity" (read: bigger executive bonuses).

title: In the Shade
description: With beach holidays in the offing, drugstores are running out of Jergens's new Natural Glow Daily Moisturizer, which has spawned a nationwide waiting list. The moisturizer ($5.99), which comes in two formulas, for fair or medium skin types, works as a gradual tanner. The waiting list can be found at www.jergens.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AMATNIEK, ERNEST
description: AMATNIEK--Ernest, 89, April 9, 2005. Bioelectronics pioneer and International Brigade veteran, Spain, 1937-38. Beloved of family, colleagues, friends. Memorial on May 14, NYC. Call 352-246-6525.

title: ON THE MARKET
description: Correction Appended

title: Torture, Satan and Good Times
description: Shakira

title: The Masters of the Maybe
description: Washington - IT may well be that governing is choosing. But in the United States Senate, it sometimes seems more like waiting until you really, really have to.

title: Meet Benedict XVI: Shy, Orderly, Funny
description: VATICAN CITY, April 23 - The new pope, Benedict XVI, introduced himself on Saturday to the world's news media, and if he was upset about hard-edged headlines that focused on his years as enforcer of the faith, he did not show it.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Cash for County Groups

title: Still Going Fast in Aviation
description: Since retiring as chairman and chief executive of Northrop Grumman in 2003, Kent Kresa has been a man on the go. Sometimes he is on the Los Angeles freeways, driving to work in loaner Corvettes and other glamour cars, courtesy of General Motors, where he is a director.

title: Dog Whistle
description: Issue-labeling received its first big boost a century ago when the presidential candidate William Jennings Bryan decided that free silver was the paramount issue. Since then, our burning questions on economics have gone through bread-and-butter and pocketbook issues, while war-and-peace controversies are gut issues that can turn into switcher issues. The louche canon's "zipper problem" has been elevated to the character issue, and the social issue can heat up into a hot-button issue.

title: A Funny Thing Happened
description: When you're laughing so hard it hurts, you don't usually stop to analyze the setup for the joke. Which is why Donald E. Westlake's latest crime caper, WATCH YOUR BACK! (Mysterious, $24.95), is so sneaky. Unless you're keeping tabs on all the plotlines set in motion when the glum John Dortmunder and his merry band of crooks decide to rob an art-filled penthouse on Manhattan's Upper East Side, you'll be blind-sided by the farcical payoff.

title: Acela, Built to Be Rail's Savior, Bedevils Amtrak at Every Turn
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 - It was called the American Flyer, and its goals were ambitious: to speed train travel between Northeastern cities, steal customers from air shuttles, provide the model for a nationwide fast rail system and help its deficit-prone parent, Amtrak, earn a profit.

title: A Brief Interruption to a Longstanding Drought in Southwestern Montana
description: In Montana, the one thing worse than a dry winter is a dry spring. It multiplies disappointment. The hills, already ashen, come into April looking autumnal. The wind is as sympathetic as a boot heel. Clouds of dust rise up behind the plows on wheat and potato ground. The fields blow east with each pass of the tractor and disc. So does the water from the big irrigation pivots. Where developers are laying out new housing lots -- all around Belgrade and Bozeman -- the wind does what it can to scour away any memory of the grassland that preceded them. The snowpack in the mountains will barely meet summer's needs. The drought is a bad debt, compounding itself day by day.

title: Paperback Row
description: BLUE BLOOD, by Edward Conlon. (Riverhead, $16.) In this thoughtful memoir, Conlon recalls his rise from rookie cop to detective in the New York Police Department. A Harvard-educated Irish Catholic, Conlon ruminates on family history (his father, uncle and great-grandfather were cops) and on a policeman's day-to-day life -- from housing-project patrols to armed confrontations. Spanning a period in the 1990's that saw the shooting of Amadou Diallo and the station-house abuse of Abner Louima, "Blue Blood" also looks at departmental dysfunction, the war on drugs and urban race relations. Our reviewer, Ted Conover, said Conlon's memoir, "in terms of its ambition, its authenticity and the power of its writing, is in a class by itself."

title: Under One Roof
description: TUCKED away on one floor of a nondescript dormitory at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J., is a hall that throbs with student activism: its walls are plastered with pictures of impoverished children, world maps, news clippings and the entire text of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, adopted by the United Nations in 1948.

title: Nets Pummeled by Heat in Game 1
Mr. Skilling, Come On Over
description: For the preview screening in Houston last week of the documentary "Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room," two indicted executives from the company, Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, were not in the room -- even though their multimillion-dollar homes were just a few blocks from the theater.

title: Saturday Night's All Right
description: AFTER a week of hitting the books in no-nonsense comfort clothing (sweats, sneakers and the like), 10 o'clock scholars get serious about dressing up on Saturday night. Indications abound that old-school haberdashery is making a comeback on the party circuit. At Vassar (above, from left), that means an update on "Annie Hall" neckties for Vanessa Soto and vintage suiting elements for Christopher Punj and Lincoln Madley. "I look forward to trying on new outfits," says Mr. Madley, a senior, who pairs a vintage charcoal-gray coat and matching vest with Earl jeans and a tie by Karl Lagerfeld for H&M. He leaves his shirt deliberately untucked: "My inspiration for this combination was the lead character in the movie 'Withnail and I' -- he had an Edwardian style that was very proper, yet it wasn't worn properly; I liked that he looked a total mess." Across the continent, Tam Vo, a junior at Stanford (right), proves that tailored trousers need not cramp one's style. "They're really comfortable," she says. "I can long-board in them, or go from class to a campus party to a night out in San Francisco, to hang out and dance at Bottom of the Hill," a music club. "I wear them with ballet flats I found for $15 in Chinatown." JULIA SZABO

title: How Not to Behave at an Open House
description: THERE is trouble plaguing the open house, that weekend institution intended to mate buyers with desirable properties. The trouble, according to some brokers, is that more and more attendees belong not in someone else's perfectly coiffed apartment but in an etiquette or anger-management seminar.

title: Text: Pope's Homily at Installation Mass
Watching TV Makes You Smarter
description: The Sleeper Curve SCIENTIST A: Has he asked for anything special? SCIENTIST B: Yes, this morning for breakfast . . . he requested something called "wheat germ, organic honey and tiger's milk." SCIENTIST A: Oh, yes. Those were the charmed substances that some years ago were felt to contain life-preserving properties. SCIENTIST B: You mean there was no deep fat? No steak or cream pies or . . . hot fudge? SCIENTIST A: Those were thought to be unhealthy.

title: A Park Avenue Battle for Status, Almost Won
description: The future of a stretch of Park Avenue has been the topic of bitter debate recently, with residents disagreeing on whether to be part of the Upper East Side Historic District.

title: The Unreal Road From Toontown to 'Sin City'
description: ROBERT RODRIGUEZ'S "Sin City" and Stephen Chow's "Kung Fu Hustle" are, without question, two of the most inventive screen entertainments released so far this year, but nobody is likely to accuse either one of being terribly original. Indeed, both movies base their appeal on a combination of visual novelty and generic familiarity. Looking quite unlike anything you have ever seen before, they are also knowingly and ostentatiously derivative, packed with quotations, allusions, spoofs and outright thefts from older movies.

title: Trading in the Stock Traders
A Distressing Trend
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Yankees Bounce Back With a Blowout of Their Own
Daughter of the Enlightenment
description: By lauding a woman who is not trying to reform Islam but rather drawing attention to its backwardness, we do a disservice to a readership that already knows too little about why Islam is meaningful to so many people (Christopher Caldwell, April 3).

title: A Modest Proposal: No Quarters? No Problem.
description: Even City Council members, or maybe especially City Council members, are not immune to the petty annoyances of urban life. Exhibit A is Councilwoman Eva Moskowitz from the Upper East Side, and her travails with parking meters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SALK, CHARLES
description: SALK--Charles, born December 12, 1915, of Floral Park, NY, died on April 12, 2005. Loving husband of Reva Salk for 54 years. Devoted father of Toby and Peter Salk. President, NARFE Chapter 23 for 21 years. Memorial May 31, at Community Church, 40 East 35 St, Manhattan, 1-3 PM.

title: Leaderless on Land Use
description: Garden City - WHEN it comes to development, Long Island is on a path to self-destruction. And the person leading the way is the Smithtown supervisor, Patrick Vecchio.

title: Cheaper by the Half Dozen? They Should Know.
description: POSSIBLY the single most important thing you need to know about the Strautmanis household is that there is one bathroom. Tucked into the corners of a 4,000-square-foot, 1970's-era artist's loft in SoHo -- and there are a lot of corners in its impressionistic floor plan -- three adults and six children are living harmoniously with a 55-gallon water heater and its attendant plumbing.

title: Career and Volunteer Firefighters
description: To the Editor:

title: Smaller Parties Give More Choices (2 Letters)
Paid Notice: Deaths   STANFIELD, PAMELA HOPE
description: STANFIELD--Pamela Hope. Artist, on February 15, 2005. Pratt graduate 1980. Pam brought sunshine and pleasure into every life she touched. All who loved Pam miss and mourn her tragic passing. Pam is survived by mother Marie, brother Jim, Jim's wife Cindy, loving family, countless friends. All our lives were blessed by your presence, your absence leaves us bereft, and your loving spirit will never be forgotten. We know the angels are smiling with you in their midst. We know you are smiling because you are with your sweet Burmese. Friends may e-mail memoriesofpam@aol.com

title: POPE BENEDICT XVI: Roots of Conservatism; Turbulence on Campus in 60's Hardened Views of Future Pope
description: TBINGEN, Germany, April 23 - For all Pope Benedict XVI's decades as a Vatican insider, it may have been the crucible of a university town swept by student radicalism in the late 1960's that definitively shaped the man who now leads the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Corrections
description: A capsule guide on April 17 with an article about Cologne, Germany, included an incorrect Web site for the Im Kupferkessel hotel. It is www.im-kupferkessel.de.

title: Succulence of the Lamb
description: TRENTON - IF there were a dish that is early spring to summer, a likely candidate would be the rack of lamb with hot peppers at Amici Milano.

title: The N.F.L. Draft: A Study in Cockeyed Overconfidence
description: MORE than 40 years ago at a California hospital, a group of clinical psychologists were given some basic information about a 29-year-old man. They were asked to evaluate his personality and to say how confident they were in their diagnoses.

title: Tea Party in the City
description: WHEN Caroline Daifotis of New Canaan heard that the Plaza Hotel will be closing on April 30, she planned a "girly day" for her daughters -- tea at the Palm Court in the lobby of Manhattan's legendary hotel, then a little shopping on the Upper East Side.

title: 'My Life in the Middle Ages': Making It
description: MY LIFE IN THE MIDDLE AGES A Survivor's Tale. By James Atlas. 220 pp. HarperCollins Publishers. $25.95.

title: Up Front
description: David Orr, a lawyer who works for Wollmuth, Maher & Deutsch in New York, has been a frequent contributor of poetry criticism to the Book Review since 2002. (His first review for us, a witty and penetrating assessment of Marie Ponsot's work, made our cover that spring.) We are happy to report that this week marks the debut of Orr's column, On Poetry, which will run in these pages every four to six weeks.

title: Survival of the Fittest

title: The Teacher: Wise Man, Fool, Tempter

title: Comings and Goings
description: Two Internet travel stalwarts have changed course. Priceline, which has sold travel-related products in a bidding format since 1998, has just introduced a new version of its Web site, featuring retail prices. Users can still try their luck with the name-your-price option. title: The Other Stem-Cell Debate
description: Regarding Jamie Shreeve's dazzling article on bioethics, it is pretty well established that many of the early rocket scientists were inspired by science-fiction writers like Jules Verne and H. G. Wells. Is it possible that neurosurgeons have been inspired by children's books and movies and the literature of animal lovers? I grew up reading "Lad: A Dog," by Albert Payson Terhune, and I'd bet on Lad any day against the brainiest gene-altered animal coming out of these labs. As for a sheep with human features -- does "Charlotte's Web" ring a bell? What about the movie "Babe"? Shreeve's scientists muse about sobbing monkeys. We've seen animal grief heart-rendingly portrayed from "The Yearling" to "Lassie Come Home."

title: Democratic Moral Values?
description: You can forgive Democrats in Washington for feeling somewhat vindicated by the way the controversy over Terri Schiavo played out. For years, after all, they waited in vain for the moment when Republicans might trip over their own arrogance while crusading for moral values, and finally, if polls are to be believed, it happened. Spurred by opportunism and more than a little genuine religious fervor, the heirs to Goldwater and Reagan seemed to forget how they came to control the values debate in America in the first place: not by interfering in the moral choices of families but by promising to stop government from doing exactly that. In truth, it had been a long time since Republican leaders paid more than superficial tribute to their libertarian creed, but it was only now, in the battle over a dying woman's wishes, that the public seemed to call them on it.

title: Inside the List
description: BELLOW'S BREAKTHROUGH: Saul Bellow, who died earlier this month at 89, won the Nobel Prize, three National Book Awards and a Pulitzer Prize, yet he was no stranger to the Times best-seller list. For a stretch of almost 30 years -- from the publication of "Henderson the Rain King" in 1959 through the release of "More Die of Heartbreak" in 1987 -- nearly everything Bellow wrote appeared for two months or so on the hardcover fiction or nonfiction list. It took the public time to pick up on Bellow's busy, rueful, comic charms. None of his first four novels -- "Dangling Man" (1944), "The Victim" (1947), "The Adventures of Augie March" (1953) or "Seize the Day" (1956) -- made this page. Bellow's real breakthrough came in 1964 with "Herzog," a novel about a failed academic whose wife leaves him for his best friend. The book was praised on the cover of the Book Review and held on at No. 1 for more than seven months. (The book it bumped out of the top slot: John le Carr's "Spy Who Came In From the Cold.") Twenty years after the publication of his first novel, Bellow was financially secure. In his biography of Bellow, James Atlas writes that female readers were particularly taken with "Herzog," and with its dashing author. Women would write to him, Bellow said in a television interview, "to ask me how they should behave with intellectuals, for recipes of dishes mentioned in the book. They make me feel like an editor of Vogue."

title: Arts, Briefly; Farewell, 'Kiss'
description: An original print of the widely reproduced Robert Doisneau photograph "The Kiss by the Htel de Ville" fetched $242,000 at an auction in Paris last night, when Franoise Bornet, the woman in the picture, sold her copy, autographed by Doisneau, who died in 1994. (The presale estimate was $19,600 to $26,000. The buyer was an unidentified Swiss collector.) Doisneau spotted Mrs. Bornet and her then boyfriend on the streets of Paris in 1950, and they agreed to pose. A few days later, Doisneau sent her an original copy, part of a series on Paris lovers assigned by Life magazine. Mrs. Bornet, a former actress, emerged from anonymity in 1993 when she sued Doisneau for $18,000 compensation and a share of the royalties. The case was dismissed, but during it Doisneau revealed that the scene had been staged. Since 1986, when the photograph was first printed as poster, the image has been widely reproduced. The rights remain in the hands of Rapho, Doisneau's photo agency. HLNE FOUQUET

description: A Brooklyn man charged with killing his pregnant ex-girlfriend and dumping her body in the Hudson River pleaded not guilty to second-degree murder yesterday. The suspect, Roscoe Glinton II, 42, entered his plea in State Supreme Court in the death of the woman, Lisa D. Eatmon, 33, whose body was found off a Chelsea pier on April 3. She was eight months pregnant with Mr. Glinton's child, and had been shot in the head, the police said. Mr. Glinton, a sanitation worker, was arrested on Friday after a grand jury returned an indictment against him. Two weeks earlier, the prosecutor contended, he had planned to flee to the Bahamas with $20,000, but was arrested after driving away from officers at speeds up to 100 miles per hour on the Belt Parkway. Mr. Glinton must remain in jail until a bail hearing on May 24. His lawyer, Steven B. Kirschner, argued that his client had known he was under investigation for more than three weeks, but did not flee. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: DEGUSSA BUYS OUT A JOINT VENTURE PARTNER
description: Degussa, a maker of specialty chemicals, agreed to buy the 50 percent share it did not already own of Cyro Industries, a plastics joint venture in the United States, for $95 million from its partner, Cytec Industries. The agreement over Cyro, which Degussa and Cytec started in 1976, includes four manufacturing sites, research and development, and sales and marketing services, Degussa said. Degussa, which is based in Dusseldorf, Germany, said it would take on about 680 workers at the venture. Cyro, which had sales last year of $317 million, makes antigraffiti plastic sheets and sound-barrier systems. The acquisition "positions Degussa for growth both in North America and worldwide," Degussa's chief executive, Utz-Hellmuth Felcht, said in a statement. Cytec, based in West Paterson, N.J., said it would use proceeds from the sale to reduce debt.

description: WEISFOGEL--Jaret Wayne, Ph.D., 38, died on April 25, 2005. Beloved son of Drs. Jerry & Matonah Weisfogel, older brother of Amiel, and brother-in-law of Rebecca. A distinguished scholar of East Asian studies, he received the prestigious Heyman Center Postdoctoral Fellowship in Confucian Studies at Columbia University. His first love in life was his family, to whom he was selflessly devoted. His thoughtfulness and kindness were as essential to his character as were his honesty, his integrity, and his intellectual curiosity. He surrounded himself with his beloved scholarly works and classical music. On walks with family and friends, he would always stop to appreciate the smallest details of life. To say that he will be sorely missed would understate the immense void he leaves behind in the lives of those who loved him. He fought a long and courageous battle against Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma. description: The World Chess Federation has announced that it will hold a tournament in San Luis, Argentina, from Sept. 27 to Oct. 16, to select a new world champion. The prize fund is $1 million, with the winner receiving $300,000 and the title of world champion, according to the federation. The federation said it would invite eight of the world's best players, including its current champion, Rustam Kasimdzhanov of Uzbekistan; Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, who also claims to be world champion; and Garry Kasparov, also of Russia, the world's No. 1-ranked player, who recently announced his retirement. (Representatives of Mr. Kramnik and Mr. Kasparov said they would not play.) The world championship has been split since 1993 when Mr. Kasparov, then the undisputed champion, broke from the federation. Mr. Kramnik defeated him in 2000 and defended his title by drawing a match with Peter Leko of Hungary last year. Previous efforts to reunify the world championship have not been successful. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ASM International Posts First-Quarter Loss
description: ASM International, Europe's second-largest maker of equipment to build semiconductors, yesterday reported a first-quarter loss and said it was less optimistic about 2005 as customers remained reluctant to spend. ASMI, based in Bilthoven, the Netherlands, has been hurt as customers have worked to cut excess chip inventories and have delayed ordering new machines.

title: PHILIP MORRIS BUYS COLOMBIAN TOBACCO COMPANY
description: Philip Morris International, a unit of the Altria Group, bought Compaa Colombiana de Tabaco, Colombia's biggest tobacco company, for about $300 million to increase sales of such brands as Marlboro in Colombia. Shareholders sold 61.4 million shares of Coltabaco, or 97 percent, for $4.88 a share, or 4.3 percent more than the price on March 18, the last trading day. Coltabaco, based in Medellin, said in August it had agreed to the sale. The result was announced by the Colombia stock exchange. "Our priority is the local market," said Luc Gerard, general manager of Philip Morris Colombia. "Close to 50 percent of the market is still in the hands of our competitors and I want to maximize our participation." With the purchase, Philip Morris has 51 percent of the Colombian market, Mr. Gerard said.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Gaza: Abbas Says He Expects Hamas To Disarm
description: Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian leader, said he expected the radical Islamic group Hamas to relinquish its weapons when it joins the Palestinian parliament this summer, but he did not say what he would do if the group refused. "Once a movement or militia is transformed into a political party, I would say that there is no need for them to possess weapons," he said at a news conference in Gaza City. Hamas has said it will take part in parliamentary elections planned for July, and it is expected to make a strong showing. title: Arts, Briefly; Trouble for 'Lennon'?
description: Is it just like starting over? That was the impression coming out of San Francisco yesterday, when producers of the Broadway-bound musical "Lennon" announced that they were canceling a planned tryout run in Boston in favor of returning to New York for more rehearsals. Allan McKeown, the lead producer, said the Boston run (scheduled at the Colonial Theater from May 31 through June 25) was being sacrificed for "changes that will be beneficial to our show," but he said the Broadway opening remained set for July 28. It is not the production's first sign of turmoil; reviews in San Francisco, where it plays until May 14, were mostly unfriendly, and sales in Boston not particularly strong. "Lennon," written and directed by Don Scardino, tells the story of John Lennon through his songs, and is produced by arrangement with his widow, Yoko Ono, above. JESSE McKINLEY

description: A group of Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee, including the ranking minority member, John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, are urging the Justice Department to investigate the New York Police Department's conduct during the Republican National Convention last summer. In a letter dated yesterday to the United States attorney general, Alberto R. Gonzales, the Democrats called for "immediate federal scrutiny" of "troubling reports" of police misconduct and perjury in connection with the arrest and prosecution of hundreds of demonstrators. The Democrats, who included Representative Jerrold L. Nadler, whose district includes parts of Manhattan and Brooklyn, noted that 91 percent of the 1,670 cases brought against the demonstrators have either resulted in dismissal of the charges or a not guilty verdict after trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITE, JOHN F. (JACK)
description: WHITE--John F. (Jack), 87, died April 22 at home in Virginia Beach, VA. In NYC, Jack became President Emeritus of The Cooper Union after 11 years as President. Formerly, he was President of National Educational Television and Radio (now PBS and NPR) and served as special assistant at ASPEN Institute. A graduate of Lawrence College, with Master's from U. of Chicago, he had honorary degrees from Lawrence, Cornell College, Hamilton and Temple. On the vestry of Trinity Parish and Trustee of St. Margaret's House, he was also Trustee of General Theological Seminary, Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Pres. of Venture Fund of Diocese of NY, and Sr. Warden of St. Marys-in-Tuxedo. He was director of Kornfeld Foundation, Orange and Rockland Utilities, and Shearson, Lehman, Hutton Mutual Funds. Honoraries are from the American Society of the Order of St. John and NY Society of Architects. Jack served as Director of Viacom International, Foreign Policy Assoc. and was Trustee of Bard College and the United Negro College Fund. Recent residences are Tuxedo Park, NY, and Sarasota, Florida. Predeceased by son, Michael and parents The Very Rev. Edward S. White and Lilah, Jack is survived by Joan, his wife of 61 years, and children Susan Sherman (Ted) and Christopher (Ellen); daughter-in-law Molly; brother Pat (Rose); eight grandchildren; Whitney, Kate, Cameron, Jamie, Alex, Sean, Teddy, and Lulu; and great-grand-daughters, Zoe and Madeline. Memberships include the University Club and The Tuxedo Club, where he had been Governor and Chairman. A memorial service will be held Sunday, June 12, at 12:30 PM at St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo Episcopal Church. Memorial contributions may be made to The Cooper Union or the Nashotah House Seminary, Nashotah, Wisconsin 53058.

title: Arts, Briefly; In a Pickle
description: The plaza around the building nicknamed the Gherkin, a prize-winning skyscraper in the financial district in London, has been cordoned off after one of its giant glass panels plummeted from the 28th floor to the street. Officially opened last May, the 34-story, 600-foot missile-shaped building, formally known by its address, 30 St. Mary Axe, is a creation of the architect Lord Norman Foster. The structure is made of 5,000 glass panels, 744 of which open. A spokeswoman for the building said that the incident, on April 18, happened early in the morning, and no one was hurt. "It was one of the opening panels that fell out," she said. "At the moment a full investigation is under way to check all the other windows." Lord Foster's Millennium Bridge, a footbridge across the Thames from St. Paul's Cathedral to the Tate Modern, became known as the wobbly bridge and was closed immediately after opening in June 2000. Suspension system problems caused it to sway under the first crowds. After a $10 million repair, it bridge reopened in February 2002. PAM KENT

A Tighter Rebooking Deadline
description: A TIGHTER REBOOKING DEADLINE -- Northwest Airlines has shortened the deadline for rebooking unused nonrefundable tickets to 90 days after a missed flight, from 365 days. "The ticket can still be used for a year, it's just that the actual change has to be made within 90 days," said Kurt Ebenhoch, a Northwest spokesman. The new policy, which he said was adopted for better inventory control, applies to all tickets issued on or after April 15. Terry Trippler, the chief executive of Farefacts.com, a travel adviser based in Minneapolis, said, "It's a big change." As of yesterday, he said, no other airline had followed Northwest's lead. Typically, major airlines allow passengers who cancel an original flight on a nonrefundable ticket to rebook the ticket anytime within a year for a $100 change fee. Over the last five years, business travelers have been rebelling against high walk-up fares by switching to the nonrefundable tickets favored by tourists. Because business travelers change their plans so often, many corporate travel managers use procedures, like American Express's TicketTrax service, to keep track of unused tickets and flag them for rebooking.

description: State foster-care and school authorities have been sued by the estate of a 7-year-old boy whose body was discovered in a plastic storage container in a Newark basement in 2003. In the suit, filed in December in Essex County Superior Court and made public yesterday, the State Division of Youth and Family Services and the Newark school system were accused of negligence in the care of the boy, Faheem Williams. Two of the boy's brothers were also found in the basement of the home of their mother's cousin, Sherry Murphy. The children were in foster care with Ms. Murphy, who with her son, Wesley Murphy, have been charged in Faheem's death. Faheem's brothers and their mother, Melinda Williams, are also plaintiffs in the suit. The brothers were severely emaciated when they were found. They have since been placed in foster care elsewhere. Foster-care authorities had received 11 complaints of abuse and neglect about the children, but the case was closed after a division worker was unable to locate them. The state has countersued Ms. Murphy, saying she was responsible for Faheem's death. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Tarrytown: Man Talked Out Of Jumping
description: The police stopped all traffic on the Tappan Zee Bridge for almost three hours yesterday afternoon while they talked a man out of jumping into the Hudson River, the state police said. Sgt. Christine Revella of the New York State police in Tarrytown said that the man, whom the police identified as Armando Chico, called local police on his cellphone from the bridge. After "a long conversation," a police negotiator persuaded him to come down, Sergeant Revella said. She said no charges would be filed against the man, who is a registered sex offender. The state's registry of sex offenders lists Mr. Chico, 40, of Middletown, whose name is given as Armondo on the list, as having been convicted in September of having sex with a 13-year-old girl. The shutdown of the bridge, which ended about 5:20 p.m., caused traffic backups of up to 10 miles in each direction, according to a spokeswoman for the New York State Thruway Authority. Judge R. Gary Klausner of United States District Court in Los Angeles last week blocked Del Monte's sale of any pet food product that violated Mars's patent. Judge Klausner also upheld the jury's decision last month to award Mars $3.6 million in damages. Mars, whose Kal Kan unit makes Pedigree dog food and Whiskas cat food, sued in 2001 seeking unspecified damages and to block the H.J. Heinz Company from selling pet food with soft centers surrounded by hard, cereal-based shells. Del Monte, which is based in San Francisco, was brought into the case when it bought the North American pet food division from Heinz in 2002. Del Monte said it was considering an appeal.

description: A front-page article last Wednesday about a new study on weight and mortality referred imprecisely at one point to the risks of being very thin. title: When the Dollar Bill Comes Due
description: WASHINGTON - OVER the last two years, the value of the dollar against the major currencies has dropped by more than 25 percent. With the dollar having depreciated so much, why haven't we seen a narrowing of the trade deficit, which in February (the latest month for which numbers are available) reached a new record of $61 billion? A dollar depreciation should bring about what economists call "expenditure switching": as the cost of imports rises, Americans should start buying more goods made at home; in turn, our exports become less expensive for foreigners, which means foreign demand for our products should rise. This shift in exchange rates and prices should eventually correct the country's trade deficit.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Technology Job Market Weak But Stable
description: The job market in the technology industry remained weak but stabilized last year, according to the American Electronics Association. In a yearly report based on government data and released this week, the trade group found that the technology industry lost 25,000 jobs in 2004, declining to 5.6 million. That represented a far slower decline than in 2003, when 333,000 jobs were lost, and 2002, when employment in the technology business dropped 612,000. "The severe hemorrhaging has stopped," said William T. Archey, chief executive of the trade association. Employment fell in manufacturing and communications services, which continue to shed jobs as the telecommunications industry consolidates. But jobs were added in software services and engineering and technology services. In trade, America's technology exports rose 12 percent, to $191 billion last year, while imports rose 17 percent, to $271 billion. Steve Lohr (NYT)

description: The shows in CBS's highly rated 9 p.m. to 11 p.m. block on Monday night -- "Everybody Loves Raymond," "Two and a Half Men" and "CSI: Miami" -- were repeats, but the network still managed to come in first in total viewers for the night. "CSI: Miami" was Monday's most-watched show, bringing in an estimated audience of 15.54 million. NBC's lineup featured original episodes of "Fear Factor," "Las Vegas" and "Medium," and the combination was No. 1 among adults 18 to 49. "Medium," with a guest appearance by Chad Lowe as a murderous airline pilot, was NBC's biggest draw: 14.23 million viewers watched the show, starring Patricia Arquette. CBS's Monday loss among viewers 18 to 49 aside, the network, which used to skew older, continues to do well in that demographic. It was first among those viewers for the week that ended on April 24. title: Who Has Raspberries? So Soon?
description: The local raspberry season usually kicks in by early July. But there is a splendid sneak preview in the Union Square Greenmarket on Saturdays for the next two to three weeks. Jack Torrice of Fruit Valley Orchard farm in Oswego, N.Y., is harvesting big juicy-sweet hothouse raspberries. "I learned about it and thought I'd give it a try since I had the greenhouses anyway," he said on the first Saturday he had the berries for sale. Even at $6 a half-pint, his supply was gone before noon. The grape-size berries come with a bit of stem, which keeps them from collapsing. Grab it and gently pull out the core.

description: A teenager who the police say left her newborn daughter in a closet overnight, then showed up at a hospital with the baby's body in a plastic shopping bag the next morning, has been charged with criminally negligent homicide. The mother, Shariece Patterson, 18, of Harlem, left the child's body at St. Luke's Hospital on her way to school on Jan. 24, one day after giving birth at her home on Broadway near 135th Street, the police said yesterday. Ms. Patterson, who had hidden her pregnancy, delivered the baby alone, the police said. An arrest was not made until the medical examiner determined the cause of death, which was asphyxiation, officials said. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

The new plant is expected to produce 50,000 cars a year eventually, Tokuichi Uranishi, Toyota's senior managing director for Europe and Africa, said in a statement. Toyota sold 47,000 cars last year in Russia, out of total foreign car sales of just more than 353,000. Toyota's initial investment in the plant is estimated at 4 billion rubles ($144 million). title: Making Housework A Bit Less Painful
description: A new line of ergonomic mops, brooms, shovels and rakes uses soft vinyl grips to reduce hand pain and "Smart Handles" that prevent back strain by allowing the user to stand straight. The tools, from Delta Ergo, were first developed for industrial cleaning and have been adapted for residential use. They have various types of aluminum handles; some are bent, some can be adjusted to accommodate the user's height, and some swivel to reduce repetitive motion. The self-wringing mop, right, has a swivel handle ($29.99). A rake that adjusts from 8 1/2 inches high to 22 inches high is $29.99. Other cleaning tools include a sponge mop, a push broom and a tub and tile scrubber. At deltaergo.com or (800)435-7338. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

description: The Alliance Data Systems Corporation, which manages credit cards for retailers, agreed yesterday to buy the Blair Corporation's credit portfolio for about $176.3 million. Blair, based in Warren, Pa., has more than 800,000 credit accounts and annual sales of about $500 million. The company, founded 95 years ago, sells casual and business clothing for men and women under the Blair and Irvine Park brands. Alliance Data, based in Dallas, manages cards for retailers like Fortunoff, AnnTaylor Stores, Victoria's Secret and J. Crew. The Blair purchase "gives us access to customers in suburban middle America who are shopping for reasonably priced apparel," said Edward J. Heffernan, chief financial officer of Alliance Data.
