title: Arts, Briefly; Paying for the Past
description: Giving in after years of pressure from Jewish groups, Friedrich Christian Flick, the billionaire contemporary art collector whose grandfather was a Nazi arms industrialist, has finally paid $6.5 million into a fund for former slave laborers, the German news agency ddp reported. Mr. Flick, whose collection was installed in September at the Hamburger Bahnhof Museum in Berlin, had been accused by critics of using his art to try to whitewash his family's past. Although his Nazi grandfather employed as many as 50,000 slave laborers in his factories, Mr. Flick refused to contribute part of his family inheritance to a major compensation fund, choosing instead to set up his own fund intended to fight racism and neo-Nazism in Eastern Germany. KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

title: Mussina Is Tattooed by the Angels
description: Mike Mussina's 100th pitch last night was belted past him into the outfield at Yankee Stadium, and Mel Stottlemyre, the Yankees' 63-year-old pitching coach, suddenly chugged toward Mussina as if he were legging out a double. Vladimir Guerrero was looming in the on-deck circle, and Stottlemyre had to offer some advice in a hurry.

title: Boeing earnings sag 14% in quarter
Reflections of You, in Another Place
description: Jason Miller, a product designer in Brooklyn, replaces some of the reflective backing on mirrors with digitally printed photos of oceans and trees. "I'm interested in pushing the idea of the artificial, additional space that mirrors create," Mr. Miller said. He took the pictures in New Jersey, at a beach he played on as a child and in his uncle's backyard. "I chose these idiosyncratic landscapes, to keep away from postcard imagery," he said. Between the tree trunks and waves, there's enough reflective surface for viewers to shave or apply makeup. The Future Perfect store in Brooklyn sells the mirrors, 20 by 30 inches, for $400 each. (718)599-6278 or www.thefutureperfect.com. EVE M. KAHN

title: House Leaders Talk Terms
description: It's a sad day for the Senate when the House of Representatives sets the example on how to get along. But this week the Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, rejected a Democratic proposal to resolve the standoff on judicial nominees by letting through most of the small number being blocked. Right now in the Senate, it is clear that the only acceptable compromise is one in which everyone agrees to do exactly what Senator Frist wants. But in the House, Republican leaders made a more rational call, deciding to end their stonewalling of an ethics committee investigation of Tom DeLay, the House majority leader.

title: Leading With the Women
description: If war breaks out in the Senate over judicial nominations, the initial battle is likely to center on two women, Priscilla Owen and Janice Rogers Brown. Republicans seem to think that those nominees will come off as so likeable that Democrats will be forced to back down from their threats of a filibuster. But when the American public looks beyond the photo-op, it will be clear why these women do not belong on the federal bench. Both have records of kowtowing to big business and showing contempt for ordinary people who are the victims of injustice.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hospital's Prosecution Urged
description: The widow of a Westchester County man whose death this month is being investigated as a possible case of Legionnaires' disease has asked the Manhattan district attorney to consider criminal charges against the hospital where he might have become infected. The widow's lawyer, David Fair, said yesterday that he had asked District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau to consider prosecuting NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital. Mr. Fair said he believed the hospital had had evidence that its water was tainted with the bacteria that causes Legionnaires' disease, and should have taken greater care to prevent the death of Richard Montesano, 63. The hospital said on Tuesday that its own autopsy showed that another patient, whose identity has not been disclosed, died of Legionnaires' disease, but that the cause of Mr. Montesano's death was still being investigated by the medical examiner. title: Arts, Briefly; Topping the Chart on First Try
description: Rob Thomas, left, the singer of the band Matchbox Twenty, made Billboard chart history this week. His solo album, "Something to Be" (Atlantic), opened at No. 1 in its first week of release, and Billboard said he was "the first male artist from a pop or rock group" to open at No. 1 with a debut solo album since the Billboard 200 chart began 50 years ago. In addition, "Something to Be" is the first No. 1 album released only in the new DualDisc format, combining CD and DVD on one disc. "Something to Be" sold 252,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, about 26,000 more copies than the No. 2 album, Mariah Carey's "Emancipation of Mimi" (Island), which was last week's chart-topper. As 50 Cent's "Massacre" (Interscope) continues to slide -- it is at No. 5 this week, with 127,000 copies sold -- some new releases have entered the Top 5. Mike Jones's "Who Is Mike Jones?" description: A man who has served time for sodomy has been arraigned on charges that he sexually assaulted two boys, 11 and 13, in MacNeil Park in College Point, the authorities said. The man, Timothy Felton, 31, of South Ozone Park, was seen talking to a young girl by an off-duty police officer who alerted other officers, the authorities said. At the arraignment yesterday, Kenneth Appelbaum, an assistant district attorney, said that officers found Mr. Felton with the boys, one of whom said that Mr. Felton lured them to the woods on Monday, fondled them and promised them gifts if they returned on Tuesday. At the arraignment, Mr. Appelbaum said that Mr. Felton had sex with the 11-year-old in a park bathroom while making the older boy stand guard. Prosecutors said Mr. Felton was paroled in February after serving time for sodomy and robbery. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

description: The Cognizant Technology Solutions Corporation, an American computer services company with two-thirds of its workers in India, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit gained 62 percent as sales rose faster than costs. The company raised its forecasts. Net income increased to $32 million, or 22 cents a share, from $19.8 million, or 14 cents, a year earlier, according to the company, which is based in Teaneck, N.J. Sales surged 52 percent, to $181.7 million. Cognizant's sales are expected to rise 48 percent this year on demand for its low-cost computer and software management services based in India. It plans to add 7,700 workers this year, mostly in India, to handle additional contracts from American companies like IndyMac Bancorp, a bank in Los Angeles.

title: China's Selective Memory

It is indeed news, then, that people have been protesting in the streets of Chinese cities about Japan's wartime past, its textbooks' reluctance to face history squarely, and its proposed accession to the United Nations Security Council.

The agency suspended her, and its superintendent, James D. Mapes, said he planned to fire her and have the state revoke her educator's certificate. The agency's outside auditor, Miller, Lilly & Pearce, also audited many other school districts, including Roslyn, where investigators say administrators stole millions of dollars. Dr. Bolin is accused of pocketing instead of returning money that was refunded after some students canceled their reservations to Russia. Dr. Bolin's lawyer, William T. Headwaters sued a Gallagher unit, AJG Financial Services, in 2000, saying it breached the agreement by failing to pay royalties on technology used in the making of alternative fuels at two production plants in South Carolina. A jury in Provo, Utah, found on Feb. 11 that AJG breached the agreement and owed Headwaters $175.3 million. Headwaters agreed to settle for less to avoid lengthy appeals, a spokeswoman said. Compared with the year-earlier period, however, the jobless rate decreased two percentage points last month. That decline is a sign that Brazil's economy has yet to feel the full impact of the eight consecutive interest rate increases since last September intended to curb inflation. Real wages, which are adjusted for inflation, continued to rise in March, increasing 0.5 percent from the previous month, to 945.2 reais ($375) a month. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint Offers Media File Access
description: Residential customers of Sprint's high-speed Internet service can now obtain remote access to media files on their home computers with a service called Personal Media Link. Sprint said this week that it would make software from Orb Networks available for home computers running Windows XP, enabling users with portable devices or remote PC's that are connected to the Internet to stream video, music and pictures from their home computer. The remote device needs Windows Media Player or RealPlayer software, and the content is adjusted for its connection speed. If the home PC has a TV tuner card or Webcam, live video can also be streamed to a remote device. Sprint, which has 550,000 residential subscribers for its digital subscriber line service, will make the software available free. Sprint, based in Overland Park, Kan., is the first distribution partner for Orb, a privately held company based in Emeryville, Calif., which hopes the deal will provide a new way to distribute songs, movies and TV programs to a variety of devices. Ties a Whole Room Can Wear
description: For men who are only comfortable in Brooks Brothers, the Gramercy division of F. Schumacher & Co. has just introduced a collection of wallpapers that reproduce the stripes, foulards and paisleys of the store's silk ties. Debra Del Vecchio, the senior vice president of operations at Brooks Brothers, and an owner of the store with her husband, Claudio, suggested a wallpaper collection in 2002, when she was decorating her husband's office. "We could use our fabrics to upholster the walls," she said, "Or we could turn the fabrics into wallpaper." She and Glen Hoffs, the store's fashion director, chose the designs from the Brooks archives. The collection of 22 designs sells for $29.99 to $46.99 a roll. Information: 1-800-332-3384.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Dr. Philip Morrison, a Manhattan Project scientist who helped assemble the first atomic bomb and later campaigned against it, misstated the release date of "Powers of Ten," a film narrated and partly written by Dr. Morrison that takes viewers to the outer edge of the cosmos. It was released in 1968. (It was rereleased in 1977.) The obituary also misspelled the given name of Dr. Morrison's second wife, who died in 2002. She was Phylis, not Phyllis.

title: A Hick and a Bumbler Walk Into a Comedy Club . . .
description: If you're looking for America's favorite comedian, you might start with Larry the Cable Guy, a shirtless growler who performs -- and for all we know, lives -- in character, as a rough-and-ready, sex-obsessed good ol' boy with a heart of gold. He's a veteran of the Blue Collar Comedy Tour and a star of "Blue Collar TV," on the WB network. Earlier this month Larry the Cable Guy's new CD, "The Right to Bare Arms" (Warner Brothers), made its debut at No. 7 on the Billboard album chart, the highest debut ever for a comedy album.

title: A Thriller Stars the U.N., as Itself
description: The United Nations serves several functions in Sydney Pollack's new thriller, "The Interpreter": it's a plot device, a film location and, most conspicuously, the centerpiece of the hype. Anyone who has heard or read a thing about the film must know that it was the first to shoot at the U.N., and on screen the General Assembly looks real enough. But then so does the fake Oval Office on the "The West Wing."

World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Manufacturers' Confidence Slips
description: Manufacturers' confidence in France fell to the lowest in 18 months in April, a steeper-than-expected decline, as rising oil costs hurt consumer spending and corporate profits. An index measuring sentiment among 2,000 manufacturers fell to 97, the lowest since October 2003, from 101 in March, the government office Insee said. The report added to concern that economic growth is faltering in Europe's biggest countries.

description: When soldiers in war are not properly trained and supervised, atrocities are all but inevitable. This is one reason why the military command structure is so important. title: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Tide Lifts 'House'
description: Fox's "American Idol" has a powerful ripple effect on the Nielsen television ratings. It has lifted "House," a hospital drama about a sourpuss diagnostician, to be one of this season's new hit shows. On the strength of Tuesday's "Idol," which drew an estimated 24.6 million viewers, 17 million stayed tuned to watch a repeat of "House," and Fox was No. 1 for the night in all key ratings measures. But despite the crushing effect of "Idol" on its direct competition, WB's "Gilmore Girls" has shown surprising resilience in the same time period. Tuesday's episode of the mother-daughter series, during which Rory (Alexis Bledel, above), was able to extract a commitment from her caddish boyfriend (Matt Czuchry), brought in 5.4 million viewers. It was second to "Idol" among adults 18 to 34, teenagers and the audience that WB specifically targets: women 18 to 34. KATE AURTHUR

A physicist by training, his scholarly gifts and intellectual interests ranged widely, bringing him distinction as a scientist and much admiration from his colleagues. His contributions to this community of scholars will be sorely missed, as will his warm friendship. His loved ones are in our thoughts. MOODY'S CUTS MAYTAG SENIOR DEBT RATING
description: The Maytag Corporation's senior unsecured debt was cut to below investment grade by Moody's Investors Service yesterday because of the company's worsening financial condition. Moody's said it lowered Maytag's rating two grades, to Ba2 from Baa3. About $1 billion of debt was affected. Maytag, based in Newton, Iowa, reported last month that first-quarter profit slid 80 percent as rising steel and oil costs exceeded savings from a reorganization. Maytag's financial "deterioration resulted from sluggish top line performance and margin pressure caused by higher steel and energy costs," Moody's said.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Togo: Loser Declares Himself President
description: A day after Faure Gnassingb, the son of Togo's longtime leader, was declared the winner in the presidential election on Sunday, Emmanuel Akitani-Bob, left, the opposition candidate, said he had been cheated and proclaimed himself president. "Togolese, your president is speaking to you," he said at a news conference in Lom, as post-election violence continued, bringing the death toll to at least 12. He called on his followers to continue demonstrations and offered little evidence to support his claim of victory. Official results gave him just 38 percent of the votes. Michael Kamber (NYT)

description: RABBE--Marjorie H., 89, born September 11, 1915 in New York, NY, passed away Monday, April 25, 2005 in Naples, FL. Daughter of the late George W. Harris and Minnie C. Harris of New York, NY. She graduated from the St. Agatha School for Girls and was the Class of 1937, Smith College, Northhampton, MA. Formerly a resident of New York, NY and East Hampton, Long Island, she was a member of the Colony Club (NYC) and the Maidstone Club, as well as the Moorings Country Club and The Royal Poinciana Golf Club in Naples, FL. Paid Notice: Deaths   LITCHFIELD, PHILIP AXEL
description: LITCHFIELD -- Philip Axel. Died at the age of 89, on Thursday, April 21, 2005, in Vero Beach, Florida, after a long illness. He was born October 22, 1915, in Brooklyn, New York. He was descended from Edwin Clark Litchfield and Grace Hubbard Litchfield of Prospect Park, Brooklyn, New York. Mr. Litchfield attended Hamilton College and Iowa State University. He served in the U.S. Army at the outbreak of World War II and later served with the American Field Service as an ambulance driver in the Italian theater. After the war he became a professional portrait photographer and was the first full time photographer for The Patent Trader, Mt. Kisco, New York. Besides an affinity for exotic sports cars, Mr. Litchfield was an avid outdoorsman. He was a member of the Anglers' Club of New York, The Bedford Golf and Tennis Club and The New Canaan Country Club. His Florida affiliations included Hawk's Nest Golf Club and The Moorings Club, both of Vero Beach. But, he was in his glory hosting hunting and fishing trips for friends and family at his beloved Adirondack home. Mr. Litchfield is survived by his wife of 35 years, Sarah Richardson Hamill, of Pound Ridge, NY; two sons from a previous marriage to Isabel Crouse of Greenwich, CT, Christopher Sands of Greenwich, CT, and Eric Hubbard of Darien, CT; a stepson Robert B. Hamill of New Canaan, CT; a stepdaughter Amelia H. Hopkins of Simsbury, CT; and eight grandchildren. He also leaves a sister, Mrs. James J. Lowe (Tatiana) of Bedford Hills, NY. Services will be held at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Bedford, New York at 11 A.M. Thursday, May 19. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, 382 Cantitoe Road, Bedford, New York 10506, or to Indian River Memorial Hospital, 1000 36th Street, Vero Beach, FL. 32960.

Arts, Briefly; A Victory for the Barnes
description: The Pennsylvania Supreme Court dismissed an appeal yesterday from a student trying to stop the transfer of the renowned Barnes Foundation art collection from its gallery in a Philadelphia suburb to a new museum downtown. A lawyer for the foundation, which is financially troubled and has long sought the move to save itself from bankruptcy, said the decision had removed the final hurdle to moving the collection, which contains dozens of works by Renoir, Czanne and Picasso. "This should end the legal dispute so the Barnes should be able now to go forward with building its new facility," said Ralph G. Wellington, the lawyer. Many art scholars have opposed the move, saying that the collection should remain true to the vision of Albert C. Barnes, a patent-medicine millionaire who stipulated that no picture in his collection could be lent, sold or even moved on the walls of the quirky neo-Classical galleries that he had built for it in the mid-1920's. The court ruled unanimously that the student who had filed the appeal, Jay Raymond, had no standing to do so. Calls to Mr. Raymond's lawyer, Howard J. Bashman, were not returned yesterday. RANDY KENNEDY

title: Arts, Briefly; You Can Mail Him
description: The Postal Service will honor E.Y. (Yip) Harburg, the lyricist beloved by Broadway and Hollywood audiences, with its highest accolade -- by putting him on a postage stamp. A dedication ceremony is to takes place at 6 tonight at the 92nd Street Y Tisch Center for the Arts, 1395 Lexington Avenue, and is open to the public. Harburg, , born to Russian immigrants on the Lower East Side in 1898, supposedly earned the nickname Yipsel (meaning squirrel in Yiddish) as a child, thanks to his boundless energy. Collaborating with composers like Jay Gorney and Harold Arlen, he wrote more than 600 songs, including "Brother, Can You Spare a Dime" and "Over the Rainbow," which was sung by Judy Garland, above, in the "The Wizard of Oz" and won an Academy Award in 1939. Harburg died in 1981. The stamp goes on sale nationwide tomorrow. MATTHEW HEALEY

The company's return to investment grade reflected Corning's transformation into one of the world's largest makers of glass for the liquid-crystal displays used in computer monitors and TV sets. Arts, Briefly; 'Sweeney' Gets a Lead
description: One lead has been cast for the revival of Stephen Sondheim's classic murder musical "Sweeney Todd," due on Broadway this fall. Michael Cerveris, seen last year as John Wilkes Booth in Mr. Sondheim's "Assassins," has landed the title role of Sweeney Todd, the butchering barber. There is no formal word on who will play Mrs. Lovett, Sweeney's salty admirer whose meat pies run toward the cannibalistic, but production insiders say Patti LuPone has the inside track. This version of "Sweeney," which features just nine actors doubling as musicians, was a hit in London in 2004, and is to begin previews on Oct. 3 at the Eugene O'Neill Theater, with an official opening scheduled for Nov. 3. The show, with music and lyrics by Mr. Sondheim and book by Hugh Wheeler, won eight Tony Awards for its original Broadway production in 1979 and was revived in 1989. JESSE McKINLEY

description: WARREN, Conn. - THAT a marriage begun in the Connecticut of the late 1950's could have produced a near unblemished record of happiness over 47 years seems as unlikely now as the chance of a fine tan acquired during a visit to Minsk. But it was in this small, well-to-do village in the northwestern corner of the state -- far enough away, perhaps, from the Cheeveresque depravities of the eastern suburbs -- that Francine du Plessix embarked on her contented life with Cleve Gray. An abstract painter, Mr. Gray ferried her away from the world of high style and society to which her parents had hoped to conscript her and installed her instead in a quiet, cozily unkempt 18th-century fieldstone house, where the two set up working studios in neighboring outbuildings across a driveway from each other.

title: A Coast Less Traveled
description: SOUTH of Oregon and far north of the Golden Gate, the Pacific coastal road retreats inland, bypassing 120 miles of wild, rugged shoreline aptly called the Lost Coast. In this isolated pocket of gargantuan redwoods, surf-pounded mountains and hidden valleys, there's scant access to road-trip staples like cellphone connections and four-lane asphalt. But brave the bumps and guardrail-free switchbacks of the lonely Lost Coast roads, and you'll drive into a wild, majestic California little changed from the time when today's 2,000-year-old redwoods were just seedlings. In some places, trees are so dense they nearly block out the sun. In others, astounding scenery of precipitous cliffs, foamy sea and empty beaches unfolds around every bend.

title: In Ojai, Calif.
description: PLACES considered spiritual seem invariably to be beautiful, and Ojai, Calif., is no exception. A town of about 8,200 set in a valley 20 minutes from the ocean, Ojai has a multitude of religious retreats, rich-hippie boarding schools (like the Happy Valley School, which counts Aldous Huxley and Jiddu Krishnamurti among its founders) and people walking around convinced that the area has magical healing powers. Spiritual teachers, gurus and Hollywood celebrities are drawn to the beauty of Ojai, with its clean white Spanish architecture and oak and citrus trees framed by the Coastal Range. More Telluride than Aspen, more Sonoma than Napa, it's a wealthy community that seems to pride itself on playing down its affluence. Many spa visitors never leave their resorts - a shame, because the Ojai Valley has plenty of chilled-out charm, good restaurants, a web of fine hiking trails and, seemingly around every corner, another alternative religion to try to understand.

title: Infinity turns to amateurs to defend itself
'HOMESTYLE'
description: When artists turn a hand to furniture, the results are usually not for the timid. This small show of five pop-oriented artists from different generations makes the point with Yayoi Kusama's silver-painted stool covered with pop-up phalluses. And -- more orderly if not as pretty -- Tom Sachs's "Bong Station," a rough-hewn console organized in compartments to contain the licit and illicit: a mirror, an electric clock, a machete, a remote-controlled toy racing car, cigarettes, a beer can, a water bottle and a bong (for marijuana). But there are more decorous works, too, like Roy Lichtenstein's dashing chair and ottoman of painted bronze (above), formed from several heroic blue and black brushstrokes, and Ed Ruscha's highly lacquered five-panel wood screen, painted on both sides with dreamy atmospheric cloud drifts. They carry lines in block lettering from an Elvis ballad: "I Forgot to Remember to Forget" on one side, "I Remembered to Forget to Remember" on the other. Jeff Koons is seen here at his most minimal, with a trio of simplified wall-mounted floral cut-outs of mirror-finish stainless steel, each having a different-colored center, cutesy but not very Koons-y. Artists doing furniture is by no means a new phenomenon, and given more room, the gallery could undoubtedly have provided many other examples. But in this case, the show's intimacy adds to its punch. (Leo Castelli, 18 East 77th Street, Manhattan, (212)249-4470, through May 27; free.) GRACE GLUECK

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett Introduces New TV Models
description: Hewlett-Packard yesterday announced a collection of new television models that the company said improve picture quality by incorporating its so-called wobulation technology. The new products included high-definition microdisplay rear-projection TV's, HD plasma displays and three HD liquid-crystal displays. The rear-projection TV's incorporate the wobulation technology, which jitters the projected image in a controlled way that effectively replaces a single pixel with four. The company, based in Palo Alto, Calif., is marketing the feature as HP Visual Fidelity. "This is the first product H.P. is bringing to market with wobulation," said Matt Schulz, product manager for the company's microdisplay TV's. The new televisions also adjust the image to a room's ambient lighting using a "photorealistic sharpness enhancement" and a 3-D color enrichment system, the company said. Hewlett-Packard shares rose 13 cents, to $20.30.

title: Technology Briefing | Patents: Symbol Technologies Sues Intermec
description: Symbol Technologies said yesterday that it had sued Intermec Technologies for infringing on two bar code patents, expanding a dispute that broke out last year over Intermec's claims of fundamental patent rights in the fast-growing business of using radio tags to identify products. The legal wrangling began last summer when Intermec sued Matrics, a start-up manufacturer of radio tags and scanners that balked at paying licensing fees to Intermec. Symbol acquired Matrics last July and in March, when efforts to negotiate a settlement broke down, filed a suit charging Intermec with violating Symbol's Wi-Fi patents. Intermec responded with further patent infringement claims against Symbol. The battle is the first major intellectual property dispute in the field of radio frequency identification, or RFID. Specialists say the outcome could affect how fast the field develops and who profits from it. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: PAT GRANEY COMPANY
description: This Seattle troupe comes to Dance Theater Workshop with the New York premiere of "the Vivian girls" (above), inspired by the life and art of Henry Darger, a notoriously reclusive Chicago artist who mopped floors by day for a charity organization. But at night in his crowded one-room apartment, he created his own fantasy realm in the form of a lavishly illustrated 15,000-page novel and 300 paintings. Darger's writings and artworks chronicle the turbulent battles of the innocent Vivian sisters against an evil male empire. The images are often as disturbing as they are fantastic, for they abound with psychological implications of cruelty and enslavement. Pat Graney, a choreographer who often takes the visual arts as a point of departure, will have reproductions of some of Darger's imagery projected during her work for five dancers, costumed like characters from the paintings and novel. For instance, the Vivian girls are in brunette wigs and white dresses, while butterfly-like creatures wear colorful wings and dance en pointe. And all the adventures take place on a stage cluttered with giant books. (Opens Wednesday, through May 7, at 7:30 p.m., Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212)924-0077 or www.dtw.org. Tickets: $20, or $12 for members, students and 60+.) JACK ANDERSON

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADAMS, MASON
description: ADAMS--Mason. Born Mason Abrams in Brooklyn. Decided to be an actor at age twelve and was successful on radio, television, stage and the film. He is survived by his wife Margot Weinberg and their children Betsy and Bill. His brother Herbert Abrams, a professor of radiology at Stanford University, together with his son and daughter, their grandchildren and two great-grandchildren are living, as are his brother-in-law, Irving Mauss and his sister's son, daughter and granddaughter. To all of us he represented the finest in actingskilled, brilliant, passionate. Words, visual images, speech, drama, antidotes and laughter - booming, hardy laughter at his own jokes and those of others, at the ironies and absurdities of life, were Mason's hallmarks. Towards the end when illness savaged him, he was only partly the Mason we knew. Even then great flashes of the real Mason shown as his mental and physical strength ebbed.

Formerly a resident of New York, NY and East Hampton, Long Island, she was a member of the Colony Club (NYC) and the Maidstone Club, as well as the Moorings Country Club and The Royal Poinciana Golf Club in Naples, FL. She was active in various volunteer activities for her communities throughout her life. She is survived by her husband of 60 years, Richard F. Rabbe; 2 sons Richard John of San Jose, Costa Rica and George William of Naples, FL and Sherman, CT; along with two grandchildren, George William, Jr., and Charlotte Barstow Rabbe. Services will be private for the immediate family. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Trinity-bythe-Cove Episcopal Church, 553 Galleon Drive, Naples, Fl, 34102, would be appreciated.

description: Mayor Andrs Manuel Lpez Obrador of Mexico City praised the decision by President Vicente Fox on Wednesday night to conduct a new review into the government's legal actions against him and guarantee that he would be allowed to participate in the race for president next year. Meanwhile, leaders for the two political parties that pushed the unpopular case against the popular mayor began trying to repair the damage to their organizations. Interior Minister Santiago Creel, who hopes to run for president from Mr. Fox's conservative National Action Party, spent most of the day in radio and television interviews saying that the government was ready to put the case aside and get back to work. Roberto Madrazo, another presidential hopeful and the president of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, which ran the country for more than seven consecutive decades, said his party looked forward to competing against Mayor Lpez Obrador and his leftist Party of the Democratic Revolution at the polls. title: TWO EX-HOMESTORE EXECUTIVES FACE CRIMINAL CHARGES
description: Stuart H. Wolff, the former chief executive of Homestore, the largest online home-listings company, and Peter Tafeen, a former vice president, have been charged with directing a scheme to inflate the company's revenue, the United States attorney's office in Los Angeles said in a statement yesterday. The Securities and Exchange Commission also sued the two men. The S.E.C. has sued 16 people over the scheme, and prosecutors have brought criminal charges against 11 of them. All of the defendants except Mr. Tafeen and Mr. Wolff have settled the civil claims, pleaded guilty to criminal charges and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors. Brian Hennigan, a lawyer for Mr. Tafeen, said his client was not guilty of any wrongdoing. Howard Privette, a lawyer for Mr. Wolff, said that most of the activities described in the indictment were typical business activities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KENNEDY, RICHARD TIL GHMAN PACA
description: KENNEDY -- Richard Til ghman Paca, recently retired producer of on-air production with Channel 13/WNET New York, died suddenly April 16 at his home on East 81st., Manhattan, on his 69th birthday. Mr. Kennedy was with Channel 13 for many years, most recently the creator of Cabaret Thirteen, featuring a variety of singers performing selections and then discussing their careers and outlook. He was also featured in a TV tribute to Jack Paar, recalling the late host's remarkable personality and creative late show format of the '50s and 60's which still sets the style today. Joining NBC as a page in the mid-50's, Mr. Kennedy always had his heart in Manhattan. He was involved in buying rights to older movies for Corinthian Broadcasting, a network of CBS stations, anticipating TV's great demand for classic and run-of-the-mill cinema. Summers of watching movies in Maine gave him a competitive resource. He later helped develop Time Life Films, a division of Time Life, introducing BBC films to American TV audiences--series such as "Civilization" and Alistair Cooke's "America." It was Mr. Kennedy's devotion to the theater that began with a childhood of watching Gilbert & Sullivan operettas and local theater in suburban Philadelphia and Maine Summer Theater. He was permanently hooked. A graduate of The Episcopal Academy, Merion Station, Pa., and Bowdoin College, Brunswick, Maine, he was active in theater groups, and president of Bowdoin's Masque and Gown. Mr. Kennedy is survived by two brothers, Anthony Kennedy III, Rose Valley, Pa., and Jackson W. T. Kennedy, Toms River, N.J.; six nephews and nieces and eight grandnephews and nieces, including an identical birthday grandnephew, Bentley Kennedy-Stone, Baton Rouge, LA.; and an uncle, The Rev. Canon Albert W. Tarbell of Albuquerque, N.M. A memorial service will be held Friday, May 6, at 10:30 A.M., at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, 109 E. 50th St., Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, friends may consider a contribution to Channel 13/ WNET New York.

title: More Germans working
In Ojai, Calif.
description: PLACES considered spiritual seem invariably to be beautiful, and Ojai, Calif., is no exception. A town of about 8,200 set in a valley 20 minutes from the ocean, Ojai has a multitude of religious retreats, rich-hippie boarding schools (like the Happy Valley School, which counts Aldous Huxley and Jiddu Krishnamurti among its founders) and people walking around convinced that the area has magical healing powers. Spiritual teachers, gurus and Hollywood celebrities are drawn to the beauty of Ojai, with its clean white Spanish architecture and oak and citrus trees framed by the Coastal Range. More Telluride than Aspen, more Sonoma than Napa, it's a wealthy community that seems to pride itself on playing down its affluence. Many spa visitors never leave their resorts -- a shame, because the Ojai Valley has plenty of chilled-out charm, good restaurants, a web of fine hiking trails and, seemingly around every corner, another alternative religion to try to understand. GARY ANDREW POOLE

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Gunman Kills One And Injures Two
description: A gunman killed an 18-year-old woman and wounded two other teenagers in a Sunset Park apartment last night, the police said. Officers said they knew of no motive for the shooting, which occurred at 8:20 p.m. in a fourth-floor apartment at 346 54th Street. The family of one of the wounded teenagers identified the two who were hurt as Rachel Rivera, 15, who was struck in the ankle and shoulder, and her boyfriend, Octavio Figueroa, who was shot in the leg. Both were in stable condition last night at Lutheran Medical Center. Shevonne Rivera, Ms. Rivera's sister, said her sister was seven months pregnant and had been alternating between their father's home in Mill Basin and another sister's home in Queens. She said that the family did know why Rachel was at the apartment where she was shot and that the family did not know her boyfriend well. Friends of Ms. Rivera said they only knew the dead woman by her nickname, China. The police said that the suspect was a male teenager, and that they were looking for him last night. title: BALTIMORE SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA
description: This was a first-rate orchestra when Yuri Temirkanov took it over in 1997. It had, during the years David Zinman led it, become expert in American music and in the Germanic mainstream. Mr. Temirkanov, above, has extended that expertise with his own proprietary approach to the Russian repertory, particularly the music of Shostakovich. Not surprisingly, Shostakovich is the drawing card here, not least because Mr. Temirkanov is to be joined by the violinist Gidon Kremer in what promises to be a searing account of the composer's Violin Concerto No. 1. Also notable, if somewhat briefer, is "Lonesome," a recent work by Giya Kancheli, an idiosyncratic Georgian composer whose music leaves room for silence and calls for the most carefully hushed tones, as well as quadruple forte explosions of sound. Rounding out this colorful program are "La Mer," Debussy's vivid seascape, and "La Valse," Ravel's concentrated vision of a swirling dance hall. (Tonight at 8, Carnegie Hall, (212)247-7800. Tickets: $24 to $83.) ALLAN KOZINN

title: MICHAEL STUHLBARG
description: Simple-minded is the customary euphemism for people like Michal, the hulking, childlike man being held prisoner in "The Pillowman," Martin McDonagh's dazzlingly dark new play. But there is nothing remotely simple about Michael Stuhlbarg's portrait of this character, which finds embers of a scorching slyness within a brain made dim by torture. Mr. Stuhlbarg, above, an exotically artificial Richard II for Steven Berkoff at the Public Theater, turns bruisingly human with his haunted and haunting portrayal of Michal, the brother of the play's storytelling hero, Katurian (Billy Crudup). Michal loves his brother's scary bedtime tales, an affection he conveys with infectious ingenuousness. But in a play that has more twists than a hangman's rope, Michal emerges as a master of his own kind of fiction. Mr. Stuhlbarg expertly demonstrates that in the world of Mr. McDonagh even the infantile can be artful double dealers. (Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street, (212)239-6200.) BEN BRANTLEY

The company, which is based in New Delhi and has a fifth of India's market share, said net profit rose to 4.37 billion rupees ($100 million), from 3.04 billion rupees a year ago. Sales grew to 23.17 billion rupees, from 15.53 billion rupees. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: The Way the World Ends, With a Shrug and a Smile
description: In the hugely likable, long-awaited film of Douglas Adams's "Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy," the world comes to an end not just with a bang, but also with something of a shrug. It isn't that Arthur Dent, the hero of our charmingly bent story, has no feelings for this cursed plot, this Earth. But being English -- and played by Martin Freeman, the lovesick sales representative from the original British television series "The Office" -- he generally faces even the most perilous bumps during his intragalactic tour with a degree of resignation. On one occasion, though, he does steady himself with a cup of tea.

description: On the third day of hearings to determine whether a Marine officer should face charges of premeditated murder in the deaths of two Iraqis, former comrades said they would willingly go to war with him again. None witnessed the shooting, so they shed no light on why the defendant, Second Lt. Ilario Pantano, killed the two Iraqis a year ago near Mahmudiya. Lieutenant Pantano, who has said he acted in self-defense, had tears in his eyes as he listened to some of the marines he once commanded. "He is a great marine who has the attention to detail to bring the men back alive," said Martin McPherson, who is now a civilian. John DeSantis (NYT)

Bedrich Smetana's opera "The Bartered Bride" has a whiff of an American musical to its simple sweet story (boy loves girl, boy figures out how to get together with girl) and pretty tunes, and the Juilliard Opera Center's production, which opened on Wednesday, brought out the similarities.

title: BOEING MUST BID AGAIN FOR $3 BILLION CONTRACT
description: The Boeing Company must compete again for United States Air Force work worth more than $3 billion to upgrade avionics on C-130 transports because of a conflict of interest in the original contract. Michael L. Dominguez, acting secretary of the Air Force, announced his decision in an April 26 letter to David M. Walker, the United States comptroller general, two months after a government agency concluded that the 2001 contract was tainted by Darleen A. Druyun, the former acquisition chief. The original award was worth $4.1 billion; Boeing, based in Chicago, will keep the continuing development portion, worth about $1 billion. Bids for the production phase -- producing and installing the electronics upgrade kits -- will be solicited again, Mr. Dominguez wrote.

description: Three months of jockeying among Iraq's victorious Shiite and Kurdish parties have finally produced a cabinet that won quick ratification from a legislature where those same parties dominate. The January election that began this process was inspiring. The months of petty haggling that followed were not, and while the formation of an elected Iraqi government is a historic moment, its makeup is far from ideal. Crucial choices have been needlessly delayed, and an incomparable opportunity for drawing patriotic Sunni Arabs away from the insurgency was largely squandered. Many Iraqis, particularly supporters of secularism, women's rights and national unity, will greet this government warily.

title: LILLY SUSPENDS STUDY OF SEPSIS DRUG FOR CHILDREN
description: The Eli Lilly & Company, the pharmaceutical company, stopped a study of its Xigris sepsis drug for children earlier this month after a preliminary analysis showed the medicine did not work and might increase the risk of bleeding. Xigris was "highly unlikely to show an improvement over placebo" as a sepsis treatment for children, Lilly said in a letter to doctors dated April 21 and posted yesterday on the company's Web site. The analysis also found that 4 of the 201 children getting Xigris experienced bleeding in the brain, compared with a single child among the 198 children given a placebo, the letter said. The results are preliminary and do not affect the use of Xigris in adults, said Sondra McQueary, a spokeswoman for Lilly, which is based in Indianapolis.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: 2 Guilty Of Feeding Victim To Lions
description: A judge handed down murder convictions for a farm owner and an employee who were accused of beating a rural laborer and then throwing him to 20 rare white lions. The farmer, Mark Scott-Crossley, left, and his employee, Simon Mathebula, were said to have attacked Nelson Chisale with knives in January 2004, after Mr. Chisale, who had been fired, came to collect his belongings. Mr. Chisale was tied to a tree and beaten, then driven to the lion enclosure and thrown over its fence. Only part of a skull, a few bones and shredded clothes remained when the police searched the pen. Testimony never established whether Mr. Chisale was alive when he was tossed to the lions. The spectacular case was held up as an example of continuing racism in rural South Africa. Mr. Scott-Crossley is white, his employee and Mr. Chisale black. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: A Coast Less Traveled
description: SOUTH of Oregon and far north of the Golden Gate, the Pacific coastal road retreats inland, bypassing 120 miles of wild, rugged shoreline aptly called the Lost Coast. In this isolated pocket of gargantuan redwoods, surf-pounded mountains and hidden valleys, there's scant access to road-trip staples like cellphone connections and four-lane asphalt. But brave the bumps and guardrail-free switchbacks of the lonely Lost Coast roads, and you'll drive into a wild, majestic California little changed from the time when today's 2,000-year-old redwoods were just seedlings. In some places, trees are so dense they nearly block out the sun. In others, astounding scenery of precipitous cliffs, foamy sea and empty beaches unfolds around every bend.

description: Kim Ki-duk's "3-Iron" ends with a reminder, printed on the screen (and awkwardly translated from the Korean), the gist of which is that we can't always distinguish reality from dreams. While the general truth of this idea may be open to question, it undoubtedly applies to movies like this one, which unfold in a finely detailed and familiar world even as they are governed by a sometimes enchanted, sometimes sinister dream logic. The movie camera is able to make the impossible look natural and the ordinary seem strange, not so much through elaborate special effects as through tricks of composition, perspective and editing. Mr. Kim is a master of such estrangement, and "3-Iron" is a teasing, self-conscious and curiously heartfelt demonstration of his mischievous formal ingenuity.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Yemen: 18 New Cases Of Polio Found
description: Eighteen new cases of polio have been found in Yemen, and the country is "now facing a major epidemic," Dr. David L. Heymann, the chief of polio eradication for the World Health Organization, said in Geneva. Four cases were identified in the Red Sea port of Al Hudaida on April 20, but the new ones have been found across the country, including in the capital, Sana. Yemen had been polio-free since 1996. Dr. Bruce Aylward, who coordinates the W.H.O. eradication campaign, said testing "quite clearly" showed that the strain had arrived recently and had come from Kano, in Nigeria, by way of Chad and Port Sudan, across the Red Sea. Yemen, worried about outbreaks in Sudan and Saudi Arabia, held a vaccination day for children this month, and more are planned. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLOAN, STEPHEN
description: SLOAN--Stephen, died April 28th, 2005 at home. Adored and adoring husband of Nannette (Nancy) Sloan, beloved father of Suzanne & Robert, treasured father-in-law to Kieran & Elizabeth, loving grandpa to Stephen Samuel Sloan II & Theodore Robert, and devoted brother-in-law to Sandra Barkin. He served as President of Lehman Bros. Realty Corp in the '70's, then started his own firm developing real estate across the country. He served as President of 510 Park Avenue for many years. He graduated from the Horace Mann School and served as a Trustee. He graduated from Washington & Lee University and in 2004 received their Distinguished Alumnus Award. At the age of 70, he went back to Columbia University and completed The Morningside Institute Program in Conservation Biology. He was an internationally recognized environmentalist and sportsman and served as Adjunct Professor of Marine Biology at the University of Miami Rosensteil School of Marine & Atmospheric Sciences. He was also the author of four books, holder of 44 World's Records & host of the syndicated radio show "The Fishing Zone". The legacy he leaves is the love of his family, the respect of his peers, and the challenge to future generations to conserve, replenish and be mindful of our streams, rivers and oceans. Services will be held Sunday, May 1st, 1:30 PM, Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65th St, NYC. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Fisheries Defense Fund, 1040 1st Av, Suite 367, NY, NY 10022. SLOAN--Stephen. The Horace Mann School sadly mourns the passing of Stephen Sloan '50, cherished alumnus, distinguished former Trustee, dedicated fund-raiser and inspirational lecturer to our students. Throughout his 50 years at Horace Mann, Stephen Sloan enriched our lives with his friendship, warmth and support. He will be greatly missed. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Nancy, his children Suzanne '77 and Robert '81, and his entire family. Dr. Eileen Mullady Head of School Robert J. Katz '65 Chair, Board of Trustees SLOAN--Stephen. The Chaim Sheba Medical Center and the American Friends of Sheba sorrowfully mourn the passing of Stephen Sloan, real estate developer, renowned sports fisherman, marine conservationist and author. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to our cherished board member, Suzanne Sloan Doyle, his daughter, and to his wife, Nannette, and son, Robert. Prof. Mordechai Shani, Director General Emeritus Leonard Shaykin, Chairman, American Friends of Sheba Shoshana Weisser, CEO American Friends of Sheba SLOAN--Stephen Samuel. In sorrow, Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records the passing of our distinguished member, Stephen Samuel Sloan. With his family, we share the grief of loss and bereavement. The beautiful qualities of his life shall endure forever in the hearts of those who loved him. Rabbi David M. Posner Robert A. Bernhard, Pres. Herbert C. Bernard, Sec'y. SLOAN--Stephen. The officers, directors and share holders of 510 Park Avenue Corp mourn the passing of our esteemed president, friend and neighbor, Stephen. Stephen served as our president for the past 16 years. He devoted countless unselfish hours in the management of our building. He will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife Nancy, his children Robert and Susan and grandchildren. SLOAN--Stephen. We join our cousins Nancy, Suzanne (Kieran) and Robert (Elizabeth) in mourning the untimely passing of Stephen our devoted friend and partner. A man of keen intelligence, wit, and charm. An astute business man and a negotiator without parallel. We will greatly miss his inspiring presence in our lives. Steve, may you have "tight lines and a very good drift". With love, Stephen and Madeline Barkin SLOAN--Stephen. Cherished friend of long-standing, Stephen was a first-rate guy and great world citizen. The hallmarks of his life were his integrity, his competence and his personal warmth. Susan and Elihu Rose

title: Puncturing Another Weapons Myth

Never mind that American military leaders said that he could not have pulled that off during the war, when his regime was collapsing too fast to salvage much of anything, and that reconnaissance craft had seen no major arms shipments at the borders. Paid Notice: Deaths   HOCHSCHWENDER, HERMAN KARL
description: HOCHSCHWENDER-Herman Karl, 85, passed away Thursday, April 28, 2005, in Naples, FL. He was born in Heidelberg, Germany, on March 1, 1920, and came to the U.S.A. in 1930, moving to Akron, Ohio in 1944 where he lived most of his life. He earned a Bachelor of Science degree from Yale University in 1941, and did post-graduate work at Harvard Business School. His professional career spanned several years in the private industrial sector with Sargent & Co. in New Haven, CT; the Firestone Tire & Rubber Co. in Akron; and Mohawk Rubber Co. of New York. In 1959, he founded his own consulting firm Hochschwender & Associates and, in 1972, acquired Smithers Laboratories to form Smithers Scientific Services Inc. in Akron where he served as chief executive officer and later chairman of the board until his death. He was a member of several professional organizations - the International Laboratory Assurance Co. (ILAC), the American Council of Independent Laboratories (ACIL), the International Union of Independent Laboratories (UILI) serving as president, the American Society of Testing & Materials (ASTM), the Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) and the American Association of Laboratory Accreditation (A2LA). He authored a number of articles and papers on testing, research and management subjects related to the rubber and plastics and supplier industries, and addressed numerous technical and lay groups on a variety of subjects in his fields of expertise. In 1983, he headed a joint mission of the ACIL/State Department group to Japan to explore and develop the possibilities of increased trade in Japan by independent testing laboratories. He served as a trustee of the Akron Regional Development Board (ARDB), Akron General Medical Center, Children's Hospital Medical Center of Akron, and the Summit County Chapter of the American Red Cross. In 1976, he participated in a trade mission to China and served as an advisor to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce on international affairs. A year later, he was appointed by Ohio Governor James Rhodes an Ohio Commodore. In 1989, he was recognized for Smithers' commitment to growth and dedication to the Akron, Ohio area and received the coveted Eagle Award for Business Heritage. In 1994, he was inducted into the Tire Industry Hall of Fame. He was also a member of the Yale University Alumni Association, the Yale Club of New York, the Yale Club of Southwest Florida, the Akron City Club, the Portage Country Club in Akron, the Naples (FL.) Yacht Club, and the Royal Poinciana Golf Club in Naples. He had maintained a residence in Naples since 1969. He is survived by his loving wife, Mary "Bo" Koger; children Lynn Anne McGowin, Herman Karl Jr. "Ted", Irene Harris, James E., J. Michael, Patricia A. Mosely; six grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Calling hours will be Tuesday, May 3, from 4 to 7 P.M. at the Billow Funeral Home, 85 N. Miller Road, Akron, OH. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, May 4, at 2:30 P.M. at Westminster Presbyterian Church, 1250 W. Exchange St., Akron, OH. Memorials may be made to the Akron General Development Foundation, 400 Wabash Avenue, Akron, Ohio 44307, or to the Women's Auxiliary Board, Akron City Hospital, 525 E. Market St., Akron, OH 44304. (Billow FAIRLAWN Chapel, 330-867-4141)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Record Budget Surplus
description: Brazil posted a record primary budget surplus of 12.3 billion reais ($4.9 billion) in March, the highest monthly figure since the government started tracking the data in 1991, the central bank said. That lifted the budget surplus, which excludes interest payments on public-sector debt, to 88.3 billion reais over the last 12 months, equivalent to 4.84 percent of gross domestic product, well ahead of the government's year-end target of 4.25 percent of gross domestic product. Brazil, South America's largest economy, uses the surplus to pay down its debt, which was equal to 51 percent of gross domestic product at the end of March.
